column2: If any expert solver of intricate puzzles desires to pit his patience and ingenuity against something really hard all he has to do is to undertake a search for information among the judgment dockets in the County Clerk's office.
Messrs. Healey Co. have on exhibition at their salesrooms, in Broadway, at Forty-secondstreet, a duplicate of the celebrated new Sedan brougham which took the grand prize at the Paris Exposition.

Threatening weather could not keep people from the track of the New-Jersey Jockey Club yesterday, and, strange as it may seem, the gate receipts show that there were 1,200 more people present than on Wednesday.

ATHENS, Oct. 31.--The German man-of-war Kaiser, with Emperor William of Germany on board, left the Piraeus at 1:30 o'clock this afternoon. The British, German, and Italian squadrons ware drawn up in three lines, and all red a royal salute as the Kaiser passed.

The Board of Directors of the Brooklyn Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children met in the rooms of the society, 141 Montaguestreet, on Wednesday night. Henry R. Jones presided, and among those present were Alexander Munn, William B. Leonard, George L. Pease, Charles A. Schieren, Thomas S. Moore, and Robert J. Wilkin.

DENVER, Col., Oct. 31.--It is learned here that negotiations have been completed between the Rock Island, Denver and Rio Grande, Colorado Midland, and Rio Grande Western to run through trains from Chicago to Salt Lake City.
HELENA, Montana, Oct. 31.--Judge De Wolf has sustained the motion of the Democrats and issued a peremptory order to have the Canvassing Board make returns of the Tunnell Precincts.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 31.--The eighth annual national convention of the Women's Home Missionary Society of the Methodist Church be gan here this morning with more than two hundred delegates present.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 31.--Gen. Mahone is spending the closing days of the campaign in his den in Petersburg scheming to even up with the Democrats for the setbacks he has met with during the past ten days.

CITY OF MEXICO, Oct. 31, via Galveston.-- Another telegram from Guatemala states that the revolution in that republic is ended, and that the Government has triumphed over its enemies. All the revolutionists taken prisoners were shot.

At the meeting of the Emigration Commissioners yesterday the committee which has investigated the alleged abuses in the Castle Garden baggage room reported that Mr. Biglin was not responsible for the irregularities which had been proved. The overcharges had been made by employes of Mr. Biglin, ...

Some well-known ladies, the patronesses of the New-York Infirmary for Women and Children at 5 Livingston-place, are planning an exceedingly novel and beautiful entertainment for the benefit of that institution.

FREDERICKSBURG, Va., Oct. 31.--The City Council last night took final action on a communication recently received from the "Old South Church" of Boston, asking contributions from Fredericksburg to complete the unfinished...

PARIS, Oct. 18.--Everything is very dull now. It is the last breathing spell, as one might say, before the sad interest of the close of the exhibition and the formal opening of the regular Paris season.
A performance and reception by the NewYork telegraph operators was given last night in the new Central Opera House. Sixty-seventhstreet, near Third-avenue, under the management of Martin J. Dixon.

Fire completely destroyed the four-story brick building at 171 and 173 Plymouth-street, Brooklyn, early yesterday morning. The flames started on the fourth floor, occupied by the Electric Manufacturing Company. A defective wire is supposed to be responsible for them.

The will of Henry Fisher, formerly a wealthy merchant of this city, who died at the Chateau de Janvry, near Paris, on Sept. 16, was filed in the Surrogate's office yesterday. It is dated Sept. 27, 1887, and names the United States Trust Company as executor and trustee.
BOSTON, Oct. 31.--Out in the stream, earer East Boston than Boston itself, there lies the largest four-masted schooner that over came by Boston Light.
E.P. Smith, a cotton broker, was arrested on Wednesday night by Detective Sergeant Mulvey of the Central Office as he was leaving the Alpine flats, Broadway and Thirty-third-street.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 31.--At daybreak this morning the Chicago, Santa Fe and California vestibule train was derailed near Carrollton, Mo. A rail gave way near that place and all the coaches except the dining and sleeping cars were thrown from the track.

Oidche Samhna was the title given the festival of the Gaelic Society held last night in its rooms at 17 West Twenty-eighth-street in celebration of Halloween. The President, L.J. Callanan, occupied the chair, and in his...

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Oct. 31.--The last sad rites were to-day performed over the remains of Mr. William Henderson late proprietor of the Academy of Music, Jersey City, N.J. The old home here was thronged all day by the hosts of friends who had come, many of them many miles, to pay their respects. Many theatrical people were present, and some of them ...

The Mallory steamship Rio Grande, which arrived yesterday from Galveston, sighted on Wednesday what was undoubtedly a portion of the wreck of the ill-fated steamship Tonawanda, or as she was more recently called, the Brooklyn. But little hope for the vessel had been entertained for some time past Capt. Connor of ...

HAVANA, Oct. 31.--Many central estates will begin to grind earlier than usual, owing to the fact that the cane is rapidly attaining to ripeness on account of the dry and cool weather prevailing for the past few weeks. Some planters, however, complain of lack of water retarding the growth of the cane.

A man went into the jewelry store of Max Freund Co., 8 Maiden-lane, yesterday, and, presenting the business card of William Bartman of 174 Broadway, told Mr. Freund that he wanted to sell three valuable rings and that he had been referred to him by Mr. Bartman.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct.31--The NewBrunswick Ballot Reform Club, of which President Merrill E. Gates of Rutgers College, the Rev. Dr. M.H. Hutton, Prof. Austin Scott, Dr. C.H. Voorhees, Dr. H.R. Baldwin, T. Robinson warren, and other prominent town and college men are members, has sent to candidates...

NORRISTOWN, Penn., Oct. 31.--The Tradesmen's National Bank of Conshohocken, Penn., was closed this morning by order of the Bank Examiner. The following notice posted on the door of the bank explains the cause:

CHICAGO, Oct. 31.--The negro question was the principal theme for discussion in the meeting of the American Missionary Association today. Several papers were read, the most interesting of which was one by Col. J.M. Keating of Memphis.

Any one who steps upon the toes of a corporation Judge commonly elicits a cry of pain from the Evening Post. The Post has given its editorial support to Judge HAIGHT, the Republican candidate for the Court of Appeals, and it is informed that the "attack" made upon that Judge by THE TIMES "has...

The pilot chart of the North Atlantic Ocean for the present month will be issued by the Hydrographic Office at Washington today. It refers to the International Marine Conference at Washington, saying that so many plans and devices have been presented that it has been decided not to consider anything not submitted to the conference by Oct. 30.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 31.--For the second time the international American excursion party entered the State of Illinois at an early hour this morning.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 31.--Information has been received to the effect that the first-class twin-screw armor-plated barbette ship Warspite, 8,500 tons, 10,000 horse power, carrying ten guns of the modern fashion, is shortly to replace the Swiftsure as flagship of the North Pacific station.

SCRANTON, Penn., Oct. 31.--In the course of quarrel about money this afternoon Martin Schultz shot and stabbed Patrick Hughes so desperately that he cannot recover. The fight took place just outside the residence of Schultz...

CHATTANOOGA Tenn., Oct.31.--A large real estate transaction was closed to-day by the transfer of 2,000 acres adjoining the eastern corporation limits of this city to a company of manufacturers and bankers of Boston and Lynn, Mass., for $750,000.

One of the prettiest of the recent Brooklyn weddings was that last evening of Miss Miriam Brandon Salmon, daughter of Hamilton H. Salmon, and William F. Tooker, Jr., at the bride's home, at 15 Spencer-place.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31.--Lawrence Percy Dawson, the son of ex-Commissioner Dawson, of the Bureau of Education, was arrested last night on a warrant charging him with the larceny of ninety-one dollars' worth of postage stamps from the bureau where he had been employed.

Coroner Levy yesterday concluded the inquest in the case of William F. Campbell, a manager of a liquor store at Albany and West streets, who was shot and killed by Patrolman Patrick T. Morris of the Second Precinct about ten days ago.

A.B. George won a match half-mile race with J. C. Devereux yesterday afternoon on the Manhattan Athletic Club's tract. Both are Manhattan athletes and ran to settle the question of speed at the distance and to decide which one would have to buy the other a new hat. George led throughout the race and Devereux stopped thirty-five yards from the finish.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31.--This was the last day of the Unitarian Conference. The Rev. Edward Everett Hale, Chairman of the Committee on Schools and Colleges, in a short address spoke very emphatically upon the fact that many of the State universities, while they claimed to be non-sectarian, were not such in truth.

In three weeks the Paris Exhibition will close, but it has been at last settled that the structure is not all to be pulled down. Parts of it have served their purpose so well, have so much inherent beauty in them from the architect's ...

Winthrop Parker, Gen. John E. Ward, and John H. Wood, Commissioners appointed to take evidence and appraise the value on a proposed school site bounded by Washington, Albany, and Carlisle streets, met at 17 Williamstreet yesterday afternoon.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31.--It is apparent that a gang of smugglers here has for six months been making a very handsome profit out of the opium trade, and an investigation has brought to light figures which place the loss to the Government through fraud at nearly $400,000.

In the suit of Ida Rafferty as administratrix against Charles R. Partridge, the lumber merchant, to recover $5,000 for having caused the death of her husband, Judge Andrews yesterday granted an order for the examination of Daniel Coleman, who was a witness of the killing and is about to leave the State.
John B. Skehan recovered a judgment of $6,922 92 against the Electric Time Company, whose offices are at 60 Broadway, and factory at 45 Cortlandt-street, for moneys loaned.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31.--Following are copies of letters written by John Wanamaker, Post office Inspector Edgarton, and col. Charles H. Banes relative to the management of the Phila delphia Post Office by Postmaster Harrity.

LONDON, Oct. 31.--Mr. Michael Davitt continued his speech before the Parnell Commission to-day. He said that Farragher, who had been clerk of the Land League, but who had turned informer and testified for the Times, had been unable to prove the assertion made by Attorney General Webster that the League had advanced ...

Edward C. Perkins of the law firm of Davenport, Smith Perkins, acting for Francis J. Dominick, one of the holders of property the easements of which the elevated railroad company is seeking to have condemned, made a motion before Judge Andrews, in Supreme Court.

The founding in this country of a company of capitalists for the purpose of building seagoing torpedo boats will afford the United States Navy Department an opportunity to encourage the development of a peculiar and distinct American type of torpedo boats, that is, if it is intended by the company having the matter in hand that the type shall be a distinct one.

PINEVILLE, Ky., Oct. 31.--News reached here to-night by reliable parties that Judge Lewis came up with Howard and his gang yesterday on Martin's Fork and killed six of the Howard gang without lossing a man.

After much delay it has been decided that the system now used to heat and ventilate the Post Office in this city is entirely inadequate. Bids for improving this system were advertised for and it was announced two days ago that Blake Williams of this city had offered the lowest figures--$13,680.

Though there were no one-thousand-dollar subscriptions to help swell the Washington Memorial Arch Fund during the month of Octo ber, yet the people took such an active interes in the progress of this patriotic movement that a largely-increased number of subscribers added ...

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 31.--The delegates from Clinton County to the Republican Senatorial Convention, held at Port Henry, were in favor of the renomination of Senator Kellogg.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 31.--Thomas R. Trowbridge, Secretary of the New-Haven Colony Historical Society, received a letter yesterday from the Hon. Richard A. Wheeler of Stonington, a Connecticut historian, inclosing for the society a letter from the Rev. Joseph Noyes, ...

Police court punishment was meted out yesterday to Willy Loeb and Maurice Mendham of the Consolidated Exchange for their pugilistic behavior on the floor during business hours Wednesday. The officials to whom the case was presented decided to impose a fine of $5 each. The offenders paid the fine and re-established friendly relations in the customary way.

The first concert of the New-York Philharmonic Club this season will be given at Chickering Hall on Tuesday evening, Nov. 26. The soloists will be Mrs. Charles Tylor Dutton, soprano; Miss May E. Smith, flutist, and Mr. Richard Hoffman, pianist.

For the great Catholic Congress in Baltimore, the Pennsylvania Railroad Company will sell ex cursion tickets to the public, from New-York to Baltimore and return, Nov. 7 to 12, valid for return trip until Nov. 16, inclusive, at $5 30.
It is definitely settled, all reports to the con trary notwithstanding, that Henry Irving will not visit this country professionally next sea son.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31.--Col. Samuel Parker of Honolulu, a member of King Kalakaua's military staff, said to-day in an interview here on his way home after a several months' stay in this country and Europe, that he was able to authoritatively deny the stories that the Hawaiian Islands want to be annexed to this country.

Articles of incorporation of the St. Louis, Indianapolis and Eastern Railroad Company have been filed in the office of the Secretary of State of Illinois. The friends of John F. Ahearn, who is the County Democracy's candidate for Senator in the Sixth District, are charging that the police are taking a hand in the canvass in behalf of Thomas F. Grady, the Tammany candidate.

PROVIDENCE, Oct. 31.--The will of Henry J. Steere, one of the wealthiest men in Providence, who died recently, gives away directly and in trust the sum total of $1,139,000. Mr. Steere was a single gentleman and was all his...

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 31.--R.W. Hughes, the father of Mamie Hughes, who disappeared from her home in New-Brunswick Tuesday night, left here this morning after a vain attempt to obtain a clue to his daughter's whereabouts.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31.--Albert Sutherland, the young criminal who has recently gained considerable notoriety because of his resemblance to Tascott, the murderer of Millionaire Snell of Chicago, was given another hearing in a magistrate's court to-day on charges of passing forged checks for various amounts on tradesmen in this city.
At a meeting of the State Committee of the Legislative Reform Party, at 35 Clinton-place, last night the following preamble and resolu tions were unanimously adopted:

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Oct. 31.--Suit has been begun here by a Pottawatemie chief, representing his tribe, for the recovery of large tracts of land out of which the Indians claim to have been swindled.

The candidacy of Senator M.C. Murphy for the Senate from the Fifth District was indorsed last night by the Republican Senatorial Convention. The Richmond County Republican Genral Committee met at Stapleton, S.I., yesterday, and also voted to indorse Murphy.

Wall-street seems to be getting into a mood to be Wall-street again. Real life ventured into the Stock Exchange yesterday, and the close of business saw abounding headaches, and heartaches, and tattered bank accounts. Alas, the lamb! The shearer has had another merrymaking.

Jeremiah Laud, aged 29, a lineman employed by the New-York and New-Jersey Telephone Company, was stringing wires on the Kings County Elevated Road at Fulton and Bedford avenues, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, when he lost his balance and fell to the street.

A message came into the delivery room of each newspaper office yesterday that said in substance: "Tell all the newsboys who come into your place to-day, without regard to race, creed, or previous condition of servitude, that if they will come up to the Park Theatre tonight and see 'McKenna's Flirtation' the manager and the company will treat them with distinguished consideration."

An authorized statement is made that Belford, Clarke Co. have settled with their creditors and have formed two new corporations for the purpose of carrying on Belford's Magazine and the publishing business of Belford, Clarke Co.
Before being dismissed by Judge Martine, in Part I. of the Court of General Sessions yesterday, the Grand Jury handed up a presentment in regard to excise cases.

There is no longer anything like a serious dispute of the fact that the Chicago and Alton has been bargained for by the Vanderbilts and the Union Pacific interests. A further and consequent deal will be made public within the next ten days.

ALBANY, Oct. 31.--The report of the Central Park, North and East Rivers Railroad Companies, for the quarter ended Sept. 30, when compared with the corresponding quarter last year shows an increase of $32,000 in gross earnings and a gain in net income of $136,580. The operating expenses this year fall off $94,337.

A mass meeting under the auspices of the Repub lican Club of the City of New-York will be held at the Cooper Institute this evening, beginning at 8 o'clock. Mortimer C. Addoms, the President of the club, will preside, and addresses will be made by the Hon. Chauncey M. Depew, the Hon. J. Sloat Passett, the Hon. Stewart L. Woodford, and the Hon. C.P. Vedder. Ladies will be welcomed and seats reserved for them.

According to prominent steel and iron merchants the opinion seems universal that the building up of the new navy has worked wonders for the steel and iron industry in this country.

Anselme Stanislaus de Bortkiewitch, the alleged professor of languages, who was arrested on Thursday evening for trying to sell three stolen finger rings to down-town jewelers, was arraigned in the Tombs Court yesterday, and was remanded until to-day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1.--Ohio Republicans at the capital are in the possession to-day of a generally gloomy line of news from the Buckeye State. Some of them are getting rid of it with a readiness that looks suspiciously like pleasure. They do not openly rejoice to learn that the outlook for Foraker is dubious, and that for a Republican majority in the Legislature darker still.

John Virtue, Roman Catholic Bishop of Portsmouth, England, who sailed for New-York yesterday on the steamship Saale, will represent England at the celebration in Baltimore of the one hundredth anniversary of the establishment of the Catholic hierarchy in the United States.

Prof. G. Frederick Wright of Oberlin College delivered a very interesting lecture on "The Ice Age of America" before a large audience last evening in the hall of the Harlem branch of the Young Men's Christian Association. It was illustrated with a number of lantern views.

There is renewed interest in naval circles in the proposition to secure legislation which would open a way for enlisted and appointed men in the navy to obtain commissions. It is declared that a more healthful tone would be imparted to the whole naval establishment by making it possible for deserving young men to rise above the grade of warrant officers.

The Japanese proprietor of a little store in the shopping district, where all sorts of puzzling Oriental goods, usefal, ornamental, ugly, and positively frightful, are sold, had an experience the other day with that terror of the shopkeepers, the professional "beater-down." He didn't actually enjoy the encounter, but he came out victorious.
OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 1.--A heavy snow has been falling here since early the morning. The storm played havoc with the railway telegraph wires and the overland trains generally.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1.--The Grand Jury returned three additional indictments in the Times case this morning. There are two indictments against J.J. West and Secretary Graham-- one for overissuing the stock of the Times Com pany and one for assigning overissued stock. There is a separate indictment against West for overissuing stock.

The market through the week has been about what it was expected to be--irregular; dull a good deal of the time, with spells of extreme liveliness by way of compensation. Some specialties have gone up, and one or two have gone down, much down; and the way of the bull speculator has in general been made hard for him, particularly if he was speculating in trusts.

Pakenham, Charles Knight Rogers, Cornelius J. Van Wyck, the Rev. Lloyd Jones, George Grant Francis, Dr. L. B. Graddy, Howard W. Berry, and Capt. Henry A. Bartlett.

Mrs. Jennie Guttenberg of 146 Broadway, Brooklyn, was locked up in Police Headquarters in Hoboken late Saturday night. She is held ostensibly as a witness in the matter of the recent suicide of Jacob Glucklich, at Kohler's boarding house on Second-street, Hoboken. Glucklich, before killing himself, wrote a letter in which he told a remarkable story as to the circumstances that prompted his suicide.
Capt. Mallett of the schooner Sainte Marie, which arrived yesterday from the West Indies, reports that on Oct. 15 his vessel got out of her course and ran ashore on the Colorado Reet, in the Bahamas.

Coin collectors are promised a new example without which no cabinet can be complete. A dollar is to be struck in Italy larger in size and greater in value than the familiar five-lire piece. The old Marie Therese thaler is to be the model.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 3.--A number of removals have taken place at the Naval Academy this week, it is charged for political reasons. One of the bosses, who has been discharged, had been employed at the Academy from boyhood, and another had been connected with the navy for twenty-six years. Republicans have been put in the places vacated.

BLOOMSBURG, N.J., Nov. 3.--Moses Robbins hanged himself in a vacant building near his house this afternoon. No cause is assigned for the act. Mr. Robbins was one of the most prominent and wealthy men in the town. He was an Elder of the Presbyterian Church.

LONDON, Nov. 3.--There was a fair demand for discount during the past week at 4 to 3 . The Stock Exchange loan rate to next account is 4 to 4 . Business on the Stock Exchange was slow, but prices were maintained.

Bull, President of the New-York Stock Exchange, who comprise the committee appointed to prepare a plan for converting the Cotton Oil Trust into an ordinary corporation, are to meet at the office of Winslow, Lanier Co. in Wall-street this afternoon, and formally adopt a programme. They have agreed upon a plan.

The Hamilton Club of Brooklyn has made arrangements to give ex-Mayor Seth Low a farewell dinner prior to his departure from the city to assume the Presidency of Columbia College. Mr. Low accepted the invitation on Saturday, and named Jan. 23 next as the date for the banquet. He will leave Brooklyn on Feb. 1.

A larger audience than usual was present last night at the weekly meeting of the AntiPoverty Society at Cooper Union. Dr. McGlynn had been announced to speak upon election issues, and although he delayed referring to any such issues until pretty late in the evening, he expressed himself in no uncertain tones.

Orlando Mayo was arrested at Bridgton, Me., Saturday, charged with the embezzlement of $849 from the Swampscott office of the Maverick Company, about a week ago. Mayo, who was a clerk for the company opened the office safe, and taking the money disappeared.

SYDNEY, N.S.W., Nov. 3.--Sir Henry Parkes, in a circular letter to the Prime Ministers of the Australian Colonies, after pointing out difficulties in the way of the creation of a Federal army, gives in detail the objects of the convention recently proposed by him in a speech here.

Prof. Cromwell lectured at the Bijon Theatre last night on "The World's Fair of 1889 and other Sights in Paris." The lecture was exceedingly entertaining and instructive, and was listened to with marked interest by a large audience.

The laws of New-Jersey forbid the sale of liquor on Sundays and on election days, but it is not the custom to observe the law. In Jersey City yesterday the sale of liquor appeared to be going on as usual. Most of the liquor dealers are Democrats, since there is a tradition that the Republican Party is fanatical on the liquor question.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 3.--Although the day of the election is less than thirty-six hours off, both sides are continuing to press forward with their campaign work. The Democrats are determined that for close hard work and enthusiasm displayed by their side this contest shall exceed anything known in the past. The real practical work of the campaign, though, is pretty well at an end.

Wall-street has been much worried lately over a mystery in the affairs of the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company. The price of the company's stock fell three points in the last two days of the week's business on the Stock Exchange from causes that apparently nobody but insiders could understand.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Nov. 3.--After his arrival at the Yildiz Palace yesterday Emperor William witnessed a parade of the troops in garrison here. The Emperor praised the excellent bearing of the soldiers, especially commending the appearance of the artillerymen.

BANGOR, Me., Nov. 3.--The hunting grounds of Maine, where abound moose, caribou, and deer, are divided into sections, and one of the most famous of these is Nicatous, which contains a big lake of that name and some four hundred square miles, the water being in the centre.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 3.--The campaign now practically closed has been the most interesting, and the result on Tuesday promises to be the closest, in the history of Iowa politics since the war. Iowa has offered an interesting study for years, but this year the situation here has been intensified.

At yesterday's meeting of the Central Labor Union the knife cutters asked the meeting to advise the voters in the Fifth Senatorial District not to vote for Col. W.L. Brown because his paper had not printed their advertisement when they were on strike.

The Lyceum Theatre stock company, after its present week's engagement in Brooklyn, will rest and devote its attention to rehearsals of "The Charity Ball," preparatory to the opening of the regular season at the home theatre the following week.
The very successful meeting of the NewJersey Jockey Club will be resumed this afternoon, and continued every day throughout the week with six races daily.

All the political managers in Brooklyn were busy yesterday arranging the details for tomorrow. Wagons filled with ballots were sent to every ward association, and to-day they will be distributed at the various election districts. The polls will open to-morrow at 6:39 A.M. and close at 4:49 P.M.

Pilot Joseph Nelson, who took out the steamship Cienfuegos of the Ward Line on Oct. 15, was unable to leave the vessel at the Sandy Hook pilot station, owing to the heavy sea which was running. He remained on board the vessel during her trip to and from Cuba. The Cienfuegos returned to this port yesterday and Pilot Nelson's enforced voyage was brought to a close.

Robert Boyd was taken to St. Vincent's Hospital from his room in the house of Mrs. Ballantine, 5 Waverley-place, yesterday, in an unconscious state. It was not determined whether he was suffering from brain trouble or opiates, but the physicians in attendance do not give any hope of his recovery.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3.--The retirement of H.C. Wicker from the office of Traffic Manager of the Chicago and northwestern Railroad gave rise to an incident yesterday that demonstrates the popularity of that gentleman among his associates in the office and the regret that is felt at his departure.

SOFIA, Nov. 3.--Prince Ferdinand opened the Sobranje to-day. Slavkoff, the Government candidate, was elected President of the Sobranje.

With its November number the Century enters upon its twentieth year. The number is worthy to mark such a setting out for new fields to conquer. Joseph Jefferson's autobiography opens in a very promising manner.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 3.--The last day of the campaign has been reached, and, following their wont, the politicians on both sides have taken up their pencils and have begun to figure on probable results. It is admitted that Gen. Grubb, the Republican candidate for Governor, has made a more energetic and effective campaign than he was expected to make.
BROWNWOOD, Texas, Nov. 3.--The southbound Santa Fe passenger train, consisting of five coaches and two baggage cars, was wrecked this morning three miles south of Brownwood.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 3.--To-day has been a busy Sunday with both parties in Cincinnati. Confessedly, during the entire campaign, Hamilton County has been the rallying seat of the fight, and there was a feeling that it would determine the election.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3.--Mr. Romero, the Mexican Minister, arrived in the city yesterday, having left the Pan-American excursion. He said this evening that his return was not due to the Mizner incident. That affair was settled before he left Washington some days ago.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 3.--The schooner Flora Rogers, which rescued the mate and four of the crew of the water-logged schooner Jennie Roseline, from Savannah for Providence Oct. 25, was off Charleston bar this morning and the rescued mariners were brought here in the tug Jacob Brendow. Their names are: Mate Frank Maxson of Baltimore, James A. Runney of St. John, A.A. Pinckney, New-York; M. Heffron, Berkenhead, England, and George Smith, Norway.

Frederick Davis, twenty years old, of 159 West Twenty-third-street, was yesterday committed by Justice Hogan for trial for attempted suicide. He is a clerk in the woolen house of Collins, Downing Co. at 480 Broadway. Davis's father is the proprietor of the Narragansett Hotel at Providence. On Saturday night the young man cut the viens of his right wrist, with suicidal intent, it is charged.

CONSTANTINOPLE, NOV. 4.--This afternoon the Emperor William made an excursion to Therapia. In the evening the Sultan gave a banquet in honor of his guests and afterward escorted the Emprees to the royal harem, where she remained nearly an hour.

The candidates for Governor were Leon Abbett (Dem.) and Edward Burd Grubb (Rep.) The returns come in slowly, and in most cases will not be obtainable to-night. There is every indication of a sweeping Democratic victory.

The engine, tender, and three cars of a live stock train left the rails near Hamilton, Ontario, yesterday. It is to be hoped that our bonifaces will not forget this wise maxim.

The revision of the drill tactics for the United States Army, which will also affect the infantry drills in vogue in the navy, appears to be a direct outcome of the changes rapidly going on in the armies of Continental Europe. The close communication between this country and the Old World enables military men of all nations to keep pace with the very latest developments in military science.

The Washington Memorial Arch fund was increased yesterday by contributions by Prof. Theodore W. Dwight, of the Columbia Law School, of $100; Guy R. Pelton, $50; A.P. Segur, $5, and the following through the Commercial Advertiser: Travers Brothers, $10; E. N. Howell, $5; George F. Keith, $2, and Simon Klee, August Goldsmith, and "Cash," $1 each; total $175, swelling the total in the hands of Treasurer William R. Stewart to $58,715.80.

HUDSON, N.Y., Nov. 9.--The brickmaking season along the Hudson River is about ended. Unfavorable meteorological conditions materially retarded the work. Next year many manufacturers will burn brick in the kilns with oil. It has been demonstrated at a score or more of points that oil is a cheaper and a better fuel than wood.

RED BANK, N.J., Nov. 9.--As a hunter was gunning near William H. Grant's farm a day or two ago he saw a fish in a small stream. Thinking it was a snoker, he fired at it. His aim was good and the fish was killed. It proved to be a trout weighing about a pound.

Mrs. Calyer; her granddaughter, Mrs. Galway, and three great grandchildren, the youngest being two years of age. When the members of the Rutgers Glee Club appeared in Baltimore on Monday they were mistaken for repeaters and had some difficulty in persuading the officials of their innocence and so escaping arrest. It became whispered about later that the whole demonstration by the Baltimore officials was the result of a practical joke played by one of the members on the others. The glee club has also sung in Harlem and Brooklyn within the week.
LONDON, Oct. 30.--Prayers were offered in the churches of Northampton on Sunday last for the recovery of Charles Bradlaugh! The whirligig of time brings strange changes, we all know.

HAMILTON, Ontario, Nov. 9.--The annual meeting of the Lake Yachting Association was held here to-day. Delegates were present from Rochester, Oswega, Toronto, Belleville, Kingston, and Buffalo. It was decided to do away with the present mode of classifying by water line, and substitute therefor classification by corrected length. Under this system both length and sail may not be considered constant, as in the present mode, but both are variable.

LONDON, Nov. 9.--At a meeting in the Guildhall to-day Lord Salisbury delivered an address in which he congratulated the country upon the splendid expansion of its trade. ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 9.--An important proposition will be submitted by the Pennsylvania Railroad Company to the City Council here on next Tuesday night. The company will agree to abolish its grade crossings in this city and to run its tracks across the streets at an elevation of from twelve to sixteen feet, and to fill in the roadbed solidly with earth and wall it. The roadway will be forty feet wide.

FRANKLIN, Mass., Nov. 9.--Elmer Labadie, a Frenchman, about forty-five years of age, while on trial for criminal assault, before Judge Wiggin to-day, killed himself by cutting his throat with a jackknife. "Silver-Dollar" Charles Smith is said to be thinking about contesting the seat of Philip Wissig, who was elected over him in the Eighth District. Smith's friends claim that about 300 votes were purposely deposited in the wrong boxes and then thrown out of the count. "Sil ver Dollar" as a cheated candidate is an amusing spectacle.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 9.--The United States Grand Jury to-day indicted eighteen of the one hundred and twenty-four Navassa rioters for murder and being accessories before the fact, the penalty for which is death. Seven are charged as principals and eleven as having aided and abetted the murderers.

RED BANK, N.J., Nov. 9.--Charles Oser, a German laborer, aged about twenty-five, committed suicide last night by hanging himself in the lockup at Keyport. HUDSON, N.Y., Nov. 9.--During the past three years incendiary fires have been alarmingly frequent in this city. H.S. Moul's carpenter shop was the last building to which the torch was applied. A young man named William Casey was suspected, and on being arrested confessed that he was guilty.

RED BANK, N.J., Nov. 9.--James Lambertson of Matawan and his son Albert went quail shooting on Thursday. Mr. Lambertson fired into a flock of quail and part of the load struck his son in the head. The wound is a serious one, and young Lambertson has been taken to a New-York hospital for treatment.

AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 9.--A large and enthusiastic crowd witnessed the Amherst-Williams football game on Blake Field this afternoon. The field was muddy and slippery. The score at the end of the half was 6--6.

CITY OF MEXICO, Nov. 10, via Galveston.-- The accounts of recent desertions from the garrison here were exaggerated. It appears that a guard, in deserting, stabbed a Sergeant, inflicting a slight wound. This affair led to rumors of serious trouble.

The death of Manager William Henderson will not affect the career of the Academy of Music in Jersey City, except in so far as those now incharge of it will naturally miss his wise suggestions and counsel.

The vessels composing Admiral Walker's squadron of evolution are now anchored in the North River off Twentieth-street. As they lie they offer about as effectual a blockade of the river as one can imagine. But this is, in part, the fault of the revised anchorage regulations for New-York Harbor, which permit vessel of war to anchor below Thirty-fifth-street.

An absent-minded Newburg man on Tuesday presented himself at the Third Ward polls in that city and tendered his vote. The name was announced by the clerk, the registry polls checked, the ballots accepted and deposited in their respective boxes. The voter then left to attend to his duties in a business line.
The Fall club games of the Star Athletic Club of Long Island City were held yesterday afternoon on the grounds of the club. The contests were witnessed by 500 people.

J. B. Gibbs returned to the temperance arena yesterday, after remaining quiescent for some months. But he is not doing business at the old stand. The walls of Masonic Temple no longer throw back his exhortations. He is now at Dockstader's, where each Sunday afternoon all are welcome at 10 cents apiece.

LONDON, Nov. 10.--Discount was firm during the past week at 4 to 3 . Business on the Stock Exchange was extremely quiet. Speculation was stagnant and the flow of investments diminished. The markets seem to be passing through the dull period often experienced toward the end of the year.

Within the last six months, and under the direction of the Trustees of the Home for Aged and Infirm Hebrews, an annex has been added to that institution. SYDNEY, N.S.W., Nov. 10.--A public meeting to discuss the subject of colonial federation was held here to-day. Sir Henry Parkes and others made addresses. Resolutions were adopted in favor of federation at the earliest possible period.

Republican special says: "The bodies of John Martin and Henry Miller, the cowboys who were frozen to death near Sierra Grande in last week's terrible blizzard, were brought to Folsom for burial. The week which Young Men's Christian Associations all over the world devote to special prayer for young men began yesterday. The opening service at the Association Hall in this city was crowded and enthusiastic. From 2:45 to 3:15 P.M., while the members and their friends were coming in, the orchestra of the association furnished music.

The farm of the late Isaac Varney, in the western part of the town, was offered at public auction last week, but no bidders appeared at the sale. This is the third nice farm that has been offered at auction in this vicinity within a short time without finding a purchaser. On all these farms large families were raised, and the farm owners accumulated handsome properties by farming.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10.--The Aparchist memorial celebration to-day was very tame-in fact, the only noteworthy incident was furnished by Mrs. Luey Parsons, who, in defiance of the police prohibition of red flags, hung one from the window of her residence on Milwaukee-avenue early in the day. A policeman was sent to her house to notify her to take down the anarchical emblem.

The baboon, writes the Graaff-Reinet Advertiser, a South African Paper, seems to be changing its nature with the changing, climatic conditions. In former years he was a vegetarian, his worst offense being stealing mealies in the gardens when he got the chance.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10.--The Pan-American party spent Sunday in sightseeing. In the morning they visited Girard College, and from there went to the Eastern Penitentiary. After dinner many of the visitors took carriage rides through Fairmount Park.

BALTIMORE, NOV.10.--With fitting grandeur the most important group of events in the history of the Catholic Church in America began here this morning. It was the commencement of a triple celebration--the hundredth anniversary of the appointment of the first American Catholic Bishop, the inauguration of the first Congress of Catholic laymen held in the United States, and the dedication of the new National University for Catholics.

St. John Roosa presided and opened the meeting with a short address. He was followed by Donald MacColl, of the Class of '91, of Princeton University.

Police Captain Early, two detectives, and a squad of patrolmen raided a gambling room at 475 Adelphi-street. Brooklyn, last night, and captured eleven negroes playing poker. The place was fitted up in fine style and contained four poker tables, a faro "lay-out," a roulette table, and a "sweathoard." A dozen packs of cards, several boxes of chips, and other paraphernalia were captured.

Capt. Edward O. Bird, who died suddenly on Friday evening at his home, 13 West Thirtyfirst-street, was well known in military and business circles in this city. He was born in New-York in 1839, and for a number of years was engaged in business with his father, Matthew Bird, an old-time merchant.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10.--Under any Administration, no matter how much it may be disposed to be communicative, it is not easy to get from its members the admission that there is not absolute agreement on all questions.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 10.--The registration of voters for 1889 was 580, being 25 less than last year. The number of votes cast was 442, about the usual number for an off year.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 10.--Another smashup on the Jersey Central Railroad occurred about midnight on Saturday at Roselle. A coal train west-bound ran off the main line there into the company's yard and collided with a train of five passenger coaches on a side track.

Sunol is her name, and she is a three-year-old daughter of the famous stallion Electioneer, by Waxana, a daughter of General Benton. Waxana's dam was the thoroughbred mare Waxy, by Lexington, the most famous American racers.

TRENTON, N. J., NOV. 10.--The New-Jersey State Board of Assessors have completed their assessment of the railroad systems of the State. The total amount of taxes to be paid by the railroads for the year is $1,329,608, against $1,316,282 last year, an increase of $13,326.

Prof. Heinrich Bauer, who was at one time instructor of philosophy at a Hungarian university, and is now orchestral director of the New-York Maennerchor, the Turnverein, and the Heine Bund, is to give a series of lectures on "Psychology," beginning next Sunday, at the Maennerchor Hall, on East Fifty-sixthstreet.

BOSTON, Nov. 11.--Representatives of all the athletic societies of Harvard College met the Chairman and Sub-Committee on Organization of the Athletic Committee to-night and entered into articles of agreement tending to secure more systematic and economical management of the funds of the athletic associations.

ATHENS, Nov. 11.--In the Chamber of Deputies to-day Prime Minister Tricoupis said he must confess that he had been deceived by the Turks; but Greece would one day vindicate Cretan rights. The Government had hitherto desired to maintain cordial relations with Turkey, but after recent events in Crete that was impossible.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11.--An explosion of flash powder occurred at the chemical manufacturing establishment of Wiley Wallace, 123 North Seventh-street, this afternoon, by which three men were instantly killed, one fatally injured, and another seriously injured.

ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 11.--The Novoe Vremya, referring to the statements made by Lord Salisbury at the Lord Mayor's banquet that the difficulties in Europe appeared to be tending toward a peaceful solution, and that all the great powers were desirous of avoiding a conflict, says that the optimism of the British Premier is artificial and insecure.

PARIS, Nov. 11.--The Soleil says that the interviews between the Czar and Prince Bismarck during his Majesty's visit to Berlin resulted in a decision to oust Prince Ferdinand of Bulgaria from the rulership of that country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11.--The Supreme Court of the United States to-day rendered an opinion in the case of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, plaintiff in error, vs P.H. Miller. In this the railroad held that it was not liable for injury to property, but merely for property taken, as expressed in its charter.
Special Customs Inspector Charles Traiteur made a discovery on board the schooner Willie Lowrie, from Hayti, yesterday.

The seventh annual meeting of the New-York Indian Association was held yesterday afternoon at the residence of Mrs. Theodore Irving, 21 West Thirty-second-street, and was largely attended by ladies interested in the work of bringing the red men to a higher state of civilization and advancing the cause of Christianity among them. Mrs. Irving presided.

Mr. Robert Bonner was a very happy man last night, having purchased the great three-yearold filly Sunol from Leland Stanford of California. BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 12.--In spite of its great size and immense accommodations the Hemenway gymnasium has proved to be too small for Harvard as far as locker room is concerned.

The funeral of the late State Treasurer Hart of Pennsylvania took place yesterday at Harrisburg, and was largely attended. After a service at the family residence the body was conveyed to the rotunda of the Capitol, where it lay in state until 1 o'clock. A military guard of honor surrounded the casket.

The Mayor got any amount of letters, some very respectable subscriptions, and a lot of advice concering the World's Fair in yesterday's mail. Now that the "Central Park bugaboo" has been removed, subscriptions are coming in more rapidly.

LONDON, Nov. 12.--The Hon. William M. Evarts and his family will sail for New-York to-morrow. Mr. Evart's health has improved, and his eyesight is stronger. He has received many attentions during his visit in London. He was given a farewell dinner last night. Among the guests were Lord Chief Justice Coleridge and Presiding Justice Hannen of the Parneil Commission.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Nov. 12.--The Missionary Conference of the Particular Synod of NewBrunswick began here to-day. This synod comprises all of the 125 Reformed Churches in the State of New-Jersey and those in the city of Philadelphia and in Bucks County, Penn.

Hunt, a member of the court, will take his place. Lieut. DALLAS, Texas, Nov. 13.--The Capitol Hotel was destroyed by fire this morning. The seventy-five inmates lost all their clothing, most of them escaping in their night clothes. Two druken men perished in the flames. The building was owned by Henry Hamilton. The hotel was run by Orr McIrvay. The total loss is $40,000; insurance $28,200. The fire was the work of an incendiary.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 13.--There is great excitement here over the announcement that the steamboat A.C. Conn., a Mississippi River craft, has passed through the Muscle Shoals Canals, and will arrive at the wharf in this city to-morrow morning. This is the first vessel which has passed through the great canals now about completed.

A Prussian named Andreas Koeppe, who arrived yesterday on the steamship Slavonia, tells a vary peculiar story. He claims that he has been expelled from Prussia for being an American citizen. This man without a country says that he is a native of Schneidemuhl in Posen, where his parents own a farm worth about ...

Templeton of Greenville, and Lewis Walker of Meadville, were the legal lights that appeared in the United States Circuit Court at Pittsburg yesterday, in the case in equity against the Shenaugo and Allegheny Railroad. New-York has among its residents to-day two Princes of royal blood, though their complexion is dark and they come from the mid-Pacific Ocean. An early express from the West brought Prince D. Kawanawakoa and Prince J. Kalamanaole, nephews of the King of the Hawaiian Islands and next after the King's sister, now no longer young, in the line of succession to the throne.

The School Trustees of the Ninth Ward held a prolonged and very heated meeting last evening in Grammar School No. 3, at 488 Hudsonstreet. As he had promised to do, Trustee L.J. McNamara, M.D., brought before the board charges against the Principals and teachers of ...

DUBUQUE, Iowa, Nov. 14.--The returns of the late election, as received by the various papers in the State, of the official count of the vote in Iowa in the several counties vary considerably. On the Lieutenant Governorship at the State capital the Leader (Dem.) has figures showing that Poyneer (Rep.) was about 275 plurality over Bestow. (Dem.)

ALBANY, Nov. 14.--The annual report of the Prospect Park and Flatbush Railroad Company has been presented to the State Board of Railroad Commissioners. It shows: Gross earnings from operation, $2,831; operating expenses, ...

WILMINGTON, Del, Nov. 14.--"Jimmy Hope, the notorious bank burglar now held in the Tombs Prison, New-York, upon a charge of being implicatod in the Manhattan Bank burglary, is wanted in this State to finish a sentence imposed for one of his burglarious acts, and a requisition for his return will be forwarded to Gov. Hill of New-York to-morrow:

There were two meetings of paper manufacturers in the Gilsey House yesterday, the Paper and Bag Manufacturers meeting as guests of Mr. Arkell and the Paper Manufacturers' Association as guests of ex-State Senator T.C. Bates of Worcester, Mass.

Peter Schnitgen, who was a portly angler and kept a saloon and restaurant at 811 Third-avenue, was drowned yesterday while trolling for striped bass on the Sunken Meadow, where the ill-fated Seawanhaka was beached. Mrs. Schnitgen had been bedridden through an attack of ...

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 14.--A parting echo of the famous Credit Mobilier litigation was heard in the United States Circuit Court before Judge Wales in this city, this morning, in the summary ending of a case in which that celebrated close corporation was a plaintiff.

BOSTON, Nov. 14.--The Republicans of Boston last night held caucuses in all the city wards to select delegates to the City and Aldermanic Conventions. Without an exception the delegates to the City Convention are pledged to renominate Mayor Hart.

Brooklyn and Cincinnati having grown tired of the workings of the American Association, yesterday made formal application to join the League. They were admitted, and next year tha organization will be composed of ten clubs--five in the East and a like number in the West.
LONDON, Nov. 14.--Upon the reassembling of the Parnell Commission this morning, the cashier of the National Bank proceeded to testify as to the accounts kept at the bank by members of the League.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Nov. 14.--A leading banker of Pontiac telegraphs regarding the flight and defalcation of W.H. Fursman as follows: "Mr. Fursman's personal liabilities are confined to a few scattered debts for household and office necessities and a note for $1,000 to the National Bank of Pontiac amply secured.

NASHVILLE, Nov. 14.--The annual congress of the National Prison Association of the United States will convene in the Senate Chamber at the Capitol in this city at 10 o'clock A.M. next Saturday and will continue its session until the evening of the following Wednesday.

The following persons have been appointed cadets at West Point: John William Barker of Syracuse, Twenty-fifth New-York District Robert W. Lawler of Mexico, Seventh Missouri District, with Theodore Sternberg of St. Charles, alternate; Walker Irving Bates of Meadville. Twenty-sixth Pennsylvania District, with Gay Golden Painter of Titusville, alternate.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 14.--The annual Fall meeting of the Board of Trustees of Princeton College was held to-day in the Trustees' room in the college library. The main interest of the meeting was centred in President Patton's report.

The Washington Memorial Arch fund is constantly growing in size by receipts from fresh sources. There is but little reason to doubt now that the much-to-be-desired completion of the amount needed to carry out the work in one year from the day the idea was originated, or in April next, will be accomplished.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Nov. 14.--The Hahn House, the largest and best-appointed Summer hotel in Sullivan County, which has been in litigation for some time, has been sold to G.W. Rockwell of this plce for $15,000. It was built in 1886 at a cost of $35,000, and has all the modern improvements, including gas and baths. It will accommodate 100 guests. It will be refitted and put in first-class order for next season.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14.--The trial of L. Lum Smith, charged with libel on Anthony Comstock, which has been in progress for four days, was continued to-day. Smith, though not a lawyer, is conducting his own defense. When he found he could not cross-examine Comstock, except within the narrow limits of his direct testimony, he called Comstock as a witness for the defense, and for three days has kept him on the rack.

BOSTON, Nov. 14.--John McTammany, State organizer of the Prohibitionists, has a plan of work which he thinks will, if adopted by the State Committee, enable the Prohibition Party to poll at least 25,000 votes for Governor next year. What this plan is he declines to state. The knowing ones, however, say it is nothing less than to nominate Gen. Benjamin F. Butler for Governor.

District Attorney Nelson H. Baker of Westchester County has decided, now that the election is over and he was not elected County Judge, to prosecute all those liquor dealers of Yonkers whose indictments for violating the excise laws in selling liquor on Sundays have been for so many months pigeonholed in his office.

ALBANY, Nov. 14.--Commissions have been issued by the Adjutant General to Herman Dowd as Colonel, Joseph Jonasson as First Lieutenant, John Nelson Borland, Jr., and Robert Shaw Minturn as Second Lieutenants of the Twelfth Regeiment; Benjamin Stephens Cooke as First Lieutenant, Ninth Regiment; George Benjamin McWhinney as Second Lieutenant, Seventy-first Regiment, and William Atwood French as Captain and Inspector of Rifle Practice, Thirteenth Regiment.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14.--Senator Frye left Washington with his committee as the Pan-American delegates were assembling, but he has kept close watch of their travels and will observe with closer interest the proceedings of the congress. He was the originator and framer of the bill making the appropriation for the congress.

The ninety days' notice given the Brush and United States Electric Light Companies by the Board of Electrical Control to remove their poles and wires from Fourteenth-street has expired, and at the next meeting of the board it will be in order for the Mayor to be requested ...

Charles M. Preston of Kingston, John V. Cockroft of Sing Sing, Albert C. Tennent of Cooperstown, Frank W. Downs of Binghamton, and Charles C. Kromer, members of the commission appoined by Gov. Hill to investigate the subject of the removal of Sing Sing ...

BOSTON, Nov. l4.--Four sad-eyed, dejected young men stood up in the municipal dock this morning before Judge Ely. Charles Stewart, J.F. Wilson, G.W. Wentworth, and Dans Smith, as they called themselves, crossed the briny Charles last night prepared to paint the town, but, alas for them, they came under the spell of the tickle goddness and dallied too long in her affections.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14.--Judge Shepard to-day made an order giving Herbert C. Ayer the custody of his daughter, Margaret, who, since Mrs. Harriet Hubbard Ayer secured a divorce from her husband in 1887, has been under Mrs. Ayer'e guardianship.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14.--When Florella, Falsacappa'd daughter in "The Brigands," bounded upon the stage at McVicker's this evening there was a thrill of surprise in the audience. It was not Lillian Russell, but Miss Anna O'Keffe, who assumed the part.

LOUISVILLE, Ky, Nov. 14.--Look and Smith's barn, on the old Standiford farm, near Louisville, used for sheltering brood mares and young colts, was burned last night, together with seventeen brood mares and sixteen yearling colts, entailing a loss of about $25,000; insurance, $1,500.

Among the principal benevolent institutions of the city of Brooklyn is the Orphan Asylum Society. It is supported wholly by voluntary contributions. Once every year the asylum comes before the public, through the medium of a fair held in the Academy of Music, and covering the better part of a week.

TORONTO, Ontario, Nov. 14.--The Baptist Congress to-day discussed Sabbath observance. The trend of thought was very liberal. Many speakers contended that the solution of the problem of how best to achieve Sabbath observance is found in the amelioration of the condition of the masses in cities. Sunday street cars, newspapers, and railway travel were all condemned.

Since the dismissal of the female Customs inspectors Collector Erhardt and Surveyor Lyon have been besioged by the friends of the unlucky ones, who desire their reinstatement yesterday a letter was received from Washington which makes such reinstatement impossible.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 14.--The Young Men's Institute to-day brought suit against the city of New-Haven to recover $65,000, the amount of one of the bequests of the late Philip Marett. Among Marett's numerous bequests was one of $65,000 for "the use of the institute librarry or public library of New-Haven."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14.--The International Marine Conference resumed its session at 11 o'clock this morning. A number of amendments were offered to the rules of the road by Dr. Sieve-King of Germany, Mr. Frederick Verney of Siam, and others. They were laid over and will be printed.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 14.--Several gentlemen desirous of purifying the political atmosphere of this city and county are about to start an independent Democratic newspaper.
LONDON, Nov. 14.--A dispatch from Rio Grande, dated yesterday, says that the Swedish bark Hilma, from New-York Aug. 27, for Pelotas, went ashore near there and became a total wreck.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Nov. 14.--The manufacture of glassware by machinery on a permanent scale is now for the first time undertaken in this country at the long-idle Ellenville Glass Works, in the neighboring village of that name.

BURLINGTON, Iowa, Nov. 14.--William Maxwell, a young switch engineer in the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy yards, is suffering from the effects of a strange occurrence which may cause him to go speechless during the remainder of his life.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Nov. 14.--It is rumored here to-day that Dan Rice, the veteran showman and famous clown, will, within a short time, emerge from an eight years' retirement and again engage in the circus business.

WATERBURY, Conn., Nov. 14.--The Waterbury Board of Trade last night passed resolutions favoring New-York as the best place for holding the World's Fair. Frederick B. Rice, President of the board, was appointed to co-operate with the New-York committee, and to assure them of the substantial sympathy and support of Waterbury merchants.

The Central Elevated Transit Company has made application to the Jersey City Board of Aldermen for permission to build an elevated railroad. The line is to extend from the Jersey Central Ferry at Communipaw directly west to West Side-avenue, on the Bergen hillside.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Nov. 14.--The second annual Fall games of the Plainfield Bicycle Club took place at the Crescent Rink to-night in the presence of about 2,000 spectators. Gold and silver medals were awarded as first and second prizes.

JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 14 .--A special train on the Central Illinois Branch from Aberdeen, Miss., collided three miles north of Canton with a switch engine to-day, resulting in the death of Patrick Redmond, engineer of the switch engine; Tom Loftins, switchman, and an unknown negro. Jim Smith, D. Halsey, and V. Thomas, and several other persons were injured.

The Bottlers' Protective Union held a meeting yesterday at Beethoven Hall in Fifth-street. Mr. Loudon made his report about the search that had been made for bottles and siphons on a search warrant in the establishment of John Morgan, the President of the Union, and that hundreds of bottles of various bottlers had been found there, besides 116 cases of broken glass.

A jury in the Court of Oyer and Terminer last night, after being out more than two hours, brought in a verdict acquitting William Blauvelt, who, on March 15 last, shot and killed John Duggan in a vacant lot near 72 Oliver-street. Blauvelt's trial was begun on Monday before Judge Brady, Assistant District Attorney Goff conducted the case for the people, and the prisoner was defended by Blake Sullivan.

WILMINGTON, N.C., Nov. 14.--The third biennial session of the United Synod of the Evangelical Lutheran Church, South, convened in St. Paul's Lutheran Church in this city to-day. The opening sermon was preached by the retiring President, the Rev. E.T. Horn, D.D., of ...

Mrs. Mary C. Fairfield was yesterday awarded 6 cents damages against the elevated railroad company in the Court of Common Pleas, before Judge Allen, because a ticket taker at the City Hall station called her a liar and shook his fist at her in a dispute as to whether her husband, Samuel E. Fairfield, had put a ticket in the box for her.

There was a meeting of the Board of Managers of the Produce Exchange yesterday to again consider the desire of option brokers to be allowed to remain on the floor of the Exchange and to conduct business up to 4 o'clock. It is understood that the decision will be announced to-day.

The James A. Smith Sons Ice and Fuel Company of East St. Louis. Ill., has made an assignment. Its liabilities are placed at $91,000, but its assets, which are heavily incumbered, are not given. Among the largest creditors are the State Bank of St. Louis, $49,000, and the Franklin Bank of St. Louis, $19,000.

The Australian ballot system was tried in Massachusetts last Tuesday week, and the results have been so marvelously satisfactory that every newspaper in Boston is enthusiastic in its eulogy. That the principles of the system were the only defensible principles was clear ...

The plans of the Consumers' Brewing Company of New-York, Limited, were given in THE TIMES of Thursday. Yesterday more than 100 subscribers, representing $335,000 worth of the capital stock, met in the Germania Assembly Rooms, 291 Bowery, to adopt bylaws and elect Directors.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 14.--The Secretary of State to-night completed the verification of the vote cast at the State election Nov. 5, and the following are the official results:
Prof. J.H. Van Amringe of Columbia College gave a dinner last evening at his residence, 115 west Forty-fourth street, to Seth Low, the newly-elected President of the college.

BOSTON, Nov. 14.--The Charlestown and other people who have been agitating the reopening of the Charlestown Navy Yard have just found out that a movement is on foot which, if carried out, will have some influence on their agitation.

Yesterday's stock market was without any very remarkable features; trading was limited, and there were few changes of consequence in quotations. Chicago has suddenly become bullish upon the market, thanks largely to the influence of one man--Philip D. Armour--whose friends have been quietly given the point to buy St. Paul for a speedy and rapid rise. There was a gain of about a point in the St. Paul quotation yesterday.

George Kennan delivered the second of his course of lectures for the benefit of the building fund of the Brooklyn Woman's Homeopathic Hospital and Dispensary, in the First Baptist Church, at Clinton and Pierrepont streets, Brooklyn, last evening Mr. Kennan took his listeners with him through the mountains of the Caucasus, ...

A dinner will be tendered by members of the Admiralty Bar Saturday evening, Nov. 23, at the Hotel Brunswick, to such delegates of the International Marine Conference as are lawyers, and to the Judges of the United States courts of this city and Brooklyn.

Funeral services of a noteworthy character were held yesterday afternoon in the front parlor of 708 Greenwich-street, where the body of Patrolman August M. De Nyse lay in a rosewood coffin, around which stood some thirty police officers.

Columbia has at last won an intercollegiate football contest. Stevens was defeated by a score of 12 to 6. The game was played yesterday afternoon on the St. George Cricket Grounds, Hoboken. H. Sheldon, '90, Cornell, of the Crescents, was chosen referee, and ...

Mr. Mercler's fellow-Nationalists will be greatly astonished when they hear his declaration that no French Canadians have any thought of creating a distinct French nation of their own on this continent, and much disheartened should they believe such to be his real sentiments.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 14.--The Hon. Andrew D. White, ex-President of Cornell University, who has just returned from extensive travels and a prolonged residence abroad, was interviewed to-day by a representative of THE TIMES. In the course of his talk President White said:

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 14.--Cornelius Prince, age nineteen, son of the pastor of the Presbyterian Church of the Netherlands, Passaic City, was drowned at the Erie Railroad bridge in that place at about 10:30 this morning. He had been employed only since yesterday morning by Bush Brothers, masons, as a driver.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14.--The semi-annual meeting of the National Academy of Sciences which began at the University of Pennsylvania on Tuesday, ended this afternoon.

MILWAUKE, Wis, Nov. 14.--A special to the Evening Wisconsim from Bessemer, Mich., says that Reimund Holzhay, "Black Bart," on trial for the murder of Banker Fleischbein of Belleville, Ill., and the robbery of the Gogebic Stage, took the stand in his own defense to-day and made a confession.

American silk manufacturers have recently had their attention called to a new discovery, which was represented to them as a cheap substitute for silk and was destined to revolutionize the silk industry. It was the invention of the Count Hilaire de Chardonnet of Besancon, ...

Even the big boom of the brewers in raising nearly half a million for the World's Fair guarantee fund did not produce the effect expected yesterday. The total amount reported to the Finance Committee and recorded on its books at the Chamber of Commerce is $2,972,345, and this, with what the Mayor received yesterday, will bring the guarantee fund up to over $3,000,000.

The second annual meeting and dinner of the Union College Alumni Association of New-York will be held at Delmonico's on Monday evening, Dec. 9. The Presidency of the association having been left vacant by the recent death of Judge Van Vorst, the Rev. Dr. Charles D. Nutt, a grandson of Union's celebrated President, has been selected to preside at the dinner.

LONDON, Nov. 14.--This was the third day of the Derby Autumn meeting. The race for the Osmanton Nursery handicap of 500 soverigns, for two-year-olds, about seven furlongs, straightaway, was won by Oxeye, by Oxlip, out at Lady Regian, Shall We Remember, by Clairvaux, out of Sonsie Queen, was second, and Galway third. There were seven starters.

Though it be Friday, the principal item on most of the hotel and restaurant bills of fare to-day will be venison in one form or another. Dealers had put in large stocks of this meat under the supposition that it was salable until Dec. 15.

REGINA, N.W.T., Nov. 14.--Lieut. Gov. Royal is having a good deal of difficulty in administering the affairs of the Northwest Territories or Canada. The fault, however, is more with the system than with the Governor. The system and the present dead-lock have no parallels.

The Board of County Canvassers yesterday looked into the curious fact that in the Fourth Election District of the Seventh Assembly District Iceman Turner, Tammany candidate for Senator, received but 24 votes, while the head of the Tammany ticket got 155.

The managers of the Woman's Exchange held their annual meeting yesterday afternoon at the house of Henry Villard of East Seventy. second-street. There were present Mrs. Andrew Carnegie, Mrs. Elliott F. Shepard, Mrs. Judge Dillon, Mrs. Jacob Schiff, Mrs. Edward ...

The Commissioners of the State Reservation at Niagara held their quarterly meeting at the office of Andrew H. Green, in the Park Bank Building, yesterday morning. There were present Commissioners Andrew H. Green, James Mooney of Buffalo, John Hodge of Lockport, ...

ST. PAUL, Nov. 14.--A Pioneer Press special from Butte, Mont., says: "News was received here to-day of a bad accident on the construction branch of the Northern Pacific fifteen miles east of here, in Jefferson County, on Tuesday night.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 14.--The Cowie Reorganization bill for the navy, prepared by Past Assistant Paymaster Thomas J. Cowie, United states Navy, which was before Congress at its last session and which will come up again when Congress meets, is exciting much attention at this time.

BOSTON, Nov. 14.--The office of President of the Fitchburg Railroad is attracting more than usual attention just now. Railroad men are all anxious to know who will succeed President E.B. Phillips when he retires from the active management at the close of the year.

In spite of the thousand ways that exist in this great city of dishonestly cajoling the reluctant pennias from the pockets of some into the pockets of others, a now discovery seems to have been made recently by a humble young negro. The enterprising worthy, whose name, according to his own unsubstantiated ...

BOSTON, Nov. 14.--Messrs. Drexel, Morgan Co. have agreed to advance $10,000 more for the Boston Steam-Heating Company to carry through the investigation into the cause of the failure of the system. This makes $267,000 advanced by them, for which they are secured by pledge of the $750,000 mortgage bonds. The other creditors hold claims for about $200,000, and suits may be brought to place these latter under the Drexel-Morgan claims.

It is proposed by the American Copyright League to prosecute its crusade for international copyright with renewed vigor. To this end the Council of the League, at its annual meeting, held in the editorial rooms of the Century Company on Wednesday, elected the following officers: President--James Russell ...

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14.--Mr. Thomas C. Platt paid a brief visit to Washington to-day, and, as usual, forgot to register at his hotel. During his stay he found time to look after some matters concerning his express business, and to call upon Secretary of the Navy Tracy.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 14.--The striking of the new oil well on the George Davis farm in the Chartiers Creek Valley, four miles from this city, has started afresh the oil excitement in Pittsburg that broke out at the coming in of the Arbuckle gusher.

The third day's session of the Congress of the American Ornithologists' Union in the rooms of the American Museum of Natural History opened at 11 o'clock yesterday morning. Among those present were Dr. George Bird Grinnell, editor of Forest and Stream, and ...
The funeral of William A. Horan, who was a member of the Executive Board of District Assembly No. 49, took place yesterday afternoon from the house of his brother, at 600 Fifthavenue, Brooklyn.

Just about the time when Wall-street was busiest yesterday afternoon there came a shout from the bootblack who pursues his calling beneath the stoop of 66 Wall-street: "Oh, jest look at that wire!" He was the first to see, it, but within three minutes afterward there was a crowd of 2,000 persons blocking the street, giving a spluttering and snapping Western Union wire a wide berth.

BATH, N.Y., Nov. 14.--The official vote of Steuben County gives Gilbert 8,313, Rice 6,881, Griffin 860, Cooke 8,341, Wemple 6,846, Hedges 8,358, Danforth 6,841, Varnum 8,347, Tabor 6,843, Van Reneselaer 8,357, Bogart 6,842, Haight 8,381, O'Brien, 6,746.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14.--A dispatch to the News from Des Moines, Iowa, says: "The news of the withdrawal of the Iowa Woman's Christian Temperance Union, under the leadership of Mrs. J. Helen Foster, from the National convention did not create much of a sensation, as it was not unexpected.

The sale of original water-color drawings at the Fifth-Avenue Auction Rooms was continued last evening. Six of the thirty sold were by John Falkner and six by John McPherson. "In the Library," by A. Brozzl, brought $55; John Drummond's "The Two Mothers," $67 50; G. Fortunati's "Returning Home," $50, and Falkner's "Twilight," $55. H. Roberto's "Baiting the Hook" brought the highest price of the evening--$77 50.

Emma B. Young, wife of Richard D. Young, manufacturer of perfume on Barclay-street, yesterday caused the arrest of, and prosecuted, Arion Arions, a private detective, who claims to be associated with a Broadway agency, and said that he lives at 394 Douglass-street.

The third regular season of the Lyceum Theatre under the management of Daniel Frohman will open next Tuesday evening, when the longtalked-of new play, "The Charity Ball," by David Belasco and Henry C. De Mille, who so successfully co-operated in writing "The Wife," will be presented for the first time.

The Catholic Church has again showed its determination to punish such of its followers as kicked over the traces with the Rev. Dr. McGlynn. Yesterday the edict went forth that the body of Miss Theresa Kelly, which now rests in the receiving vault at Calvary Cemetery, ...

BALTIMORE, Nov. 14.--Baltimore Day for the close of the Catholic Centennial was as bright and beautiful as could be desired. It was intended to show the visitors something of Baltimore and its environs, but a large majority of them, on account of the unpleasant weather ...

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 14.--The news of the death of Howard B. Crissey, Cornell, '90, which took place at his home in Fredonia on the 11th, has been received in university circles with feelings of profound sorrow. The present Senior Class has been particularly unfortunate ...

Capt. Nickels of the Red Star steamship Noordland, which arrived yesterday from Antwerp, reports that on Nov. 11 a cabin passenger named Valentine Herckoirath died of consumption. He was forty-five years of age, and was a native of Cincinnati. His body was buried at sea on the following day. He had gone abroad for his health, and was traveling alone. His effects were sealed up and will be forwarded to Cincinnati.

The racing public turned out in good numbers to witness the different events that were run off at the Clifton track yesterday. Twenty-five bookmakers were kept busy, as the talent banked their favorites heavily. Four favorites passed the wire winners, giving good returns to their backers who heaped their money on them. MONTREAL, Nov. 15.--The Mayor received a letter to-day from Mr. H.T. Moffatt of Chicago asking the City Council to indorse the claims of Chicago for the World's Fair in preference to New-York.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 15.--Fire broke out at 3:15 A.M. in the forward compartment of the British steamer Merchant, at the head of St. Andrew-street. There were 1,200 bales of cotton stored in this compartment, all of which was damaged by fire of water. The loss will approximate $20,000, fully covered by insurance.
The project of holding a World's Fair a thousand miles from a seaboard is on the face of it so preposterous that people who live on the seaboard have refused to take it seriously.

Even the New-York Ledger has been unable to hold out unchanged against time and fashion, and with to-day's issue it will appear with sixteen pages and in a new and handsome dress of type.

A note of alarm has been sounded that Gov. Hill has designs upon the Democratic organization in Pennsylvania, with a view to securing its support of his candidacy for the Presidency in 1892. There is only one man in the State of New-York who can get the support of the Pennsylvania delegates.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 15.--District Attorney Lowis E. Griffith and R.E. Parmenter of Rensselaer County made application before Judge Mayham at the Special Term in this city to-day for a mandamus to compel the Republican inspectors in six Troy districts to sign the returns of the canvass on election day.

The semi-annual meeting of the Nineteenth Century Club was held on Thursday at the residence of Mrs. Vincenzo Botta. The Lecture Committee reported that in this season's course greater prominence would be given to literature, as last season's course was criticised as being too largely political and ethical. BOSTON, Nov. 15.--President Angell of the Cruelty to Animals Society has persuaded the coachmen of the city to adopt a system of signals, which will soon be used by all drivers. President Angell said to-day the system was to be the best and most ingenious of any that had ever been attempted in the United States or any other country, and would so regulate street travel as to avoid collisions and prevent blockades.
LONDON, Nov. 15.--The Cunard Line steamship Etruria, (Br.,) Capt. Hains, from New-York Nov. 9 for Liverpool, passed Brow Head at midnight tonight.

The record from Nassau made by the Ward Line steamship Santiago on the voyage ended yesterday by her arrived at this port was a remarkably creditable one. Capt. Allen reports that he left Nassau on the night of Nov. 11. With very favorable weather and light winds his ship succeeded in making the run from Nassau in three days and seven hours, crossing Sandy Hook Bar at 3:30 yesterday morning.

The great granite warehouses strung along the Brooklyn water front near Hamilton Ferry, and known as the Finlay Stores, were sold at auction yesterday to the Equitable Life Assurance Society for $161,000. The eight stores on the north pier brought $86,000, and those on the south pier $75,000. The Equitable holds mortgages on the property exceeding the purchase price by $30,000 and dating back to 1875.
