A meeting of the Trustees of Amherst College was held yesterday, and they voted to confer the degree of LL. D. upon President Seth Low of Columbia College.

The annual meeting of the Trustees of the House of Rest for Consumptives was held on Thursday. The report of the President, the Rev. Dr. Peters, states that 164 patients have been under the care of the institution during the year, of whom eight were discharged recovered and thirty-one improved.

The Governors of the new Seventh Regiment Veterans' Club held a meeting last night at the Hotel Brunswick. It was announced that the club now has a membership of over four hundred. The clubhouse at 756 Fifth-avenue will be ready for occupancy on Dec. 15. Rules and regulations regarding the club were adopted.

In a day or two more the Washington Memorial Arch fund will undoubtedly reach $60,000. Yesterday's subscriptions made it $59,295 80, and are acknowledged by Treasurer Stewart of 54 William-street as follows: Gerard Beekman, $50; Cash, $50; Edward J. Dunphy, $25.
St. James Methodist Episcopal Church, Madison-avenue and One Hundred and Twentysixth-street, received a new lease of life last evening.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 15.--The case of the People against Theodore W. Myers, Controller, , came up in Special Term to-day on a motion of Deputy Attorney General Poste for a supplemental writ of mandamus. This is the proceeding by which the county of New-York is attempting to test the validity of the apportionment of State taxes and which is now being heard before Referee Countryman. The motion was granted.

The Fellowcraft Club had one of its monthly dinners last evening, and it was a pronounced success. Tables were spread both up stairs and down, and were surrounded by more than one hundred members and guests.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15.--The consideration of amendments to the rules of the road was resumed by the International Marine Conference to-day.
David R. Francis, Governor of the State of Missouri, and Col. C.H. Jones, editor of the St. Louis Republic, are spending a few days in this city.

The twelfth semi-annual session of the Universalist Sunday School Institute was held yesterday afternoon and evening at the Second Universalist Church, One Hundred and Twentyseventh-street, near Lexington-avenue.
The work of advancing the sentiment in favor of ballot reform and of explaining the merits of the proposed change in the voting law was continued...

AMPERSAND, SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Nov. 15.-- What might be called the first touch of Winter here and through the Adirondacks set in last night with a snowstorm, which has prevailed all day. The thermometer at the Signal Service station stands at 15 above zero to-night.

Sawtelle, Deputy Quartermaster General; Lieut. Col. Charles B. Daudy, Deputy Quartermaster General; Major Lewis M. Carpenter, Fifth Cavalry.
TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 15.--The Kansas Railroad Commissioners rendered a decision to-day involving the right of eminent domain, and to some extent coming in contact with the Federal courts.

The Columbia College Boat Club, at its adjourned annual meeting, filled the following vacant offices: Vice President--T.M.R. Meikleham, '90; Undergraduate Directors--S.R Bradley, '90; C.C. Kalbfleisch, '91; F.N. Blossom, '91, and E.M. Post, '93.
Charley Flynn, thirty-five years old, and living at One Hundred and Fifty-ninth-street and Courtlandt-avenue, was severely injured by a crowd of roughs about 1 o'clock yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15.--To-day's bond offerings accepted aggregated $134,350, as follows: Registered 4s. $2,000, $22,000, $8,350, $50,000 at 127; registered 4 s, $10,000, $2,500, $4,000, $5,000, $10,500, $20,000 at 105 .

Two weeks ago Mrs. Joseph Johnson took a man and woman, who gave the name of Wilson, as tenants into her house, in Grove-street, Jersey City. Wednesday afternoon Mrs. Wilson went out, telling Mrs. Johnson that she would soon return, but she failed to come back, Thursday evening Wilson took his goods away, and Mrs. Johnson supposed she had seen the last of them.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15.--There is no news to be had at the Brazilian Legation concerning the report that a serious revolution has broken out in Rio de Janeiro, and that the establishment of a republic is imminent. Dr. Valente, the Brazilian Minister, has had no advices on the subject ...

The will of Mrs. Agnes Jane Maitland was filed for probate yesterday in the Surrogate's office with Probate Clerk Tinney. Mrs. Maitland's son, Thomas A. Maitland, is made sole executor, and receives all but $6,000 of the estate. The Roman Catholic Provincial Seminary of New-York for the Education of Priests is to have $1,000, the Hospital for Incurables, in charge of the Sisters of St. Francis; the...

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 15.--Millard Powers Fillmore, son of the late Millard Fillmore, thirteenth President of the United States, died tonight of apoplexy at the Tifft House. His exact age is not known, but it was something over sixty years.

The guarantee fund of the World's Fair did not have a notable day yesterday, and the only big subscription was that of William W. Astor for $25,000. But the work went on steadily, many smaller sums being subscribed, and there is no reason to fear a lose of headway. The total amount of subscriptions now in the hands of the Finance Committee is a trifle over $3,000,000.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 15.--The Knights of Labor Committee on Land resumed its report immediately after the convention was called to order and continued until the hour arrived when Col. L.F. Livingston, President of the Farmers' Alliance, was to be received.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15.--The fast mail service overland from Chicago to the Pacific coast was inaugurated at 3 o'clock this morning over the Burlington Road. It is expected to diminish the time between Chicago and Portland, Oregon, nearly one-third.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15.--The new cruiser Baltimore, which showed such surprising speed on list recent trip and yet was found by the trial board to have fallen short of the requirements, made her second trial to-day in a four hours' steady run on a northeast by east course from Cape Henlopen.

LEXINGTON, N.C., Nov. 15.--The Members' Stake of the Eastern Field Trials Club was run yesterday. The weather was fine and birds were plenty. The quality of the entries was unusually good; there was not one among them that was not possessed of high qualities as a field dog.

To-day is the great football game between Princeton and Harvard at Cambridge, Mass. The Princeton players went to Boston yesterday by train, and many New-York people went both by rail and by the Fall River boat to witness the match. The chances favor Princeton somewhat, but the contest will be one well worth seeling, for Harvard will make a hard struggle. Yale is scheduled to play Wesleyan at Springfield, Mass., to-day also.
The New-York State Forestry Commission held a meeting in the office of Commissioner Sheridan W. Knevals yesterday, with its usual accompaniment of closed doors, intense secrecy...
Few of the experts and art critics who were admitted yesterday to the loan exhibition in aid of the Barye monument fund could have been prepared for the eight of the paintings that greeted them.
There has been as yet no accurate and full publication of the vote of the State as cast on the 5th of November. The last summing that we have seen gives McKinney over 42,000 majority.

George W. Bangay, a veteran journalist, temperance advocate, and abolitionist, lies stricken with paralysis at his home, 114 Taylor-street, Brooklyn, E.D. Owing to his great age, seventy-one years, his condition is critical.
Dock Department developments yesterday included the arrest of William L. Smyth for perjury, Gouverneur Kemble's dismissal from the...
The recent cable dispatch reporting the agreement of the Diet of the Central American republics on a plan of union should not be taken to mean too much.

Ex-Mayor Hewitt has bought an inhabited island, called by its fifty or sixty people Plum Island. It is one of the small islands in the Sound between Long Island and the Connecticut shore, and is situated just east of Orient. It was sold on Wednesday last, under foreclosure, for $15,000.

There seems to be no end to the joy which has been brought into Wall-street by trust stock manipulators. Yesterday the Cotton Oil Trust cut up more capers. While everybody had the point to buy the stuff it went tumbling downward, and for the first time since the recent demoralization set in the quotation broke under 30.

The second annual Conference of the Church of God in Jesus Christ was held in Chicago yesterday. The members hold to the restoration of Israel, that there is life only through Jesus Christ, and that man's present state is mortal, dependent upon Christ for future life. They hold that Christ while on earth was not controlled directly by the Supreme Being.

Alexander Montgomery, the Colusa capitalist, has given $25,000 to the relief fund of the Society of California Pioneers. Several days ago the society asked Mr. Montgomery to give a life-size portrait of himself. He promised to do so, but before sending the picture he sent the welcome check. The relief fund now amounts to over $40,000.

LONDON, Nov. 15.--The dockmen demand pay for the time allotted for meals. The Directors refuse the demand, pleading that this claim is specially debarred under the recent agreement. The Directors, in a letter to the papers, complain of the men's tyranny in refusing to work with non-unionists. The Tilbury dockmen have struck because the foremen and clerks refused to join the union.

The first public rehearsal of the forty-eighth season of the Philharmonic Society took place at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday aftornoon. The house was crowded, and the audience was extremely attentive. The programme was varied in style and quality, and contained matter to please all tastes.

To-morrow at noon the Winter schedule of passenger trains will go into effect on the Erie Railway. The through trains westward remain unchanged. Eastward the principal change in through service is in the Chicago and Grand Trunk express, now leaving Chicago at 2:35 P.M., which, on and after to-morrow, will leave Chicago at 11 P.M.

People who chanced to be out of doors during the middle hours of last night were the beholders of unusual activity among the heavenly bodies. The night was clear and cold, with but little breeze stirring, and the atmosphere was of the kind called bracing.

The appearance of the dynamite cruiser Vesuvius among the commissioned vessels in the United States Navy is awaited with interest in naval circles.

SALT LAKE, Nov. 15.--The excitement here over the great Endowment House expose continues unabated. Mormons and Gentiles alike are on the tiptoe of expectancy as to what the decision of the Judge will be when the case is finally submitted.

BOSTON, Nov. 15.--The adjourned third meeting of the creditors of George H. Binney, the missing insurance broker, against whom criminal proceedings are pending, was held in the Suffolk Insolvency Court this morning.
Between four and five thousand persons were in attendance at the Clifton race track yesterday.

A fine overcoat is the noblest work of the tailor's art--at this season of the year. A. Raymond Co., of 254 and 256 Broadway, and of Fulton and Nassau streets, appreciate this, and are prepared to offer the best, in both ready-made and custom-made garments.

Another carload of passengers had a narrow escape from being crushed to death at the Newark-avenue crossing of the Pennsylvania Railroad, in Jersey City, Thursday evening. An Erie-street car, comfortably full of passengers, was being driven over the track, when the gateman began to lower the gates for an approaching train. Driver John Conway saw the danger and put the whip to his horses.

John McGrane, one of the best-known contractors in Hoboken, and till a few days ago a Commissioner of Assessments in the city, was found dead in his carpenter shop's on Clintonstreet, when Jeremiah Conlin, one of his assistants, opened the place yesterday morning.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 15.--Orrin W. Tyler, formerly a farmer at Marcellus, this county, but more recently a traveling agent for Aultman, Miller Co., Akron, Ohio, whose headquarters in this State are at Rochester, disappeared about three weeks ago, and now the discovery is made that he is about $400 short in his accounts.
Internal Revenue Collector Nathan appointed Augustus Berwin bond clerk in the Brooklyn office yesterday, in place of Alexander McKinney. Berwin is a Third Ward man and a follower of Hugo Hirsh.
The type founders of this country--and there are not a great many of them--are said to be talking of organizing in such a way that they will be benefited permanently.

About 6 o'olock yesterday morning Post Office Inspector Hartshorne arrested Joseph H. Bresnan, a Post Office clerk at Station B, at 380 Grand-street on a charge of taking money from the mails.

Creditors of James W. Ramsey, builder, at One Hundred and Thirty-fourth-street, near Eighthavenue, are trying in vain to get their money from him. His liabilities outside of mortgages amount, it is reported, to over $45,000, and his unincumbered assets are very small.

The statement printed yesterday that Nov. 15 was the last day on which venison could be legally sold here caused a great deal of anxiety and inquiry among dealers, many of whom have large quantities of the meat on hand.

There was an interesting meeting of the Reform Club last night, at which the discussion was confined almost exclusively to subjects concerning tariff reform. Many of the members were present. Mr. Willlam J. Coombs presided, and began the evening with a few remarks.

On Monday next the curtains of R.H. Macy Co.'s big show windows, which for several days have been drawn up, will be lowered and there will be revealed to the delight of the children and a good many older people, the firm's annual holiday display. Artists from the Eden Musee are now engaged on the work, which surpasses anything previously attempted by the firm.
Isaiah Browe, who lived in Pennsylvaniaavenue, Newark, N.J., and John F. Leal of 438 West Thirty-seventh-street, two young grocery clerks, visited a resort in West Sixteenth-street yesterday morning.

The young lady managers of the St. John's Day Nursery of 233 East Sixty-seventh-street held a "chocolate" and bazaar last evening, when articles of fancy work, made and given by the managers and friends of the nursery, were sold.

The companies owning the drop-a-penny-inthe-slot machines are having a hard time of it with the devisers of new schemes to beat the game. Somebody has undoubtedly gone into the business of turning out round pieces of metal which serve as well as coins when put in the slots.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 15.--George P. Decker, as THE TIMES predicted, is making it pretty warm for the Hon. George F. Loder, who claims to have been re-elected by the Republicans of the Third Monroe Assembly District. The judges of election of the Second District of Greece counted eight votes that Decker claims were cast for him for the Prohibition...

Miss Lillian Russell arrived in New-York from Chicago at 7 o'clock last night. She was alone and went directly to her flat in West Forty-third-street. She said that the story of her elopement which appeared in some papers yesterday was without any foundation in fact.
Rainy weather has interfered with the hunting during the past week and discouraged many of the gunners, who were anxious to have a go at the quail and rabbits.

The American Society of Mechanical Engineers will hold its annual meeting in this city, beginning on Monday next and ending on Friday following. The professional sessions will be held at the hall of the New-York Academy of Medicine, 12 West Thirty-first-street.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 15.--The news that Jefferson Davis, ex-President of the Confederacy, was seriously ill at Brierfield, Miss., was circulated here yesterday and caused much comment. Investigation, however, shows that Mr. Davis's illness is not of an alarming charcharacter.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 15.--A revolution has broken out here. The Ministry has resigned, and there is great excitement among the people. The Brazilian Army is in control of the town. The Minister of the Navy has been killed.

BOSTON, Nov. 15.--One of the biggest political fights of the coming year in this city will be over the reappointment of Chairman Albert T. Whiting of the Metropolitan Police Board, which is under the Governor's control.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 15.--Dr. Walter C. Camp, the well-known football authority at Yale, thinks that Princeton will win the football game at Cambridge to-morrow.

BISMARCK, N.D., Nov. 15.--The point was informally raised to-day by F.M. Dudley of the legal department of the Northern Pacific Railway in the United States Land Office that the pre-emption law had been repealed by the act of Congress providing for the admission of the new States.

John Shibock, the foreman of a factory on Barren Island, committed suicide a fortnight ago, supposing that his wife had eloped with a workman named Allbright. Yesterday Mrs. Shibock returned to her home and expressed great surprise and intense grief at her husband's death. She denied that she had run away with Allbright or any other man, and said she had been living with one of her husband's cousins in Fourteenth-street, New-York.
The seventeenth anniversary of the old McAuley Water-Street Mission will be celebrated at the mission, 316 Water-street, to-morrow afternoon and evening.

NEWPORT, Nov. 15.--Commander C.T. Goodrich, in charge of the torpedo stations for three years, relinquished the command to-day and goes to Germany on a year's leave of absence to engage in business. Lieut. Commander W.T. Moore, executive officer, is left in charge.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Nov. 15.--A serious railway wreck occurred on the Fall Brook Railroad, at Tioga Village, Tioga County, Penn., late last night, in which one man lost his life and three enginess and several cars were smashed.
Ex-Judge Richard Busteed has for the last six weeks been suffering from paralysis of the left side, and is now slowly recovering at the house of his friend and associate, Edmund Blankman.
Second Baseman Pfeffer of the Chicago Club walked into the Fifth-Avenue Hotel yesterday afternoon. He wore a tall hat, a beaver overcost with sealskin trimmings.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 15.--At the meeting of the National Farmers' Congress to-day R.F Kolb of Alabama was elected President. Resolutions asking Congress to establish deep water harbors on the Gulf coast, for the purpose of facilitating the grow of trade between this country and the countries of South and Central America, were adopted, as was also a resolution in favor of holding the World's Fair in Chicago.

The registration yesterday in the Sixth Congressional District was 155. All persons registered in the last election in the Assembly districts comprising the Sixth Congressional District are entitled to vote for the election of a Congressman to succeed Frank T. Fitzgerald, resigned.

PEMBINA, N.D., Nov. 15.--A United States customs station has been established on the south shore of Lake of the Woods, near the mouth of Rainy Lake River. The Deputy Collector there will probably have his hands full in putting a stop to the wholesale plundering of Uncle Sam's forests on the northern boundary of Minnesota.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 15.--Edwin R. Kelly was indicted at Paterson a week or two ago for a criminal assault on a young Irish girl who had been in this country but a few months, and had employed in his family as a servant.
Final action was taken by the Board of Street Openings and Improvements yesterday in the matter of the widening and extension of College-place.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 15--On Tuesday afternoon Bert Snyder escaped from the Oswego County Jail, where he was serving a sentence for grand larceny. Under Sheriff Van Buren tracked him to Fulton, where he found that the man had taken passage on a canalboat under Capt. Bradner Montague. The officer overtook the boat here, and, getting on board, asked for Snyder.

The last will and testament of Barney Foshay, who died recently at Sing Sing, was flied for probate in the Westchester County Surrogate's office at White Plains yesterday, and by it he disposes of his estate, estimated to be worth $50,000.

MONTREAL, Nov. 15.--The firm of A.W. The government of Brazil since 1822 has been a constitutional empire. The history of the means by which it become such and by which the Portuguese House of Bragance came to rule in Brazil is interesting.
If the committee which is engaged in revising the building laws had appointed a committee to prepare a plan of procedure it would have saved itself much valuable time.

Kansas City has followed the example set by Brooklyn and Cincinnati. The Cowboys yesterday thought that they had better retire from the American Association, and consequently sent in their resignation.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15.--The Rev. A.W. Lightbourne, the distinguished Congregational clergyman, who has been wandering about the country for the past two months without communication with family, relatives, or friends, was seen on Chestnut-street to-day by one of his old parishioners who was visiting this city. Mr. Lightbourne was for years the pastor of that most popular of New-England ...
The canvass of the vote at the recent election was continued yesterday by the Board of Aldermen sitting as a Board of County Canvassers.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15.--Clancy, the man who is to be the last witness for the prosecution in the Cronin case, arrived in this city from New-York yesterday afternoon, and this morning had a talk of an hour with State's Attorney Longenecker. He will be put on the stand at the opening of court to-morrow.

LIVERPOOL, Nov. 15.--A fire broke out in the cotton on the Guion Line steamer Alaska, Capt. Murray, at this port from New-York, while she was unloading at the Alexandra Dock to-day. Five hundred bales were damaged. The vessel sustained no injury.
It is not in New-York alone that expressions in favor of the Australian systems are coming from unexpected sources.

The funeral of Mrs. Louisa Zerbina Jordan took place yesterday at the "Little Church Around the Corner," and was attended by a number of friends who gathered in the little church to pay their last respects to the dead actress.

Dr. Reuben P. Holden, a dentist, was brought before Judge Andrews and a jury in the Supreme Court yesterday from the Ward's Island Insane Asylum for examination as to his sanity. LAKE PROVIDENCE, Nov. 15.--Several Jew stores at Goodrich Landing, Alsatia, and Atherton, in East Carroll, were fired into by miscreants last night at midnight, shots passing just over the beds of the sleeping families. At Alsatia this placard was stuck on the door: "No Jews after the 1st of January. If you disregard this warning fire and lead will make you leave."

ALBANY, Nov. 15.--Major George H. Treadwell, the defeated Republican candidate for Senator in the Seventeenth District, sent his resignation as State Civil Service Commissioner to Gov. Hill Oct. 21, two days after his nomination for the Senate. The Governor has failed to act upon it yet.

A German experimenter has found that the human eye is more sensitive to green rays of light than to red rays, and to red more than to blue rays. ELMIRA, N.Y., Nov. 17.--Milo M. Acker of Hornellsville, who has been reported to be in the race for the Assembly Speakership, said to a reporter to-day that he was not a candidate, and that he had never, directly or indirectly, intimated that he was a candidate.

BORDENTOWN, N.J., Nov. 17.--Dr. William H. Shipps of this city, who has been the attending physician of the Parnells here for the past ten years, says that at no time since Mrs. Parnell took up her residence at Ironsidies has she lacked either medicine or medical attendance. He further says that her present physical condition, considering her years, is remarkable.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 17.--The United States of Brazil, constituting a federated republic of the different Provinces of the empire over which Dom Pedro had ruled so long, is an established Government. The new republic is to-day acknowledged by every Province except Bahia, in the north.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 17.--A Pierre (S.D.) special to the Pioneer Press says: "The steamer Batchelor, on the way from Bismarck to Pierre with a cargo of beer, struck a rock about fifty miles north of here and sank in fifteen minutes. The loss is estimated at $40,000. The Batchelor had on board part of the cargo of the ill-fated Missouri, which met with the same end some weeks ago."

Last Wednesday the Attorney General of Missouri made a ruling under the anti-trust law of that State which is of interest not only to wholesale drug corporations in Missouri but also to manufacturers of patent medicines elsewhere.

AUBURN, N.Y., Nov. 18.--Mrs. Clara C. Longstreet, wife of George B. Longstreet, teller of tha National Bank of Auburn, wound up a Summer's folly Saturday evening by eloping with Louis H. Leach, a young man employed as bookkeeper by the Birdsall Manufacturing Company.

CAIRO, Nov. 18.--The Egyptian budget for the coming year abolishes weighing dues on cotton and other agricultural products, increases the educational grants, restores the amounts previously deducted from the Khedive's civil list, and provides for various railway extensions. Although the remission of taxation causes a falling off of 90,000 in the revenues, there is still left a surplus of 135,000.

LONDON, Nov. 18.--Dispatches from Mozambique say that Bishop Smythies of the Central African Mission while attempting to reach Quilimane was attacked by Makololo and some of his followers were killed. The Bishop escaped to Nyassa.

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 18.--The Yale Athletic Association, at a poorly-attended meeting tonight, elected Walcott, '91, President, and Pearce, '91, Vice President. Corbin, Woodruff, and Wallace, of '89, played on the college side at the field to-day. The rumor that Corbin would play in the game with Princeton is authoritatively denied.

ZANZIBAR, Nov. 18.--Capt. Wissmann has succeeded in pacifying the natives in the Useguha district. He has received numerous petitions from the chiefs asking that he conclude peace negotiations with them.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18.--President Harrison was visited to-day by a committee of the National Convention of Commercial Bodies, headed by Col. James O. Broadhead of Missouri as Chairmen, and accompanied by Col. Jay L. Torrey, the author of the Torrey Bankrupt bill.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 18.--A hot contest will take place to-morrow night at the Democratic primaries in every ward of this city over the election of delegates to the City Convention, which will be held next Thursday afternoon, to place in nomination a candidate for Mayor, and also to nominate four Chosen Freeholders, all of whom are to be elected for a term of two years. Sixteen Councilmen are also to be elected.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18.--Acting Secretary Batcheller has settled the questions involved in the controversy between the customs officers at Detroit and Mr. James E. Scripps of that city in regard to certain paintings imported by the latter and claimed to be exempt from duty as "antiquities."

William H. Wilson of Montreal came to this city some months ago and instituted habeas corpus proceedings for the custody of his child, who was then in the care of his wife's mother, Mary Matilda Woodman of Brooklyn.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 18.--The County Commissioners of Stevens County have issued an appeal for aid for the destitute population of the county. The appeal states that the crops of the last year were a total failure, that the whole farming population is in a destitute condition, and that immediate aid must be furnished or starvation and terrible suffering must ensue. The appeal is addressed only to the prosperous residents of Kansas.

Mestayer appeared as T. Henry Slum and was quite as large as ever, both as regards his physique and his voice. In his own abundant way he made a great deal of fun and was rewarded with much applause.

ST. Louis. Nov 18.--The first news is months, and the last for at least a year, of the Government expedition for the survey of Alaska reached this city yesterday. It came in a letter to Mr. Patrick McGrath, father of Mr. John E. McGrath, one of the chiefs of the exploring party.

President Richardson said that he had decided that the interests of his company would be best served by getting rid of the five drivers.

Mme. Modjeska acted Lady Macbeth at the Broadway Theatre last evening for the first time. She had never seen a performance of "Macbeth" and had no model to follow in building up her portrayal. ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 18.--The attempt of the Democrats to gain the election certificate for the seat in the Assembly from the Third Monroe District failed, the Republican Board of Supervisors, acting as a Board of County Canvassers to-day, deciding that the claim of error in the Second Election District of Greece was not substantiated.

RIO JANEIRO, Nov. 18.--The city awoke Friday to hear the republic proclaimed. Gen. da Fonseca, Senhor Constant, and others proceeded to Petropolis in the morning and informed the Emperor that he had been dethroned.

BATH, N.Y., Nov. 18.--Among the gentlemen who have been prominently mentioned for appointment as Bank Superintendent, in place of Mr. Payne, who recently resigned, is Frank Campbell, a banker of this place. Mr. Campbell says that he has had no conversation with ...
This week opened with encouraging subscriptions for the Washington Memorial Arch fund. The daily average continues to be gratifying, and more earnest efforts are promised each day.

The three thousand people that attended the races at the New-Jersey Jockey Club's course yesterday were well paid for their journey. They also had the pleasure of meeting Mr. John Kelly, who was at the track for the first time since his illness.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18.--The President made the following appointments today:

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 18.--Ex. Gov. Cameron of Petersburg, one of the warmest anti-Mahone Republicans in the State, when asked what he thought of substituting the Australian system for the present election laws of the State, said:
MALDEN, Mass., Nov. 18.--Joseph W. Norcross of Malden, formerly of East Boston, was adjudged insane to-day and taken to the Westborough Asylum.

ALTOONA, Penn., Nov. 18.--The Rev. Frank Rodgers of Orange, N.J., died in his berth on the Atlantic Express east this morning at Derry, Penn. He was returning from Colorado, where he had gone for the benefit of his health. His wife accompanied him. The body was taken from the train here, prepared for burial, and sent east on the day express.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18.--A special dispatch from Minneapolis, Minn., says: "Ivan Panin, the Russian litterateur, was baptized in the Central Baptist Church last evening after his renunciation of infidelity. For four years Panin has been gradually 'seeking the truth,' as he expresses ...
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18.--A verdict for $28,500 in favor of the plaintiffs was rendered to-day in the case of Henderson, Hull Co. against the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad ...

The New-York Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association held its regular meeting in St. Luke's Hospital last evening. There were present Hyman Blum, the Rev. George S. Baker, George W. Kruger, Charles N. Kent, Robert Olyphant, A.G. Agnew, W.G. Riddle, the Rev. Henry S. Day, Dr. George G. Wheelock, Charles S. Smith, George Macculloch Miller, John S. Bussing, A. B. Ausbacher, Henry Rosenwald, R. Waller, Jr., I. Eppinger, and Louis Stix.

Several of the leading concerns of the country engaged in chair-cane cutting have formed themselves into a corporation, the better to protect themselves against a growing competition on the part of home and German workers.

BERLIN, Nov. 18.--The Reichstag to-day discussed the estimates for the Home Office. During the debate Herr Richter, the leader of the German Liberals, moved the stoppage of the steamship service to Samoa and Sydney and a corresponding reduction of the subvention to the North German Lloyd Company. He declared that the service was a dead loss.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18.--Not more than half the members of the International Marine Conference were in attendance when it was called to order by Admiral Franklin this morning. A driving rainstorm seriously interfered with the prompt arrival of the delegates.

Hackensack, N.J., is excited over the story of a woman who is believed to have sacrificed her liberty in order to secure the safety of her husband. Six years ago George W. Aber made the acquaintance of Emma J. Voornees, the daughter of a rich Bergen County farmer, and it was not long before they made known the fact that they had been married.
VANDALIA, Ill., Nov. 18.--The first snow of the season fell here yesterday. The ground is covered to a depth of three inches on a level.

The United States started a squadron of cruisers out of this port yesterday the sole purpose of which, sailing under the euphonious title of "the Squadron of Evolution," will be to demonstrate in a peaceable sort of a way to the rest of the world that the United States Government has a navy, or rather the nucleus of a navy.

The new race track of the Hudson County Jockey Club at Guttenberg, N.J., will be opened to-day with a splendid day's sport. People who remember the Guttenberg track as it has been in the past will find a complete surprise awaiting them this season. The old half-mile track has disappeared and in its place is a new track of a mile, which is as good a track as there is in this country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18.--The special dispatch to THE TIMES from Rio, bringing full and interesting details about the revolution in Brazil, was read in this city with great interest. It gave to the State Department the fullest confirmation of the dispatches of Consul General Dockery, since the receipt ...

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Nov. 18.--The conference of papermakers appointed to be held at the Massasoit House on Thursday is not likely to be a harmonious meeting.

BISMARCK, N.D., Nov. 18.--All is excitement and uncertainty in the contest for United States Senators. A call was issued for a Republican caucus this evening, but there was so much opposition that the caucus has been abandoned.

READING, Penn., Nov. 18.--The Philadelphia and Reading Railroad managers at the shops here have adopted a novel, but effective, plan of getting rid of their old-fashioned four wheeled coal cars, now regarded as altogether out of date for the requirements of modern ...

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Nov. 18.--Mormonism is still on trial here. The court room was packed with spectators all day long, and on the streets people gathered in small conclaves discussing the situation.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18.--The Supreme Court of the United States to-day rendered an opinion in a case involving the proper definition of the term "statuary" in the Tariff act of 1880 and 1881.
A fair that is characteristic of German sentiment and enterprise was inaugurated last night at the imposing new edifice of the Central Turn Verein in East Sixty-seventh-street, near Third-avenue.

"Colonel" Elliott F. Shepard should have slept contentedly last night. In the way he has of doing good, yesterday was rich in events for him. By a bare shave patience and purchase did their appointed work for him, and now he is boss of the Fifth-avenue stages.

Augustus L. Lang of 143 East One Hundred land Seventeenth-street was found unconscious in the areaway of his house at 11:30 o'clock last night. His skull was fractured and his right leg was broken. He was taken to the Harlem Hospital.

HIGH POINT, N.C., Nov. 18.--The Eastern field trial derby commenced to-day, and the first series of heats was run off with the following result: Beppo IV. and Flirt ordered up for want of merit; Annie F. beat Trip of Kippen, Fannie M. beat Harry C., Lettie Ling beat Bessie M., Riprap beat Dan C., Rawdy Rod beat Lamoa, Nannie B. beat Blue Ridge.
The Brooklyn Aldermen finished canvassing the votes cast for Aldermen at Large and District Aldermen yesterday, and announced the following result for the head of each ticket:
Henry Beard, the artist, whose accidental asphyxiation at the Homestead Hotel was reported in yesterday's TIMES, had not regained consciousness at a late hour last night.
NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Nov. 18.--The bathing beach at Narragansett Pier, always good, is to be improved next year in a manner that the patrons of this health-giving resort will warmly appreciate.
Angelo De Cecco, a steerage passenger on the French steamship La Gascogne, which arrived yesterday, committed suicide by cutting his throat on Nov. 11.

ELKO, Nev., Nov. 18.--The first limited fast mail on the Union Pacific Railroad reached here on time. Notwithstanding the extraordinary fast schedule time from Council Bluffs to Odgen, the run was made without any difficulty.
HALIFAX, N.S., Nov. 18.--The British schooner C.W. Redmond left Oct. 2 for Jamaica and has not since been heard of.
The greatest success of the Australian, or rather the Massachusetts election law, is that it eliminates "the workers" and "heelers" from politics.

The squadron of evolution represents, with the exception of two vessels, the combined force of commissioned war ships known as the new navy. It also represents a higher degree of excellence than can be found in any other known squadron composed of cruisers of similar tonnage displacement.

It is now the painful duty of the Protective Tariff League to rebuke Senator JOHN SHERMAN for having "excited popular prejudice against the continuance of protection for American sugar interests" and to describe his speech at Orrville, Ohio, as the "mischievous harangue of an irresponsible demagogue."

The steamship Italy of the National Line, which arrived at Quarantine late Monday evening after a long and stormy passage, came up to her dock early yesterday morning. One of her officers stated that the delay was largely caused by defective boilers.
The Union Ferry Company elected these Directors yesterday: Walter N. Degrauw, James S.T. Stranahan, Abiel A. Low, Byran H. Smith, Ripley Ropes, Samuel McLean, William A. Perry, ...

CHICAGO, Nov. 19.--Several witnesses for the defense were examined in the Cronin case to day for the purpose of proving an alibi for the prisoners. William Mulcahy testified that O'Syllivan was not out of the house on the night of the murder and that he went to bed about 9 o'clock.

Three additional ball players have deserted the Brotherhood. They are Gleason, Clements, and Schriver of the Philadelphia Club. The former is a pitcher, and the other two are catchers. Harry Wright, the veteran manager, who was spoken of as President of the Brotherhood, has also put his signature to a Philadelphia League Club contract. The Philadelphias, with the exception of Brooklyn, are better equipped than any other League team.
NOTTINGHAM, Nov. 19.--A German dentist named Arnemann shot and dangerously wounded Judge Bristowe of the County Court in the railway station here to-day.
The Washington Memorial Arch fund, of which William R. Stewart, 54 William-street, is Treasurer, still continues to increase in size.
John McReynolds, an old man living in Greenwich, Conn., who was reported last Thursday as having appeared at Castle Garden in search of a wife, appears to have been the victim of a practical joke.

Some interesting revelations were made yesterday by the Commissioners of Accounts in their efforts to dredge the corrupt channels of the Dock Department. The feature of the day's proceedings was the voluntary testimony of Timothy Shea, oysterman, and a prominent member of the County Democracy.

NEW YORK, NOV. 19, 1889. President of the Chamber of Commerce: DEAR SIR: With Congress about to assemble, the admitted importance of this question (upon which our bankers are by no means agreed) must excuse this submission to the business community of points at issue which can only be determined by the representatives of the people.
BOSTON, Nov. 19.--Actor Wilson Barrett has probably won his case and will recover the whole of the $6,000 duties paid under protest on his scenery here.

The correspondents' corps at Albany loses its "Dean" through the acceptance of the editorship of the New-York Press by Haines D. Cunningham, for a number of years the representative of the New-York Post at the State capital.

Republican primaries were held in all the wards of Brooklyn last evening and in each of the four county towns. In each case ward or town officers and delegates to the General Committee were elected, and in nearly every instance there was a contest.

Little Otto Hegner yesterday afternoon did some of the best playing which the public has yet heard him do. His matinee concert at the Broadway Theatre was attended by an audience of moderate size, as was to be expected in such discouraging weather: but those who were there heard some excellent work.
Some months ago Silk Manufacturer Hugo Funke of College Point, L.I., contracted with the Prince-street firm of Bavier, Meyer Co. for ten bales of raw silk.

The annual statement of the Manitoba Railway for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1889, shows total gross earnings of $8,586,565.56; operating expenses, $4,751,475.61. The percentage of freight and passenger earnings were .0149 per ton per mile and .0257 per passenger per mile. The total equipment had been increased to 8,253 cars. Lines measuring 153.54 miles were completed and operated during the year.

When Dock Commissioner MATTHEWS testified some days ago before the Commissioners of Accounts he admitted that there was a certain looseness in the administration of the board, but attributed it to the "system." He did not, however, explain wherein the defects of the system lay or how they could be corrected.

LONDON, Nov. 19.--The White Star Line steam ship Teutonic, Capt. Parsell, from New-York Nov. 13 for Liverpool, passed Brow Head at 11:25 P.M. yesterday.
Felix Broessel, a young artist, who formerly did some work for the Sun, committed suicide at midnight last night in the house 241 Wooster-street.

MOBILE, Ala., Nov. 19.--Saturday, at Mauriceville, Monroe County, Ala., Theodore Marshall, a well-known planter, shot and killed in his own house W.C. Stevens, a popular young man, son of an ex-Tax Collector.
DUBLIN, Nov. 19.--A Tenants' Defense League convention was held at Tralee to-day. One thousand delegates were present, including a number of prominent Parnellites. Great enthusiasm prevailed.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 19.--The track was slow again to-day, and the favorites won in only two races.

There was a shooting case developed at the Chambers-Street Hospital on Saturday which involves a New-York and Brooklyn Bridge policeman in a network of troubles from which it will be difficult for him to escape.

The Paterson (N.J.) Aldermen had an exciting meeting on Monday night. Mayor Barnert, who, politically, is opposed to a majority of the Aldermen, sent in a message severely criticising the manner in which the almshouse is managed, and referred to French China, costly furniture, fine carpets, c., which he said the Superintendent was provided with at the public expense.

By the official action of the Board of Supervisors, represented by the Supervisor at Large the city of Brooklyn was last night placed in possession of a new armory. The structure is situated at the junction of Bushwick-avenue and Stagg ...
The Yonkers Bicycle Club celebrated its tenth birthday last evening by a dinner at the Getty House in that village. Covers were laid for forty.

The nineteenth annual meeting of the Brooklym Maternity and New-York State School for Trained Nurses was held Monday in Historical Hall, Clinton and Pierrepont streets, Brooklyn. The Treasurer's report showed that the receipts for the year were $9,764 63, and the expenses $8,837 03.

A wonderful old lady died in Brooklyn on Monday night at her residence, 117 Pacificstreet, she was Mrs. Louisa Wilson Evergnham, and she lacked only seven years of rounding off a century of life. She was a baby during Washington's second term of office as President of the United States, and the war of 1812 was being waged before she was out of her teens.
HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 19.--The noted micaslate quarries in Bolton, which have been worked for seventy-five years, turning out annually a large supply of pavement stone, seem to be inexhaustible.

PARIS, Nov. 19.--The Figaro says that merchants in Hamburg have received dispatches from Rio de Janeiro stating that a movement has been started in that city for the restoration of Dom Pedro, and that fighting has occurred in the streets between the Monarchists and Republicans.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19.--At a meeting last night of the Typographical Union a resolution was adopted repealing the eight-hour rule that has heretofore prevailed.

With all due deference to the good judgement of our Albany contemporary, [the Times, which has nominated Gov. Hill for President in 1892,] the Courier thinks that the formal presentation of candidates for 1892 at this stage of the proceedings is premature.

Secretary Windom was a very much talkedabout man in Wall-street yesterday. His express determination to withdraw $47,000,000 of Government deposits in the national banks was news of more consequence than Wallstreet has had to discuss in many a day. The money market reflected Stock Exchange apprehensions on this score, call loans ruling during most of the day above 10 per cent.
St. Philip's Parish Home, 127 West Thirtiethstreet, will have its annual donation visit today and to-morrow.

The small crowd that attended the racing at Clifton yesterday was treated to some excellent racing despite the bad condition of the track. The feature of the day's sport, the Battle Royal Handicap, resulted in a dead heat between Young Duke and Juggler.

Ferdinand Baucau, a well-to-do wine grower of Los Angeles, Cal., arrived in the city on Monday on his way to Europe, and put up for the night at the Hotel Martin at Ninth-street and University-place.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Nov. 19.--Sergt. Emerick of Company E, Engineers, West Point, says the reports that his family were badly treated by the post authorities during the recent sickness by which four members of his family died from diphtheria are false.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 19.--The first municipal election in the city of Rockville, which was chartered by the last Legislature, will be held on Monday, Dec. 2. The Mayor and members of the Council Boards are to be elected, and the ballot will be conducted under the new State law providing for secrecy.

The tenders for the construction of four firstclass battleships on the barbette system are to delivered to the British Admiralty by the last of the present month. The contracts for the new cruisers have been placed.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 19.--The citizens of the First Ward, irrespective of party, held a meeting last night to discuss the political situation in reference to the forthcoming charter election. It was decided to place in nomination for Aldermen none except the very best citizens that could be prevailed upon to take the position.
The local advices from Brazil yesterday were as indefinite as at any time since the revolution was first reported. Consul General Mendonca was in Washington.

On account of the storm yesterday the ColumbiaWesleyan football game at the Berkeley Oval was postponed. Though the Wesleyan team had come to the city, the game was put off indefinitely by mutual consent and the Columbia Association paid them the guarantee of $50.

Just now the minority stockholders of the semi-pious Shepard's Fifth-Avenue Stage Line are engaged in calling Mr. De Mott, who, notwithstanding his protestations to them that he would vote his stock in their favor, sold it out ...
BOSTON, Nov. 19.--The Athletic Committee of the Harvard College Faculty has just granted permission to Capt. Linn of the university baseball nine to employ a professional coach for the nine.
Though the rain came down in torrents it did not prevent the Hudson County Jockey Club from holding its opening meeting at its new race track at Guttenberg, N.J., yesterday afternoon.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Nov. 19.--Bishop O'Hara visited Plymouth this afternoon to adjust the church difficulty between the Polanders and Lithuanians.

A stated meeting of the Trustees of the Normal College was called yesterday, to be held in the meeting room of the Board of Education; but only ten Trustees responded to their names on the roll call.

TORONTO, Nov. 19.--The Potson Iron Works Company, Limited, is in difficulties and has decided to go into liquidation. The company is engaged in engine, boiler, and machine building in Toronto, and has a big ship yard and shops in Owen Sound.

Two alarms were sounded last night for a fire discovered about 10 o'clock on the third floor of the five-story building, 10 Lispenard-street, occupied by the Empire Underwear Company.
On Saturday last Charles Brewer, fourteen years old, ran away from his home, 1,129 Vinestreet, Philadelphia, taking with him his week's wages, amounting to $3.50 and $7.62 belonging to his employer.

It is believed in Quarters where information ought to be fairly correct that Mr. WINDOM Will make some radical suggestions regarding silver in his report to Congress. There have been no indications in his official action that he contemplates any such course, and his annual report will be the first means the public have of knowing his views.

A singularly-reticent Dalmatian, Nicholas Skowelje or Skovelj, was found dead in his room on the top floor of 49 Oliver-street yesterday. He had driven a fierce-looking bowie knife into his heart by pressing on its handle with a wad made of towels, and no doubt died immediately. He was a vendor of the Italian papers Il Progresso and L'Eco d'Italia, but no ...

GUTHRIE, Indian Territory, Nov. 19.--Report has reached here of a serious freight wreck in the Wichita canon on the Denver, Fort Worth and Texas Railway yesterday. A flange of one of the engine's driving wheels broke, and the engine and five cars were thrown from the track. Engineer Wilmarth and Brakeman Wier were instantly killed. Fireman Elam was dangerously injured.

BERLIN, Nov. 19.--The Reichstag to-day resumed the debate on the motion of Herr Barth, a Progressist, to rescind the law against the importation of cattle. After considerable discussion the motion was rejected.
NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 19.--Mr. Davis has passed a comfortable day, his temperature being a triffle above normal.
ALBANY, NOV. 19.--The Sing Sing Prison Commission met in the Secretary of State's office yesterday. It went to Kingston and Woodstock to-day.

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 19.--It has for many years been a matter of vexation to New-Haveners that this the most important city of the State and the seat of Yale College had no public library building and no free library.

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 19.--At the Methodist convention to-day the Rev. Dr. G.L. Thompson, speaking of the religious future of the Nation, said that immigration and the saloon power are two great evils to feared.

The annual inspection of the Seventy-first Regiment took place last evening at the armory, Broadway and Forty-fourth-street, in the presence of many spectators.

HIGH POINT, N.C., Nov. 19.--The Derby Stakes of the Eastern Field Trial Club were continued to-day. The weather was fine and favorable for good work. The first prize was awarded and second and third will be decided to-morrow. The All-Aged Setter Stakes were commenced and the first two heats run off. How quickly the big buildings on Wall and Broad streets can be emptied and how an immense crowd can gather and fade away in an astonishingly short time was exemplified yesterday afternoon about 1 o'clock. Some mischievous person fired off a revolver.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19.--The suit of Edmund B. Caldwell against the Government, which originated in the seizure of a quantity of cloths and cassimeres fifty years ago, came to an end in the United States District Court only this afternoon.
LONDON, Nov. 19.--Sir Henry James continued his speech in behalf of the Times, before the Parnell Commission, to-day.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 19.--Joseph Cayton, a well-known resident of Monmouth Junction, committed suicide at his home there yesterday.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 19.--There is trouble among the crews of freight trains on the Central Hudson Railroad, with the prospect of a strike within a few days unless the company accedes to the demands of the men.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 19.--A new electric railway is about to be constructed in the upper portion of this city if the City Council will grant a franchise for the purpose.

The American Society of Mechanical Engineers held the first session of their annual meeting yesterday at the hall of the New-York Academy of Medicine, 12 West Thirty-firststreet. About two hundred of the most prominent engineers in the United States were present, among whom were the following:

The steam padddle wheel steamer St. Sebastian, built for the Jacksonville, Tampa, and Key West Railway, was launched from the ship yard of the Pussey Jones Company, at Wilmington, Del., yesterday. The new steamer is 130 feet long, 24 feet beam, and 4 feet depth of hold, and has accommodations for 150 passengers.

The subject of ballot reform is receiving a good deal of attention at the hands of the press and legislators-elect throughout the State. The scene of the battle this year will be transferred from the Assembly to the Senate, the introducers of both of last year's measures, Messrs. Saxton and Linson, being members of that body.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Nov. 19.--Dr. Willett Kidd, State Game Protector, says the reports from Albany that he intends to make numerous arrests in New-York City for exposing venison for sale are some what erroneous.

The first chamber concert of the Beethoven String Quartet this season will be given in Chickering Hall to-morrow evening. The soloists will be Miss Emily Winant and Mr. Arthur Foote. The programme includes Schumann's quartet, opus 41, No. 3, in A major, and the G minor quartet of Brahms.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19.--To-day's bond offerings accepted were as follows: Coupon 4s, $600 at 127; registered 4s, $5,000 $8,000, $50,000, $20,000, and $4,500 at 137; coupon 4 s. $56,000 and $14,000 ...

A number of Baptist pastors of this city gathered yesterday afternoon at a special meeting at the Twenty-third-Street Baptist Church to arrange for a week of prayer. The Rev. Dr. John W. Ashworth, pastor of the Macdougalstreet church, stated that this week of prayer was intended for the pastors only.

SHAMOKIN, Penn., Nov. 19.--This morning a north-bound freight train on the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad ran into a landslide at Winfield, a short distance from here. The engine and twenty cars were thrown from the track into the Susquehanna River. Several of the train men are injured. The engine and cars are buried in the river. The heavy rains of the past several days caused the accident.

In arranging the annual entertainment in aid of the Roman Catholic Orphan Asylum this year, Mr. Augustin Daly, under whose management they will be given, has been unusually successful in securing attractions. QUEBEC, Nov. 19.--The schooner Marie Ann, which was wrecked off L'Islet, yesterday, was commanded by Capt. Pellatier, who, with his crew, went down with the vessel. The cargo was valued at $2,000.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 19.--A bad railroad wreck happened on the Worcester Division of the New-York, Providence and Boston Railroad about 9 o'clock Monday evening, caused by the rear end of a freight train crashing into the front part of the train.

J. Henry Beard, who was sound in an unconscious condition at the Old Homestead Hotel, Sixth-avenue and Fifty-ninth-street, on Sunday afternoon, having been suffocated by escaping gas, died in Roosevelt Hospital last evening at 6:25 o'clock.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19.--The President made the following appointments to-day:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19.--When the International Marine Conference met to-day the Secretary read an invitation tendered to the delegates on behalf of the New-York and Cuba Mail Steamship Company and the Delaware River Iron Ship Building and Iron Works to witness the launching of the steamship Orizaba, at Chester, Penn., Nov. 23.
LONDON, Nov. 19.--An evangelistic movement of a very unusual character is attracting some attention in London just now.

Gallagher Baer, wholesale dealers in dry goods at 50 Walker-street, have failed and the Sherifff took charge yesterday on executions for $5,961 in favor of the following creditors: Bowery National Bank, $1,534; Tradesmen's National Bank, $1,232; ...

CHICAGO, Nov. 19.--The special production of "Shenandoah" at McVicker's Theatre to-night was given in the presence of an audience that filled the theatre. The play met with complete success, and Bronson Howard, who was present, received a double call. Special hits were made by Frank Carlyle, Joseph Rolland, Charles Stanley, Esther Lyons, and Percy Haswell.

The Brooklyn Navy Yard looks decidedly deserted since the squadron of evolution took its departure. The Dolphin is the only new ship at the yard. The Galena and Kearsarge, both of the North Atlantic squadron, are now awaiting orders and receiving stores from the yard.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19.--Members of the Brazilian Legation here have no faith in the report that partisans of Dom Pedro have undertaken to restore the monarchy, and that there is fighting in the streets of Rio de Janeiro. Minister Valente believes it is safe flatly to deny the story. He has had several telegrams from Rio de Janeiro and elsewhere, dated to-day, and all agreed that everything was quiet in the new republic.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Nov. 19.--At the annual meeting of the Newburg Skating Association tonight C.L. Waring was elected President, L. W. McCroskery Vice President, John F. Tucker Secretary, Frank G. Wood Treasurer, Tim ...

SPENCER, Ind., Nov. 19.--A cave has just been discovered near this place that rivals that of Wyandotte in Crawford County. Two men explored this underground palace yesterday. The entrance is a hole 20 feet deep and 3 feet in diameter.
Gen. Mahone of Virginia arrived at the FifthAvenue Hotel last evening. He came to meet his family, who are expected on the City of Paris. The defeated candidate is not feeling happy.

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 19.--At the annual meeting of the New-Haven and Derby Railroad Company, held in this city to-day, 3,517 of the 4,100 shares of stock were represented. Since the last annual meeting the road has been leased to the Housatonic system.

On March 27 a man, thirty or thirty-two years of age apparently, entered Gee's Hotel, at 75 Eighth-avenue and asked for a room. He was given an apartment for which he agreed to pay $2.50 a week, and he took possession immediately. He was well dressed, was short in stature, and wore a sandy mustache.

Yesterday was one of those days generally known among civilized people as dismal failures. From the moment when, from force of habit and no other earthly inducement, NewYork's civilized people opened their eyes in the morning and peeped forth at the weather, until that moment when, with a sigh of relief, they came in at night, stood their umbrellas in the bath tub, and took off numerous layers of rubber ...

If anything was needed to prove that the Executive Committee of District Assembly No. 75, Knights of Labor, had lost the confidence of the surface railroad employes in Brooklyn it was the abortive attempt made yesterday to tie up the eight lines of cars operated by the AtlanticAvenue Railroad Company. The 750 employes were ordered out at 3:20 o'clock yesterday ...

The contrast between the first dinner given by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New-York 120 years ago and the grand annual banquet which the same organization held at Delmonico's last night was strikingly and appropriately illustrated on the cover of the menu card.

TROY, Nov. 19.--The contested election case in the Sixth Ward in this city came up before Justice Edwards of the Supreme Court this morning on an application for a writ of mandamus directed to the Board of County Canvassers, ...

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Nov. 19.--H.C. Nichols, an old men living alone in a sparsely-settled part of the city, was found dead to-day in his house. His absence from work since Saturday led his employer to investigate.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 19.--Lord Stanley, Governor General of Canada, and the viceregal party returned to-day from a two months' transcontinental trip via the Canadian Pacific Railway.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 19.--Articles of incorporation for a workingman's co-operative association were filed to-day with the County Clerk. The association is situated at Plainfield and begins business with a capital of $3,000, divided into 600 shares of the value of $5 each.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Nov. 19.--The pretty Casino at Short Hills was crowded to-night by an audience attracted by the announcement that "The Day After the Wedding" was to be played by Mrs. W. Fellowes Morgan. Mrs. Daniel Warfield, and Messrs. Edward Fales Coward, ...
MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 19.--Three weeks ago George Bliss, J. Dillon, I. Collinger, and Sam Newsman came here from Chicago and went to work for Jacob Mueller soliciting orders for enlarging pictures.
BISMARCK, N.D., Nov. 19.--Gilbert A. Pierce was made the unanimous choice of the Republican caucus for United States Senator.

PARIS, Nov. 19.--M. Floquet, President of the Chamber of Deputies, delivered an address to the Chamber to-day. He declared that he would endeavor to sink all personal predilections and assured the members of the Chamber the liberty of the tribune. All France, he said, had manifested a desire that concord should prevail among her representatives, and he therefore appealed to all the forces of democracy to rally around the Republicans.

LONDON, Nov. 19.--Mr. John Morley, speaking at the Eighty Club to-night, held that the social questions to which many of the Radicals were now seeking to give the first place in the programme could not efface the Irish question, on which the next election would turn.
A reception was tendered last night by the Young People's Association of the First Presbyterian Church to Pastor Richard G. Harlan and his bride, who have recently returned from Europe.

LISBON, Nov. 19.--Advices have been received from the Guinea coast of Africa that the Geba war has ended in favor of the Portuguese. Eighteen Dembos chiefs have offered their submission to the Governor of Angola.

The Republicans of this State have diminished their animosity toward the Administration since election day because the boys have been given to understand that Gen. Harrison proposes to open the patronage spigot wider. "The cry of reform wil be continued by the Administration," said a well-known Republican yesterday, ...

JACKSON, Mich., Nov. 19.--A dynamite explosion occurred on a window ledge in the State Penitentiary here at 5:30 o'clock last evening, shattering the walls and causing some excitement. The opening made was too small to allow any one readily to escape, and prompt action by the officials prevented a break of the convicts.

The World's Fair subscription market was exceedingly dull yesterday. When the subscriptions at the Mayor's office yesterday amounted to but $4,490, it seemed as if no higher notch could be reached. But later in the day this encouraging little message was received:

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 19.--The Rev. Father Gleason of Nashville opened the second day's session of the National Prison Association with prayer, after which Secretary Wines read several letters from distinguished friends of the cause in the United States.

Just as the first faint glimmer of dawn began to force its way through the heavy clouds which poured torrents of rain down upon this city yesterday morning, the inhabitants of East Third-street in the neighborhood of Secondavenue were aroused from their slumbers by a most unearthly noise. At first was heard a violent thumping and pounding as if somebody ...

During the recent voyage of the North German Lloyd steamship Fulda, which arrived yesterday from Bremen and Southampton, four children died of diphtheria in the steerage.

NORWICH, Conn., Nov. 19.--The perplexing problem of how to dispose of the garbage of this city has been brought to the attention of the Common Council by Dr. H.M. Bishop, Chairman of the Board of Health, in an elaborate paper in which he calles attention to the great ...
NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 19.--This day beats the record in the receipt of cotton at this port. The amount in by boat and rail up to 6 this evening aggregated 37,731 bales of cotton.
Dr. Ernst Freund of New-York read a paper Monday evening before the Academy of Political Science on "The Proposed German Civil Code."

"General" Abe Greenthal, one of the oldest and shrewdest criminals in this country, died last Sunday at the home of his daughter in Harlem, and was quietly buried yesterday. His death was due to a complication of diseases incident to old age, which were aggravated by recent confinement in the Kings County Penitentiary, from which institution he was released a few weeks ago.

A retiring board has been appointed to meet at Chicago, composed of the following officers: Major Gen. George Crook, Col. Robert Williams, Assistant Adjurant General; Lieut. Col. Michael R. Morgan, Assistant Commissary General of Subsistence; Major Ell McClellan, Surgeon; Major Henry McElderry, Surgeon, Capt. George M. Randall, Twenty-third Infantry, Recorder. Lieut. Col. George A. Forsythe Fourth Cavalry, has been ordered before the Board of Examination.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Nov. 19.--The Rev. William McGlathery, rector of Grace Episcopal Church, this city, has resigned from the charge on account of impaired health.
NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 19.--Emily Hobbs, a fiften-year-old girl whom the police have for some time been endeavoring to arrest for theft, ...

The suit of Oscar Moore, stock broker of London, England, to recover $7,000 from the estate of Henry J. Nichols, (the latter person being now confined in a lunatic asylum,) will be tried in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, to-morrow.
The Court of Errors at Trenton, N.Y., yesterday overturned Vice Chancellor Bird's decision in the matter of the bequest to Henry George. George Hutchings, an old Gloucester County ...
The promises that the Florida Orange Auction Association made to the orange growers in Florida that they would obtain for them better prices for their fruit by selling them at auction ...

There was a special meeting of Presidents and general officers of the trunk lines yesterday, which had been called for the purpose of considering the proposed advance in corn rates to the seaboard. But they gave very little time to that matter.

An Iowan has just been acquitted, upon a second trial, of the charge of having killed one of his neighbors while the neighbor was engaged in giving him what is called in the dispatches a "charivari," but ...

ELMIRA, N.Y., Nov. 19.--This city is the scene of another flood, and fears are entertained that the water will reach a higher point than last June. Already the damage is very great. In the lower districts of the city houses are inundated, and in some instances people have been removed to places of safety in boats.

Mayor Grant's appointment of seven School Commissioners will no doubt be announced at the meeting of the Board of Education this afternoon. The interest in them is very marked, and little else appears to be talked of in school circles. But the Mayor appears to have kept his own counsels, for no one even pretends to know who the appointees will be.

PROVIDENCE, Nov. 19.--His Excellency Gov. Herbert Warren Ladd is likely to be remembered in local history as an ideal Rhode Island Governor. He had a record as a clever man and a hustler before he became the Chief Executive of the State. He has added to his laurels by making the interesting discovery that the Governorship of Rohode Island is good for ...
BELVIDERE, N.J., Nov. 19.--A large sale and transfer of slate property has just taken place at Bangor, Penn.

PALMER, Mass., Nov. 19.--Walter Haynes of Brimfield is celebrating his one hundredth birthday to-day. He is in excellent health and does not look to be over seventy-five. As a carpenter Mr. Haynes helped to build the first block erected in Syracuse, N.Y., and alone excavated a quarter section of twenty-six rods of the Erie Canal. He never used liquor or tobacco, and attributes his longevity to "boiled victuals" and "johnny cake."
The ladies' bazaar given by the "Silver Cross Circie" of the Order of King's Daughters opened last night at 1,266 and 1,268 Broadway.
John Van Varrick and John Drewes are booked at the Hoboken police station as suspicious characters.

President-elect Seth Low of Columbia College visited the college yesterday. He was introduced to the Senior Class by Acting President H. Drisler during a lecture in astronomy by Prof. W.G. Peck. The room had been darkened for the use of the calcium-light illustrations of the lecture.
Count de Keratry of France is at the Hoffman House. Gen. John McNulty of Illinois is at the Windsor Hotel.
Congress will meet one week from next Monday. From the very opening of the session its doors will be besieged by representatives of the World's Fair Committees of St. Louis and Chicago.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 20.--A special from Oswego, Kan., says: "The preliminary examination of Mrs. Monroe and Mrs. Eliza Davis, the women who are supposed to be old Mrs. Bender and Kate Bender, respectively, was concluded...

The Rev. G.W. Chamberlain lectured last evening at the chapel of the Madison-Square Presbyterian Church to a large audience on Brazil. A physical map of that country was hung on the wall and frequently referred to.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20.--A meeting of the members of the Philadelphia bar was held today in Room C, Court of Common Pleas, to pay respect to the memory of the late ex-Attorney General Lewis C. Cassidy.

READING, Penn., Nov 20.--The Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company to-day sent to Milton from here a large force of carpenters to construct temporary bridges in place of the three structures washed away during last night by the flood.

Owen Bixby, a sixty-year-old resident of Hillsdale, Columbia County, N.Y., was found dead yesterday morning in his room at the Putnam House, Fourth-avenue and Twentysixth-street, having been suffocated during the night by inhaling gas. The burner was turned on, and it is supposed that Bixby, on retiring for the night, in turning out the gas accidentally turned it on again.

BOSTON, Nov. 20.--The forty-third annual convention of the Theta Delta Chi College Fraternity assembled at Young's this morning for the three days' session under the auspices of the Grand Lodge. About sixty members were present, two undergraduates, and one ...
Patrolman William Honan of the United States Life-Saving Station at Point Lookout, Long Island, was on duty Tuesday about dusk.

Mayor Grant announced the following appointments of Commissioners of the Board of Education yesterday: Mrs. Mary Nash Agnew, Mrs. Clara M. Williams, James W. Gerard, Eugene Kelly, Randolph Guggenheimer, ...

A cable dispatch announces that the latest race between the Teutonic of the White Star Line and the City of New-York of the Inman Line has been won by the first-named vessel. She was spoken off Brow Head late Tuesday night, and reached Queenstown at 2:30 yesterday morning.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 20.--In answer to the question if the Irish National League of America was going to take any public steps to relieve the alleged straitened circumstances of Mrs. Parnell, President John Fitzgerald replied in the negative. He said: "I think any...

There was a sensational rumor floating about political haunts up town last night. It was in effect that Dock Commissioner Matthews had become a Tammany man, and that that wing of the Democracy would hereafter practically control the patronage of this big Dock Department.

Policeman McCarthy last night found a young woman sitting on the stoop of St. Barnabas Home in Mulberry-street. She had a seven months' boy baby in her arms. She told the officer that she had tried to gain admission to the home for the night, but had been refused.

Attorney General Miller has given an adverse opinion on the claim of Gen. Casey, Chief of Engineers, for $16,000 as commission on funds disbursed by him for the construction of the State, War, and Navy Departments Building.

Among the nine delinquent jurymen fined $250 each by Judge Ehrlich in the City Court on Tuesday, was Fitzallen Flynn. Mr. Flynn yesterday applied to Judge Ehrlich to have his fine remitted. He said at the time he was summoned to serve on the jury he was about taking his family into the country, and thought his ...

In regard to the dispatch from Chicago in reference to trouble between the Baltimore and Ohio and Illinois Central Railroads regarding terminal facilities Mr. Thomas M. King, Second Vice President of the Baltimore and Ohio, states that his road ...

There is going to be a fine time in the Sixth Congressional District when the campaign begins for a successor to Frank T. Fitzgerald, who throws off his brand new garb of Congressman to go into the Register's office, where he will make more money.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 20.--Mr. Davis passed a restless and feverish night, partly on account of the change in the weather, but as the day advanced the fever diminished, until by tonight it had disappeared entirely. Dr. Bickhan has no fears about Mr. Davis's final recovery, though he lacks the recuperative powers of a younger man.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20.--H.A. Taylor, the Commissioner of Railroads, has received from the Assistant Attorney General for the Interor Department an opinion upon the question as to whether railroads receiving grants of lands from States, which grants have been made to ...
LONDON, Nov. 20.--Among the visitors at Barnum's show to-day were the Prince and Princess of Wales, the Marquis of Lorne and the Princess Louise, and the Earl and Countess of Fire.

TACOMA, Washington, Nov. 20.--John B. Allen of Walla Walla did the Territory of Washington notable service when he was its delegate to Congress, and his election yesterday as Senator is an almost unanimous recognition of these services.

ALBANY, Nov 20.--The Telegraph Club has been incorporated to exist in New-York City with these objects: The promotion of healthful exercise and a closer relationship between members of the telegraph profession, and the giving of entertainments and maintaining of a clubhouse in New-York City.

A curious accident occurred at the Elizabethport station of the New-Jersey Central Railway shortly after 11 o'clock yesterday morning. The engine of the Matawan train that left this city at 10:30 jumped a frog at the intersection of the main line and the Long Branch division, ran along on the ties for three car lengths, and ...

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov 20.--Reliable information from the scene of the reported killing of Rube Burrows's right bower, who wore, it is said, a home-made coat of mail, and whose last words were: "Rube's in the West," shows that the story as sent out from Birmingham is a falsehood pure and simple. There has been no man killed in Marshall County, Ala., for more than a year, willfully, maliciously, or otherwise.

According to La Revue du Cercle Militaire, there has been a reorganization of the telegraph system all over France upon a more simple basis, whereby the military and civil departments may be enabled to work harmoniously.

One of the most fashionable of the November weddings was that last evening of Miss Eleanor Louisa Hoffman, daughter of the Rev. Dr. C.F. Hoffman, and William MacNeil Rodewald of this city at St. Thomas's Church, at Fifty-thirdstreet and Fifth-avenue.
The members of the Stock Exchange, always enthusiastic and generous when their help is needed, have come forward again with another subscription to the Washington Memorial Arch fund.
LONDON, Nov. 20.--The steamship Island, (Dan.,) Capt. Skjodt, from New-York Nov. 2, arr. at Copenhagen to-day.

The New-York Society for the Relief of the Widows and Orphans of Medical Men is one of the many charitable associations in this big town which give a helping hand to the needy. During the annual meeting of the society at the Academy of Medicine last night a number of beneficiaries was added to the list.

BOSTON, Nov. 20.--The Massachusetts Tariff Reform League held its first dinner of the season to-night, with a considerably-increased attendance over last year. The after-dinner speaking was informal and was upon the decline of American shipping resulting from the high tariff.
Col. O'Byrne last evening refused to make a statement of the part he took in the oystermen's legislation. "If the Commissioners of Accounts want me," said he, "they know how and where to find me.

John Highland, an employe in one of the packing houses at Kansas City, Mo., was shot and mortally wounded by some person unknown at midnight Tuesday. Highland was a guest at John Gilliland's boarding house at Armourdale, and ...

James D. Reid, the recently-appointed United States Consul to Dunfermline, Scotland, was tendered a farewell dinner by the Magnetic and New-York Telegraph Clubs, jointly, last night at Martinelli's, on Fifth-avenue.
