Lawyer Abraham Suydam, who was indicted for grand larceny for having received $750 from Fay Stacom, real estate dealers, on July 12, under false representations, was brought to trial yesterday before Judge Cowing in the Court of General Sessions. Mr. Suydam was in a great measure his own lawyer, though he had Frederick B. House to back him up.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 20.--One of the biggest awards of damages made in many a year by a jury was given this afternoon in the Law and Equity Court in the case of Michael J. Tierney against the Standard Oil Company.

BOSTON, Nov 20.--At a recent meeting of St. John's Episcopal Church, East Boston, it was proposed to make preparations for the annual fair, as heretofore. To this the new rector, the Rev. H.A. Monro, emphatically objected.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 20.--The fact came to light to-day that the twelve-year old son of John M. Bruce, a well-known ice dealer of this city, had been abducted a week ago, and all trace of him was lost. The alleged abductor is the lad's own mother, Mr. Bruce's divorced wife, who has succeeded in evading the police thus far.
Although "Erminie" is weighted with the veneration and the familiarity due to 1,200 performances, the revival of this operetta last night drew out an audience that completely filled the Casino.

The Women's National Indian Association opened its annual meeting at the Third Presbyterian Church, Newark, N.J., yesterday morning. About one hundred ladies, who are active in the work and support of the association throughout the country, were present.

The Mallory steamship Leona, which arrived yesterday from Galveston, brought the crew of the three-masted schooner Furman L. Mulford, which foundered at sea on Nov. 17 in latitude 30 10' and longitude 79 30'.

One of the most enjoyable social events of the season was the reception last evening tendered the visiting gentlemen of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers by their sister society the Engineers' Club at their well-appointed clubhouse, 10 West Twenty-ninth-street.
PARIS, Nov. 20.--The Bureau of the Chamber of Deputies has pronounced valid many elections in which the Conservative candidates were successful. The invalidated elections do not exceed ten in number.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 20.--Full Back Ames has received two telegrams from the managers of the baseball teams on which he played during the past Summer, on which grounds Harvard accuses him of being a professional.
ALBANY, Nov. 20.--The Autocrats' Society has been incorporated, and its objects are stated to be: "For the cultivation of a social feeling among its members, which object is to be attained by...

F. H. Kimball, the architect, appeared yesterday before the Board of Building Examiners at the Mutual Life Insurance Building and gave his views in regard to proposed changes in the laws relating to the construction of buildings for theatres. Mr. Kimball had prepared himself carefully not only with notes but with plans drawn to illustrate his recommendations.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 20.--The fifty-thousanddollar damage suits instituted some time ago in the Common Pleas Court by Fayette Hewitt, then State Auditor, against the Owenborough Enquirer and Covington Commonwealth have been settled by compromise. Only a few formal matters remain to be arranged, when the suits will be dismissed.

Mr. Theodore Whiteman, freight agent of the Cromwell Steamship Line, was waylaid by a highway man in Washington-square at 7 o'clock last evening. He was struck across the back of the head with a club or sandbag and fell to the path unconscious. While prostrate the robber took $130 from his vest pocket and made his escape.
LONDON, Nov. 20.--Capt. Wissmann telegraphs that Henry M. Stanley arrived at Mpwapwa Nov. 10.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20.--The defense in the Cronin murder case was continued to-day, but, although much time was occupied, nothing of importance was elicited. Witnesses were put upon the stand to prove that O'Sullivan was at home when Dr. Cronin was murdered. Testimony was also given showing that there was no inner circle in the Clan-na-Gael.

FAYETTEVILLE, N.C., Nov. 20.--The centennial celebration of the ratification of the Constitution of the United States by North Carolina opened here today. Gov. Fowle delivered the opening address, speaking in glowing terms of the American Union and North Carolina as a member of the Union.
Mayor Grant received the following letter yesterday from Elihu Root, counsel for the Broadway and Seventh-Avenue Railroad:

General Superintendent Toucey of the NewYork Central and Hudson River Railroad said yesterday that the reports about a threatened strike on the freight trains of that line that were published were greatly exaggerated.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 20.--Ex-Representative John R. Byrne of the Knights of Labor was arrested at Scottdale, Penn., this evening on a charge of conspiracy preferred by ex-Representative Edward Callaghan. The information also includes General Master Workman Powderly and Peter Wise, local labor leader.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 20.--Sister Gonziga, an inmate of the Convent of Mount St. Ursula, this city, has been sent to Dixmont Insane Asylum. She has become demented through worriment over the affairs of the institution, and it has...
Mrs. Maria McCann was found dead in her room at 370 Bond-street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning, and her husband, Edward, a laboring man, was arrested on suspicion of having caused her death.

Coroner Schultze held an inquest yesterday in the case of Johannes Rosenow, the young man who died at Bellevue Hospital from the effects of injuries received by being run over by a Harlem train between Mount Vernon and Bronxville on Oct. 16.
The Courts of the American Order of Forestry of New-Jersey met in Roche's Hall in Jersey City yesterday to organize the State Court ...

Some of the people who have been investigating the wonderful discovery of artificial silk by Count Chardonnet, a brief description of which was published in THE TIMES of Friday last, are inclined to accord it a much greater importance than was apparent upon first impression.

The story that has been brought out in the Dock Department investigation in regard to the leasing of a pier to the Wholesale Oyster Dealers' Association and the attempt to have it permanently set apart for the exclusive use of its members is not a direct reflection upon the administration of ...

BISMARCK, N.D., Nov. 20.--Both the House and the Senate to-day gave their entire Republican vote to Gilbert A. Pierce for the United States Senate, but owing to the provision of the Constitution he cannot be elected in joint session until noon to-morrow, to which time the Legislature adjourned.
An electric wire belonging to the United States Illuminating Company was broken by some unknown cause in front of the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company, 55 Beaver-street, yesterday morning.

The work of making the official count was completed yesterday by the Board of Aldermen acting as county canvassers. The figures are not materially different from those heretofore published. Before the declaration of the vote the Committee on Protest reported that after ...

ATLANTA, Nov. 20.--In the Knights of Labor convention to-day the Finance Committee recommended a change so that in future only the actual car fare to and from conventions will be paid. In future all local assemblies attached to the General Assembly will pay a per capita tax of 10 cents per quarter instead of 6 cents as heretofore.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 20.--Chief Engineer W.H. Brown of the Pennsylvania Railroad to-day submitted to the Mayor and Common Council of this city a plan for the abolition of all grade crossings in the city.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Nov. 20.--The abandonment of Ocean-avenue is one of the foremost topics of discussion here. Warren Leland, Sr., of the Ocean Hotel says there isn't money enough in Monmouth County to preserve Oceanavenue as a fashionable drive.

At the regular monthly meeting of the Board of Underwriters yesterday nothing was done toward a settlement of the vexed questions of rates and commissions, which have been in the hands of a committee for the past year.

William F. Bruff, who lives on Church-avenue, near the Ocean Parkway, Flatbush, reported to the town police on Tuesday that he had brained a burglar with an axe and had left him propped up against the Greenwood Cemetery fence in a dying condition.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 20.--James R. Keene's stock farm near here is to be broken up next month, and the stock, including the stallion Spendthrift and some fifteen brood mares, the best known of which are Kapanga, the dam of ...

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 20.--D.L. Moody tonight opened a series of Gospel revival meetings in this city, which are to continue one week. All the evangelical churches are interested in these meetings, three of which will be held daily, and excursions will be run in from neighboring towns. The largest church in the city was densely packed at this evening's meeting.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 20.--Pilot boat Pet, No. 9, of New-York went ashore this morning on the east side of Canonicut Island, half way between Beaver Tail and Mackerel Cove. She left here at 3 o'clock and when well over to the ...

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 20.--A meeting of the stockholders of the Richmond, Fredericksburg and Potomac Railroad Company was held here to-day. The report of the Board of Directors showed the operations of the road for the nine months ended June 30, 1889, that being the end of the present fiscal year.

HIGH POINT, N.C., Nov. 20.--The Eastern Field Trial Derby was finished to-day, and the Allaged Setter Stakes, which commenced yesterday, were continued. The weather was cold and clear. The following is the result of the day's work: Piprap beat Nannie B. and won second prize; Nannie B. was placed third and Harry C. fourth.

BOSTON, Nov. 20.--An evening paper publishes a story to the effect that while Lamson Store Service stock was selling in the stock market yesterday at 50, a block of 1,000 shares changed hands privately at 55, and many other lots were sold privately at various prices, running as high as 58 .
A stranger entered the restaurant of Michael Carroll, at 1,606 Broadway, about 9 o'clock last night, and assaulted the proprietor with a sandbag.

Charles Goldzier, a lawyer, whose office is at 206 Broadway, was indicted by the Grand Jury yesterday for usury and grand larceny in transactions with Mrs. Rettie Gillette of 212 West Forty-sixth-street. The usury indictment was found upon the claim of Mrs. Gillette that he charged her $75 interest on $360 from Jan. 8 to Feb. 16. The larceny was of a couch and chair worth $80.

The various lines of street cars operated by the Atlantic-Avenue Railroad Company in Brooklyn were all in regular working order yesterday morning, and the abortive attempt at a strike inaugurated on Tuesday was not renewed.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 20.--The Western Association of American Architects held its final meeting to-day. President Carlin announced that 246 members voted for consolidation with the National Institute of American Architects, 3 voted against it, and 80 did not vote. The property of the Western Association was turned over to the National Institute, and the Western Association adjourned sine die.

The New-York State Conference of Unitarian Churches opened its second day's session in the Church of the Messiah yesterday morning with prayer by the Rev. H.H. Woude. The Rev. Robert Collyer delivered an informal address of welcome in behalf of the Church of the Messiah.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20.--The President made the following appointments to-day:

TROY, N.Y., Nov. 20.--Justice Edwards was unable last night to complete his examination of authorities in the matter of the Sixth Ward ballot box case. This morning he granted a stay, preventing the Supervisors from canvassing the returns until the pending litigation is decided.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20.--The third day's session of the International American Conference was devoted entirely to efforts to perfect the organization. Senor Romero of Mexico presented the report of the Committee on Credentials.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 20.--Fire at Baldwinsville last night caused a loss of $250,000. The flames originated in the second story of the Seneca Hotel, at Oswego and Genesee streets, and the entire hotel block, with two large warehouses adjoining, was destroyed.

The absolutely secret ballot is something that was unknown till recently at the East. The ballot is nominally secret in most States, but as different kinds of paper and devices are used by the opposing parties it may be said to be partially open.

CITY OF MEXICO, Nov. 20, via Galveston.-- The Board of Directors of the National Bank of Mexico has sent a formal protest to the Government against the establishment of new banks of issue, this action being a duty imposed on the Directors by the terms of their concession.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Nov. 20.--For the second time within a year the Post Office at Fishkill Landing was last night broken into and robbed. The building is situated on the main street, and a night watchman passes the office at stated intervals.

William Janes, who had his foot crushed by a dummy on the Bushwick Railroad on Jan. 5, 1888, testified yesterday in the City Court, Brooklyn, in his suit to recover $25,000 damages. HELENA, Mon., Nov. 22.--Excitement is running high to-night over the question of the organization of the Legislature to-morrow, and it is difficult to predict the outcome of the contest.
"I never made a speech in my life," said Mr. Peter Soden at the meeting held last evening at the Commercial Club room in the interest of the Missouri River Packet Line; "I came here to subscribe."

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 22.--Ex-President Cleveland, the referee in the famous case brought by George B. Phelps of this city against Clarence H. Venner, banker and broker of Boston and New-York, to recover the difference between the price at which Venner sold certain ...
DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 22.--Michael Clary, the aged father of Postmaster Clary of Lawler, Chickasaw County, arose at 4 o'clock yesterday morning and went to the barn to milk his cows.
CHICAGO, Nov. 22.--T.M. Balley, ex-cashier of the Security Loan and Savings Bank, has mysteriously disappeared.

LONDON, Nov. 22.--The investigation into the circumstances of the collision between the State Line steamer State of Georgia and the coasting steamer Agate, in the Clyde last October, has resulted in the certificate of Capt. Moodie of the State of Georgia being suspended for three months.

The officers and members of the ThirtiethStreet Methodist Church tendered their pastor, the Rev. John G. Oakley, and his wife a reception last night at the church, in honor of the twenty-fifth anniversary of their marriage and of the completion by Dr. Oakley of a quarter of a century of service in the ministry.

Thomas P. Wickes's successor as Second Assistant Corporation Counsel will be Charles Blandy, Corporation Counsel Clark having decided to appoint him to the place, the salary of which is $6,000 a year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22.--The President made the following appointments to-day:
Estimates for the Thanksgiving supply of poultry, , for the Department of Public Charities and Correction were opened and contracts awarded at 66 Third-avenue at 9:30 yesterday morning.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Nov. 22.--At the opening of court to-day Henry Lawrence was further cross-examined, and strengthened materially the testimony for the Gentiles. He said the general teaching of the Church was in the direction of disloyalty to the Government, and gave one very impressive incident.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 22.--Mrs. Russell, the mother of Tommy Russell, the precocious little fellow whose interpretation of the role of "Little Lord Fauntleroy" has won him fame, said to-night:

Wonderful are the changes in Dublin within the last few years, writes a correspondent of the Pall Mall Gazette. The city has become quite bustling and busy, while everything sold in its shops seems to be ticketed "Irish manufacture."
Mr. Austen Chamberlain is to make his entry into public life as a member of the Birmingham Town Council, it seems.
TORONTO, Ontario, Nov. 22.--Hog cholera, which threatened to assume serious proportions in Chatham Township, not far from American boundary, has been treated with vigorous measures.

A meeting of members of various Irish societies was held at the monastery, 210 West Thirty-first-street, last night to arrange for a lecture by and reception to Father Mathew, who is now in this country.

PALMER, Mass., Nov. 22.--A tally-ho party of Harvard students from Boston to attend the Harvard-Yale football game at Springfield were detained here to-day for stealing guide boards, with which they decorated the coach. They settled and proceeded.

The news that a remarkably large freight steamship is unloading at Almond-street wharf might be accepted as a harbinger of returning commerce to this port but for the added information that she will go to New-York to get a return cargo.

BOSTON, Nov. 22.--The dinner of the Boston and Cambridge Civil Service Reform Associatians at Young's Hotel this evening was an event in the history of the movement for the reform of the public service. About 125 persons prominent in the politics of all parties showed their deep interest in the cause by their presence.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 22.--The attendance at the races to-day was the largest since the meeting opened. The weather was all that could be desired, and the track was in fairly good condition.

At a meeting of thirty-four of the thirty-nine insurance companies still parties to the NewHampshire withdrawal compact of 1885, held at the Insurance Exchange yesterday, it was voted that the agreement known as the NewHampshire compact be dissolved, and that the Secretary of the Insurance Exchange be requested to notify all signers that they are no longer bound by any of the conditions of that agreement or any modification thereof.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 22.--Jefferson Davis is improving, so far as his illness is concerned, but new complications seem to be arising. The fever which troubled him for some days appears almost entirely to have disappeared.

The business meeting of Plymouth Church, which took place after the prayer meeting of last evening, took the first positive action in the way of calling a council to ordain to the ministry Howard S. Bliss, who has been acting as associate pastor, and to install the Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott in the pastorate of the church.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 22.--The Hambletons in their circular to-morrow will say: "The people of Baltimore must some day realize that the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad is no longer a home institution, and that eventually its objective point and major interest will be at NewYork." The article advices the city of Baltimore and the Johns Hopkins University to sell out their holdings of the stock.

One of the Administration organs finds it expedient to explain that Mr. BLAINE does not expect that the Pan-American congress will take measures in bahalf of reciprocity in trade between this country and the republics south of us.
The Lord Mayor receives from the city of London funds for his year of office 10,000, and on an average spends 8,000 to 10,000 in excess of that allowance.

Capt. E.L. Zalinski will remain abroad until April 1. He is now in Paris at work on the subject of high explosives. The United States is singularly deficient in a knowledge of the powders now being adopted by all the military powers of Europe.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Nov. 22.--A rumor has prevailed in financial circles for several days that an English syndicate had made overtures for the purchase of the plant of the Glens Falls Paper Company, and that the mission of M.A. Sheldon, who left recently for England, was to negotiate the sale on the part of the paper company.

Policeman J.T. Myers was hurrying along toward the Fourteenth-Street Precinct Station House yesterday afternoon when Albrecht Braner rushed up to him and cried out: "Officer, officer, there's a man killing his children over in the Lawrence Flats!"

The iron steamship Manhattan of the Old Dominion Steamship Company was sunk on Wednesday morning at 5 o'clock about eight miles northeast of Fenwick Island Lightship, near Delaware Bay, of the coal schooner Agnes Manning, bound from Baltimore for New-York.

To-day at Springfield, Mass., will occur the second of the three great football games of the intercollegiate championship series. It will be between Yale and Harvard, and promises to be quite as exciting as the game between Harvard and Princeton a week ago. A special train will leave the Grand Central Station for Springfield at 9 A.M., returning after the game is over, and will carry many NewYork enthusiasts to witness the sport.

We observe that some of our contemporaries, intent on the completion of the subscription to the World's Fair, are asking what has become of Mr. John H. Starin and his guarantee of half a million dollars.

There is less talk among Republican members of Congress about repealing the civil service law than there was a month or so ago. The fact is that a man who goes to Congress and wants to stay there must make up his mind that the civil service act has come to stay also.

Congressman Thomas B. Reed, the most prominent candidate for Speaker of the Fiftyfirst Congress, sauntered into the Victoria Hotel at a late hour on Thursday night with his wife and daughter. He did not register. He spent the day yesterday in shopping with Mrs. Reed, who proposes to remain here several days. He had no callers and saw but one politician.

Alderman Storm presided at the meeting of the Aldermanic Law Committee which yesterday afternoon gave a hearing to those opposing and those favoring the ordinance which banished wandering bands and hand organs from the streets. Before the committee was Alderman Morris's amendment providing that street ...
JUNEAU, Alaska, via Port Townsend, Washington, Nov. 22.--The first Republican convention ever held in Alaska convened at Juneau Nov. 5.

Dispatches from Chicago yesterday said that the Atchison-Rock Island deal was substantially completed, the companies binding themselves to the operation of a through line, to be known as the Rock Island and Santa Fe route.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 22.--The schooner C.B. Church, which left this port Oct. 19 with 1,324 tons of coal for Boston, has been given up for lost by her managing owners, Morse Co. of Bath, Me. The cargo was wholly and the schooner partly insured. Capt. J.T. Gallagher, the master of the vessel, was accompanied by his wife and child, the latter a boy about four years old.

It was published yesterday in an afternoon paper that a New-York banking house had received a private cablegram that the Hon. George H. Pendleton, ex-United States Minister to Germany, was dying at Brussels of an internal abscess.

A large number of oil paintings from the collection of the late Lawrence Barton of Dorchester, Mass., were sold at auction at the rooms of W.W. Palen Co., 290 Fifth-avenue, last night. The prices ranged from $15 to $700.
The Nineteenth Century Club opened its season of 1889--90 at the Metropolitan Opera House Assembly Rooms last evening with a large attendance.
BOSTON, Nov. 22.--At the Theta Delta Chi Convention yesterday Epsilon Charge of Yale announced a gift of $1,000 from Frederick Carter, a member of that charge and Treasurer of the Grand Lodge.

It was the intention of the Commissioners of Accounts and the Corporation Counsel to round up yesterday "Tim" Shea's story of how the oystermen at the foot of Charles-street were "bunkoed" out of $13,000 as disclosed in the developments of the Dock Department investigation.

The money scare seems to have a good deal of staying power. Call loan rates were up again yesterday to 12 per cent., and though most demands were supplied at lower rates there were legitimate transactions at the high figure. The result did not show so much in any depression of the stock market as it did in the way of inducing dullness.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 22.--Drs. Charles C. Clark and A. Melville Ewing have long been successful teachers in the medical department of the Niagara University. They are specialists, and recently decided to join forces in practice.

PARIS, Nov. 22.--It is semi-officially announced here that the anti-Slavery Conference at Brussels is looked upon with distrust as an attempt to isolate France on the question of the right of search. The French Government will not admit that right, and is trying to induce Russia, Spain, and Portugal to join in opposition.

The report of the Board of Directors of the Real Estate Exchange for the year ending Nov. 15, to be submitted to the stockholders at the annual meeting on Dec. 9, will show that the past year was one of great activity.

The 2,000 persons that attended the NewJersey Jockey Club's races yesterday not only witnessed some excellent racing, but carried away the bulk of the money wagered, as four favorites and two well-backed second choices won.

DRAIN, Oregon, Nov. 22.--The tug Fearless of Coos Bay, Capt. James Hill commanding, ran on to North Spit at the mouth of the Umpqua River Tuesday evening and soon went to pieces, not one of the crew or passengers escaping. She was on her return trip from Astoria, where she had to go to take a lot of Chinamen lately discharged from the canneries on Coos Bay.

Some of the Republican Congressmen from this State are agitating the question of investigating the civil service work of the last four years in the hope of slurring Mr. Cleveland's Administration and making political capital thereby.

Deputy Sheriff Bennett has received attachments against A. Del Pino Brother, manufacturers of cigars at Key West, Fla. They were granted by Judge Patterson of the Supreme Court in favor of Horace R. Kelly Co. for $30,000, and in favor of William Wickes Co. for $10,751.

The actual recorded subscriptions for the World's Fair guarantee fund are now well past the four-million-dollar point. This does not include something over $100,000 of the amount pledged by the brewers, but not yet turned in, nor the half million ...

Judge McAdam in the City Court yesterday brought joy to the household of Goldman by ordering the release of Julius Goldman from Ludlow-Street Jail.
The much-expected official report to the stockholders of the Oregon and Transcontinental Company was issued yesterday, filling a pamphlet of about a dozen pages.

PARIS, Nov. 1.--The regular Paris theatrical season has been opened by M. Koning at the Gymnase with Daudet's "Lutte Pour la Vie," or, as the playbills put it also in rather queer English, "Struggle Liffers."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22.--The forthcoming report of the Board of Visitors to West Point Military Academy will contain a paper read by Gen. Lew Wallace, President of the board, containing suggestions of changes respecting education both in the army and at West Point.

ATHENS, Nov. 22.--The Rev. T. De Witt Talmage and his party are in this city. Dr. Talmage has secured a cornerstone for his new church in Brooklyn from Mars' Hill, where St. Paul preached to the Athenians.

It is said there are a lot of Dakota boomers in the East who carry Oregon wheat and represent it as having grown in Dakota. An Oregonian saw an exhibit of this kind at Buffalo, N.Y., and says he found a sample of wheat he had put up in the stalk from wheat grown on Mr. W.S. Ladd's farm. He recognized it by a peculiar string which he tied to the sample in arranging it.

James Douglas Reid, the recently appointed United States Consul to Dunfermline, Scotland, was the honored guest at a dinner given at Delmonico's last night by the officials of the telegraph companies to which he gave nearly half a century of faithful and efficient service.

HIGH POINT, N.C., Nov. 22.--The running of the All-Aged Setter Stake of the Eastern field trials was continued to-day. The weather was fair in the morning, but changeable, and in the afternoon cold and windy.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 22.--Gov. Taylor yesterday acted upon the case of the five Barnards sentenced to be hanged for murder in Hancock County. The Governor pardoned absolutely John, Jr., and Elijah Barnard, commuted to five years in the penitentiary the sentences of Clint and Anderson Barnard, and to ten years that of John Barnard, Sr.

Whether the deaths of J. Henry Beard, the artist, and Ferdinand Baucan, the wine grower, both of which were by asphyxiation in their hotels, were the results of their own carelessness or of design, or were brought about by accidents for which they were not responsible, are mysteries, which, perhaps, may be impossible of solution.

LONDON, Nov. 22.--The court room in which the Parnell Commission meets was crowded at the opening of to-day's session. All the counsel for the London Times were present. While Ward, Hanlon, Ewing, Pieffer, and other shining lights in the baseball firmament are busily engaged in securing men for the Brotherhood, Keefe is looking after his sport ing goods business in this city.

WATCH HILL, R.I., Nov. 22.--The Rhode Island Harbor Commissioners are considering the important matter of proposed harbor lines at Point Judith Pond, and are hopeful that Congress will take action favorable to the construction of jetties in a semicircle outside of the breachway there, so that larger craft may lie there, leaving the shoaler pond inlet for lighter craft.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 22.--The Directors of the Federal Steel Company completed their business in this city to-day, and all of them, with the exception of J.W. Gates and George W. Douglass, who remained here as a committee to finish detailed work assigned to them, departed for their homes.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 22.--The Lawrence Bank at Lawrenceville, Penn., closed its doors to-day. The failure has caused but little flurry in financial circles, and it is said that no other banks are involved.

CITY OF MEXICO, Nov. 22.--The transfer of the powers of the old Board of Directors of the International and Mortgage Bank was made late Wednesday afternoon, and the formal transfer of the cash and securities was to have been made at 10 o'clock yesterday morning, in the presence of the members of the old and new boards.

The Hon. John Cardwell of Houston, Texas, who for the past four years has represented this Government as Diplomatic Agent and Consul General at the Egyptian Court, was in this city a few days ago and gave a TIMES reporter some interesting incidents of his stay in Cairo. He said:
Mr. Roswell P. Flower yesterday indicated in an interview with a reporter for THE TIMES what he would do in the forthcoming session of the National Congress, of which he is a member.
President Lyon of the Third-Avenue Railroad Company sent a communication to Commissioner Gilroy asking permission for the company to begin laying its cables.

The Hon. Thomas C. Platt has been interviewed by the New-York Tribune in regard to the results of last Tuesday's elections.
HARTFORD, Nov. 22.--United States Senator O.H. Platt, who reached his home in Meriden this week from the Pacific slope, has expressed himself as a thorough advocate of Territorial irrigation.
I was absolutely amazed at the prices in a catalogue of rare stamps which I was looking over the other day.
The hearing in the matter of E. Berry Wall's unpaid tailor's bill was continued yesterday afternoon before Referee Myers.
TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 22.--The New-Jersey Sanitary Association began its fifteenth annual meeting here to-day, Dr. Dowling Benjamin in the chair.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 22.--Senator Allison on the surface treats the situation in Iowa lightly and pretends to be very confident of his re-election, but it is well known among his political confidants in this State that he is filled with the gravest forebodings of the result. The Legislature is close.
EUREKA SPRINGS, Ark., Nov. 10.--The Rev. John Mayhow, a Free Will Baptist minister, fell dead last night in the pulpit while preaching at the Mountain School House, about six miles from this city.
A number of book men were relating professional anecdotes the other night. "About twenty years ago," said one of them, "I was employed with the Lippincotts.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 22.--The departure on Commander Caspar F. Goodrich, United States Navy, from the torpedo station at this place last week gives occasion for a review of the work accomplished at the station during the three years he was in charge.
At yesterday's session of the Committee on Revision of the Building Laws Architect Burkmeier made a plea for cast-iron uprights in the walls of buildings, instead of wrought iron.

A rather pretty young woman, handsomely attired, stepped from the Brooklyn ferryboat upon its arrival at the Fulton Ferry in this city at 9:30 o'clock yesterday morning. She betrayed a nervousness of manner that attracted momentary attention on the part of those nearest to her.
The mail which has just arrived in London from China brings news of the total destruction by fire, on Sept. 18, of the famous Temple or Altar of Heaven at Pekin.

Interest in the subscriptions to the World's Fair guarantee fund continues, and yesterday the sum subscribed passed the four-milliondollar mark and turned into the last million. The grand total, reported from the Chamber of Commerce at 5 o'clock, was $4,060,717.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Nov. 22.--For sixty-one years the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company have been engaged in litigation with the towns along its line on the question of taxes.
HAVANA, Nov. 22.--The London and Paris rumors cabled here of a revolution existing in Cuba are without any foundation whatsoever. The island, politically, is entirely tranquil.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 22.--The Grand Jury will meet to-morrow and probably conclude the baby bond investigation by returning findings and a report, and also making public the report of State Treasurer Pipes and State Auditor Steele.

The second joint appearance of the great pianist, Eugen d'Albert, and the great violinist, Pablo de Sarasate, took place at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening in the presence of a large, brilliant, and enthusiastic audience.

The ruins of Bernard S. Levy's block of seven brick houses in process of erection on Eightiethstreet, between Ninth and Tenth avenues, were visited by many persons yesterday. The houses fell with crash shortly before midnight on Thursday night, when no one was in or near them.

ST. JOHNS, Quebec, Nov. 22.--A scandalous affair that occurred at the barracks here on Sunday last has given rise to a good deal of bad feeling among military men, and may result in breaking up the mess.

Harper for December, which is now looked for regularly every year as the Christmas number, and which is about the first reminder that a periodial gives us of the approaching festival, possesses this year its old-time originality and charm.

A very interesting judgment was rendered by Judge Jette yesterday. The case was that of the Jacques Cartler Bank against Abel Valin, contractor. On Dec. 7 last defendant came to the bank with seven fifty-dollar bills of the Molsons Bank and asked to have them changed for smaller ones.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 22.--The Iowa Methodists have several fine colleges which are supported by the Church and which are objects of great importance to the rural villages in which they are situated.

HAVANA, Nov. 22.--The Government has awarded the contract for the building of new water works for this city to the American firm of Messrs. Runkle, Smith Co. The amount to be paid is $2,000,000.

Some days ago the Brunswick-Balke-Collender Company announced through the newspapers that it was ready to give $5,000 for two billiard tournaments, $2,500 each for one in New-York and one in Chicago, to be held as early as possible during the coming Winter.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22.--To-day's bond offerings accepted were as follows: Registered fours, $1,000, $111,700, $45,000, and $100,000 at 127; registered four and a halfs, $200, $3,600 and $100 at 105 .

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22.--The International American Conference was not in session to-day, and the force engaged on the publication of the record of the proceedings was enabled to reduce in a large measure the accumulated work.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 22.--Great interest is being taken in the Ohio Senatorship, and there are not less than a dozen willing Williams anxious to represent Ohio in the United States Senate. Mr. Payne is now a very old man and will not be a candidate for further political honors. Mr. John R. McLean is not, nor will he be, a candidate.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 22.--While at a public sale yesterday at Herndon, Guthrie County, W.L. Edwards attacked Representative Ira S. Shipley, completely biting off one of his ears, lacerating his cheek with his teeth, almost biting off one thumb, and otherwise maiming him.

Mayor Grant passed an uneasy half hour yesterday in the witness chair in the Court of Common Pleas before Judge Allen and a jury. He was called to give his testimony in a suit brought on behalf of Miss Frances E. Demarest to recover $25,000 damages for injuries received on the toboggan slide at Fleetwood.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 22.--The meeting of graduates and undergraduates at Yale to-night to discuss the football situation was largely attended, but the result was not what had been anticipated. Several old football men came from New-York this afternoon and held a conference with the officers of the Football Association.

The hereditary Prince of Hesse, who will attain his majority on the 25th, is going to England during the Winter to visit the Queen at Osborne and Windsor, and the Prince and Princess of Wales at Sandringham.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 22.--The Grand Jury, which has been investigating for some time past the charges of bribery brought wholesale against the City Council, added another chapter to its labors this morning by bringing in three indictments against Alderman John Chris Jacob, President of the Council.
The success of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company is assured, the rapid growth of its business being remarkable.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22.--"Prince Russell" Harrison has had a set-back. Postmaster General Wanamaker has once more got ahead of senator Quay, and all the Pennsylvania, oliticians have been treated to a real surprise. For all of this President Harrison is responsible because he to-day appointed John J. Ridgway to be Surveyor of Customs for the port of Philadelphia and Thomas J. Powers to be Naval Officer.
Mrs. A. Belmore, a member of Wilsen Barrett's company, now playing at the Fifth-Avenue Theatre, was seriously injured last night during the performance of "Claudian."

RIO JANEIRO, Nov. 22, via Galveston.--All the pensions granted by the imperial Government have been confirmed by the Provisional Government, and an order has been issued that they be paid out of the revenues.

Charles H. Turner, driver of an icewagon and recently Tammany's candidate in the Eighth Senatorial District, was nominated for Congress by the Tammany Convention in the Sixth District last night, with a whoop and a hurrah. The nomination was made at the dictation of Richard Croker and the Tammany Committee of Twenty-four, and the whoop and hurrah came as incidents.

Several witnesses were examined in the Lederer case yesterday and an adjournment was taken until Monday morning. Samuel Gardiner, a musician, of 219 East Eleventh-street, said that he knew the complainant very well, but never as Mrs. Lederer.
The city authorities have given permission to an ice and cold storage company to introduce its mains into Washington Market.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 22.--Patrick Sheridan has been nominated by the Democrats of Elizabeth as their candidate for Mayor. His only opponent in the convention was Dr. David Schieimer.

Property owners in Union County, New-Jersey, are delighted with the outcome of the County Road bill, the object and purpose of which is the acquirements, improving, and maintenance of public roads in that State. Speaking of the benefits accruing therefrom, Mr. Chauncey B. Ripley said yesterday:

In the suit of Frank C. Hollins against the St. Paul, Minneapolis and Manitoba Railroad Company an argument was had yesterday before Judge Ingraham, in Supreme Court, Chambers, on the application for an injunction to restrain the company from transferring to the Great Northern Railroad Company of Minnesota $22,000,000 worth of assets and leasing its line to the latter corporation for ninety-nine years under the proposed plan of reorganization.
The insect house at the Zoological Gardens containes an interesting little bird which might be easily passed over by the visitor on account of its resemblance to an ordinary pigeon.

The Italian wine industry is in a most depressed state owing to the quarrel with France. Having laid themselves out to suit the French demand, and adapted their wines for mixing up with other sorts, the Italians find it difficult to secure new markets.

The Washington Memorial Arch fund continues to grow. Mr. George Kemp has subscribed $100, and other subscriptions reported are as follows: Cash, $10; W.B.F., $2; H.D., $2; Mrs. Claire Harral, $1; through the Com- mercial Advertiser, eight subscribers, $8; through the New-York Sun, 10 cents. The sum last acknowledged was $60,378.95; with the above new subscriptions the grand total now reported by Treasurer W.B. Stewart of 54 William-street is $60,502.05.

The Secretary of War has ordered that the follow ing sleeping and parlor car accommodations be allowed officers and soldiers while traveling on public duty: Officers of the army traveling on duty with troops, clerks and agents in the military service traveling under orders on public business.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22.--An audience such as one sees at the Grand Opera only on a Nilsson or Patti night filled Central Music Hall this evening when the sale of tickets began for the Patti season, which is to open formally the great auditorium, commencing Dec. 9.

WATERBURY, Conn., Nov. 22.--At the recent session of the Connecticut Legislature a law was enacted providing for a new survey of the State.

At noon yesterday the cornerstone of the new armory for the Citizens Corps of Saratoga, N.Y., was laid by Grand Master John W. Vrooman of the Masonic Grand Lodge of this State. POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 23.--Sylvia Nester, aged seventeen, a student at a boarding school for young ladies in this city, has become violently insane and has been removed to her home at Geneva, N.Y. On Wednesday evening she caught her roommate by the throat and almost choked her to death.

Policeman Aikler of the Park police was strolling up Park-avenue yesterday, when a woman rushed into the street with her clothing on fire. He ran into a house near by and got a blanket, which he hurriedly wrapped around her, thus extinguishing the flames. Then he took her to the Presbyterian Hospital. She had been pretty badly burned. She was Minnie Wish, a domestic.

Since his conviction it has been learned that he is probably not guilty and that an Italian named Spiotti committed the deed.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 24.--Yesterday five bodies of those lost by the explosion of the steamship Corona some two months ago in the Mississippi River, opposite Port Hudson, were found floating near Plaquemine. They were identified as Capt. J.W. Blanke, Clerk Swimp Hanna, the barkeeper, the colored barber, and a passenger who lived in Atlanta.

VALLEY FALLS, Kan., Nov. 24.--The stud barn of I.C. Webster at Orchard Hill Farm was destroyed by fire this morning. Four noted stallions were burned to death--Evanmond, Prairie Wilkes, Joe Larkin, and Weagimont. The loss is placed at $75,000. The fire originated from the explosion of a lantern.

The twenty-second anniversary of the execution of Allen, Larkin, and O'Brien, "the Manchester martyrs," was recognized with appropriate exercises by the Innisfail Club at the Grand Opera House Hall last evening. Judgeelect James Fitzgerald presided. The oration of the evening was delivered by Dr. William B. Wallace. It was outspoken in its eulogy of the Irish martyrs, the Irish nation, and all things that are Irish.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 24.--The Rev. E.P. Cowan, D.D., pastor of the Third Presbyterian Church, administered a rebuke to fashionable society this morning that has occasioned no little comment. The reverend doctor had been preaching upon Christ's prayer to God for the Apostles (John xvii., 15.)

BRUSSELS, Nov. 24.--The Anti-Slavery Conference has decided that territorial questions are outside of its competency. King Leopold today received the delegates to the conference, who waited upon him in a body. He expressed confidence in the result of the labors of the delegates, and said he was firmly resolved to suppress slavery in the Congo State.

The American schooner Lackawanna arrived in port yesterday from Port au Prince with a cargo of logwood. She made a good passage, being at sea only seven days. Capt. Ford reports all quiet at Port au Prince.

Gov. Foraker, Secretary of State Ryan, and Attorney General Watson formally canvassed the returns on the three proposed constitutional amendments yesterday, and declared that as none of them had received "a majority of the votes cast at the election" none of them were adopted.

William Schwerker, a lad of seventeen, lost a situation as cutter of optical glasses recently. Last night, at 216 East Fourth-street, his mother reproached him for not being a bread winner, and he went into another room and shot himself in the right temple with a revolver. He was sent to Bellevue Hospital, and was regarded as seriously injured, although the bullet did not appear to have penetrated the brain.

The body of Dr. Karl Bran, who disappeared from 216 East Fifty-third-street on the 9th inst., was washed ashore on Staten Island yesterday. Dr. Bran probably committed suicide. He was sixty-nine years old and graduated as a physician from Erlangen in 1852, and shortly a er came to America as a political refugee.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 24.--The Republican City Convention for the nomination of a candidate for Mayor and four candidates for Freeholders will be held on Tuesday night at Collet Hall. Only three men are prominently mentioned in connection with the Mayoralty. These are ex-President of the City Council John C. Rankin, David H. Chatfield, and Dr. William M. Mack. The latter ran last year and was beaten by a small majority.

The express and mail cars were robbed. The passengers were not molested. The amount secured by the robbers is unknown.

The run was made in thirty-seven days, the vessel averaging over eleven knots an hour throughout the whole passage. On many occasions she logged fourteen, fifteen, and fifteen and a half knots.

The funeral of Richard Lawrence Schieffelin was held yesterday afternoon in Grace Church, and was largely attended. The cloth-covered casket was strewn with lilies as it was borne into the church. The Episcopal burial service was read by the Rev. Dr. Huntington, rector of Grace Church, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Peters of St. Michael's and the Rev. Mr. Schwab of St. Mary's. There were no pall bearers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24.--The first annual report of Secretary of War Proctor, given to the public to-day, covers many grounds which have already been dwelt on in the various reports of army officers to the department. It is a long document and embraces many recommendations which, if acted on, the Secretary thinks, will greatly improve the condition of the service.

The announcement has been already made that the Tuesday subscription performances, which were so popular and successful at Daly's Theatre last season, will be repeated this Winter. They will surely be among the most pleasurable and fashionable events of the theatrical year.

Charles O. Tripp, a young clerk, was suffocated in his room on the third floor of 343 Franklinavenue, Brooklyn, at 9 o'clock last night. The building is a three-story brownstone structure, used as a boarding house by Mrs. F.A. Birdsall. It was set on fire last night by the explosion of an oil lamp in the basement.

FOREST CITY, Iowa, Nov. 24.--At the late election John Law of this place was supposed to be elected as Representative from the Eighty-fifth District, composed of Hancock and Winnebago Counties. There were three candidates, John Law, Republican; W.C. Ripley, Democrat, and W.F. Greemp, Granger. Law received 60 more votes than Ripley, the next highest, and was given the certificate.
Hiram Howe, a veteran horseman well known to all patrons of the race track and many others, is seriously ill at his home on Ocean Boulevard, near Gravesend, Long Island.

Steamship Alvo, (Br.,) Port au Prince, Savanilla, Carthagena, Port Limon, Navassa, and Fortune Island 21 ds., with mdse. and passengers to Pim, Forwood Co. Arrived at the Bar at 9 P.M. Steamship Richmond, Dole, West Point, Va., with mdse. and passengers to Old Dominion Steamship Company.

All Souls' Protestant Episcopal Church was transferred yesterday from the old home of the parish in West Forty-eighth-street to the beautiful edifice which was recently erected at Sixty-sixth-street and Madison-avenue by the parish of the Holy Spirit, and which is to be the future abode of the Rev. R. Heber Newton's congregation.

The first impression of the reader of Marie Bashkirtseff's journal, in French, is that it is the work of one of the modern French masters, who, with much ingenuity and some audacity, has chosen to throw his story of a girl's life into the form of a journal intime.

ST. PAUL, Nov. 24.--A Pioneer Press special from Pine City, Minn., says: "William Brooker committed a double murder here this afternoon, shooting down in cold blood William P. Coombs and his wife. Then he visited a neighbor's house and sat with his rifle across his knees, conversing coolly about the heartless deed. Coombs left two small children. The murderer is still at liberty."

Amateur photographers in the city are complaining of the poor weather of the last two months. Usually there are plenty of fine, bright days in Autumn, when excursions can be made to many localities near the city where fine natural views are to be had.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 24.--It is reported, on what is believed to be good authority, that the local representatives of the National Lead Trust have resigned their trustships, and developments relating to the condition of the trust are likely to follow, which will be very interesting. It is also said that the Trustee at Cincinnati has taken the same action.
A number of ladies met at the residence of Mrs. D.G. Croly, (Jennie June,) 148 East Fortysixth-street, yesterday, and formed the "Women's Press Club of New-York."

Three matinees of "Erminie" will be given at the Casino this week, on Tuesday, Thursday, and Saturday. The performance to-morrow will be for the benefit of the World's Fair fund of this city, and the total receipts will be devoted to swelling that fund. ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 24.--It is now believed that John B. Bond of 1,093 Magnolia-avenue, who was killed by a train on Saturday evening, deliberately committed suicide.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24.--It is said that there are 600 theatrical companies now playing in this country, besides musical and operatic organizations. If that is true, it would seem as if novelties might reach Chicago a little oftener. Of all the theatres in the city, only four had anything new to offer the public last week, the rest having on their stages plays seen here times ...

Mrs. Southworth, who killed Stephen Pettus in Fulton-street on Friday, spent yesterday in bed in her cell in the Tombs, having experienced the reaction which would naturally be expected to follow her intense nervousness of the two days previous.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Nov. 24.--For some time counterfeit coin has been in circulation in the vicinity of Bristol and Lincoln, in small quantities. While Sheriff Clark was searching the dwelling of Newell Haskins for stolen property, he found some counterfeit silver dollars and minor pieces.

WHEELING, West Va., Nov. 24.--The managers of the Monongahela River Railroad, running from Fairmont south through Harrison and Lewis Counties, have suspended work until Spring, and about 350 men have already been discharged.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 24.--A special from Fort Wayne, Ind., to the Sentinel says: "A misunderstanding of train orders was the occasion of a disastrous wreck on the Nickel Plate late last night. An east-bound freight train was run into by a west-bound night train near Argos, Ind., sixty-six miles west of Fort Wayne. The crew of the through freight saved themselves by jumping, but every one of the crew on the other train was injured.

BISMARCK, N.D., Nov. 24.--It has been quiet about the political centres here to-day, but the caucusing of friends of the various candidates indicates a struggle between the candidates opposed to Johnson for supremacy.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 24.--When the news of Yale's victory over Harvard in Saturday's football game reached this city a large party of students proceeded to celebrate.

LONDON, Nov. 24.--The Cunard Line steamship Etturia, Capt. Hains, from Liverpool, sld, from Queenstown at midnight to-night for New-York. The steamship Polynesia, (Ger.,) Capt. Franck, from New-York Nov. 7, arr. at Copenhagen to-day. The General Transatlantic Line steamship La Bourgogue, Capt. Frangeul, from New-York Nov. 16, arr. at Havre at noon to-day.
The discussion in the daily press in regard to the reappointment of Col. John L. Rice as Postmaster at Springfield, Mass., revives his interesting war history.

In reply to a suggestion that cable dispatches from Germany stated that there was danger of a division of Brazil into three parts, Minister Valente said that the telegram received to-day was a complete refutation of all such reports.
A barkentine, the John Swan, of 700 tons burden, was launched Saturday at Columbia Falls, Me. She is owned by John Swan Sons of New-York, and will be commanded by Capt. Price.
ERIE, Penn., Nov. 25.--The Hon. William L. Scott has spent a million in houses and barns here, and now adds a mausoleum to his other possessions.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25.--The International Marine Conference reassembled this morning after a recess since Wednesday. There was a large attendance.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25.--The Supreme Court of the United States to-day postponed, until the hearing on their merits, the motions to dismiss or affirm in the case of Cornell University against Willard Fisk and others. This case has been pending in various courts for a long time. The effect of the decision of the court is to postpone the final determination of the case for about three years.
Owing to the bad condition of the track the races of the New-Jersey Jockey Club yesterday were postponed.
Fire damaged the Hecla Iron Works, at North Tenth, North Eleventh, and Berry streets, in the Eastern District of Brooklyn, last evening, to the extent of between $150,000 and $200,000.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 25.--A special to the Post-Dispatch fron Edwardsville, Ill., says a disastrous conflagration occurred there at an early hour this morning, entailing a lose of about $300,000.

BOSTON, Nov. 25.--The Independent Democrats to-night indorsed the renomination of Mayor Hart. The Hon. Robert Treat Paine, who was recently nominated for Mayor by an independent citizens' convention, declines the nomination.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 25.--W.G. Brownlee, the well-known free trader and Detroit citizen, was superintending the work of unloading some logs at his mill this morning, when one of the stays broke and two of the logs rolled upon him, inflicting fatal injuries, to which he succumbed shortly after being removed to his residence. He leaves a widow and five children.

Nicholas Quinn, a clerk employed in the office of the Brooklyn Jockey Club at 397 Fultonstreet, stole $4,585 belonging to Green B. Morris, the horseman, yesterday afternoon, and got safely away with the cash.

One of Gov. HILL'S contentions in regard to ballot reform has been that it should be accompanied by a requirement for a general registration throughout the State every year, and one of the features of the Linson bill was a provision for such a registration.

TAYLORSVILLE, Ind., Nov. 25.--A farmer named Frank Engleman, living a few miles west of Nashville, Ind., was attacked by a fierce, full-gown gray eagle on Friday evening while on his way to town.

BELGRADE, Nov. 25.--The authorities have discovered a plot to depose King Alexander and to replace him by Prince Peter Karageorgevics. Many Russian diplomats are implicated in the conspiracy. Three of the conspirators have been arrested.

Roland Reed presented "The Woman Hater," David D. Lloyd's farcial comedy, at the Bijou Theatre last night before an appreciative audience of good size. As Samuel Bundy, the woman hater, Mr. Reed repeated the success which he had previously achieved in the role in New-York. He was as droll as ever, and his songs were heartily encored. The one hundredth performance of "Shenandoah," Bronson Howard's successful play, will be made the occasion for great jubilation at Proctor's Theatre next Tuesday night. Two years ago, when Mr. Howard's play which met with so much approval, "The Henrietta," was produced at the Union-Square Theatre by Robson and Crane, "The Wife" was enacted at the Madison-Square Theatre.

The World's Fair guarantee fund is steadily growing. It is now estimated that in at least three days more the books at the Chamber of Commerce will tell the story of how, finally, the big but imperatively necessary sum of $5,000,000 was pledged.

The law plainly says that the official canvass of votes cast at a general election shall be sent to the Secretary of State within twenty days after that election, but although that limit expired yesterday the canvass of the Kings County vote will not be completed for several days.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Nov. 25.--The court room was crowded all day with spectators who came to witness the closing scenes of the cause celebre. Before the arguments began the Gentiles introduced the certified copy of a record of the First District Court at Provo.

On a very important point the members of the Central Council of the King's Daughters stand seven against seven. Half of them favor admitting to the order, practically, any one who wishes to live according to the Golden Rule and who is a professing Christian, as Unitarians are. The other half would have every member a believer in the divinity of the Saviour.

BERLIN, Nov. 25.--The North German Gazette (Bismarck's organ) says that the situation in Brazil causes the European powers no anxiety. The Government at Rio Janeiro appears to lack neither the power nor the will to maintain order. There is no need, the Gazette says, of sending a German man-of-war to Brazil.

The Operative Plasterers' Society of this city received its reward at Tammany Hall last evening for its fine marching in the civic parade of last Spring. The reward was a handsome banner of yellow silk adorned with a portrait of Washington.

John Vansack murdered Mike Zovetshin during a quarrel at Vanderbilt, four miles west of Conneilsville, Penn., late Saturday night. Both men are Hungarians, coke-workers. Vansack in drunken rage plunged a knife a half-dozen times into Zovetshin's breast. One of the thrusts penetrated his heart, and the Hungarian died instantly. Vansack was arrested, and is now in jail.

It is not surprising that the silver mine owners are dissatisfied with the silver coinage law as it now stands. It is of course, an advantage to them to have a purchaser secured in advance for $24,000,000 worth of their product every year at current market rates.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 25.--Some good time was made to-day, the track being in fine condition and the weather fair. The favorites were beaten in every race.

LONDON, Nov. 25.--The yacht Lady Evelyn arrived at Cowes to-day from New-York. The Pall Mall Gazette states that a virtual rupture has occurred in the relations between Germany and the Vatican.

AUBURN, N.Y., Nov. 25.--Another Auburn Prison convict, and a pretty desperate man he is, too, escaped from the custody of a keeper at 3 o'clock this afternoon, and up to 8 o'clock this evening he had not been captured.

BOSTON, Nov. 25.--Mr. W.H. Crane produced, at the Hollis-street Theatre, to-night, "The Senator," a new American comedy, written by the late David D. Lloyd and Sydney Rosenfeld. Mr. Crane, personally, had a very warm greeting, and was forced to make a speech during the evening. The play is likely to be very successful, and Crane's part is well suited to him.

ROME, Nov. 25.--The Italian Parliament was opened to-day by King Humbert in person. In his speech from the throne his Majesty alluded to the smallness of the deficit in the budget, and said that the Government's wise and equitable policy assured tranquillity to Italy and guaranteed peace, which, thanks to the concert of the great powers, appeared to be assured to Europe.

The emigrant from Russian Poland never relinquishes his race characteristics. Dwarfed as to stature, swarthy in complexion, phlegmatic as to temperament, and clannish past belief in his blind confidence in his own people, he constitutes a peculiar phase of the cosmopolitan population of New-York. He works unceasingly, eats sparingly, and sleeps little; ...

The report of the Austrian section of the Alpine Club shows that mountaineering in the Austrian Alps has this year caused twenty-two accidents, while in the course of last year the number of persons injured was thirty-one. Only four deaths occurred. Ninety-four new shelters were erected during the year, and fifty difficult mountains were ascended by 200 tourists, most of whom were young, and among whom figured eight ladies.
Jacob Levy came to this country from Poland on Saturday last, and took up his abode with his brother in the big tenement house 83 Norfolk-street, which is inhabited exclusively by Polish Hebrews.
LONDON, Nov. 25.--Mr. Mackinnon, the President of the Emin Relief Committee, has received another letter from Henry M. Stanley. It was written at the camp at Kizinga Uzinja and is dated Aug. 17.

In the case of Waiter Martin J. Flynn, who on the 28th ult. was injured by an umbrella stick thrust into his eye, a Coroner's jury yesterday found a verdict in accordance with the evidence, and exonerated his assailant, Stegfried H. May, who surrendered himself at the Nineteenth Precinct Station House just before Major Joseph Stewart, who believed that he had hurt Flynn, surrendered himself to Inspector Byrnes.

There was a very large audience at the FifthAvenue Theatre last night, and Mr. Wilson Barrett's portrayal of the afflicted here of "The Silver King" was received with many demon strations of satisfaction. The play is old, but it still possesses what the theatrical agents call "draught."

BLACKFOOT, Idaho, Nov. 25.--The Teritorial Asylum was destroyed by fire this morning. The fire was caused by a defective flue in the basement. Fifty-seven out of sixty-five inmates were rescued, while two women and two men are known to have perished, and four are yet missing, and are supposed to have been burned. The building was partially, and its contents totally, destroyed. The loss is estimated at $300,000.
JOHNSTOWN, Penn., Nov. 25.--Two more bodies have been found in the Conemaugh River. One was that of a boy, and is unidentified.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25.--Cyrus Bussey, the Assistant Secretary of the Interior, has submitted to Secretary Noble a report of the operations of his office in the adjudication of pension claims that are appealed from the decisions of the Commissioner of Pensions. He speaks of the thorough investigation to which pension appeals are subjected and the important work ...

District Attorney Fellows, at the request of the Grand Jury, has decided to push the criminal proceedings against Mrs. Hanna M. Southworth for shooting stephen L. Pettus at once without waiting for the result of the Coroner's examination. To-day the facts in the case will be laid before the Grand Jury, and the woman probably will immediately be indicted.

The proposed reorganization of the Marine Corps by the Naval Board on the Revision of Drill and Tactics is a subject which has been strenuously advocated from time to time by many well-informed officers. As stated in yesterday morning's Washington dispatches to this paper, "the corps has stood still and is to-day not different from the corps of 1865."

Counsel for John Greenwall, sentenced to be hanged on Dec. 6 for the murder of Lyman S. Weeks, have sent a lot of affidavits to Gov. Hill, on which they base a petition for a reprieve.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 25.--The citizens of Cleve land are up in arms against the electric street car motor wires in the streets. From 7 o'clock yesterday until sundown a big force of linemen under Fire Department Chief Dickinson were at work cutting and slashing down wires.

BRIDGEPORT, Nov. 25.--A number of changes in the postal service between Boston and NewYork have been arranged which will probably result in a great saving of time between the two cities and deliver the New-York morning papers in Boston half an hour earlier than now.

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 25.--The Yale students intend to take the young black bear with which they celebrated the victory over Harvard Saturday to the Yale-Princeton game on Thanksgiving Day. They have great faith in the cub as a mascot, and in the event of victory, to quote the phrase used at Yale, they will "make a lion of it."

It was a great day for intrinsic values on the New-York Stock Exchange yesterday. The only stock able to advance was Tennessee Coal and Iron, which rose about three full points; you can't suppress a big spontaneous public demand.
The Goethe Society held a meeting last evening in the ballroom of the Brunswick Hotel and listened to an interesting address by Mr. Gaorge Parsons Lathrop on "Genius and Society."
LONDON, Nov. 25.--The Anchor Line steamship Anchoria, Capt. Campbell, from New-York Nov. 16, arr. at Glasgow to-day.
Some charitably-disposed person has advertised that anybody unable to buy a Thanksgiving turkey who shall mail his address to "Anonymous," Post Office, Station G, will receive a bird gratis.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Nov. 25.--The Turkish journal Soodet reports that the steamship India, with 500 Mohammedan pilgrims on board, has been sunk in the Aegean Sea, and that of all on board only the Captain and two passengers survive.
BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Nov. 25.--The Appellate Court at Springfield has rendered a decision in favor of the city of Bloomington in its case against Mrs. Washburne of the Salvation Army.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 25.--A special from Racine, Wis., to the Evening Wisconsin says the suit of the Farmers' Trust Company of New-York against John E. Burton, the ex-mining king, for $330,000 and interest, was settled to-day. Burton withdraws the charge of usury, and the plaintiff accepts $330,00 as payment in full. A receiver was appointed for Burton's property.

Great expectations in regard to new developments in the Dock Department investigation were not realized by yesterday's proceedings in the office of the Commissioners of Accounts. One of the earliest comers was Col. John O'Byrne, the lawyer who was paid $13,000 by the Oyster Dealers' Association.
HIGH POINT, N.C., Nov. 25.--The All-aged Pointer Stake was continued to-day and the weather was very favorable for good work. Bounce beat Dolgorouki.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25.--Twenty-eight delegates were present this afternoon when the international American conference was called to order. Dr. Zegarra of Peru presided. The temporary Secretary, Dr. Guzman, read the report of the Committee on Credentials passing favorably upon the credentials of the Brazilian delegates and those of Mr. Cornelius Bliss.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 25.--In the case of George H. Williams, colored, indicted for the murder of Walter F. Wright, the jury came in shortly after noon to-day, after two hours' deliberation with a verdict of guilty. The penalty is death, but the usual motion for a new trial will be argued before sentence is pronounced.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Nov. 25.--When the term of the Circuit Court and Court of Oyer and Terminer opened in this city this morning the court room was crowded.

Interest in athletics at Columbia College seems to be growing. During the Thanksgiving intermission the interclass football championship will be played. The Seniors hold the championship at present. Ninety-two is at present boasting of its ability to win this year. Assistant District Attorney Jerome announced yesterday that the trial of Mrs. Anna Swinton and Josh Mann, who are indicted for grand larceny and conspiracy in securing $500 from Robert Ray Hamilton under false representations, would be moved at the beginning of the December term Monday next. The accused have been in the Tombs since Sept. 16, and their lawyer, J. Stewart Ross, has become impatient for their trial.

BOSTON, Nov 25.--The dinner given by the Dorchester Yacht Club at the Parker House this evening to the Admiral, Captains, and officers of the United States squadron of evolution, now anchored in the harbor, was attended by a large and jolly company, which included many distinguished guests.

DANVILLE, Va., Nov. 25.--In the United States District Court to-day the Grand Jury failed to indict J.S. Willis and S.J. Douglass for intimidating voters in North Danville in the last Presidential election, and the prisoners were dismissed.

Justice Patterson, in Supreme Court, Cham bers, yesterday handed down a decision under which George B. Sims will have to go to jail or pay his wife, Ellen T. Sims, allmony and counsel fees.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 25.--The Alaska boundary question is likely to be settled by a series of compromises. This is the conclusion reached by officials of the Interior Department who have been devoting their attention to the subject during the past season. READING, Penn., Nov. 25.--Four brothers, living at Pine Grove, Schuylkill County, where they had been regarded as respectable citizens, have been arrested, charged with burglary.

The Brooklyn Aldermen yesterday increased the salary of the Mayor from $6,000 to $10,000 a year, to take effect on Jan. 1. President McCarty offered the formal resolution, which was adopted without a dissenting voice.

The general public of this city, as well as that part of it which the gods made poetical, is enjoying without stint the wonderful playing of D'Albert, the pianist, and Sarasate, the violinist. Last night's concert at the Metropolitan Opera House, the third of their series, was attended by an audience which was large, demonstrative, and, upon occasion, even vociferous.

A fashionable wedding was that yesterday afternoon of Miss Kate Wynkoop, daughter of Dr. Gerardus H. Wynkoop of this city, to Harold Stanley Forwood, son of Sir William Forwood, ex-Mayor of Liverpool and the NewYork agent of the Atlas Steamship Line. The ceremony was held at Grace Church at 3:30 o'clock, the rector, the Rev. Dr. Huntington, officiating, and was witnessed by fully one thousand friends of the bride and groom.

Some of the subjects in the popular lantern slide exhibtions are duplicated. An old millon Long Island turns up regularly three or four times a year in the exhibitions of this city. The statue of Liberty was among the collection shown on Friday at the rooms of the Society of Amateur Photographers in this city. It was a bit of good work, but very familiar.

Acting President Johnston of the Brother hood received a telegram from Cleveland last evening saying that O'Brien, pitcher of the Cleveland Club, had signed a Brotherhood contract. Paul Radford of the same club has also joined the players' organization.

HARTFORD, Nov. 25.--The annual report of State Treasurer Henry for the year closing June 30, 1889, has been submitted to Gov. Bulkeley, and among other gratifying exhibits it shows that the public debt has been reduced $279,073.22 during the year.
ITHACA, N.Y. Nov. 25.--A debt of $150 has been handing over the Cornell crew since its great victories last July. The greater part of this amount to due Courtney for coaching the ...

PITTSBURG, Nov. 25.--As yet the depositors of the broken Lawrence Bank are still in the dark. They can get no trustworthy information as to how much they will receive. They held a meeting to-night and appointed a committee to employ counsel to look after their interests.

Stephen Crowell, one of the oldest insurance men in the country, died at his home, at 3 East Twelfth-street, yesterday morning from the effects of injuries received in falling on the steps of the Mutual Life Insurance Building on Wednesday last.

William H. Shepard, a young man of twenty one, who said he lived at 371 Marcy-avenue, Brooklyn, established a very profitable milk route a month ago, but yesterday he was arrested for stealing his stook in trade. He admitted his guilt and was sent to the penitentiary for 100 days.

Miss Minna Ritter, the daughter of Nathan T. Ritter of 708 Union-street, Brooklyn, is missing from her home, and her parents say she has gone away with an actor named Louis J. Montico. He has been an attraction at a local variety theatre for some time, and whenever he was off the stage Miss Ritter was in his company.

BALTIMORE, Non. 25.--A new skin disease among cattle in Maryland, Pennsylvania, Delaware, and Virginia has recently come under the observation of Dr. Wray, State Veterinarian Surgeon of Maryland.

The shipments of flour, grain, and provisions from Chicago to the seaboard by the lines in the Central Traffic Association last week aggregated 32,182 tons, against 33,089 for the preceding week --a decrease of 907 tons--and against 33,924 for the corresponding week last year--a decrease of 1,742 tons. The Vanderbilt lines carried 50.3 per cent. of the business, the Pennsylvania lines 23.2, the Chicago and Grand Trunk 13, the Baltimore and Ohio 13.5.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Nov. 25.--The ticket agent and baggagemaster of the New-York Central have been at Vassar checking baggage and selling tickets to the students, who will begin to leave the college to-morrow for the annual ...

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25.--Mr. Richard Mansfield was among his friends to-night at the National Theatre, and the throng that filled the house was not warmer in its first greeting of Richard III. before the Tower, marvelously disguised in make up, than it was hoisterous in its appreciation of the later and more stirring scenes of the play.

The picture at the Autumn exhibition of the Academy of Design before which stands the largest number of people is Frederick Remington's "Dash for the Timber." A party of eight prospectors for gold, or perhaps cowboys, with one lead horse carrying a meagre outfit for a camp, are retreating before a band of redskins to the shelter of the woods.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 25.--By the action of Secretary of State Leseuer yesterday, under the provisions of the anti-pool and trust law passed by the last General Assembly of the State, the charters of 700 corporations doing business in Missouri are revoked.

Mr. John H. Starin, the well-known steamboat owner, arrived is the city yesterday morning after a European tour. WASHINGTON, Nov. 25.--The President made the following appointment to-day: United States Marshal.--FRANK HITCHCOCK of Illinois for the Northern District of Illinois.

ASHLAND, Wis., Nov. 25.--Two men and one woman are under arrest for the robbery of the Iron Exchange Bank, at Hurley, Wis., on the night of Sept. 20 last. One of the men is Phelps Perriu, assistant cashier of the bank and son of Leonard Perrin of New-London, Wis., a prominent and wealthy man.

The Washington Memorial Arch Fund is rapidly increasing and now is very near the $61,000 mark. Additional subscriptions from the employes of the Collector's Department in the Custom House, amounting to $148 75, were received yesterday, making the total received to date $60,756 80.

FAIRLAND, Ind., Nov. 25.--A few days ago Mr. and Mrs. Gebhart, living several miles from this place, came to town and found their on in a state of intoxication. They at once notified the saloon keepers not to sell him any more intoxicants. Friday night then came in again and caught their son drinking beer.

Thanksgiving trade in the provision business was brisk yesterday. Wagons blocked Washington-street, and the drivers swore at each other right merrily. The merchants in the poultry line were very well satisfied with their day's work and profits. Thanksgiving's favorite bird, the turkey, was almost at a premium.
