A sale of eighteen horses from P. Lorillard's Rancocas State took place yesterday morning at the Horse Exchange, Fiftieth-street and Broadway. The majority of the animals were yearlings and brought fair prices. Following are the particulars of the sale:

Objects discovered in and near Rome by excavators will henceforth be placed in the Baths of Diocletian, there to form a Museum of Urban Antiquities, while those found in Etruria, Latium, and elsewhere will be placed at the Villa Giulia, on the Flaminian Way beyond the Porto del Popolo, named from the famous art patron, Pope Julius III. This will be called the Museum-without-the-City.

The preposition for the substitution of the present silver certificates in place of the legal tender and national bank notes, and the increase of silver coinage was referred by the action of the Convention of the American Bankers' Association at Kansas City to the Executive Conncil, composed of twenty-one leading bankers, representing eighteen different States.

The Philharmonic Club gave the first concert of its present season at Chickering Hall last evening. The instrumental programme consisted of Brahms's trio, opus 101; Beethoven's "Kreuzer" sonata, for violin and piano, and Bach's concerto No. 4, for violin and two flutes.

The approach of the Thansgiving holiday has ended apparently to make business dull on the Stock Exchange. Many brokers and operators with homes or relatives in New-England quit business two or three days ago to prepare for this holiday, which many more will not end till the week is over.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 26.--The Republican Convention of Elizabeth, held to-night at Collet Hall, nominated for Mayor on the first ballot ex-President of the City Council John C. Rankin, the well-known stationer of New-York.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 26.--The ChronicleTelegraph, a leading Republican journal here, this evening prints a curious story about Senator Quay from its correspondent in Washington. The dispatch says:
The evolution of Charles H. Turner from ice man to Congressman made progress last night in the Sixth Congressional District.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26.--The stipulations in the settlement of the litigation between Herbert C. Ayer and his wife, Harriet Hubbard Ayer, for possession of their daughter, Margaret, were field in court here to-day. Mr. Ayer withdraws his petition for the custody of the child, together with his charges that his wife was a victim of the morphine habit, and Mrs. Ayer in turn renounces any claim for alimony upon Mr. Ayer.

Mr. Booth's familiar performance of Bertuccio, the jester, in "The Fool's Revenge" and Mme. Modjeska's Donna Diana in Westland Marston's dainty comedy of that name may be seen at the Broadway Theatre to-night and on Saturday night.

The attendance yesterday at the Clifton track was a very good one, the weather was bright and clear, but the track was very sloppy. Good fields contested the six events, in which the short horses carried off the honors of the day.
BOSTON, Nov. 26.--The Old Colony Railroad Company stockholders at their meeting to-day elected the old Board of Directors. It was voted to increase the capital stock to $15,000,000.
Wall-street has a growing faith in the reports a long time current that the New-York, Ontario and Western Railroad is likely soon to pass into the control of the Vanderbilts.

The handsome new school building of No. 86, at Ninety-sixth-street and Lexington-avenue, was the scene of an interesting flag presentation and general exercises in the mixed primary and male grammar departments, respectively, yesterday afternoon.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Nov. 26.--A clever swindler has been cheating the farmers in this vicinity out of large sums of money recently. The other day a man who said his name was William Richardson, and who claimed to be an agent for "The Hay Fork and Pump Company" of New-York, went to the farm of William Parker, who lives about a mile from this place. He told his story smoothly and immediately got the farmer's confidence.

The Most Rev. Francisco Satolli, Archbishop of Lepanto, who is in this country on a special mission from the Propaganda, was tendered a reception last evening by the Catholic Club at its West Twenty-seventh-street house. There was a very large gathering of prominent Catholic...
DANVILLE, Va., Nov. 26.--The Federal authorities continue to harass the judges of the Fall election of 1888.

Circulars are being extensively distributed by the Board of Trade and Transportation, calling attention to the resolution adopted at the last meeting of that body, protesting against unjust discrimination by the railroads against shippers of goods from the seaboard to the interior.

The East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia passenger train No. 3 left the track three miles west of Greenville yesterday on a heavy down-grade reverse curve. The engine, postal, express, baggage, first and second class coaches, and two sleepers went off. Engineer Gregg Dunn was thrown under his engine and fatally injured. The express messenger and four passengers were badly hurt. The postal car and contents were destroyed.

Burglars entered the residence of Joseph Leach at New-Rochelle early yesterday morning and carried off some silverware and clothing. The house of Nathaniel Valentine was also entered, the thieves capturing some clothing. They then attempted to break into the Baptist church, but failed.

BERLIN, Nov. 26.--In the Reichstag to-day Herr Richter, commenting upon the dispute regarding the Niger Company, contended that the company levied duties where it had no right to exercise a protectorate. The German companies in East Africa and New-Guinea, he said, similarly erred.

The annual meeting of the Children's Aid Society was held yesterday in the American Exchange National Bank. After the adoption of the annual reports of the Secretary, C. Loring Brace, and the Treasurer, George S. Coe, the following Trustees were elected for the ensuing three years: Robert Hoe, Jr., Howard Potter, E.P. Fabbri, W. Bayard Cutting, and A.B. Stone.

PARIS, Nov. 26.--The Chamber of Deputies has quashed the election of Count Dillon. The election of M. Arnault for Montauban was also declared invalid on the ground that he was elected through clerical pressure.
It became the pleasing privilege of Justice Gorman yesterday to stretch out the strong hand of the law and prevent the spilling of gore on the "field of honor."

The annual report of the Children's Aid Society appears, very appropriately, on the eve of Thanksgiving, which is one of the holidays the existence of which as a day of rejoicing the society alone makes known to thousands of otherwise friendless children. The present report is the thirty-seventh.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 26.--A ghost which at irregular intervals for the past two years has made visitations in the neighborhoeod of Key East has resolved into a very substantial reality.

CITY OF MEXICO, Nov. 26, via Galves on.-- The election of Mr. Whitehouse, Secretary of Legation of the United States at Mexico, to the Secretaryship of the Pan-American Conference, was no surprise to that gentleman.
Wilson Barrett, the well-known English actor, read a paper yesterday afternoon before the New-York Academy of Anthropology on "Acting and the Influence of the Drama."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26.--At the opening of the International Marine Conference to-day amendments were offered to the rules of the road by Delegates Goodrich and Shackford of the United States and Lieut. de Seoane of Spain. They were ordered to be printed.
HIGH POINT, N.C., Nov. 26.--The all-aged pointer stake of the Eastern Field trials was concluded to-day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26.--Secretary Blaine gave a dinner of the delegates to the International Marine Conference at the Normandie to-night. Covers were laid for sixty-two persons, and, besides the delegates and attaches of the conference, there were present Sir Julian Pauncefote, ...

CITY OF MEXICO, Nov. 26, via Galveston.-- Archbishop Labastide, it is reported, has sent to Spain for 500 priests. The wondering people are saying that the venerable Archbishob claims that his native priests are useless. Archbishop Labastide is soon to celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of his ordination to the priesthood, and great preparations are making for an elaborate ceremonial.

"The Senator," the late David D. Lloyd's comedy of American life, finished since the author's death by Sydney Rosenfeld, was successfully produced in Boston on Monday night at the Hollis-Street Theatre by Mr. W.H. Crane and his company. "The Senator," dealing as it does with the political and diplomatic life of Washington, affords the opportunity...
Mr. G.M.L. Sacks, the well-known supporter of amateur athletics, who was stricken with an acute illness while on his way from Chicago to this city, was brought here yesterday morning.

The first of the big steel rifled breech-loading guns manufactured at Watervliet, to which reference was made a short time ago in the reports of Gen. Benet, Chief of Ordnance, and Secretary of War Proctor, was shipped yesterday by rail for New-York.
HAVANA, Nov. 26.--The Civil Governor has issued a decree dissolving the following associations: The Manufacturers' Union, the Artisans' Centre, the Workmen's Circle, and the Abianza Obrera.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 26.--The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Richmond and Danville Railroad Company will be held here Dec. 4. As usual the question of the Presidency of that corporation is exciting considerable interest. Mr. George S. Scott of New-York, the President of the Richmond and Danville, it is...

LONDON, Nov. 26.--A Conservative conference was held at Nottingham to-day. The principal address was made by Lord Salisbury. He said that the views of Mr. Gladstone, looking to the separation of Ireland from Great Britain, were making no headway.

ALBANY, Nov. 26.--New-York City wins its cases against the Third-Avenue Railroad Company, which were to recover lincense on the cars of the company. The opinion in the decision by the Court of Appeals to-day, written by Judge Danforth, is concurred in by all the Judges.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 27.--The city election returns are coming in slowly on account of the close contest. At 1 o'clock the details of the vote from three wards are still lacking.

The second chapter in Mrs. Hanna Bartley southworth's criminal history came to a close yesterday, when Coroner Levy committed her to the City Prison without ball to await the action of the Grand Jury, the Coroner's jury having decided that Stephen Pettus had met his death at her hands on last Friday.

By the most strenuous efforts the Kings County Supervisors yesterday completed the official canvass of the votes cast at the recent election. But they could make totals only of the votes cast for candidates on the State ticket. The rest of the work will not be completed until to-day, and then the whole thing, if no more mistakes are discovered, will be approved.
HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 26.--The Connecticut Association of Civil Engineers and Surveyors has appointed a committee to secure better legislation for inspecting dams and reservoirs.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 26.--There was a large attendance at the races to-day and the track was in fine condition. Most of the favorites were beaten.

Edward A. Newell, dealer in gentlemen's furnishing goods at 859 Broadway, has brought suit in the Supreme Court to enforce the payment of a balance of $710 on a note for $1,200 given by Charles Francis Gilman.

Messrs. Blumenstiel Hirsch, attorneys for a number of the creditors of M. Strauss Son, wholesale dealers in tailors' trimmings, at 508 Broadway and at San Francisco, have obtained several attachments against the firm which were granted by Judge Bookstaver of the Court of Common Pleas.

OTTAWA, Ill., Nov. 26.--The Supreme Court filed a decision in the Chicago Gas Trust case to-day, in which the case was reversed and remanded, and the union of the four gas companies of Chicago, with a view to monopoly, was declared illegal. The opinion was filed by Justice Magruder, and is vigorous and aggressive.

Kelly, the Captain of the Boston team, started for San Francisco last evening. The object of his trip is to secure the signatures of the Boston men who are now playing on the Pacific slope to Brotherhood contracts. The "King," as Kelly is termed, is very popular with his club mates, and it is thought that he can induce even the most stubborn of the men to attach his signature to a Brotherhood contract.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 26.--The following statement in regard to football matters is made public to-day: "The Princeton University football management desire to make public the following official statement in regard to the members of the eleven which played Harvard upon Nov. 16 and will meet Yale on Nov. 28, first, as to their college standing; second, as to their receiving pecuniary compensation.

An evening paper devoted considerable space yesterday to the endeavor to show that even if New-York was selected by Congress as the site for the fair it would be mechanically impossible to construct the necessary buildings in time for a fair in 1892.

Herman Oelrichs, Stanford White, and others interested in the new Madison-Square Garden called on Mayor Grant yesterday to get his permission for the arcade which it is proposed to run around the building, and for which the Legislature has already given permission. The Mayor did not grant the request. He doubted the constitutionality of the legislation on the subject. The petitioners will be given another hearing later on.

For years the regular meetings of the Yonkers Common Council have been called for 8 o'clock in the evening, but it has been the invariable rule for the Aldermen to assemble in the City Clerk's office anywhere from 7:30 to 8:30 o'clock and then go on with committee...

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 26.--A special dispatch from Havana to the Picayune says: "The scarcity of laborers on the plantations of Cuba and the inducements held out by the Government brought a large number of the farming class of people from Spain. They came here with the intention of making this island their future home.
A large number of small popular contributions have been made recently to the fund for the Washington Memorial Arch.
Alexander Graham Bell of Washington is at the Gilsey House.

Many pupils in Grammar School No. 4, at 203 Rivington-street, which has an entrance for girls on Ridge-street, were alarmed at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon by a cry of "Fire!" and the result was a panic, during which 200 pupils rushed precipitately to the street. It is marvelous that no one was injured.

LEECHBURG, Penn., Nov. 26.--A fire broke out in this place this evening and for three hours raged fiercely, destroying a large portion of the business and residence section of the town and entailing a loss of at least $80,000.
Police Captain McCuilagh of the Fifth-street station raided the gambling house at 112 Thirdavenue last night.

CITY OF MEXICO, Nov. 26.--The organization of the great Trust and Loan Company in London for operation here is regarded with much favor, especially as the new company is under the auspices of the River Plate Loan and Trust Company of London, which has been highly successful.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 26.--The Rev. Herman A. Axmann was to-night installed as pastor of the German Presbyterian Church here in place of the Rev. John Rudolph, who has accepted a call to a church in Hoboken. The Rev. Mr. Axmann is a graduate of the Bloomfield Theological Seminary.

JOHN as to the substitution of legaltender coin certificates for United States legal-tender notes and national bank notes. Mr. KNOX'S judgment will carry authority...

The steamship Prins Frederik Hendrik, which arrived yesterday from Port au Prince, brought rumors of further troubles in the republic of Hayti. When the steamer sailed, Nov. 20, it was said that a great many people were dissatisfied with the rule of Hippoltye, and that efforts were being made secretly to put him out of office.

HARTFORD, Nov. 26.--The annual report a the Labor Commissioner of this State, Mr. S. M. Hotchkiss of Hartford, will be awaited with much interest by the advocates of ballot reform. Last year Mr. Hotchkiss devoted a considerable portion of his statement to the subject, not only discussing it at length, but embodying in...

The Brooklyn police and the Pinkerton detectives could discover no trace yesterday of Nicholas Quinn, the clerk of the Brooklyn Jockey Club who ran off with $4,585 belonging to Green B. Morris on Monday.

The recommendation of Gen. SCHOFIELD that hereafter officers should be commissioned generally in the arm of the service to which they belong, instead of in a particular regiment of that arm, is one that has been made before, notably by the late Adjutant Ganeral. Gen. SCHOFIELD...

CHERRY VALLEY, N.Y., Nov. 26.--Steps are being taken to have an analysis made of the new sulphur spring on the Duffie farm, near this village. Lying near by, equidistant from Richfield, Sharon Springs, and Cooperstown, it has long been the ambition of the citizens to have Cherry Valley made a great watering place. Whether this ambition shall be realized will depend upon the report of the scientific gentleman who will make the anaylsis.

The examination in the case of Clara Chester against her alleged husband, George W. Leder er, was continued yesterday before Justice Hogan in the Tombs Court. Lederer was put on the stand. He said that he was twenty-eight years old and lived at 442 West Forty-seventh street.
KEYPORT, N.J., Nov. 26.--Last night at about 8 o'clock Charles Barnes, a coal black negro, rushed into the house of John Flynn, on Frontstreet, near Broadway.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26.--Testimony in the Cronin case to-day was of no particular interest. The State, in rebuttal, introduced a number of witnesses who contradicted the evidence given by witnesses for the defense in several points. They also swore that they would not believe August Salzman, one of the witnesses for the defense, under oath. His reputation was bad.

BOSTON, Nov. 26.--The city of Lynn was visited to-day by the worst fire in her history, and, indeed, the worst in all New-England history, with two exceptions--Portland in 1866 and Boston in 1872. The flames have had almost undisputed sway for nearly ten hours, some fifteen or twenty acres of the heart of the city are a mass of ruins and the, loss is variously estimated at from $5,000,000 to $10,000,000.
Joseph H. Buckridge of 298 Sixth-street, Jersey City, was shot last evening by Patrick McQuaid in the latter's grocery store at the corner of Monmouth and First streets.

Several weeks ago the officers of the Church of the Strangers decided upon a novel scheme of inviting people in all the States in the Union to contribute toward furnishing some of the poor of this city with a Thanksgiving dinner, ...

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26.--After a long consultation with President Corbin and Vice President McLeod this afternoon, the managers of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company decided to modify the course they had been pursuing in regard to the construction of the terminal railway.
The National City Bank of Brooklyn discovered yesterday that it had been cashing forged checks for several days and had lost in the aggregate about $1,200.
Mr. Husted declared thus early that he is for reform with a big R. Nobody can make more trouble among the anti-reformers than he can if he is in earnest.
Congressman Ashbel P. Fitch, ex-Judge Thomas Nelson, Mrs. Mary M. Gurnee, and others will lose some money by a decision rendered by Judge Ingraham in Part IV. of the Supreme Court yesterday.

The Building Trades Club extended its hospitality last night to the members of the Machanics and Builders' Exchange, and the joint organizations listened for nearly two hours to an entertaining talk by William H. Sayward of Boston, Secretary of the National Association...

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 26.--The City Council at its meeting next Wednesday night are going to vote to do away with salaries for the members. Each Councilman now is entitled to $500 per year, and as the board after the next charter election will consist of twenty-four members, the repeal of the salary law will secure a saving of $12,000 a year to the taxpayers.
TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 26.--Major Alexander M. Way and Garret M. Boise of Jersey City were pardoned to-day. Way embezzled from a number of building and loan associations in New-Brunswick.

The probability of a cold Winter has awakened a lively interest in the fur trade. Of all the places where warm outer garments are sold none is more popular than the long-established house of W.H. Hall at 261 and 263 Greenwichstreet.
The programme announced by the New-Jersey Club for Monday will be run off to-day. The admission to the track, including railroad fare, has been reduced to $1. The entries and weights are as follows:

Umbrella handles are getting quaint and grotesque. The most remarkable handles come from Paris. One that I have seen is a model of the wand carried by the jester of Henry IV. of France. Another umbrella had a dagger of oxidized silver for a handle.

Capt. Ponsen of the Netherlands-American steamship P. Caland, which arrived yesterday from Amsterdam, reports that the Nantucket Shoals Lightship has gotten adrift. It was sighted by the P. Caland on Nov. 25 in latitude 40 15' and longitude 69 59'.

The steamship Santiago of the Wilson Line, which left this port for Hull on Nov. 17, was burned at sea two days latter. Her passengers and crew took to the boats, which hovered around the burning vessel during the night of Nov. 19. On the following morning they were picked up by the American ship A.J. Fuller, which brought them to this port.

ALBANY, Nov. 26.--The Court of Appeals today affirmed the order below in The People excel. Thomas C. Platt against Controller Wemple, which is against the relator, Platt. A half hundred forlorn Poles and Russians hung around the closed doors of Susskind Cohen's Canal-street banking and ticket brokerage establishment all day yesterday lamenting the loss of the money they had intrusted to the care of the firm.
RICHMOND, Va. Nov. 26.--The appointment to-day of Col. Otis H. Russell as Postmaster at Richmond was something of a surprise to the politicians here.

LONDON, Nov. 26.--The Pall Mall Gazette publishes a dispatch from Prime Minister Salisbury to the British Minister at Lisbon ordering the latter to protest against the Portuguese proclamation claiming countries north and south of the Zambesi River, in Africa. Lord Salisbury says that Mashonaland, which is a part of the territory referred to in the Portuguese proclamation, is under British protection.

Emma Aumann, a pretty girl of of nineteen, has been missing from her home at 576 Wythe-avenue, Brooklyn, since Saturday, and her mother says she has gone off with an actor known as Harry Ernst.

BOSTON, Nov. 26.--A Herald special, dated San Jose, Costa Rica, Nov. 14, says that Don Ascencion Esquival and Senora Esquival remain at the American Consulate, where they took refuge at the time of the uprising. The principal Esquivalists are leaving for Guatemala.
BOSTON, Nov. 26.--The steamer Lake Superior at Boston to-day from Liverpool brings the noted running horse Sailor Prince, recently purchased by Mr. George Bishop of New-York.

BOSTON, Nov. 26.--A rumor has been current in dry goods circles for some days to the effect that a consolidation of print works is contemplated which will embrace the Manchester at Manchester, N.H.; the Pacific at Lawrence, and the Indian Orchard (Mass) Mill, the consolidated interests to be controlled by British capital. Treasurer Saltonstall of the Pacific Mills was asked yesterday about the report, but would neither confirm nor deny it.
PITTSBURG, Nov. 26.--Ex-Senator Gen. George A. Jenks returned to-day from Washington, whither he had gone to close up matters with the Department of Justice.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26.--The annual report of the General Superintendent of the Life-Saving Service shows the following:

AUBURN, N.Y., Nov. 26.--The Durston-Johnson-Brewster-Smith combination of the Cauyga County Democracy received a severe shock this morning when the news arrived that John F. Agne, the assistant clerk at Auburn Prison, had been appointed clerk to succeed Albert L. Childs, resigned.

LONDON, Nov. 26.--Dispatches received here state that a French mission caravan which arrived at Altoni on Sunday met Stanley at Kilata, and that he was then eight days' march from Bagomoyo. It is stated that Stanley has no ivory in his possession.

There was a large gathering at the Hudson County Jockey Club course yesterday, and although the track was in a very bad condition, being heavy, there were very few scratches. The fields were large and afforded good speculation. Eighteen bookmakers did business, and as four favorites and a strong second choice won they were hit hard on the day.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 26.--Mr. William L. Royall, the counsel for the foreign holders of Virginia bonds, was asked this evening what he thought of the prospects of settling the debt at an early day.
It was an Oldtown teacher who thus entrapped his pupils in the district school: Teacher (upon discovering that the fire needs replenishing)--Which little boy is the strongest in the room?

GAINESVILLE, Texas, Nov. 26.--Between 10 and 11 o'clock last night the south-bound Gulf, Colorado and Santa Fe train, under Conductor Lake, was robbed near Berwyn, a small station in the Chickasaw Nation.

PARIS, Nov. 26.--Tne Banco Nacional of Rio Janeiro telegraphs as follows: "Everything satisfactory. Exchange, 27 . Internal stocks firm."

A communication sent by Capt. John Morrison of 27 South-street reached the hands of the Admiralty in London on Monday, having been sent through the British Consulate in this city. It asks for recompense for the discovery of the remains of the Sir John Franklin party found at Starvation Cove, comprising the skeleton of Lieut. Irving and 124 relics of different sorts.

MEXICO, Nov. 26, via Galveston.--Construction work on the Monterey and Gulf Railway, the New-York enterprise, is going on with great activity, a thousand laborers being employed.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 26.--Three months ago the Metropolitan Trust Company of New-York began an action in the United States Circuit Court of Kansas to foreclose a mortgage of over $25,000,000 on the Chicago, Kansas and Nebraska Railway. All except $2,500,000 of the capital stock of the railway is held by the Rock Island Company.

ALBANY, Nov. 26.--Thomas C. Platt held the office of Quarantine Commissioner unlawfully, to the Court of Appeals held to-day, sustaining the courts below, which ousted him therefrom. Judge Danforth writes the opinion, which is unanimously concurred in.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26.--It is now said that the amount involved in the alleged fraudulent transactions of Fredericksen Co. in connection with which their cashier, Bidgood, was arrested yesterday, will reach $1,000,000.
A meeting of the creditors of M. Brown Co., shirt manufacturers of 40 White-street, was held yesterday at the Metropolitan Hotel.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 26.--The field and staff of the Third Regiment, was inspected last night by Col. D.B. Murphy at the City Armory. Companies C and E, together with the gun detachment of the regiment, were also inspected.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Nov. 26.--In the case of the people of the State of New-York against ex-Alderman Thomas Cleary, indicted for bribery, Ira Shafer, counsel for the defense, ...

President Post and Chief Engineer Greene of the Dock Department were among the interested listeners at the investigation proceedings in the office of the Commissioners of Accounts yesterday. It was announced that after to-day's session the investigation would be suspended until Monday.

DOVER, N.H., Nov. 26.--In the city election to-day for Mayor Benjamin I. Neally, Republican, received 1,200 votes; Aaron Pinkham, Democrat, 908. The Republicans elect seven out of ten Aldermen and fifteen Councilmen.

There was an interesting discussion before the Section of Laryngology and Rhinology of the New-York Academy of Medicine last night concerning the misuses of cocaine. Dr. W.H. Holbrook Curtis read the introductory paper, ...

A jury in the United States Circuit Court, before Judge Lacombe, yesterday, by direction of the court, found that John Bruce Thompson had violated the contract labor law, and he will now have to pay a fine of $1,000.
The Rev. Dr. Edward Beecher, who had one foot cut off in an accident on the Prospect Park and Coney Island Railroad about a year ago, met with another serious accident on Monday.

Medical Director Francis M. Gunnell, ex-Surgeon General of the Navy and recently President of the Medical Examining Board, has been detached from the latter duty, and will Nov. 27 be placed on the retired list of the navy on account of age. This will cause the promotion of Medical Inspector Edward F. Bogert, Surgeon George L. Brush, and Assistant Surgeon John Hancock Hall.

DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 26.--A terrible natural gas explosion occurred here at an early hour this morning, completely demolishing the brick residence of W.S. Hawthorne, Superintendent of Buildings of the Public Schools, killing one...

The New-York Hydraulic Power Supply Company made an application to the Controller and Commissioner of Public Works yesterday for permits to lay pipes to supply hydraulic power. They ask permission to lay ten-inch pipes, with 750-pound pressure, in Church, Baxter, Bayard, Market, Front, and West streets and Broadway.

MASSILLON, Ohio, Nov. 26.--Fifteen years ago H.W. Priest disappeared from his home in England, and a year later news came to his wife of his death. Mrs. Priest and her children drifted to America and settled here. Some years ago the widow became Mrs. Andrew Floriet, and more children came to cheer the household.

The World's Fair Executive Committee met yesterday in its new and handsome quarters in THE TIMES Building. This committee has been enlarged by adding to the list the names of exMayor Hewitt, Alonzo B. Cornell, and W.E.D. Stokes from the Legislative Committee; ...

Justice Cullen, in the Supreme Court Brooklyn, yesterday, refused to grant the stay of proceedings in the Greenwall case. The application was based on the ground that the Sessions Court, not being a court of Oyer and Terminer, had no power to fix a day for the execution of a sentence after the Court of Appeals had decided the case in question. Justice Cullen held that the Sessions Court had jurisdiction.

PARIS, Nov. 26.--A syndicate of sugar manufacturers recently petitioned the Government for authority to correspond directly with the French Consuls abroad for the purpose of obtaining information of interest to the sugar industry. The Cabinet is disposed to favor the request of the petitioners.
At a late hour last night a man was coming along the Broadway side of the Post Office, possessed of a gait which indicated that his progress down town had been considerably hindered by tangle-foot.

The Court of Appeals yesterday decided the case of the people against the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad in favor of the railroad. The case was an appeal from the judgment of the court below, which compelled the railroad company to remove certain sheds they had erected on a pier in the East River, this city, to be used for storing freight.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 26.--The proposition made before the School Board last night to dismantle the Jeff Davis mansion has caused something of a sensation here. On every side opposition is manifested to removing this last remaining conspicuous landmark of the Southern Confederacy.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 26.--The National Silver Convention met at the Exposition Building at 10 o'clock this morning with about 350 delegates in their seats and a large number of spectators, notwithstanding the rain. The great hall was handsomely and appropriately decorated. James Campbell called the convention to order.

Efforts are being made to consolidate the Baltimore and Washington Clubs and place the former in the League. According to the National Agreement the change must be made this month if at all. The scheme has been quietly worked since the Brooklyn, Cincinnati, and Kansas City Clubs seceded, and it now turns out that the visit of Manager Barnie to this city had a great deal to do with it.

THE NEW-YORK TIMES, always honorable and reliable, claims that the article explaining the new ballot system in Massachusetts appeared in that paper originally. The Hartford Times found it in a Boston journal, the diagram being issued by the Dickinson foundry of Boston as it was published in the Times's supplement of Nov. 23. But we cheerfully give THE NEWYORK TIMES due credit for the original explanation of the new system.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 26.--The Ohio Wool Growers' Association held a meeting to-day, with a large attendance. Among those present were David Harpster, President; Columbus Delano, President of the National Growers' Association, and Judge William Lawrence.

The passengers on a Union Elevated train in Brooklyn about 3:30 yesterday afternoon were surprised to see a tall, well-dressed man, about fifty years of age, rise from his seat and after clutching his throat in a fierce effort to tear away his collar, fall in a heap on the floor. The greatest excitement prevailed for a minute.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27.--A rumor was current here to-day that the Sugar Trust had purchased all the domestic molasses sugar in the country, amounting to about 8,000 tons, and that Claus Spreckels was in a bad way.

Henry Gottschalk, a German, forty years old, was found dead in his room at 334 West Thirtysixth-street last evening under circumstances which indicate that he had committed suicide. He was the inventor of a patent instrument for the extermination of vermin.

Another victim is now to be added to the list of those who have gradually done themselves to death by the abuse of that terrible drug, morphine, which is playing havoc in Paris society.
BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 27.--The Harvard Athletic Committee last night voted to recognize no agreements entered into by any Freshman organization without the sanction of the university.

Madden of this city shortly before his death took out an accident insurance policy for $10,000 in the Travelers Insurance Company of Hartford, Conn. LYNN, Mass., Nov. 27.--Never since the great Boston fire of Nov. 9, 1872, has there been seen in New-England such a spectacle of devastation as that Viewed by thousands of sightseers at Lynn to-day. In the path of the conflagration the destruction is complete.

LISBON, Nov. 27.--It is stated that the Portuguese Government Will reply immediately to Lord Salisbury's protest regarding Portugal's claim to countries north and south of the Zambesi River. Portugal justifies her possession on the ground of discovery and exploitation.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 27--John C. Raymond, who was on Saturday convicted of the last ol a long series of arsons, was to-day sentenced by Judge Stewart to the full penalty of the law--ten years at hard labor in State prison.

At the Collegiate Church, at Fifth-avenue and Forth-eighth-street, yesterday afternoon Miss Anna Lydia Worth, daughter of Mrs. Austin Abbott, ant Benson Bennett Sloan, son of Samuel Sloan, were married by the Rev. Dr. William M. Taylor of the Broadway Tabernacle.
There is a long list of events of all kinds to take place to-day, including charities, religious ceremonies, athletic sports, and various other entertainments.
The football players of Yale and Princeton came to this city yesterday, ready to begin their struggle for the championship of the American Intercollegiate Football Association.
The Anawanda Club, affiliated with Tammany, celebrated last night at its rooms, Twentieth-street and Second-avenue, in the Sixteenth District.

ALBANY, Nov. 27.--Gov. Hill has designated Judge Miles Beach, of the Court of Common Pleas, and Judge George L. Ingraham, of the Superior Court of New-York City, to hold Circuit Courts and Special Terms of the Supreme Court in New-York during the year 1890.
As the bells were being rung in the church tower of Olah Ujtalu, in Hungary, the belfrey suddenly fell in. Under it were buried six persons, while four others were struck and badly hurt.

BOSTON, Nov. 27.--The American Wool Reporter will to-morrow publish the two petitions to Congress, with the signatures thus far obtained in favor, respectively, of free wool, and of an ad valorem duty on wool.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27.--Mr. Richard Mansfield has done something more than win the admiration of Washington theatregoers for presenting a superb "Richard Ill." for their enjoyment.

Thompson of the town of Forest have received notice of the death of an uncle of theirs in Birmingham, England, whose estate is worth $4,000,000, to which the Messrs. Another season of grand opera in German began last night at the Metropolitan Opera House under such conditions, meteorologically, as would have made almost any other artistic or business enterprise quail.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 27.--Ensign H.L. Draper, United States Navy, and Miss Edith L. Taylor were married this afternoon at St. Anne's Church of the Rev. W.S. Southgate. Ensign Francis Boughter was best man and the ushers were Lieut. Prince, United States Marine Corps, and Ensigns Decker, Long, and Wells.

ALBANY, Nov. 27.--Quite a number of decisions on important cases were among the number handed down by the Court of Appeals yesterday.
Arthur Ketchum, brokers at 29 Wall-street, yesterday announced their suspension. It was reported that the suspension was due to the defalcations of a clerk, but Mr. Arthur denied that.
The Yonkers police have captured a couple of young candidates for prison stripes in the persons of Abraham Van Boskerck and James Porteous.

TORONTO, Ontario, Nov. 27.--The gale from the southeast which has raged all day is creating sad havoc to shipping on the lake and along the water front. A very heavy sea is rolling and the breakers are the highest ever known to the oldest lake mariners.

Another hearing in the case of William L. Smyth, charged with perjury in connection with the investigation into the affairs of the Dock Department, was held yesterday in the Tombs Police Court before Police Justice Hogan.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 27.--The Germania, a three-masted schooner, went ashore at Long Branch opposite the West End Hotel to-night. She was discovered at 6:15, and word was immediately taken to the Elberon Life-Saving Station, which is a distance of only a quarter of a mile from the scene of the wreck.

The Court of Appeals has handed down a decision holding valid the assignment of Rindskopf Brothers Co., who did a wholesale clothing business at 616 and 618 Broadway. The firm failed in September, 1884, and made an assignment to J.W. Mack.

The Kings County Supervisors yesterday finished the official canvass of the votes cast at the recent election and sent them to Albany. The result on the State ticket was published in THE TIMES yesterday.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 27.--After a sharp fight to-night in the Elizabeth City Council, President Smith, who was threatened with impeachment, managed to save himself by one vote.

There came plenty of excitement to the office of the Westchester Fire Insurance Company yesterday with the advent of a mysterious-looking package found in the morning mail. It was directed to the company, was six inches long by four wide and a half inch thick, and was covered with tinfoil.

Newberry went before the Park Commissioners, at their meeting yesterday, by invitation of Commissinner Gallup, and explained the necesity for further efforts to preserve the Egyptian stone from the effects of this climate.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27.--At the Cathedral of the Holy Name, this morning, Mary A. Devine, daughter of M.A. Devine, was given in marriage to J. William Carberry, a young merchant of Rochester. N.Y. A wedding breakfast and reception followed at Mr. Devine's residence, 361 Ohio-street, and Mr. and Mrs. Carberry left on the afternoon train for Rochester.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27.--Samuel Strong, whose claim against the District has become almost historic, to-day filed a suit against Benjamin F. Butler for $250,000 damages for slander.
Among the sites of archaeological interest in Greece which still remain to be excavated Delphi is considered by all odds the most promising.

LONDON, Nov. 27.--The plan of campaign has collapsed on the Olphert estate in Ireland. Sixty of the tenants have paid in full the amounts due from them, besides the costs of the litigation against them.

The exposure of some swindlers in Chicago who pretended to give mortgages on Western lands ought to excite a feeling of suspicion and to induce vigilance on the part of the Eastern holders of Western mortgages generally.
HELENA, Mon., Nov. 27.--The lock-out still exists. The Senate met this morning at 10 o'clock, but only Republican members responded to the roll call. The Senate then adjourned till Frideay at 8 P.M.

Reuben E. Sammis, the negro who on March 31 last killed his brether, Tobias, in a quarrel at his rooms, 128 West Twenty-seventh-street, and a few days ago pleaded guilty to manslaughter in the first degree, was yesterday sentenced by Judge Brady, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, to fifteen years in State prison.

Mme. Patti and Signor Nicolini sailed from Liverpool yesterday on the White Star steamship Teutonic, and are expected to arrive here on Wednesday next. Mme. Patti will remain in New-York until Dec. 6, when she will start for Chicago over the West Shore Railroad.
James Hope, the noted burglar, was a free man for saveral hours yesterday, but he did not enjoy his freedom especially.

The crew and passengers of the burned steamship Santiago, who were brought into port on Tuesday by the ship A.J. Fuller, were landed yesterday. Capt. Potter reported at the office of his agents, Sanderson Son, and was warmly congratulated upon having saved the lives of the passengers and crew.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 27.--The track was heavy and the weather cloudy and cold here to-day.

At the close of business hours yesterday, in accordance with their usual customs on Thanksgiving Eve, Messrs. Simpson, Crawford Simpson, Sixth-avenue and Nineteench-street, distributed among their employes between 800 and 900 turkeys, aggregating in weight over five tons.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 27.--Even the noble red man, it seems, is equal to putting up jobs. The Senate Committee on Indian Affairs has been in session here this week taking testimony in relation to the claim of Canadian Cayugas to a share is the annuity paid by New-York State to the tribe.
The Ex-New-York Turner Cadets, and organization of young men who have passed the cadet ago, held their eighth annual ball in Turn Hall, on East Fourth-street, last night.

The Ligue des Femmes Socialistes has just lost Mme, Astie de Valsayre, one of its leading members, under curious circumstances. This league was connected with a daily journal which was regarded as its official organ.

The well-known firm of Thomas Cook Son, in conjunction with the Rev. Robert B. Hull, pastor of the Greenwood Baptist Church of Brooklyn, are making arrangements for another excursion to Europe and the Holy Land.

LONDON, Nov. 28.--The steamship Panama, (Fr.,) Capt. Chabot, from New-York Nov. 10, arr. at Bordeaux yesterday.

Naval Officer Willis and Franklin Woodruff returned from Washington yesterday and were delighted over the patronage they had obtained. Woodruff was especially pleased, and said that he could now show that the patronage power had not been taken away from him.
BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 27.--The official figures of the vote at the State election are as follows: For Governor--Brackett, (Rep.,) 127,357; Russell, (Dem.,) 120,482 Blackmer, (Proh.,) 15,108.

The Junior Class of Columbia College held its monthly class meeting yesterday afternoon. The Committdee on the Christmas Ball reported that it would take place on Dec. 20, the Friday evening preceding Chirstmas.

BELLEFONTE, Penn., Nov. 27.--This morning the murdered body of a young girl named Clara B. Pierce was found two miles this side of Karthaus.
HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 27.--The Episcopal churches in this city have completed arrangements for an Advent mission in December, the work beginning on the first Sunday in the month.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 27.--The news that labor organizations had united to boycott the Hon. William L. Scott of Erie created a great deal of interested in industrial circles to-day. It is declared to be the most gigantic boycott scheme ever projected.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 27.--The National Dairy and Food Commissioners' Association of the United States was organized this afternoon by delegates oppointed by the Governors of the several States.
Wall-street had a shaking up yesterday such as it has not known in many a month. Speculators in Chicago Gas Trust stock were responsible for it.
Senator James McMillan of Michigan is at the Windsor Hotel. Peter A.B. Widener of Philadelphia is at the Hoffman House.
The session of the Committee on Revision of the Building Laws yesterday was occupied mainly by ex-superintendent D'Oench, who appeared on behalf of a committee of the Architectural League.

At the Coroner's inquest held at Toronto, Ontario, Tuesday night on the death, of the man who was killed by an engine of the Grand Trunk Railway at a crossing within the city limits the jury found four men who were on the engine at the time guilty of manslaughter, and they are to be arrested. The engine was at the time of the accident running at a greater speed than the law allows.

The announcement that De Wolf Hopper is to be starred next season, under the management of Charles E. Locke, in a comic opera company which is to bear his name, is no surprise to those who have followed the career of the McCaull Opera Company for the last season.

WHEELING, West Va. Nov. 27.--Near Huntington to-day the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad bridge crossing the Guyandotte River fell while a freight train was crossing it, precipitating the entire train into the river, Engineer B. V. Freeman was killed.

The Volunteer Firemen's Association has 1,800 members, $23,000 in the treasury, a rich historical gallery, and a new home. The city provided the headquarters by permission of the State Legislature, and last evening they were opened to the public for the first time.

In the Court of Common Pleas, before Judge Bookstavor, yesterday James Martin was allowed to resign as the assignee of Guy C. Hotchkiss, Field Co., and Donald B. Toucey was substituted for him with a bond of $60,000.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 27.--The heirs of Charles and Margaret Crocker to-day perfected the scheme of forming a regular incorporation, to be known as the Crocker Estate Company.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 27.--At the conclusion of the afternoon session of the Senate committee investigating the Cayuga claims yesterday Senator Pierce of Brooklyn was adopted by the Cayuga Indians as a member of their tribe. The Senator's Indian name, phonetically spelled, is "Hah-Yah-Nay-Shaw-Nace," which means the Island lawmaker.
Louis Winter of 90 Second-street, Hoboken, is at the Gouvernour Hospital in a critical condition. Winter came to this city to find a fight, and was successful.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27.--Mr. De Wolf Hopper, the popular comedian of the McCaull Opera Company, will sever his connection with that organization May 1 next, and four days later the "De Welf Hopper Comic Opera Company" will make its first bow to the public at th Broadway Theatre in NewYork.

The Polopolian Society held its twenty-second annual dinner at the Hotel Brunswick last evening. The society was formed in the Summer of 1867 by thirty young business men of this city who wanted to enjoy a vacation of a little different order from the usual country bearding house sort.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Nov. 27.--Details have about been completed for the construction of a railroad between this city and Williamsport to form a connecting line between the great lines of the East and the West.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27.--The arrangements for the reception of ex-Gov. Gordon of Georgia have been almost completed. The Governor will arrive by special limited train over the Michigan Southern at 9:50 o'clock Saturday morning.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 28.--The Stockinet Mills of the extensive Hartford Carpet Works, at Thompsonville, is on fire. It is on the opposite side of the street from the main works, but the latter are in great danger. A steamer has been sent from this city.

HALIFAX, N.S., Nov. 28.--A report in circulation here this morning that the cable steamer Minia had been lost is probably without foundation, as no news of anything of the kind has been received here. The Minia sailed from London for Halifax ten days ago, and has since been reported at another British port.

The Columbia football players have their interclass championship games to-day at Berkeley Oval. In the morning the Seniors and Juniors will contend for the supremacy, and in the afternoon '92 and '93 will play.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28.--The prospect of a smooth Republican caucus on Saturday looks more probable to-night than at any time since the five candidates for the Speakership appeared here and began to look about for supporters of their pretensions for office.

BOSTON, Nov. 29.--Of course the universal theme in Boston to-day is the big fire and what caused it. The first explanation as to the origin of the disaster still stands, and the electric people have to bear the blame of it all.

WABASH, Ind., Nov. 29.--The first snowstorm of the season came yesterday, the ground being covered to the depth of four inches.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 29.--Carnegie, Phipps Co. are about to give Southern Bessemer pig Iron a trial. Recently 2,000 tons of this material were ordered from a Talladega (Ala,) furnace company, and at the Homestead Steel Works, near Pittsburg, the pig will be given a practical test.

Admiral Gherardi's squadron will sail next Tuesday morning for a cruise in the West Indies. The fleet will comprise the Galena, Kearsarge, and Dolphin. The Galena will be the flagship in spite of the opportunity afforded the Admiral of having a steel cruiser carry his flag.

Col. Simmons is considered the most experienced judge of horse racing in the country, and in few cases have his decisions caused any dissatisfaction. The gallant Colonel, however, broke his record yesterday at Elizabeth when he placed Oregon first in the fourth race.

The statement of the Norfolk and Western Railroad Company shows gross earnings for October, 1889 of $573,314.35, an increase of $106,223.08 as compared with October, 1888; expenses, $327,851.43, an increase of $61,045.23; net earnings, $245,463.12; an increase of $45,177.83. For the ten months ended Oct. 31 the net earnings were $1,718,302.48, an increase of $118,698.86 as compared with the corresponding period of 1888.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 29.--Three city Aldermen and six licensed detectives, who were convicted of conspiring to blackmail proprietors of illegal liquor saloons, were sentenced to-day. Their plan of operations, in prosecuting offenders and then settling the cases for a money consideration, has already been explained in THE TIMES.
Plain words and practical good sense characterize the presentment of the Grand Jury upon the subject of electric wires and subways.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 29.--Trainer James Robinson just arrived in town this evening, and there is no happier nor more popular man in Princeton. Even the urchins follow him along the street and listen to his exclamations of "I told you so!" He claimed that he could have been Mayor of New-York last night if he had so desired.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 29.--Judge Robert B. Trippe entered his office at 8 o'clock this morning and closed the door behind him. A few minutes later the report of a pistol was heard. Judge Trippe was found lying on the floor, partly on his back and partly on his right side.

DENVER, Col., Nov. 29.--The famous Aspen mining suit brought by Judge Rucker against Harvey Young and others, and involving a one-sixth interest of the Aspen mine, as well as one-sixth of four or five millions which have already been taken out, was decided in favor of Judge Rucker this morning.

It is reported that the first demand is for from 7,000,000 to 10,000,000 with which to deal with the disaffected portions of Ireland.
The sixty-third dinner of the Delta Phi Fraternity was held in the Hotel Brunswick last night. Nearly sixty members were entertained.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov. 29.--One of the most disastrous cyclones ever known in the history of North Carolina passed over a portion of Beaufort County yesterday. So far nine persons are reported killed and twenty or thirty badly injured.

The strike of the clothing cutters at the shops of Rogers, Peet Co. of 569 Broadway was continued yesterday. The strike originated in the refusal of the men to increase the number of garments cut with the clothes-cutting machine.

The importance of the decision of the Supreme Court of Illinois in the case of the Chicago Gas Trust is clearly seen when the recent movements of Trustmakers are observed.

James Furman, the negro who cut his way from the prison van in Brooklyn on Tuesday, was captured yesterday at Jamaica, L.I. Three officers from the Seventeenth Precinct of Brook-- lyn weresent after him. A colored man told them that Furman was in a tumble-down shanty in the outskirts of the village.

A number of the Presidents of the Newark savings banks met yesterday with City Controller Connolly in conference on the relations of the city to the banks on the question of the taxation of city bonds held by them.
BERLIN, Nov. 29.--A number of factory hands at Lucken walde have struck. The strike threatens to lead to a riot. The mills are guarded by gendarmes.
Every battery on the Great South Bay was in use Thanksgiving Day, and a number of hunters who had not made previous engagements for them found themselves unable to enjoy the duck shooting.
GAINESVILLE, Texas, Nov. 29.--A party from Ardmore brings information of the arrest of two women in that city charged with being implicated in the recent train robbery on the Santa Fe Road.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 29.--Fire at Burn side Beach last night, twenty miles from here on the Atlantic coast, destroyed the Palmetto Hotel, the Burnside House, and the Beach Pavilion. They were all Summer hotels, and the two last named were unoccupied.

A brick building, 30 by 30 feet in dimensions and 20 feet high, is in course of erection inside the walls of the Sing Sing Prison, to be used exclusively as an electrical execution building under the new law.

The two men who are believed to have swindled the National City Bank of Brooklyn out of over $1,200 on forged checks, purporting to be signed by Clapp Brothers, grocers, of 979 Fulton-street, were captured yesterday afternoon.

Prof. Robert Patterson, one of the editors of the Presbyterian Banner, died at his home in Sewickley, Allegheny County, Penn., yesterday. He was sixty-eight years of age and a graduate of old Jefferson College at Canonsburg, Penn., being a member of the Class of '41.

The body of ex-Congressman Edwin R. Meade, who died of paresis on Thursday in the Ward's Island Insane Asylum, lay in the Morgue last night. It was not known what disposition would be made of it.

Naval Officer Willis, by instructions from Washington, yesterday created a little breeze in his department by making several changes, all of which were unexpected. He reduced John M. Comstock to the auditorship at a salary of $3,000.

Mayor Grant announces that he will be glad to receive communication from all persons favoring or opposing the hand-organ ordinance which was passed by the Aldermen, but which the Mayor has not yet signed. These communications must be sent in before Dec. 6.

Under date of Nov. 16, Rear Admiral Kimberly, in command of the Pacific squadron, has notified the Navy Department that the Iroquois would leave Honolulu for the Samoan Islands, via Gilbert and Marshall Islands. On her arrival at Apia she will relieve the Adams, that vessel returning to Honolulu. The Alert was expected to sail from Honolulu for Mare Island Navy Yard, San Francisco, Nov. 21, with sick men, men under arrest.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 29.--Mr. and Mrs. Kendal produced at Ford's Opera House to-night for the first time in America Sydney Grundy's play, "A White Lie." The play met with much favor. The Kendals' engagement here has been a great success. To-morrow night they end their week with "The Queen's Shilling."

The attendance at the meeting of the Yale Alumni Association at Delmonico's last night was by no means particularly enthusiastic over certain recent events, but those members who summoned up sufficient courage to attend heard the President, Chauncey M. Depew, explain how it all occurred.
The Sixth Congressional District, consisting of the First, Fifth, and Ninth Assembly Districts, will have an election for Congressman all by itself to-day.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29.--Rodney M. Curtis of Binghamton, N.Y., died suddenly in a carriage this morning while driving in Fairmount Park with his wife, to whom he was married on Wednesday last. The couple were on their wedding tour, and intended to proceed to Washington to-day.

LYNN, Mass., Nov. 30.--All is life and activity throughout the devastated district to-day. Nearly every burned-out firm has built temporary quarters. Manufacturers who are heavy losers by the fire are contributing generously to the relief fund.

E.S. Bates, a young law student at Cinninnati, Ohio, from Watertown, Mass., was found dead in his bed at the Geneva Hotel Friday night. He unscrewed the gas burner, attached a paper tube to it, and, applying the tube to his mouth as he lay in bed, breathed the gas until he was unconscious. He was much given to drink and dissipation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1.--The Fifty-first Congress will assemble at noon to-morrow with a prospect of accomplishing an orderly and uneventful organization. In view, however, of the necessary consumption of practically an entire day in the organization of the new House of Representatives, the President's annual message will not be sent to Congress until Tuesday.

AUGUSTA, Me., Dec. 1.--Francis and Margarette, aged twelve and eleven, children of Major O.E. Michaelis of the United States Arsenal, while playing on the ice on an artificial pond on the arsenal grounds to-day, broke through. The girl was drowned, but the boy was saved. Major Michaelis was nearly drowned trying to save his children. He is in a dangerous condition, and inflammation is feared; otherwise he will recover.

DANVILLE, Va., Dec. 1.--A well-attended meeting of citizens was held here yesterday, and resolutions were adopted calling on the City Council to take immediate steps looking to the exemption of all manufacturing enterprises wishing to locate in this city and employing as much as $5,000 capital, where they do not conflict with manufacturing enterprises already established here, from taxation for a period of years.

The monthly bulletin of the New-York State Board of Health for the month of October shows the total number of deaths in this city during the month to be 2,724, representing an annual death rate per 1,000 of 20.38.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 1.--A Scottdale (Penn.) special says: "From what can be learned today, the Callaghan conspiracy case is not yet ended. Mr. Callaghan states that Powderly will be sent for to-morrow and that Byrne and Wise will be rearrested. A new charge will be made, and it is probable that the information will be made before Justice Eicher in a day or two."

Policeman Mahoney found two men fighting in Park-row early yesterday morning and arrested them both. One of the men had been stabbed in the left side below the heart. At Chambers-Street Hospital, where the operation of laparotomy was performed upon him, he gave the name of Micheal Murphy.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 1.--The Anti-Slavery Conference yesterday adopted resoultions in favor of the establishment, by States possessing African territory, of stations with local military forces for the suppression of slavery, the inland stations to be connected with the coast by railways and by steamers on the great lakes; also for the prohibition of trade in firearms in the slave districts, the suppression of cannibalism and human sacrifices, and the protection of commerce and missions.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 1.--A special from Wichita, Kan., says that Alderman Stone, a prominent politician and business man of this city, who disappeared mysteriously some time ago, has been found by his son near Fort Scott, Kan.

George Seitz, aged forty-eight years, a German saloon keeper at Suspension Bridge, while delirious and laboring under the hallucination that he was being pursued by a man with a gun, escaped from his home Saturday night, and yesterday morning his dead body was found on the bank of Niagara River. He fell a distance of thirty feet down an embankment.

BERLIN, Dec. 1.--Count Arco-Valley, the German Minister to the United States, dined to-day with Mr. Phelps, the United States Minister here. He afterward started for London, and will be a passenger on the steamship Trave, which will sail from Southampton Dec. 5 for New-York.

Delegates from the branches of the International Sailors and Firemen's Union in NewYork, Brooklyn, Jersey City, and Hoboken, from the Longshoremen's and the Coal Shovelers' Unions and International Boatmen's Union, met yesterday at 26 Albany-street, and organized a central body under the name of the Maritime Labor Exchange.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Dec. 1.--A committee of business men left here this afternoon for Chicago to confer with Marvin Hughitt and urge upon him the necessity of the Chicago and Northwestern Road building its Moville line into this city and extending it on northwest to a connection with the line from Centreville to Yankton.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 1.--Considerable interest has been aroused hereabout at the attempt of United States Senator Quay to control the course of certain members of the lower house from Western Pennsylvania districts.
