Hooper Sons, the Druid Mills, and the Laurel Mills.

LINCOLN, Neb., Dec. l.--There is a well-defined rumor that the Burlington is actively at work preparing to extend its line from New-Castle, Wyoming, through Wyoming and into Montana to a connection with the Northern Pacific, and that the work of construction will begin early in the Spring.

Members of Company F, Twenty-third Regiment, Brooklyn, were given a chance at their armory on Saturday night to prove their nerve, if not under fire, at least under smoke, and to their presence of mind is due the fact that danger of a panic was averted.

Jeremiah O'Donovan Rossa broke the silence he has been maintaining for a few weeks back at Halcyon Hall in Third avenue last night. Rossa began to talk after half a hundred men and one woman had been seated about the room.

Mrs. Elizabeth Taite, the woman who has proved a bone of contention between the Commissioners of Emigation and the Collector of the Port, will not be sent on to Colorado, as was proposed. Her husband had telegraphed for her to join him there, but on Saturday ...

Both the bracing weather and the clean roads combined to make yesterday an ideal driving day, and it seeemed as if every horse owner in town took advantage of the combination at some time between noon and sunset.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1.--The following is the weather crop bulletin for November, 1889, issued by the Signal Office, Washington, Dec. 1, 1889:

LONDON, Dec. 2.--A Zanzibar dispatch to the London Herald says: "Henry M. Stanley, writing from Wikessl under date of Nov. 26, says that his party are all well and enjoying the luxuries sent by Major Wissmann.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1.--Cheering and shouting to be remembered for a lifetime shook Central Music Hall last night. Nearly 3,000 typical people of a Northern city were applauding a famous Confederate General, who, carried away by the spirit of the moment, was grasping in his hand the Stars ...

Perhaps the most unsatisfactory newspaper work of the whole year to the average reader was the reports in the New-York papers yesterday of the great football game between the Yale and Princeton teams.

William Finnegan, eighteen years old, of 327 East Thirty-first-street, and Daniel Donohue, nineteen years old, of 714 Tenth-avenue, who were found by Policeman Riley of the Twentysecond Precinct in the cellar of 400 West Fiftieth-street with about $200 worth of electrical goods packed and ready for removal, were arraigned before Justice McMahon, in the Yorkville Police Court, yesterday and held in $1,000 bail on a charge of burglary.

LISBON, Dec. 1.--The Portuguese Government will give an imperial welcome to Dom Pedro, the deposed ruler of Brazil. The King will insist that the ex-Emperor take up his residence in one of the royal palaces.
We published yesterday morning a brief account of the reception in the Democratic press of Ohio of the Civil Service Reform bill when it was brought forward by the late Senator PENDLETON.

PARIS, Nov. 16.--The Ambigu Theatre has scored another success, after the very great one of "Roger la Honte." This time the management have neglected all previous inspiration and gone back almost to the ideals of Georges Sand. The career of the Ambigu during the directorship of M. Rochard has been singularly felicitous ...

John Hyland, aged twenty-seven years, residing at 864 Sixth-avenue, was arrested by Policeman Franklin yesterday morning on the charge of assaulting his wife, Mary, with a pair of shears and inflicting a serious wound in the left breast.

There has been great need of a history in English that might give authoritatively, but within resonable limits, a survey of the changes in peoples and governments of that territory which is vaguely known as the Austrian Empire.

The Cunard steamship Etruria, from Liverpool, arrived last evening at Quarantine. John J. Townsend, President of the Union League Club, who was a passenger, was dangerously ill when the vessel arrived. He was taken with pneumonia on Monday last. His wife was on the vessel with him and took care of him. It was thought last night that his chances of recovery were poor.

When the Rev. R. Heber Newton took his All souls' congregation to their new house of worship at Madison-avenue and Sixty-fifth-street he and his Vestrymen little dreamed that that spacious structure might be too small, yet so it proved to be at yesterday's morning service.

Mr. Spurgeon, at the Metropolitan Tabernacle, held it to be treason to keep untried English prisoners in the same place as convicted men and women. But Mr. Cooke, whom he introduced, and who for thirteen years has traveled in various countries visiting the prisons of the world, had on the same occasion to tell of the far more terrible evils which surround the criminals of other countries.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1.--Within the next thirty days the Mackey syndicate will have full control of the Chicago and Eastern Illinois Road. This is significant from the fact that President Mackey has proposed to the "Big Four" people to ...

Full of the impressions won yesterday during a visit to the American Art Galleries, I dreamt last night that I was the owner, the lucky owner, of that collection of masterpieces! I dreamt that I had brought them to show to the New World, beginning with NewYork, and that meanwhile one of my friends ...

A New-York publisher, or rather a gentleman editorially connected with a publishing firm in New-York, told recently this story about a now popular contributor to the magazines. He, with his partners, was seated in their private office one day about six years ago, when a gentleman entered.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1.--The McCaull Opera Com pany has afforded the only sensation of the week on the stage of Chicago, first by giving a popular and attractive representation of "Clover," and then by furnishing rumors ranging all the way from stories of friction in the com pany to the complete collapse of the organization. In previous engagements here the Mc Caull Company has been singularly free from ...

At the Church of the Disciples of Christ, Fifty-sixth-street, near Eighth-avenue, last evening, the Rev. Dr. A.F. Schauffler spoke on "The Moral and Spiritual Needs of New-York." His discourse consisted chiefly of anecdotes of his experience in city missions, which covers about sixteen years.

Hundreds of people stopped in front of Bernard Callan's dry goods store at 675 Eighthavenue, yesterday, to look at the Brush electric light from which came the current which caused the death of Harry Harris, Callan's clerk, on Saturday night.

WASHINGTON, Dec 1.--Frank MacArthur, son of Judge MacArthur of the District Supreme Court, (retired,) jumped from the limited express this afternoon near the Patuxent River, in Maryland, and was instantly killed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1.--The annual report of the Secretary of the Interior begins by calling attention to the several important events that have taken place in his department under the present Administration: The opening of Oklahoma, the successful negotiation of a treaty with the Sioux Indians of Dakota, and the advent into the Union of the four new states, North Dakota, South Dakota, Washington, and Montana.

William H. Everiss, while insane, last night committed suicide in the basement of his parents' home, at 145 Whiton-street, Jersey City. He sent a bullet into his brain. Death was almost instantaneous. Everiss was twentythree years old. He had been sick and despondent for several weeks.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 1.--The steamship Gaelic, which arrived from China and Japan to-day, brings news that the American ship Cheesborough was wrecked Oct. 30 by running on the rocks off Sluchi-Ri-Hama, and nineteen of the crew drowned.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Dec. 1.--As the facts connected with the lynching of the old man, Hans Jacob Olsen, at Preston on Nov. 23, become known a storm of indignation arises. The mob brought the old man out of the house and a rope was put about his neck. He was asked by the mob if he would leave the country ...

From the heated and rather complicated discussion of the dangers of electric lighting, the causes of them and the safeguards possible against them, it seems practicable to disengage a few facts that, though they do not necessarily warrant a conclusion as to the final solution of the question, do indicate a solution.

WILIMINGTON, Del., Dec. 1.--The operations of Delaware's peculiar suffrage laws assumed an entirely new phase yesterday, when a number of Republican party leaders entered the office of the county tax collectors and presented powers of attorney, duly executed by a number ...

Mexican Consul Raden at Kansas City yesterday received formal notification of recent grants and concesssions made by the Mexican Government to the Mexican Continental Railway Company. The company contracts to construct a railway from ...

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 1.--Four smoke-blackened and crumbling wails, towering up above a steaming, smoking, smoldering mass of machinery, brick, and building debris, is all that now remains of the eight-story brick building at the corner of First-avenue South and Fourth street, in which, until to-day ...

The Christian churches in the United States in their organization and equipment are as far apart as they ever were, but in the spirit which animates both clergy and people and in the breaking down of theological differences or barriers they are nearer together than they have been for a century or than any of their adherents imagine them to be.
In 1837 Gov. Hill appointed Thursday, Dec. 7, for Thanksgiving in New-Hampshire, but the next year he appointed it for Thursday, Nov. 29, and issued his proclamation on the 1st day of October.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 1.--This afternoon the edifice known as the Bell-Street Chapel was dedicated with peculiarly interesting services. The chapel was built in 1875 by the late James Eddy, "for the use," as he once told a friend, "of people who desired to worship as their consciences dictated and without having their views restricted by orthodox doctrines."

Mr. Welch, the Superintendent of the Niagara Reservation, does not purpose to lose any time in getting at the work of protecting the shore of Goat Island from further erosion. The plane call for the building of docking and crib-work along the shore for a distance of 1,600 feet.

Among the explanations designed to account for the result of the recent campaign in Ohio there is none more interesting than that which has been made by Mr. BUTTERWORTH, the well-known Republican Congressman who represents one of the Cincinnati districts.

The funeral of Dr. Walter De Forest Day took place yesterday afternoon at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Incarnation, Madisonavenue and Thirty-fifth-street. There was no sermon and pallbearers were dispensed with.
Mr. Donald Downie's illustrated lecture on "Japan," which was given in the Union-Square Theatre last night, was but slimly attended. Nevertheless, it was appreciated by those who heard it.

Dr. McGlynn called together his friends of the Anti-Poverty Society in Copper Union last night, to the number of nearly two thousand, and talked to them on the question whether "a Catholic could be elected President, and if not, why not?". He took as his text the words of Daniel Dougherty before the Catholic centennial in Baltimore, which have already occasioned so much discussion.

ROME, Dec. 1.--In the Chamber of Deputies, the Minister of Finance, presenting the statement on the budget, said he expected the financial position of the Government would be much improved during the coming year. It was estimated that the deficit for 1890-91 would be 21,800,00 lire. It was necessary to ask an extra credit of 40,600,000 lire for railways and defenses.

Prof. Cromwell gave his familiar illustrated lecture on Switzerland before a large audience in the Bijou Theatre last night. The views were all fine, and the spectators manifested their satisfaction in frequent applause. In connection with the illustrations Prof. Cromwell imparted much useful and entertaining information, and made the evening altogether highly enjoyable.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 1.--The first through train on the new Georgia Southern and Florida Railroad from Macon to Lake City arrived here at 9:40 to-night. It left Macon at 10:45 this morning, making the run to Lake City in exaclty eight hours.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 1.--Giuseppe de Lucca, the Italian arrested in this city last night for the murder of Edward Cunningham in Milton on Nov. 21, has made a full confession. His story is practically as given last night.

OTTAWA, Canada., Dec. 1.--The internal political situation of Canada is far from satisfactory. There are signs of a coming dead-lock between the two principal Provinces of the confederation, similar to what occurred about 1863, when no party Government could be formed or maintained satisfactorily both to Upper and Lower Canada.

LONDON, Dec. 1.--Discount was firm during the past week at 4 and 3 . On the Stock Exchange business was quiet. In the foreign department of the market attention was centred on Brazilian securities. Dealings in these shares showed a continued tranquility of feeling, which was assisted by a natural reaction from the depression caused by the change in the Brazilian Government.

There are good reasons for the belief that Gov. Hill of New-York is carefully studyinq up the new ballot system. His private secretary has been in town this week making inquiries into the working of the law in the recent election in this State, and the results of his investigation will be laid before his chief. This ought to be encouraging to New-Yorkers. It indicates that their Governor has his ear to the ground.

Two facts of interst and importance in regard to administrative methods in the Dock Department have been brought out by the investigation now going on which are worth considering calmly, as they are facts which are not disputed.

A more than ordinarily melancholy and deplorable affair was the tragic death of the young lawyer Frank MacArthur, whose suicide by jumping from the Washington express near the Patuxent River in Maryland on Sunday afternoon was reported in yesterday's TIMES. He was the man who jumped into Central Park Lake Monday of last week while out walking with his wife.

The flagship Galena and the Kearsarge of the North Atlantic squadron leave this morning at 9 o'clock on the usual Winter cruise to the southward. The Dolphin was to accompany the squadron, but yesterday the battery of that vessel was found incomplete, so orders were issued to her commanding officer to join the flagship in Haytian waters.

ALBANY, Dec. 2.--The General Term this morning handed down decisions affirming the orders of Justice Edwards in the Troy election cases, the object of which is to compel the Republican inspectors to sign the returns in live wards and the Board of Canvassers to canvass them. The prevailing opinion is written by Justice Landon, and the dissenting one by Justice Fish.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 2.--A Journal Jamestown (N.D.) special says: "A heavy snow fall began last night and still continues. Over four inches have fallen on the level. This is more then fell altogether last winter and is regarded as very promising for the future moistening of the ground."

Collector of Customs Erhardt and the Commissioners of Emigration having laid aside for the time being the cases of the other detained immigrants, have now gone to war over John Gardner, an English carpenter, and his wife and six children.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2.--A preliminary meeting of the National Wool Growers' Association was hold here to-day. Owing to the non-arrival of a large number of delegates, the regular business of the meeting was postponed until tomorrow afternoon, when a large number of the leading wool growers of the country are expected to be present.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2.--The Fifty-first Congress has opened without notable incident on the Senate side, but with a break so surprising and mortifying to the Republicans of the House that the sense of ownership of the lower branch is well-nigh lost in humiliation.

The General Term of the Supreme Court yesterday, in an opinion written by Judge Barrett, set aside the condemnation proceedings instituted by the Metropolitan and New-York Elevated Railroad Companies in several cases in which an appeal had been taken from the order of the Judge below.
At a regular meeting yesterday the Trustees of Columbia College decided that the inauguration of President Seth Low should take place Tuesday evening, Feb. 4, at the Metropolitan Opera House.
The second performance of "The Queen of Sheba" was given at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening before a large and apparently well pleased audience.

The steamship Niagara of the Ward Line, which has been undergoing repairs at the foot of Ninth-street, in the East River, started for the company's dock at the foot of Wallstreet a little after 11 o'clock yesterday morning. She was in tow of two tugs.

KALAMAZOO, Mich., Dec. 2.--Dr. Morris Gibbs walked into the American House this afternoon and coolly placing a pistol at the side of F.E' Michener, fired. A stub book in Michener's side pocket prevented serious results. The doctor tried to shoot again, but was prevented. Dr. Gibbs allegles that Michener induced Mrs. Gibbs to abandon her husband two months ago. Michener denies the charge.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 2.--To-day two men giving their names as Joe Phillips and Jacob Stern, representing themselves as traveling salemen for Stern stern, jewelers, who recently failed to New-York City, were found at the Palace Hotel loading up $30,000 worth of jewelry to remove it to Covington. Deputy Sheriff Cormany, armed with a writ of attachment for $1,000 from Totten Totten of Boston, took charge of the entire lot and is holding it.
The New-York Dispatch, a weekly paper published in this city, was sold at public auction yesterday at the Real Estate Exchange by the receiver, John N. Drake, under an order of the Superior Court.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 2.--Dr. T.K. Cruse of Wappinger's Falls, who is a member of the Dutchess County Medical Society and a surgeon of considerable repute, threatened to kill his wife last Friday.

The Baptist pastors gathered yesterday for their Monday morning conference at the Baptist Tabernacle. The speaker of the morning was the Rev. W. Parker of Newark, N.J., who read a paper on "The Christian Life of the Fourth Century, or; The Triumphant Age of the Church." In closing he pointed out some of the tendencies in the Church of to-day.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2.--Fire broke out about 2:30 o'clock this morning in the three-story brick building at the corner of Second and Huntingdon streets. The basement and first floor were used by Gustave Gross as a bakeshop and store respectively. The second floor was occupied as a dwelling by Gross, his wife, and four children, and on the third floor dwelt Joseph Bitner with his wife and six children.
The Sons of the Revolution held their annual meeting last night, adopted a new constitution, and elected officers for the ensuing year.

Pleasanter weather attracted a fair crowd to the New-Jersey Jockey Club's course yesterday. The track was in excellent condition. Although the programme contained a good list of entries, the sport was tame, the winner, with the exception of the fourth race, having his field beaten at any part of the journey.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 2.--John J. McLean has filed with the State Board of Claims a claim for $11,445, compensation for work performed and materials furnised in completing the channel between Peponic and Shinnscock Bays, in Suffolk County, and also for building an iron bridge over the channel, and in consequence of doing many things not speci fied in the contract.
The sixteenth anniversary of the Reformed Episcopal Church was held last evening at the First Reformed Episcopal Church, Madisonavenue and Fifty-fifth-street.

Wall-street was a centre of grave anxiety yesterday morning. Apprehensions grown out of the panicky stock market of last Friday and Saturday were widespread; practically everybody was in a fright; nobody had the courage to announce much courage or express much hope.

BERLIN, Dec. 2.--During the progress of the trial of Socialists at Elberfeld a police spy named Webber testified that, despite warnings he had received from a Police Commissary, he had furnished statements regarding imaginary meetings and made other false reports concerning the Socialists.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2.--The follwing were among the cases considered by the United States Supreme Court to-day:

Charles Trefz's brewery, on Rankin-street, between South Orange and Springfield avenues, Newark, was partially wrecked yesterday by a remarkable accident. The resting and fermenting departments of the brewery are in a threestory brick building facing on Rankin-street. It contained a score or more of great vats filled with thousands of gallons of beer. All the floors of the building were cooled with ammonia pipes running to an ice machine.

The New-York Press club held its annual election yesterday. There was only one ticket in the field, and the lively scenes which this event usually causes in the Press Club were wholly wanting. Col. John A. Cockerill was reelected President, and the other names on the ticket were: First Vice President--Charles J. Smith...

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 2.--The Appellate Court today affirmed the decision of the lower courts in the noted case of O.T. Garrison against Caroline Lyle of St. Louis, a habeas corpus proceeding to get possession of Lyle Garrison, grandson of Mrs. Lyle. Young Lyle is heir to an immense property, and the fight for his custody has been a long and bitter one. The court ordered him into the keeping of Mrs. Lyle.

VIENNA, Dec. 2.--In Austria a great snowstorm has been raging for thirty-six hours, seriously impeding railway travel Three thousand sweepers and twenty-four snow plows have been unable to clear the tracks in the neighborhood of this city.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 2.--As President of the Service Pension Association of the United States, Gov. Alvin P. Hovey has issued an address entitled, "Soldiers' Rights; and Appeal to the Loyal People of the United States and Their Representatives in Congress."

We recently approached an honored brother for a contribution to a good object. He frankly stated that be did not feel that the object had any claim upon him and that be preferred to give in other lines.

KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 2.--Reports just compiled at the Custom House here for the month of November show a falling off in receipts compared with October of $36,200 and compared with September of nearly $63,000.

Commissioners of Accounts Holahan and Barker and Corporation Counsel Clark yesterday resumed their inquiry into the management of the Dock Department. Among those in attendance were the three Dock Commissioners--Post, Matthews, and Cram, and Chief Engineer Greene. Most of the time Messrs. Cram and Matthews were side by side, and during a half-hour recess Messrs. Post and Greene held a consultation.

The following officers on duty at the Fortress Monroe school of instruction have been ordered to this city from Norfork for the purpose of witnessing the operation of gun making and other professional objects: Capt. John P. Story. Fourth Artillery First Lieuts. P.R. Hill Fifth Artillery; Charles Humphreys, Third Artillery; H.C. Danes, Third Artillery; Medorem Crawford, Jr., Second Artillery; John H. Gifford, Second Artillary: F.S. Harlow...

A responsibility of no small--weight rests upon the Democratic leaders for the next seven or eight months during the session of Congress that began yesterday, for the work of skillful and intelligent opposition is scarcely inferior in difficulty and not at all in consequence to that of the majority.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2.--A sensation was caused in businees circles to-day by the announcement of the embarrassment of Lewis S. Cox Co., who have a large stockinette mill at Eighth and Dauphin streets and a big dry goods store at 1,220 Chestnut-street.
The police were asked yesterday to look for Seaman L. Potter, a milk and butter dealer of 101 Ninth-avenue and 326 West Seventeenthstreet, who disappeared on Friday.

The recently-organized Hudson Democratic Society of Hudson County, N.J., gave a reception at its clubhouse in Jersey City last evening to Governor-elect Leon Abbett. Four hundred invitations were issued, and about three hundred persons were present.

The General Term of the Supreme Court yesterday handed down a decision affirming the decision of the Surrogate denying an application made on behalf of the city to have the executors of Samuel Wood compelled to make an accounting.

President William H. Wiley, in his address at the annual meeting of St. John's Guild, held at 21 University-place last evening, said that during last Summer 30,056 sick children and mothers were carried on free fresh-air excursions, all being supplied with nourishing food and the requisite medical attendance, and 1,573 sick children and mothers received hospital care at the Seaside Hospital at Now-Dorp, S.I.

The dispute between T.J. Keveney Co. of 329 Broadway and the Customs Department over the appraisal of several consignments of linoleum made by General Appraiser Donald McLean and a merchant appraiser said to be interested in the American Linoleum Company of Staten Island, will probably result in a suit against the Government.
WASHIGTON, Dec. 2.--At the session of the Pan-American Conference to-day the consideration of the report of the Committee on Rules was resumed.

While crossing Broadway at Thirty-firststreet last night Benjamin Lent, who lives at the Gedney House, and Mrs. W.H. Noble of Mamaroneck, N.Y., who is stopping at a hotel here, were knocked down by cab No. 991.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 2.--The village of Tarroh, in Barron County, Wis., is excited over the confession made by a man known as "Old Peck," who is now an inmate of the county poorhouse. Peck has been very sick, and a few days ago, thinking he was about to die, called the Almshouse Superintendent to him and announced that he wished to make a confession of murder.
United States Marshal Stafford of Brooklyn was very indignant yesterday over charges made in a morning newspaper that he had been exacting exorbitant fees from ship owners.

One of the decisions handed down yesterday by the Supreme Court at Washington recalls the history of the star-route frauds, and is peculiarly interesting, because by it the Government has at last established its right to recover money wrongfully paid to the ring contractors for "expedition" and increase of service.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 2.--The Baltimore and Ohio and the Pennsylvania Railroads are at variance concerning rates from Pittsburg to Baltimore and Washington. When the Trunk Line Association meets in New-York to-morrow the Pennsylvania will enter complaint against its rival for cutting the rate from $9 to $8 without the customary ten days' notice.

If the assembly of well-known ladies at the laying of the cornerstone of the new Women's Lodging House, 14 East Sixteenth-street, was significant yesterday, it meant that Mrs. Elliott F. Shepard's generosity in providing the funds which make the worthy charity possible will have ample support when the structure is completed.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2.--It is reported on apparently good authoriy that the new Iowa and Nebraska Railroad, recently chartered, is a project of the Rock Island to shorten its route to Denver and to help it regain some of the business which it is losing by reason of combined competition.
ALBANY, Dec. 2.--In the First Division of the Court of Appeals to-day the following business was transacted:

William Jones and his wife of England are making a tour of the world, advocating the settlement of international troubles by arbitration. They are members of the Society of Friends. Mr. Jones was a Commissioner of the war victims' fund during the France-German war.

Money loaned as high as 20 per cent. on the New-York Stock Exchange yesterday. There were loans made at much lower rates, but even at the close of business, when most wants were presumably supplied, a 10 per cent. rate prevailed.

Yesterday was ladies' day at the Fencers' Club, and the long parlors of the clubhouse at 19 West Twenty-fourth-street were filled with fair spectators who sat on each side of the platform on which the fencers met in contest. Prominent among them were Mrs. Grover Cleveland and her mother, Mrs. Perrine.
LONDON, Dec. 2.--The meetings of the Liberal Federation began in Manchester to-day. Mr. Gladstone was present and delivered an address in Free Trade Hall.

The Mellor Rittenhouse Company, manufacturers of drugs and chemicals, 218 North Twenty-second-street Philadelphia made an assignment yesterday to Francis W. Raiston. The company was organized in 1886 with a capital of $200,000. It was engaged principally in the manufacture and sale of licorice, and the failure is said to be due to the low price of that article prevailing during the past few years.

"Kajanka" is a novelty only in name. All that is in it has been seen in other pantomimes, but the culling by the author, Mr. George D. Melville, has been judicious, and what he offers is good, old-fashioned Christmas fun for the children end agreeable pastime for older folk.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 2.--The Middlesex County Teachers' Institute opened here to-day. All the teachers of the county were present, as the schools are closed during the sessions and the attendance of teachers is compulsory.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 2.--The Surpreme Court to-day, by a vote of 3 to 2, set aside the verdict in the case of Etienne De Champs, a French mesmerist, found guilty of the murder of Juliet Deitch his young subject, by an application of chloroform.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 2.--Grace Episcopal Church of this city has received a substantial and welcome gift from Mrs. Elizabeth Dean of London, England, who has presented to the congregation six valuable building lots which she owns at Elizabethport as a site for a new church and rectory.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2.--A dispatch to the Maritime Exchange from Lewes, Del., says the ship Germanic is quarantined there on account of a death from Asiatic cholera soon after she sailed from Cebu last July. There has been no sickness on board since.

DANVILLE, Va., Dec. 2.--The sales of leaf tobacco at auction at warehouses in this market during the month of November amounted to 3,826,884 pounds, more than double the sales for November last year. For the first two months of the present tobacco year the increase of leaf tobacco sold over the same period last year is 3,785,875 pounds.

Mr. Hoyt's clever farce, "A Brass Monkey," burnished up somewhat, amused a large audience at the Bijon Theatre last evening with its antics. The buildog "Handsome," as the Mascot, acted his part with his usual tenacity and solemnity, and at times made persons in the body of the house glad they were not on the stage.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2.--Today's bond offerings accepted were as follows; coupon 4s, $10,000 and $300 at 127. Registered 4s, $200,000 and $21,000 at 127: registered 4 s, $6,000 and $8,000 at 104 5/8 Coupon 4 s, $500 at 101 5/8.

CITY OF MEXICO, Dec. 2.--via Galveston.-- The Pedagogic Congress had its first session on Sunday night, and was opened brilliantly in the presence of President Diaz, whose health is improved. The incident of the occasion was the speech of Senor Baranda, the Minister of Justice.

Coroner Messemer, assisted by Deputy Coroners Donlin and Jenkins and several other physicians, yesterday made an autopsy on the ody of Harry Harris, who was killed by an electric shock on Saturday evening while helping ...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2.--Mr. George T. Williams of the Chicago Stock Yards appeared before Senator Vest's committee this morning. He was asked if he knew of any arrangement reapecting rates having been made by a stockholder of the Stock Yards Company who was also an officer of any railroad.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2.--By a decision of Judge Garnett, in the Appellate Court, the Traders' Bank loses upward of $25,000. When the bank failed that amount of money was held to its credit by the banks in New-York.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 2.--The New-Orleans Cotton Exchange statement issued to-day makes the net overland movement across the Ohio, Mississippi, and Potomac Rivers to Northern American and Canadian mills for the week ending Nov. 29 inclusive, 40,439, against 49,449 for the corresponding week last year, and the total since Sept 1,323,991, against 410,398.

The Hudosn County Jockey Club have a programme for to-day made up with both quantity and quality. The renewal of the Okolona Handicap is the feature of the afternoon's sport, and as a good list of horses has accepted the weights an exciting contest should result. The entries are as follows:

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 2.--Judge Henry made the injunction in the case of D.B. Morrison against the City Auditor, the City Controller, and the City Treasurer perpetual this morning. Morrison sought an injunction to restrain the officers mentioned from drawing warrants for and paying bills amounting to $994, being the expenses incurred in entertaining the delegates to the Pan-American Congress while in this city.

The members of the Brotherhood are making preparations for any move that may be made by the League magnates. It leaked out yesterday that it is the intention of the League men to test the legality of the reserve rule either in this city or in Philadelphia within a few days.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Dec. 2.--The still smoking ruins of the burned Tribune Building were visited by crowds of the curious this morning, among whom were a few mourning friends of the victims.

The Young Men's Democratic Club had its annual election of officers yesterday, and the result was announced at the regular weekly meeting of the organization last night at the Hoffman House. There was but one ticket, and this was headed by President J.H.V. Arnold. Following is a full list of the officers:

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 2.--The civil service reform promised by President Harrison has proved the shallowest sort of a pretense so tar as Connecticut is concerned. With only one exception, that of National Bank Examiner, is there a Government appointment here of any special moment retained by a Democrat appointed under President Cleveland.

GLASGOW, Dec. 2.--Mr. Balfour, the Chief Secretary for Ireland, in his speech here to-day set forth the ideas of the Government on the subject of a proposed Irish college. He proposes that Government aid shall be given to a Catholic college in which the regular curriculum shall be given, including the classics and mathematics, but that the Government shall not endow any institution for teaching theology in Ireland.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Dec 2.--The lass permits of the season to boatmen have been issued by the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company. Canallers have had a successful season between this port and Honesdale, Penn., in instances as many as fourteen round trips having been made.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2.--When the International Marine Conference met this morning the reports of the committees on the subject of uniform load marks, the establishment of a permanent international marine commission, and General Division 3 were submitted.

The matinee concert given by d'Albert and Sarasate at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon was an entertainment--if it may be so termed--that will not soon be forgotten. Genuine music lovers in the audience were interested in the afternoon's work because they were eager to hear how d'Albert would...

The various contractors who recently put in bids for the construction of the extension of the Brooklyn water works system to Massapequa Pond--a job that is to cost $4,500,000-- were agitated yesterday over a request, sent by City Works Commissioner Adams, to the Common Council for permission to award the contracts to other than the lowest bidders. The permission was granted, fifteen Aldermen voting affirmatively and two being excused.

It would seem that the Knights of Labor had received another defeat in the present strike of the glassblowers. They declared last Summer, at a meeting held at Atlantic City, N.J., that hereafter they would demand a reduction in the proportion of apprentices employed as well as require an increase in the rate of pay.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 2.--The Directors of the Empire State Fire Insurance Company of this city to-day declared an assessment of 50 per cent., and called a meeting of stockholders. It lost between $20,000 and $25,000 by the Lynn fire. The company's intention is to pay all claims in full, establish a surplus of $50,000, and continue in business.

The Kings County Democratic General Committee met last night at the Athenaeum in Atlantic-avenue, Brooklyn, and fixed upon Monday neat as the date for primaries for the election of delegates to the General Committee of 1890. Charges of treachery were presented against William Rafferty and Thomas Cook of the Thirteenth Ward, in that they had knifed Anson Ferguson, one of the Democratic candidates for Alderman at Large. The charges were referred to the Discipline Committee.
An interesting exposition of Burman curios will be given in Hardman Hall, Fifth-avenue and Nineteenth-street, to-day, to-morrow, and Thursday.
PITTSBURG, Dec. 2.--In view of the recent calamities at Lynn, Boston, and Minneapolis the Pittsburg Fire Department has taken extra precautions to prevent similar disaster here.
HALIFAX, N.S., Dec. 2.--Prince Victor Dhuleep Singh authorizes an emphatic contradiction of his reported engagement to Miss Jeanne Turnure of New-York.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2.--The names of the sailors lost by the sinking of the American ship Cheesbrough off the coast of Japan follow:

At the Champer of Commerce the books of the World's Fair Finance Committee still fail to show that $5,000,000 has been pledged to the guarantee fund. The total of the day's receipts up to 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon was $98,914, and it included the New-York, NewHaven and Harftord Railroad Company's...
FRANKLIN, Ky., Dec 2.--Ewing Watterson, son of the Hon. Henry Watterson, editor of the Courier-Journal, eloped Saturday evening with Miss Jennie Black, daughter of Thomas Black of McMinnville, Tenn.

Letters poured into the Mayor's office yesterday, giving his Honor much advice about the organ-grinding and street-band ordinance. These letters were on every style of letter paper and in every style of spelling.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., Dec. 2.--A large crowd of enthusiastic gunners were present at the opening shoot of the Central Club at Long Branch to-day. All matches were shot at blue rock clay pigeons.
Nothing that Mr. Wyndham and his company have done during their engagement at Palmer's Theatre has pleased the spectators nearly so much as their performance of "Trying It On" last evening.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 2.--The jury in the Navassa case brought in a verdict this morning. They find George S. Key guilty of murder in the first degree; Moses Williams, alias Dakot, not guilty, and not agreed as to the other sixteen prisoners. This verdict does not release the sixteen for trial on other indictments. Key has appealed.

A meeting of the New-York Yacht Club has been called for Tuesday Dec. 10, at which time the proposed changes in the measurement and classification of yachts for racing will be voted upon again. The men working for the movement are doing some lively husting, and as they are opposing Designer Edward Burgess of Boston and a number of leading racing yachtsmen, an interesting time is expected when the meeting occurs.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Dec. 2.--At the opening of the adjourned session of the Ulster Crcuit Court and Court of Oyer and Terminer, this afternoon, Attorney D.W. Sparling state to Judge Ingalls that he appeared for D.M. De Witt...
LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 2.--The Setter Derby of the Central Field Trial Club was commenced to-day. The weather was fine and birds fairly plentiful.

LISBON, Dec. 2.--It is semi-officially denied that there is any agitation in Portugal, arising from the revolution in Brazil, looking to the establishment of a republic. The paper making the announcement says that the Republican groups in this city and in Oporto confine their actions to a theoretical propaganda. The monarchist press considers the Government too tolerant even in this respect.

The Washington Memorial Arch fund was increased yesterday by contributions from exGov. George Hoadly of $100, and from officers and members of the First Battery of Artillery, N.G.S.N.Y., as follows: Capt. Louis Wendel...

ALBANY, Dec. 2.--Secretary H.M. Thompson appeared before the State Railroad Commission this afternoon and made application for permission to increase the capital of the Brooklyn City Railroad from $3,200,000 to $6,000,000 for the purpose of paying for a number of Brooklyn roads recently incorporated in the Brooklyn City Railroad's system.

Messrs. Barry and Fay revived "Irish Aristocracy" last night at the Park Theatre, and their friends were present in goodly numbers to enjoy it. The old piece is familiar as one of their best, but it seems to wear well. Of course Mr. Fay was Muldoon and Mr. Barry the inebriated Mulcahey.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2.--The annual report of the United States Civil Service Commission for the period covered between July 1, 1888, and June 30, 1889, which has just been made to the President, is appended:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2.--Secretary Windom today transmitted to Congress the estimates of appropriations required for the service of the fiscal year ending June 30, 1891, as follows:

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 2.--At Bruce Kidd's combination sale of thoroughbreds here to-day fifty-five sold for $17,880, which is an average of $313. All save sixteen were yearlings, the others two years old.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Dec. 2.--Gov. Hill has accorded permission to the old Senate House Society to take possession of and to occupy the Senate House here. A room will be fitted up wherein the society will meet. Antique articles will be collected and placed in the historic old stone structure.

A last attempt to save John Greenwall from being hanged for the murder of Lyman S. Weeks was made yesterday by ex-Judge Dailey, and it failed. The counsel moved before Judge Moore, in the Sessions Court, Brooklyn, for a new trial on the ground of newly-discovered evidence.

Judge Patterson in the Supreme Court yesterday signed a decree granting John J. Plunkett an absolute divorce from his wife, Mary H. Plunkett. Mrs. Plunkett is the believer in Christian Science who on May 8 last, at 13 West Forty-second-street, went through a ceremony with A. Bentley Worthington which the...

Judge Decker of the District Court at Denver, Col., yesterday sentenced ex-Lieutenant of Police James Connor and James Marshal of Kansas City to two years in jail and a fine of $1,000 each. Charles Connors received a sentence of one year and a fine of $500. The men wer recently convicted of a conspiracy to rob the Rio Grande express train last April.

Signor Commendatore Francisco Tamagno, the great Italian opera tenor, arrived here yesterday on the steamship La Champagne. He took a hasty glimpse of the city, and in the afternoon occupied a box at the Metropolitan Opera House and listened to the Sarasated'Albert concert.

Mrs. Bernard Gilday, widow of the variety actor who died and was buried at sea while on his way to New-York about three months ago, was camplainant in the Tombs Police Court yesterday against Mrs. Margaret Berrell, a matronly-looking woman of about fifty years. Mrs. Gilday was on her way to New-York from Boston, on the fall River boat, and made the acquaintance of Mrs. Berrell on board.
Savarino Radovitch, an Austrian sailor, aged fifty years, was stabbed in the back last evening in a boarding house kept by Edward Rode, at 338 Pearl-street, by a Malay sailor named Joseph Tavarro.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 2.--It took the Presbytery of Buffalo two days to talk on the revision of the Westminster Confession, and when it made up its mind it surprised the people. A committee had reported against the revision, but the Presbytery rejected the report, and by a strong vote decided that revision was necessary and desirable. A committee was appointed to indicate in what particulars the creed should be revised.

Mr. DAVID M. KEY, sometime Postmaster General of the United States and at present a Judge of the United States District Court, somehow failed to impress himself upon the country, during his brief appearance upon the stage of national politics, as a very wise statesman.

ALBANY, Dec. 2.--A new State bank is being organized. It will be known as the Harlem River Bank of the City of New-York, and will be located on Third-avenue, near One Hundred and Tenth-street, in New-York City.

Presbyterians of every shade of tenet, churchmen and laity, assembled in the most amicable union in the Assembly Rooms of the Metropolitan Opera House last night, and to the strains of Lander's orchestra within and the echoes of the "Queen of Sheba" from the great auditorium of the building, considered the revision of the Confession of Faith under the most auspicious circumstances.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 2.--An exciting charter election is anticipated here to-morrow, and both parties to-night are doing some lively hustling for votes. The most disgraceful feature of the contest is the reckless use of "boodle" by the Republican leaders. Thousands of dollars are being poured into the strong Democratic wards to buy up the purchasable vote.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2.--About eighty or ninety gentlement, including practically the entire Illinois delegation in Congress and many representative business men of Chicago, held a meeting here this evening for the purpose of advancing the World's Fair project.

The total number of paying visitors to the exhibition was 25,000,000, as compared with 12,000,000 in 1878, and 8,000,000 is 1867. Of the 30,000,000 tickets issued, 28,000,000 have been utilized. The theatre receipts during the exhibition have been the largest on record, and the railways have also profited.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 2.--The Baltimore Belt Railroad Company, about whose plans for a Howard-street tunnel and other developments there has of late been much speculation, is so far advanced with its work as to be ready to shortly lay the matter before the public.

WHEELING, West Va., Dec. 2.--The long-talkedof extension of the Norfolk and Western Railroad from the present terminus of the line through the rich timber and mineral counties of Wayne, Logan, and McDowell to and across the Ohio River to a connection with western lines at Ironton, Ohio, is assured, and work will be begun within a very short time.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 2.--Prof. Baptiste Peynaude, the aerial diver, who was badly injured on Friday night while diving from the tower at Farantas, died this morning. Peynaude was born at Marseilles, France, and had followed his profession about twelve years without meeting with any serious accidents. He came to this country about a year ago and successfully performed at Montreal, Ottawa, Rockaway Beach, and Trenton.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 2.--The annual banquet of the New-York City Club of Yale College was held at Redcliff's to-night. R.W. Fairfax Harrison acted as toast master. This club bas nearly one hundred and fifty members. Its officers are: President--R. F. Harrison. '90: Vice President--W.F. Judson. '90, S.: Executive Committee--Grosvernor Atterbury, '9l; W. Adams, '91, S.; W.C. Ivison, '92; Thomas Denny, J., '92, S.; S.B. Ives, '93.
BOSTON, Dec. 2.--The Boston Merchants' Association announces the acceptance of an invitation to speak at its annual banquet at Hotel Vendome on Thursday, Dec. 21, by ex-President Cleveland.
The recent statement issued by the Chilian Bureau of Statistics in Santiago gives the population of the republic as 2,665,926. The Indian population is estimated at 50,000.
Word was received at the offices of the Staten Island Rapid Transit Company yesterday of the burning at sea of the transfer boat Groton, which was being sent by them to Baltimore.

BOSTON, Dec. 2.--The scenes on the burned district this afternoon were mainly a re-enactment of those of the past two days. Crowds of people filled with curiosity still hung about the lines, keeping the policemen busy in restraining the too adventurous and forward ones. Passing by the ruins was still more or less dangerous on Chauncy, Bedford, and Kingston streets, although...

LONDON, Dec. 2.--Judge Cracknell of the Consular Court at Zanzibar will sail for Bagamoyo to-morrow on the British man-of-war Turquoise to meet Stanley and Emin Bey in his official character and to accompany them to England.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 3.--The Harvard football eleven held a meeting last night at which Cumnock was unanimously re-elected Captain.

Architect Kimball submitted yesterday in written detail to the Board of Building Examiners the views which he had previously given informally in regard to proposed changes in the section of the building laws relating to theatres...

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 2.--A meeting of the creditors of George Frost Sons, silk throwsters, was held this afternoon at the mill in Paterson. A statement was laid before the meeting from which it appeared that the liabilities of the firm amounted to $209,500.
CHICAGO, Dec. 2.--Lawyer Edwin A. Corbin of this city has about completed a deal whereby the great plant of the Michigan Stove Company of Detroit may pass into the hands of an English syndicate.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 2--Visitors to New-Orleans in the past thirty years have been shown, as one of the attractions of the city, the Burnside mansion on Washington-street. This building, occupying a square of ground, was erected at great expense by the famous millionaire banker, James Robb, at the time of the marriage...
About a month ago a few residents of Cranford, N.J., started the idea of establishing a family club for the purpose of bringing together the inhabitants in social intercourse.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 2.--Last evening the Rev. J.T. McCrory of the Third United Presbyterian Church preached on "The Roman Catholic methods of saving the soul contrasted with the simplicity of faith in Jesus Christ." During the course of his sermon he made the assertion that Father Sheedy sold indulgences at prices ranging from $2 to $10, and had special privileges from the Pope.

Mme. Albani, the famous singer, came ashore from the steamship Etruria yesterday morning, and, accompanied by her husband, Mr. Ernest Gye, went directly to the Fifth-Avenue Hotel, where she will remain until to-night.
The annoyances which the excavations along Broadway have recently caused, not alone to persons who were compelled to use the horse cars as means of transportation, but to pedestrians,...

Vice President Reinhart of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe confirms as accurate the published statement that the adoption of the reorganization plan precludes the payment of the Dec. 1 coupons of the Chicago, Kansas and Western first mortgage fives and the Atchison collateral trust sixes.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 2.--To-day, in the United States Circuit Court, Judge Brewer began the hearing of motions in the famous foreclosure suits against the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railway Company, in which about thirty million dollars is involved.
The United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners held a meeting last evening at Clarendon Hail to agitate for eight hours' work a day, and for an increase in wages.

A dispatch from Baltimore was published yesterday in which the statement was made that a great syndicate, with headquarters in this city, was being formed to buy up all the heavy cotton-duck mills of this country and to control the production with a capitalization of from $15,000,000 to $18,000,000.
BORN.--At midnight on Sunday last, in the Central Park Zoo, a baby to Mrs. Fatima and Mr. Caliph Murphy, the well-known and popular hippopotami.

There was a radical change of bill at Dockstader's last evening, a transition from black to white. It seems now that there must be something entirely new in minstreisy each season, in order than an exacting public may be pleased, and Mr. Dockstader proposes to keep abreast with the times.
At the regular monthly meeting of the NewYork Academy of Anthropology yesterday aft ernoon, held at 9 University-place, Mr. J.W. Keller read a paper on "Journalism as it Affects the Journalist."

The Mazeeke das Israelle (strength of Israel) a benevolent and charitable society has been incorporated to exist in New-York City, with these Trustees: President--Shapse Nickelberg; VicePresident--Israel Z. Steinberg; Secretary--Joshua Rothstein; Treasurer--Israel Kupper; Trustees-- Benjamin Hershman, Moses Jacobson, and Solomon Simon.

A Children's Christmas Bazaar, at which all sorts of articles suitable for holiday presents for the little ones will be on sale, will be held in the Sunday school room of Transfiguration Chapel in West Sixty-ninth-street, near the...
The idea of bringing into use the electric search light for the determination of a vessel's position during a fog is being developed by the Huntington Electric Light Company of this city.
Many additions were made yesterday to Mayor Grant's collection of letters of advice on the organ-grinding ordinance and the playing of street bands.

CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 3.--The Supreme Court today overruled the exceptions in the case of James Palmer, the Portsmouth murderer. Palmer was to have been hanged to-day, but had been granted a respite by the Governor until Jan. 10, at which time he will be executed unless further clemency interposes.
The trial of Shihiok Jugigo for the murder of Mulock Comi Contani, a fellow-Japanese sailor, was begun yesterday in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, before Judge Brady.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 3.--Ex-Speaker Marsh of Mercer County was in Columbus a few days ago, and in conversation on the question of the Senatorship talked in an entertaining manner...

Messrs. J.S. Conover Co., having remodeled and decorated their warerooms, at 28 and 30 West Twenty-third-street, held a special opening yesterday, when they exhibited one of the most elegant art stores in the city, and at the same time displayed a great assortment of novelties and standard goods.
A number of Hudson County Democrats met at Democratic Headquarters, 310 Grove-street, Jersey City, last evening, to arrange for the inauguration of Gov. Abbett at Trenton next month.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 3.--The representatives of a number of concerns which manufacture oil-well supplies exclusively held a conference here to-day.

A number of gentlemen of this city who have been in the of habit of holding a jollification each December for the express purpose of "putting Mother Earth to sleep" until the following Spring, composed her to slumber last evening with a collation, libation, and incantation at Morello's.
A very pretty church fair was opened yesterday at the Metropolitan Opera House Assembly Rooms in aid of the building fund of the Church of the Redeemer.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 3.--The Minister of Customs has received a further communication from the Board of Trade at Victoria, B.C., in reference to the recent order of the department instructing Collectors to enforce the Canadian coasting laws.
PARA, Nov. 21.--The news of the proclamation of the republic in Rio de Janeiro was received here with great calmness and with apparently little interruption to business.
PARIS, Dec. 3.--A dispatch from Cairo states that the Egyptian Government has received a dispatch from Zanzibar, signed Emin Pasha, requesting that a vessel be placed at his disposal at Zanzibar.

BOSTON, Dec. 3.--Municipal elections were held to-day in nineteen cities of the Commonwealth, in most cases the vote being light on account of threatening weather.
PARIS, Dec. 3.--Mr. Whitelaw Reid, the American Minister, and Mrs. Reid have gone to the South of France. They will also visit Rome. They will be absent from Paris for a month.
The London Gaiety Company will begin its engagement at the Broadway Theatre, under the management of Henry E. Abbey, next Tuesday evening, presenting "Faust Up to Date."

There was a stubborn blaze in the fourth floor of the five-story iron building numbered 542 and 544 Broadway at 7:40 o'clock last evening. This floor was occupied by Louis Kaelter, fur manufacturer, who suffered $1,000 loss.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 3.--Baron F.E. Von Sucrow, who married Miss Constable of Baltimore, has written a letter of complaint from NewYork to Mayor Davidson, the new Mayor.
KINGSTON, Dec. 3.--The demand of the Democrats for a general registration law in all the counties of the State should not be confounded with the annual personal registry which obtains...

COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 3.--Capt. J. Drake, a prominent farmer of Marlborough County, this State, has gathered the phenomenal yield of 254 bushels and 40 pounds of corn from one acre. This beats the world's record.
The trunk line Presidents met yesterday and conferred with Chairman Blanchard and other representatives of the Central Traffic Association and with some officials of the New-England roads.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3.--There were some important developments to-day in the surprising failure of Lewis S. Cox Co. beyond the action of the Sheriff of Montgomery County in levying...

Work on the improvements at the quarantine stations on Hoffman and Swinburne Islands is being pushed ahead steadily. About forty men are now employed on each island. Hoffman Island has been entirely surrounded by a concrete wall 13 feet deep by 2 feet thick, and the same kind of wall is now in process of construction about Swinburne Island.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 3.--The board of engineers to examine into the question of a site for a bridge over the Mississippi River at NewOrleans has finished its work and gone home, Gen. Comstock to New-York and Major Allen to Galveston.
LONDON, Dec. 3.--Mr. Gladstone inspired great enthusiasm among his hearers at Manchester to-day by his definite exposition of the Liberal policy.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Dec. 3.--Charles Burhans, Treasurer of the Kingston Savings Institution, and Miss Mary Swart Hoes, daughter of the late Dr. J.C.F. Hoes, were married this afternoon at the residence of the bride, on Pearlstreet. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Cornelius Van Santvoord, assisted by the Rev. Roswell Randall Hoes, Chaplain United States Navy.

DUBLIN, Dec. 3.--Mr. Redmond presided at a meeting of 100 branches of the Limerick Tenants' Defense League. He said the societies brought the landlords to their knees and would deal the final blow that would crush the Smith Barry syndicate and cripple the action of the Government.

Enough was discovered yesterday in regard to the man who shot himself twice in the head at the Spingler House to make it certain that he was Arthur C. Brown, thirty-three years old, a Harvard graduate of the Class of '77.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 3.--The Yale sentiment against withdrawing from the Intercollegiate Athletic League so as to form a dual league with Harvard is asserting itself in the college papers.

LONDON, Dec. 3.--Some leading citizens of Chicago, under the auspices of Senator Farwell, Mr. Melville Stone, and Mr. I.F. Golding, entertained at a banquet last night distinguished Englishmen interested in American railroads.

The tuneful melodies of "Martha" entertained a fair sized audience at Amberg's Theatre last evening. ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 3.--The Russian Army is to be supplied as rapidly as possible with a new rifle of Russian manufacture.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 3.--Gov. Hill declines to interfere in the case of Murderer Carlton, sentenced to be hangad on Thursday.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 3.--A party of fifty Hebrews passed through the city to-day en route to Jerusalem. Besides the desire to travel, it was admitted by members of the party that a deeper sentiment was really the cause of the pilgrimage.
Two explosions of illuminating gas from the mains of the Consolidated Gaslight Company created considerable excitement in Minettastreet at 12:20 o'clock yesterday afternoon.
WATERBURY, Conn., Dec. 3.--Edmund Burke once remarked that he loved a clamor wherever there was an abuse. The country schools of Connecticut have degenerated into an abuse...

LONDON, Dec. 3.--The largest elephant in the menagerie attached to Barnum's circus became engaged to-day and made an attack on its keeper, goring him in the head and neck and inflicting fatal injuries.

In spite of the frightful warnings that the electric lighting companies have had of the danger of uninsulated wires, it is evident that there yet remain enough of those deadly things to make traveling in the city not altogether safe.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3.--When the International Marine Conference met to-day Capt. Selvesen of Norway offered an amendment to Article IV. of the rules of the road.

St. Monica's Conference of St. Vincent De Paul Society received a substantial benefit last evening from the proceeds of a lecture on "The Stage," delivered by Daniel Dougherty, at St. Monica's Church, Seventy-ninth-street, near First-avenue.
The baby hippopotamus born in the Central Park Zoo on Sunday night last at midnight is doing well, much to the apparent delight of Mrs. Fatima and Mr. Caliph Murphy, its mastodonic parents.

It is reported from Washington that the "boomers" of the several Western cities, each of which aspires to be the seat of the fair of 1892, are endeavoring to commit Congress in the first place to the authorization of such a fair.
LONDON, Dec. 4.--The Morning Post says: "If President Harrison carries out in practice the peaceful and progressive principles indicated in his message the whole world will be gainers thereby."

CLAREMONT, N.H., Dec. 3.--The remnant of the stock ordered from Dakota by Austin Corbin passed through this town this afternoon in charge of William Kiebert of Mandan. Kiebert says he left Dakota Nov. 16 with 21 animals...

ALBANY, Dec. 3.--The State fish and game protectors are actively engaged prosecuting violators of the game law relative to the killing of fawn. Under the old law a fawn could not be shot in the "spotted coat."

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 3.--This was the second day of the Winter meeting of the new Louisiana Jockey Club. The weather was clear and pleasant, the track fast, and the racing the best witnessed here for a long time.

ALBANY, Dec. 3.--In the Court of Appeals to-day the following business was transacted: Decisions Handed Down.--Peter Gillen, appellant, vs. The Tucker Carter Cordage Company; Walter M. McKinney, an infant, respondent, vs. The Long Island Railroad Company.--Motion to correct calendar granted, without costs.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 3.--At the opening of the football season this year Mr. A.D. Cook, proprietor of the Nassau Hotel, promised to give the eleven a banquet if they won the championship.

ALBANY, Dec. 3.--It was the intention of the State Board of Canvassers to meet to-morrow and canvass the vote of the recent election, but the returns were tardy and the prospects of a long contest over the canvass in Rennselaer County retarded the sending out of the call for a meeting of the canvassers. All the returns, save those of Rensselaer, have been received. The board has until the 14th inst. to act.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 3.--John C. Rankin, Republican, has been elected Mayor of Elizabeth to-day by about 300 majority. The probabilities are that three Democratic and one Republican Freeholder are elected. The Republicans claim to have gained one Alderman in the First and Eighth Wards. The next board is likely to stand 13 Democrats to 11 Republicans.
HUDSON, N.Y., Dec. 3.--A cold wave, accompanied by high wind, prevails all along the Hudson River to-night. Boatmen are having a hard time of it. The early closing of navigation is predicted.

The Canal Boatmen's Union and others interested in the removal of the burdens now imposed on the canal traffic at this port held a second meeting at Kingston Hall, 10 Southstreet, yesterday afternoon.
Business men have anxiously awaited the removal of their sales from the ruins of the devastating fire at Lynn.

Joseph E. Newburger said yesterday that he had not heard a word said about his appointment as Assistant District Attorney to succeed Judge-elect Fitzgerald. He could give no information on the subject. Meanwhile his friends are doing their best to get him there.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 3.--By advice of Attorney General Whyte, Gov. Jackson has decided to withdraw temporarily his proclamation throwing open the oyster dredging grounds on Hog Island flats to the dredgers of both States.

LEXINGTON, N.C., Dec. 3.--The Setter Derby of the central field trials was continued today, and the Pointer Derby commenced. The weather was good and birds very plenty.
