BALTIMORE, Dec. 3.--The Baltimore Board of Trade at its meeting yesterday passed resolutions favoring the erection of a new Custom House in this city. The board also passed resolutions reported by the Committee on Foreign Commerce in reference to the Tonnage bill. The resolutions oppose the granting of subsidies or bounties to foster American shipping interests.

The first of the ten subscription performances of this Winter was given at Daly's Theatre last night. The house was crowded, and the audience included many distinguished representatives of fashionable society.

At a meeting of stockholders of the Santo Domingo Central Railroad, held yesterday at 32 Liberty-street, these gentlemen were elected Directors: H.C. King, H.L. Beam, B.P. Harris, G.G. Ward, Milton Griswold, W.H. Bibby, C.C. Monroe, J.E. Coleman, and H.W. Alden. The executive officers will be selected at another meeting to be held next Saturday.

A great quantity of wreckage, a raft to which were lashed the bodies of two dead men, and the body of a dead woman with a life preserver fastened to it were drifting about off the Capes of Delaware on Monday morning.

The Union Amateur Athletic Club of Boston has been planning for some time to give an athletic entertainment under the rules of the Amateur Athletic Union, and has advertised it extensively among athletes at Boston.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Dec. 3.--A plumbago mine has been unearthed on the place of J. McGarry, near Highlands Station, in the Highlands of the Hudson. Coal, it is asserted, has been discovered at the base of the Shawangunk Mountains, near New-Paltz, Ulster County.
The inventions for the navigation of the air give no promise, according to Prof. Le Conte Stevens, who lectured at the Young Men's Institute Hall last evening, of usefulness in a commercial sense.

LISBON, Dec. 3.--The Portuguese Government will send a circular letter to the European powers stating that the Government is ready to prove unbroken occupation by Portugal of African territories now claimed by England.

Treasurer William R. Stewart reports that the Washington Memorial Arch fund was added to yesterday by an installment of $22 50 from employes in the Collector's department of the Custom House, from the "women's list" $10, and from Dr. John T. Metcalf $1. The total is now $61 315 60.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3.--So the Republicans really think of sending to the United States Senate from the rising young State of Montana ex-Gov. B. Platt Carpenter, formerly of Poughkeepsie, in the State of New-York.
CHICAGO, Dec. 3.--Judge Wing closed his address for the defense in the Cronin case today, and he was followed by Mr. Ingham for the prosecution. The court then adjourned.

Charles Edmondson, a farmer at Mine Mount, near Bernardsville, N.J., went into his barn Sunday afternoon. While busy around the stall of one of his horses he stooped over in front of the animal to pick something from the floor.

Investigation made yesterday served to show that the wreck at Trefz's brewery in Newark, N.J., Monday, was not caused by an explosion of ammonia, but that the weight of two great vats of beer on the third floor was greater than the beams could bear.
TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 3.--This has been another day of elaborate argument in the foreclosure suits against the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railway Company.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 3.--Secretary of State Leseur has formally notified the Quick Meal Stove Company of this city that unless they withdraw from the trust or combination to which he finds they belong within thirty days he will revoke their charter.
It would seem that one by one the cobwebs which the members of the State Forestry Commission have spun about the laws which provide for the preservation of the Adirondack...
LONDON, Dec. 4.--The steamship Wimbledon, (Br.,) from Palermo Nov. 27 for New-York, passed Gibraltar Dec. 2.

Now that the North Atlantic squadron has sailed, the Brooklyn Navy Yard is without a single commissioned warship except the training ship Portsmouth. The Portsmouth has received a few repairs since her arrival at the yard. As is the custom, the training fleet will...

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 3.--Three funerals were held to-day over three victims of Saturday night's fire at the Tribune building. Milton Pickett of the Pioneer Press was buried at Lakewood, his pall bearers being colleagues...
We see no evidence that President HARRISON was influenced by conscious self-distrust in preparing his first annual message. It appears to be the work of a serene and...

Capt. Stephenson of the Thirty-fourth Precinct reported to the Board of Health yesterday that James Reynolds, a poor man, was very sick with erysipelas at the house of A. Kasmeyer, on One Hundred and Seventy-fourth-street, east of Jerome-avenue.

The Edwin A. Stevens Naval Post, G.A.R., in New-Jersey, has been interesting itself in the question of the disfranchisement of naval veterans, and has prepared a petition to Congress in favor of an act to direct courts to accept honorable discharges from the navy as evidence of citizenship.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 3.--The Central Elevator Company of this city, T.A. Cheek, President, and Albert Eakin, Secretary and Treasurer, filed a bill of assignment in the Chancery Court to-day. Their schedule shows $169,298 as liabilities and about an equal amount as assets, consisting of grain in their elevator, real estate,

Montana has come into the Union with a cry from one party that the other has tried to "steal the State" and with a dead-lock in the Legislature that threatens to prevent the election of United States Senators for some time to come.
The Atlantic transport liner Missouri arrived yesterday from London via Philadelphia. From the latter port she was in charge of First Officer Gates, Capt. Hamilton Murrell having been...

The first of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Korbay's historical song and piano recitals, which was given at Chickering Hall last evening, was an interesting and instructive entertainment. The programme contained a number of compositions which belong to the curiosities of music.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3.--The newly-elected Democratic Chaplain of the House opened the proceedings of the second day of the lower branch with a prayer that was quite free from any language that could be construed into boastfulness, and that was as brief as could have been demanded by the strictest economist of time.
This city is getting ready to welcome the delegates to the Pan-American Congress when they come here for four days on Dec. 16. Mayor Grant sent a communication to the Aldermen...
ALBANY, Dec. 3.--George B. Church of Albion, son of the late Judge Sanford E. Church, has accepted the Deputy State Treasurership under Treasurer-elect Danforth.
The Reed Powell Transportation Company of Coxsackie has sold its stock in the New-York and Hudson Steamboat Company to the Catskill and New-York Steamboat Company.
Commander E.F. Jewell has been detached from duty at Washington and ordered to assume the duties of Inspector of Ordnance in charge of the naval torpedo station at Newport.

On Dec. 11, between 5 and 9 P.M., the members of the Staten Island Athletic Club will hold their annual election of officers. The candidates regularly nominated are: For President--Eberhard Faber; Vice President--W.A. Lentilhon; Secretary--W.C. Davis; Treasurer--O.T. Johnson;...

DOVER, N.H., Dec. 3.--Early this morning the 114 inhabitants of Alton Bay were awakened by an earthquake shock which jarred the houses. Many persons rushed from their beds. Crockery and glassware were broken and clocks were stopped at 1:29.
BRISTOL, Dec. 3.--The dock strike here has ended by the strikers gaining the concessions for which they stood out.
TROY, N.Y., Dec. 3.--The Grand Jury this morning failed to find indictments against the Democratic Inspectors of Election in the Sixth and Twelfth Ward cases.

Traffic on the Brooklyn Bridge was delayed for three hours yesterday by a broken axle. The break occurred at the New-York entrance at 10 A.M., as Car 48, at the head of a train, was just ending its trip from Brooklyn.

Two theatrical performances in aid of the endowment of a room in a hospital for injured firemen of this city has been arranged. On the evening of Dec. 17 Helen Barry will appear in "A Woman's Stratagem" in the Metropolitan Opera House, and on the 21st Harry Lacey and "The Still Alarm" will be an attraction.
NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 3.--The secret ballot law was tried in New-Haven for the first time today. The principal objection was in regard to the very inferior booths furnished by contractors.
The hearing in the contest over the will of Mrs. Ellen Gavin, the particulars of which were given in last Sunday's TIMES, went on before Referee Hascall yesterday.

UPPER MARLBOROUGH, Md., Dec. 3.--About 2:30 o'clock this morning a band of masked men went to the jail here, overpowered the keeper, broke open the cell of Joe Vermillon, and took him out and lynched him on the bridge leading to this village.

At the meeting of the Board of Managers of the Inter-State Commerce Railway Association in Chicago yesterday, the report of the special Board of Arbitration on the adjustment of through and local rates to points in Nebraska and Kansas was considered.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3.--A.A. McLeod to-day resigned as General Manager of the Reading Coal and Iron Company. He was at once elected Vice President by the Directors. C.E. Henderson was elected General Manager of the company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3.--The National Wool Growers' meeting organized to-day by the election of Columbus Delano of Ohio, President; G. H. Wallace, President of the Missouri Wool Growers' Association, Secretary.
PITTSBURG, Dec. 3.--There were lively times to-day at the meeting of the Pittsburg Presbytery over the Confession of Faith. George T. Purves offered a motion to reconsider the question...

LONDON, Dec. 3--The St. James's Gazette states that Mr. Parnell disappeared several weeks ago, and since then has not been heard from. His whereabouts are a mystery, and his prolonged absence causes much trouble to his adherents.
SHANGHAI, Dec. 3.--The platform of a theatre at Wienhen, in the Province of Shantung, collapsed during a performance. Two hundred persons were killed.

The Aldermen met yesterday as County Canvassers and canvassed last Saturday's vote in the Sixth Congressional District. Turner's vote was declared to be 6,811. The total vote cast was found to be 8,534. County Clerk Reilly gave Mr. Turner his certificate of election, and the iceman turned Congressman started for Washington last night.

Mozart's "Don Giovanni" will be brought forward at the Metropolitan Opera House this evening with a strong cast. This great classical opera has not been heard here for a long time and should attract a large audience.
The North Atlantic squadron sailed yesterday for the West Indies. The Kearsarge was the first vessel to get away from the navy yard, but the others followed shortly afterward.

The managers of the New-York Club are making efforts to have a strong team in this city next season even if the Brotherhood scheme prove successful. In that event it is stated on good authority that the Indianapolis Club will...

The Mayor of Chinatown, whose official title is the Clan Sung of the Zoon Fa Goon Soo, has been having trouble of late with what his friends scornfully call "no goodee Slundayschoolee Chinamans" and with a lot of highbinding Chyos.
Judge Wallace, in the United States Circuit Court, yesterday took the papers, after an argument on a demurrer to the complaint, in the suit of Leon Bernard against ex-Sheriff Peter Bowe.
None of the sensational predictions of Wallstreet bankruptcies and Stock Exchange failures having come to pass, yesterday's stock market showed much progress toward the re-establishment...

There is still a wide margin to be covered before the guarantee fund of the World's Fair is completed, according to the figures of the Finance Committee. But to those who think that the amount desired is now further from realization...
There was variety enough in yesterday's weather to satisfy the cravings of the fickiest and most abnormal taste, and to keep cautious people busy adjusting their apparel to its eccentricities.

LYNN, Mass., Dec. 3.--The storm has not interfered with the work in the burned district. Temporary structures have been erected all over the devastated territory, and business is being transacted as usual. Postmaster Hoitt reports business at the Post Office unprecedented. One thousand Lynn workmen have registered as out of employment.
HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 3.--Several hundred policy holders of the Phoenix Mutual Life Insurance Company met to-day to vote on accepting legislative permission to buy the capital stock.
Yesterday's meeting at the Mutual Life Insurance Building of Twenty-third and Twentyfourth Ward property owners was well attended. The immediate business was to hear from...
When Commissioner Moss reached the office of the Board of Electrical Control yesterday morning he gave orders for a trip of inspection...

LISBON, Dec. 3.--A dispatch from Cape St. Vincent reports that the Alagoas sailed Dec. 1, flying the old flag of the Brazilian Empire, in compliance with the instructions cabled hither by the provisional Government.

BOSTON, Dec. 3.--Mr. E.S. Stokes, proprietor of the Hoffman House, New-York, who has been here for several days, is said to be negotiating for the control of the Quincy House in this city, which is to be leased for a term of years, dating from Feb. 1. A party from Philadelphia last week also got figures on the property.
NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 3.--It is about definitely decided that New-Orleans is to have a belt road and that the railroads will anticipate mandatory action on the part of the City Government.
A dispatch from Albany reports that in the case of Robert Fitch Shepard and others against the Manhattan Elevated Railway Company the Court of Appeals yesterday affirmed the order...

Jean Tack is the proprietor of a jewelry store at 215 Market-street, Newark, N.J., and behind the handsome plate-glass window through which the vulgar throng is allowed to gaze a large assortment of valuable jewelry is displayed.

The Old All Souls' Church building, which was occupied by the Rev. R. Heber Newton's congregation previous to their union with the Church of the Holy Spirit, will probably soon pass into the hands of the Methodists, to be reopened as a house of worship.

There are few transactions in the administration of the Government that are even temporarily held in the confidence of those charged with the conduct of the public business. Every step taken is under the observation of an intelligent and watchful people. The state of the Union is known from day to day, and suggestions as to needed legislation find an earlier voice than that which speaks in these annual communications of the President to Congress.

President HARRISON in his annual message professes to regard the "inferiority of our merchant marine compared with that of other nations" as "justly humiliating to the national pride" and "hurtful to the national prosperity," bUt he seems to be ...

LONDON, Dec. 4.--The session of the Liberal Federation at Manchester was continued today. A resolution was adopted to demand urgency at the coming session of Parliament for a bill embodying the "one man, one vote" principle.
NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 4.--Mr. Davis's condition has decidedly improved in the past forty-eight hours. The sick man sleeps well, feeds well, and is growing stronger.

Lieut. Edward Sturdy has been detached from the New-Hampshire and ordered to temporary duty in the Bureau of Equipment and Recruiting; Surgeon C.A. Siegfried from the naval station, New-London, and ordered to the New-Hampshire; Surgeon J.L. Neilson from the New-Hampshire and ordered to the Portsmouth; Passed Assistant Surgeon Henry S. Berger from the Portsmouth and placed on waiting orders.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 4.--This afternoon the wife of J.A. Rube, a wagon and carriage manufacturer of Beebe, Ark., appeared in a Justice's court to answer the charge of forgery. Rube came to Beebe from New-York twelve months ago and established a factory.

The White Star steamship Adriatic, which sailed yesterday for Liverpool took out among other passengers Joseph Jewell, Fellow of the Royal Geographical Society; Mgr. Gadd, J. Dyson Moore, and George P. Eustis.

BERLIN, Dec. 4.--In the Reichstag to-day Herr Barth, Progressist, moved to repeal the provision of law compelling miners seeking employment to be provided with a certificate showing the length of time they had been employed in their last place, and the previous employer's opinion of their capacity.

A movement is on foot in Brooklyn political circles, started by Georgeites, nourished by Prohibitionists, aided by Democrats, and abetted by Republicans, in the interest of ballot reform. How much success the movement will attain remains to be seen, but on Monday evening twenty gentlemen assembled in the rooms of the Brooklyn Single-Tax Club and exchanged views on the subject.

LEXINGTON, N.C., Dec. 4.--The running for second and third prizes in the Setter Derby of the Central Field Trial Club was finished to-day, with the following result: Sam C. beat Royal C.; Harry C. beat Sam C. and won second; Sam C. was awarded third.

Ex-Police Captain Jeremiah Petty died on Tuesday night of general debility at his home at Centre Moriches, Suffolk County, L.I. He was a pensioner of the Police Department and Possessed a snug estate, which will be shared by three daughters and a son.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec 4.--The aunnual meeting of the stockholders of the Richmond and Danville Railroad Company was held to-day. From the President's report it appears that the gross earnings from traffic of the railroad proper, including the Baltimore, Chesapeake ...

Literary curios were added to the Mayor's unique collection of letters of advice on the hand organ and street band question yesterday. Those who want the music outnumbered those who are opposed to it, and the collection now contains enough advice to supply any number of Mayors.

At to-day's meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment an effort will be begun to obtain the transfer to the city authorities of the buildings on Ward's Island which belong to the State and are under the control of the Commissioners of Emigration.

A certificate of incorporation has been filed in Albany, N.Y., by the Consolidated Chemical Engine Company. This company is formed to manufacture all kinds of fire extinguishers, including chemical engines, and to acquire patents on all similar devices. The capital is $300,000. The principal office is in this city. Among the incorporators are Alonzo B. Cornell, Louis F. Payn, and William L. Bostwick.

Funeral services over the body of Samuel Wilkeson were held yesterday afternoon at the family residence, 8 West Fortieth-street, and were attended by fully two hundred of his friends. The body lay in a casket in a front parlor on the second floor of the residence.
LISBON, Dec. 4. --Brazilian Royalists in this city state that Dom Pedro is much opposed to the propositions made in the United States looking to the organization of an American commercial Zollverein.

VALPARAISO, Nov. 2.--It is reported from Santiago that the Peruvian Minister, Senor Don Carlos Elias, has opened negotiations with the Chilian Government having for their object the liberation of the provinces of Tacna and Arica.

The General Executive Committee of the World's Fair met at its office in THE TIMES Building yesterday afternoon. The session was taken up with discussing the bill to be submitted to Congress prepared by the Committee on Legislation.

WASHINGTON, Dec 4.--When the International Marine Conference met to-day it immediately proceeded to the consideration of the amendment proposed yesterday by Capt. Richard of France to Section G of Article XII. in the additional report of the Committee on Sound Signals.

An exhibition was given last evening at the works of the Huntington Electric Search Light Company of the efficiency of their light. The evening was no particularly fine for the display of the light to its best advantage, but enough was shown to demonstrate the ability of a 3,500 candle-power light to pick up an object distant nearly three-fourths of a mile.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 4.--Seventy-four head of throughbreds were sold here to-day at auction by Col. S.D. Bruce. They averaged $636, the amount realized being $47,040. The weather was cloudy and cool, but the attendance was ...
The new Connecticut ballot law was tried for the first time in this city yesterday. Where provision was made according to law, and the booths properly erected, the result was most satisfactory.
BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 4.--Driscoll Powers, bankers and stock brokers, 80 Devonshirestreet, made an assignment this morning to George H. Perry of Perry Perry.

The President also submitted to the Senate for its confirmation many of the appointments he has previously made, including Mr. Phelps as Minister to Germany, Mr. Hirsch Minister to Turkey, Messrs. Roosevelt and Thompson as Civil Service Commissioners, and other diplomatic and departmental officers.
LONDON, Dec. 4.--The publisher of the Munster Express has been sentenced to two months' imprisonment for reporting a meeting at which boycotting was advocated.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4.--Charles Richter, the murderer of Rudolph Weltman, pleaded guilty to the charge of manslaughter and was sentenced to seventeen years in the penitentiary by Judge Anthony this morning.
TREASURY DEPARTMENT, WASHINGTON, D.C., Dec. 2, 1889. To the Speaker of the House of Representatives: SIR: I have the honor to submit the following report:

The United States Circuit Court yesterday appointed Macgrane Coxe United States Commissioner, in place of John Fitch, deceased. Mr. Coxe was one of the first Assistant District Attorneys appointed under President Cleveland's Administration.

At the meeting of the Board of Education yesterday Commissioner Guggenheimer presented a resolution for the appointment of a special committee of seven to investigate the matter of overcrowding and deficient accomodations of the public schools, to consult with the Trustees of ward schools upon the subject, and report with recommendations.

The Board of Review of the National Trotting Association continued its annual session at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel yesterday. The most important case reached during the day was the Nelson-Alcryon race at Boston, in which fraud is alleged. This is another one of the tenthousand-dollar stallion contests which have created so much scandal in turf circles.

Three women were shot yesterday during a quarrel on the top floor of the Italian tenement house at 69 James-street and one of them died in a few minutes after receiving her wound. Six persons were engaged in the quarrel. On one side were the three women, on the other two men and one woman. All concerned were Italians.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4.--The momentous question as to whether the wives of Cabinet officers would be at home this afternoon has been generally agitated in society to-day, since by some mysterious, unwritten law it appears to be generally conceded that with the coming of Cabinet day the season is first fairly set going.

NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 4.--Miss Minnie C. Lookwood, daughter of Dr. Charles E. Lockwood, a wealthy New-York physician, was married here this evening to Eversley Childs, son of W.H. Childs of the Mecca Roofing Company of Brooklyn.

A wedding of fashionable note was that yesterday afternoon, at Grace Church, of Miss Fanny Hamilton Bowdoin, daughter of George S. Bowdoin, and Daniel Parish Kingsford of this city. The church was handsomely deccrated with palms and Southern pines, and was crowded to the doors with the friends of the bride and groom.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 4.--All signs hereabout indicate that next year's output of iron and steel from the Pittsburg district will exceed this year's. Prices, too, which have had an upward tendency for some months, it is thought are likely to range higher if anything.

"There is the liveliest kind of a muddle over the production of the new Gilbert and Sullivan opera in New-York," said a wellknown theatrical man last night. "This opera has been disposed of to America for various sections of the country.

Dr. Sherer, the sugar examiner of the NewYork Custom House, said yesterday that the announcement that he was to be investigated by a committee of three Special Treasury Agents appointed by Secretary Windom made no difference to him.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 4.--The presence of Governor-elect Campbell in the city to-day was sufficient to attract a large number of politicians from different parts of the State, who have besieged Mr. Campbell during the day, urging their claims to places at his disposal.

The Hudson River steamer Newburg of the Homer Ramsdell Line narrowly escaped being burned last night, and the hundred or so passengers and crew who started on board her for the trip to Newburg from this city had ample occasion to thank their lucky stars that they got off without loss of life.

Deputy Sheriff Kaufman was successful yesterday in making a very important seizure in connection with the failure of Stern Stern, jewelers, of 13 Maiden-lane, which may gladden the hearts of the creditors.
The land for the erection of the Washington Memorial Arch is growing steadily, and the Treasurer, William R. Stewart of 54 Williamstreet, feels very much encouraged.

Arrangements have already been made to give Mr. Reed an enthusiastic reception when he comes home for the holidays. Yesterday invitations were sent to him both from the Portland Club and Young Men's Republican Club.

Testimony was taken yesterday before Mr. Underhill, the assistant to the Surrogate, in the contest of the will of Isaac Halsey, a retired merchant, who died at his residence, 289 East Broadway, in August of the present year.

Henry E. Schutte, formerly a bandmaster in the United States Navy, but now old and poverty-stricken, tried to commit suicide yesterday by jumping into the East River from the dock at the foot of Gold-street, Brooklyn.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 4.--In the First Division of the Court of Appeals to-day the following causes were argued: William Cole, as executor, , appellant vs. The Methodist Episcopal Hospital, impleaded, ...

Dook Commissioner J. Sergeant Cram had another inning with the Commissioners of Accounts yesterday in the matter of their investigation into the management of his department. The most important piece of information imparted by the young Tammany Commissioner was that he had made up his mind to resign.

The Aatlanta Boat Club, champion club of the country, is several hundred dollars better off to-day than it was yesterday. It gave a minstrel entertainment last evening in Chickering Hall, which was very well attended and enjoyable, and a great financial success as well. The club will give a ball soon in Newark, N.J., which will give its many friends and members another pleasant evening.

An Atlanta (Ga.) syndicate a few months ago purchased the Union-Street Railway of that city for $475,000, and sold it a few days ago to a New-York party for $800,000. This property was given in for taxes last spring at a valuation of $57,000.

The report of the Secretary of the Treasury presents nothing new or especially interesting except what he has to say about silver, and this is decidedly interesting, not to say startling. In regard to other matters the report keeps well within the lines cautiously laid down either by the President for him or by him for the President, or, possibly, by the party leaders for both.
President Day of the New-York Club said yesterday that he would have a conference with Mr. John L. Rogers on Saturday and steps would be taken to institute proceedings against Ward next week.

Mr. David Belasco has begun the rehearsals of "The Prince and the Pauper," the dramatization made for Daniel Frohman of Mark Twain's book by Mrs. Abby Sage Richardson. The play is to be first given at the New Park Theatre, Philadelphia, Christmas week, and will be presented there for a month.

ALBANY, Dec. 4.--Clarence W. Perry and John A. Anderson, counsel for the condemned murderer Greenwall, who is to be hanged in Brooklyn on Friday, applied to Gov. Hill this morning for a respite for Greenwall for sixty days. Assistant District Attorney Clarke of Brooklyn opposed the application.
The court of inquiry having in charge the investigation of the circumstances of the burning of the Wilson Line steamship Santiago at sea on Nov. 30 rendered its decision yesterday.

Word has been received in this city that Sir Roderick Cameron, owner of the schooner Lady Evelyn, has given an order to William Fife, Jr., the Scotch designer of the wonderful little cut ter Minerva, for a seventy-foot yacht, to be built for racing in American waters next season.
There are indications in the present cool breezes from the northwest that the city is soon to be subjected to more annoyances because of the tearing up of the streets.
Some time ago the Jersey City authorities appropriated a large amount of money for the repaving of Montgomery-street from Grovestreet to the foot of the hill with granite blocks.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 4.--The Finance Committee of the American Association is in session, but has done nothing owing to the absence of Von der Ahe, who is out trying to engage players, and the fact that the committee is not yet ready to recommend any cities for the vacant places.
The Secretary of the Interior in his annual report says, with reference to the scandalous rerating of employes in the Pension Bureau:

Thomas Costigan, the portly ex-Supervisor of the City Record, was again placed on the city pay rolls yesterday by being appointed chief clerk of the District Attorney's office, in the place of James McCabe.

William Becker, a German, aged thirty years, was shot early yesterday morning on the premises of L.D. Huntington, in New-Rochelle. Mr. Huntington's two sons, Warren and Lawrence, returned from a duck-shooting expedition shortly after midnight, and on their arrival home saw Becker prowling about the premises.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 4.--The disclosures last night in the R.G. Wood ballot box case in Cincinnati, in which it is alleged the most prominent Republicans in the State are either implicated or knew of the forgery, have created another sensation.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 4.--A heavy northeast gale, accompanied by a blinding snowstorm, has prevailed on Lake Ontario for two days. The schooner Kate left Charlotte Monday afternoon laden with 300 tons of coal for the Bay of Quinte, and fears are expressed for her safety.

LONDON, Dec 4.--Mr. Oscar Dickson, the Sothenburg merchant, already famous as a generous patron of arctic exploration, offers to defray the expenses of a new expedition to the north pole if Dr. Frighjof Nansen, who commanded the recent Greenland expedition, will accept the leadership.

A most successful fair is now in progress at the Forty-fourth-Street Methodist Episcopal Church, in Forty-fourth-street, near Tenthavenue. It was opened Tuesday night and will continue until Saturday night.

A notice of appeal in the case of Charles McElvaine, who was recently convicted of the murder of the Brooklyn grocer Christian W. Luca, and who was sentenced to die by electricity at Sing Sing next week, has been filed by ex-Judge Curtis with the Clerk of the court in which the conviction was had.
RONDOUT, N.Y., Dec. 4.--High winds prevailed along the Hudson River last night and this morning, seriously interfering with the movements of tows and sailing craft, Superintendent ...

Chief interest in Wall-street yesterday centred in the fact that the money market showed evidences of case. In banking circles it is declared that not only is the rush of money South and West over, but that finally the flow of funds is toward this city, which means that New-York's money market is to be relieved of ...
JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 4.--To-day the Point Chautauqua Summer resort on Chautauqua Lake was sold at auction by the bondholders.

The parties which have formed in the Real Estate Exchange are preparing for a lively struggle at the annual election which will occur next Monday. A spirited canvass has been going on for several weeks.
CONSTANTINOPLE, Dec. 4.--Moussa Bey has been acquitted of the charges of incendiarism, pillage, and murder by a majority of the court, and of robbery by a unanimous decision.

The gentlemen who are to direct the entertainment of the delegates to the Pan-American Congress upon their visit to this city Dec. 16 to 20 met in the Governor's Room in the City Hall yesterday, and got their work fairly started.
The incoming vessels yesterday reported very severe weather off the coast on Tuesday night. The Circassia of the Anchor Line experienced a stormy passage from Glasgow.
At yesterday's session of the Western States Passenger Association in Chicago the subject of divisions of through fares with the transcontinental lines was considered.
The attendance at the concert given in the Scottish Rite Hall, Madison-avenue and Twenty-ninth-street, last evening was only limited by the dimensions of the hall.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4.--The officers of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company to-day decided to meet the reduction in passenger rates between Washington and Baltimore and Pittsburg.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 4.--The Farmers and Laborers' Union resumed its sessions this morning. President Macune of the Southern Farmers' Alliance made his annual address. This alliance is now consolidated with the union.

Judge Wallace, in the United States Circuit Court, yesterday reserved his decision in a suit brought by Mrs. J. Hickok against Joseph R.L. Wood, a son of ex-Mayor Fernando Wood, for an accounting in regard to property on Sixtythird-street, near Eighth-avenue.
PARIS, Dec. 4.--A dispatch to the Temps from Zanzibar states that Stanley has arrived at Bagamoyo.

There was decided falling off in the attendance at the New-Jersey Jockey Club's races yesterday. In consequence Mr. Michael Dwyer, the President of the association, announced that on and after Friday next the admission would be free. The track was in excellent condition and fast, as the time for the last races ...

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4.--No settlement was reached at the conference held in this city today between Master Workman Arrington of the green glassworkers, President Smith of the flint glassworkers, and Messrs. D.W. Moore, J.P. Whitney, and Walter Swindell, representing the Wage Committee of the Manufacturers' Association.

The candidates for the Freshmen crew of Columbia College held their preliminary meeting yesterday afternoon. The privations they will have to undergo in abstaining from tobacco, highly-seasoned food, and exhilarating drinks in order to serve their Alma Mater and their class, and glorify--may hap immortalize-- themselves were pictured in eloquent periods.
A hero whom Wall-street has not lately had much change to celebrate made stock-market hearts glad yesterday by reappearing. Mr. Edwin Gould--known of old as Bad Boy Eddie-- is this attraction.
Col. John O'Byrne left Taylor's Hotel, Jersey City, about 11 o'clock yesterday morning, taking the Philadelphia train on the Pennsylvania Railroad.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4.--The judgment creditors of Lewis S. Cox Co., through thier counsel, recorded to-day a general assignment to Ezekiel-Hunn, Jr. No other steps were taken, and counsel stated that they had not yet received official notice of Mr. Singerly's injunction proceeding. When they do they will be ready to argue the question in court, and upon the decision will depend future litigation.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 4.--Great interest was attached to the assembling of the Legislatur to-day, chiefly on account of Gov. Lee's message, which was expected to deal at some length with the public debt question. It is principally devoted to this question and contains a mass of figures. Gov. Lee says on this inexhaustible topic:

A mass meeting of District Assembly No. 49, Knights of Labor, and of other workingmen, was held last evening at Cooper Union in memory of William Horan, who was a member of the Executive Board of No. 49. Hugh Greenan presided and made the opening speech.
TORONTO, Ontario, Dec. 4.--The Globe, (Liberal,) commenting on President Harrison's message, says it "raises no new issues and throws little new light upon current political questions.
HARTFORD, Dec. 4.--Insurance Commissioner Flyer to-day elected the following Directors of the Phoenix Mutual Life Insurance Company: J.B. Bunce, ...

Nathan Pollock, manufacturer of clothing at 563 Broadway, made an assignment yesterday to Emanuel Goldschmidt, giving preferences of M.K. Lustig, $5,000; S. Rosenberg Co., $1,651; Bowery National Bank, $800; The Anspacher Manufacturing Company, $240; total, $7,691.

Mr. Henry A. Blake, a lawyer at 10 Wallstreet, who lives at the Langham Hotel, promises, under certain contingencies, a startling story this evening in relation to one of his friends who was missing last night.
CHICAGO, Dec. 4.--Shrieks and cries of fire startled the guests at the Palmer House this evening. On the fifth floor a beautiful young woman was dashing wildly about the hall wrapped in flames.

At the meeting of the Trustees of the Normal College, held yesterday, the resignations of Fannie L. Rutter, Martha F. Miller, and Emma A. Newman, teachers in the training school, were accepted, and Ella Keith, Miriam L. Taylor, and Mary Belle Coles were elected to the vacancies. By resolution presented by President Hunter, ...

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 4.--The candidates for the Yale crew held a long meeting in President Sheldon's room to-night. An unusual lack of interest has been shown in boating matters, and Capt. Allen fears that what has been called "Yale luck" has deserted the blue.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4.--An evening paper says: "From every indication the brass manufacturers of the United States are perfecting a gigantic confederation. A meeting was held in the Grand Pacific to day, but the business transacted was kept secret."

Robert c. Cashin, a furniture dealer at 300 Sixth-avenue, had an exciting struggle with a lunatic at 9 o'clock yesterday morning. The man was tall and thin and wild-eyed. He strolled into the store, and walking close up to the proprietor, asked earnestly, "Are you a ...
LONG BRANCH, N.J., Dec 4.--The recent high tides undermined the iron pier to such an extent that it rested upon the concrete bulkhead which protected it on the shore end.

Lizzie Higgins, the sixteen-year-old daughter of Daniel Higgins, who left her home, 196 Nevins-street, Brooklyn, two weeks ago, notified her mother yesterday that she had been married and was on her way to Canada with her husband.

The students of rhetoric and belles-lettres of the College of St. Francis Xavier gave their relatives and friends a novel and interesting entertainment last night at the hall of the college in West Sixteenth-street.
Capt. Probst of the German bark George Washington, which arrived last night from Hamburg, reports that he was sixty-two days in making the voyage.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4.--At the National Wool Growers' meeting to-day a committee to prepare an address to the wool growers of the United States was appointed. Its report will probably be presented to-morrow.

Some skillful forgers are operating in this city and all efforts of the police to capture them have so far proved futile. Rudolph A. Hofmann, a saloon keeper at Sixth-avenue and Forty-third-street, is the last object of their attention, and the Lincoln National Bank mourns the loss of about $500 in the operation.

Nearly three hundred members of the Loyal Legion assembled in Delmonico's last night to elect a number of new associates, to eat the bimonthly dinner of the organization, and to listen to a paper concerning Gen. Grant at Chattanooga, read by Gen. O. O. Howard.

JOHNSTOWN, Penn., Dec. 4.--Ever since the flood there has been a good deal of talk about dissatisfaction in the congregation of the First Presbyterian Church here with its pastor, the Rev. D.J. Beale, D.D. Recently it was decided to call a congregational meeting to consider the pastor's status, and it was fixed for this evening.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 4.--There was great excitement in the Chamber of Deputies to-day in the course of the discussion raised by the Radical Deputy Bara, who denounced the conduct of the Government in the case of Gautier, the chief detective, recently dismissed.

The Coroner's inquest on the death of Harry Harris will take place next Tuesday. No arrests are probable until that is over with. It is evident, however, that the inquest in this particular case will cover not merely evidence as to the fact of death from a Brush lamp electric current, but as to all the complicated issue of responsibility as well.
ST. PAUL, Dec. 4.--A Pioneer Press special from Luverne, Minn., says; "About 2 o'clock to-day fire was discovered in the rear of an unoccupied building...
LONDON, Dec. 4.--The Times, in commenting on Secretary Windom's report, thinks that the Treasury Department must show an abnormal degree of sharpness to avoid buying silver at artificial prices.

President Ridgway and Emigration Commissioners starr and Stephenson, who visited Castle Garden yesterday afternoon, were in high good humor over a communication which had been received from the Secretary of the Treasury in relation to the Gardner and Mansolf cases.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 4.--At a meeting of the football eleven held last evening Edgar Allen Poe was unanimously re-elected Captain for the season of 1890.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 4.--Argument of the various motions in the Missouri, Kansas and Texas foreclosure suits came to an end in Judge Brewer's court to-day. The first motion of the day was that of the railroad company by Simon Sterne of New-York for a consolidation of the suits against the company.

Mozart's "Don Giovanni" had not been heard at the Metropolitan Opera House since the first season, when it was produced under the direction of Dr. Damrosch, until last night. A large audience was in the house last night when the curtain went up on the first scene.

The Deutscher Verein, which, being translated, means German Club, yesterday afternoon laid the cornerstone of its new clubhouse, on Fifty-ninth-street and Sixth-avenue, the erection of which marks an important period in the life of the organization.

George Heide, a keeper in the Kings County Penitentiary, who was recently suspended on a charge of carrying on business relations with the prisoners, was arraigned before the Charity Commissioners yesterday for trial.

Our great and good friend the Czar of all the Russias has become the victim of misinformation. No other hypothesis consistent with respect for him as a man and as an Emperor could account for his permitting his censor to forbid the circulation in Russia of THE NEW-YORK TIMES.

Manager Rosenquest, realizing that in time all of the theatres in this city will be obliged to reduce their prices from the standard that has prevailed since the war, has decided to adopt a reduced scale for seats and admission to the ...

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 4.--The charter election here yesterday has resulted in a disastrous defeat for the Democrats. They lose the Mayoralty, which they have held for the past nine years, and also three members of the City Council. John C. Rankin, Republican, has 581 majority for Mayor.

LONDON, Dec. 5.--Viscount Preto, the last Prime Minister of Brazil under the empire, who was exiled upon the proclamation of the republic, has arrived at Teneriffe by way of St. Vincent. While at the latter place he had a conference with Dom Pedro, the ex-Emperor. Viscount Preto has given an account of the revolution, which agrees with the details of the movement heretofore published.
The stockholders of the Jerome Park Villa Site and Improvement Company had a special general meeting at the offices of the American Jockey Club yesterday afternoon.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 5.--The Senate to-day unanimously adopted a resolution expressing the sense of the General Assembly of South Carolina that the city of New-York is the most suitable place in which to hold the World's Fair in 1892. The resolution goes to the House, where it will, without doubt, be concurred in unanimously.
The Railroad Committee of the Board of Aldermen made a report yesterday on the application of the Metropolitan and Cross-Town Railroad Company to operate a surface road from river to river.
The excellent programme of seven races offered by the Hudson County Jockey Club yesterday had the effect of drawing out a large attendance, despite the threatening aspect of the weather.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 5.--Mrs. Colin Campbell, the wife of a prominent official of the Militia Department, has cloped with Frederick O'Connor, a wealthy man about town.

Henry E. Abbey and Charles F. Chatterton will start for Chicago to-night to be present at the opening of the Auditorium by the Patti Opera Company next Monday evening. Marcus Mayer remains here to see the opening of the Gaiety Company at the Broadway next Tuesday, after which he will join his chief in Chicago.

The Rev. Dr. W.S. Rainsford, rector of St. George's Church, Stuyvesant-square, has been served with a summons to appear before Justice Berry, at Southampton, L.I., to answer to the charge of violating the game laws in regard to the shooting of quail before Nov. 1.
NYACK, N.Y., Dec. 5.--A church feud between the colored Baptists and Methodists of this place has resulted in a sensational affair which is the subject of much comment here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5.--To-day's bond offerings were as follows: Coupon fours, $100; registered fours, $17,300, $200,000, $200,000 at 127; coupon four and a halfs, $150,000, $550; registered four and a halfs, $1,000, $11,600 at 104 5/8; four per cents registered, $100,000, $50,000 at 127; four and a half per cents registered, $15,000, $350,000 at 104 5/8. A11 the offers were accepted.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Dec. 5.--Life-Saving Crew No. 7, at Belmar, N.J., today rescued a party of five fishermen from drowning. The men had ventured out to sea about three miles, and when ready to return their boat suddenly overturned.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5.--The annual report of Attorney General Miller was made public to-day. It contains a detailed statement of the operations of the Department of Justice during the past fiscal year, with a statement of the present condition of business before the United States Supreme Court and the Court of Claims.
LONDON, Dec. 5.--The men employed in the municipal gas works at Manchester recently lodged a notice that they were about to go on strike.

ALBANY, Dec. 5.--The Renwick Club was incorporated yesterday to promote social entertainment and have a clubhouse in New-York City. The Trustees are: Charles E. Sturges, Edward N. Hill, Wallace C. Goffe, George Lockwood, Charles T. Lunt, Alexander G. Cabus, Edward W. Hitchings, Louis Ferguson, James H. Hulme, and Thomas R. Gibbs.

The Metropolitan Directory of Selected Names for 1890 has just been issued by the Trow City Directory Company. It has been prepared with great care, and the company believes it to be absolutely correct.

BUENOS AYRES, Nov. 5.--The October liquidation of Stock Exchange operations in Buenos Ayres caused twenty-two failures and a large number of defaults, while in Montevideo the liquidation was again postponed to the 9th. Stock gambling appears to be occasioning trouble as well as creating wealth.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 5.--A jury in the case of Henry Doerr against the Pittsburg and Birmingham Passenger Railroad Company to-day returned a verdict in favor of the plaintiff for $13,500. This is the largest amount ever awarded in this county for personal injuries.
CHICAGO, Dec. 5.--The rumor is again current that the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company will extend its line to the Missouri River, the objective point being, it is said, St. Joseph, Mo.

Two well-dressed ladies entered the Mayor's office Wednesday and confronted mild-mannered Secretary Crain. "We want to know," said one of them, "if something cannot be done so that we can lead our dogs in the street by their chains. We come from a society interested in pet dogs.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5.--The sugar trade in particular and business circles generally are laughing over a "war" into which Claus Spreckels has been drawn and in which he has not won a victory up to the present.

Emigration Commissioner Stephenson does not believe that the commission of which he is a member will last much longer. For some time past there have been rumors to the effect that a strong attempt was to be made this Winter to get a bill through Congress placing the whole matter of immigration under a Federal commission.

MEXICO, Dec. 5.--The excellent condition of business continues to be maintained and large amounts of fresh capital are coming into the country from London, where is the centre of the principal railway and other enterprises which are on foot here.

SANDWICH, Mass., Dec. 5.--Many conflicting reports are in circulation concerning the Cape Cod Canal. It has been known here for some time that a company had been formed in NewYork, representing several millions, to obtain, if possible, from the present contractor, F.A. Lockwood, his entire right and title in the enterprise.

The Fire Marshal will investigate the origin of a fire which occurred last Sunday evening in the clothing and tailor shop of Bernard Wolf, at 74 Essex-street. Josoph Sugarman of 326 Bowery, formerly a business partner of Wolf's, went to the Fire Marshal yesterday and declared that he was sure that the fire was the work of an incendiary.

DETROIT, Dec. 5.--Capt. F.L. Dodge of the regular army, who came to this city in 1885 with the Twenty-third Regiment, and who has been stationed at Fort Wayne; a gentleman of great popularity in Detroit, has become insane and will be placed in the asylum at Washington. He has been failing for some time, and has lately been at Hot Springs for his health.

LONDON, Dec. 5.--Bishop Smythies of the Central African Mission has arrived at Mozambique from Likoma, Lake Nyassa. He made the journey overland from Quillimane, the crew of the boat in which he was traveling having demanded higher pay, and having quit work on their demand being refused. The Bishop denies the report telegraphed from Zanzibar that he had been attacked by natives belonging to the Makololo tribe.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday took up the matter of granting to the American Museum of Natural History the $400,000 appropriated for the museum's new wing. It was practically decided to make the grant without regard to any conditions as to keeping the Museum open on Sunday.

The pernicious example set by the "Dry Goods Cabinet" when they procured their proteges positions in the Appraiser's stores to arbitrarily advance the invoice prices of importations, so as to overcome the foreign competition under which their industry was languishing, has been followed by the American manufacturers of linoleum.

A board of medical officers to consist of Lieut. Col. Anthony Heger, Surgeon; Major Robert H. White, Surgeon, and Major Washington Matthews, Surgeon, has been ordered to assemble at the Army Medical Dispensary Building in Washington Dec. 9, to examine into and report upon the physical condition of First Lieut. Charles P. Elliott, Fourth Cavalry.
BRUSSELS, Dec. 5.--There was another exciting scene in the Chamber of Deputies to-day, the occasion being a debate over the suspension from office of the Administrator of Public Safety.
The mystery surrounding the identity of the young man who shot himself to death in the Spingler House on Sunday last deepens.

Within a few days reports will be received from Brazil giving the details of the revolutionary movement. To enable the readers of these reports to understand their purport and meaning it is necessary that they should have a more accurate idea of the geographical and political conditions of the country, generally speaking, than is usually found in the books to ...

The two great virtuosi who are now astonishing and delighting this public by their performances have presented more meritorious programmes than that which they performed at the Metropolitan Opera House last night.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 5.--A movement is on foot to form a straw and rag paper trust for the purpose of restricting production and advancing prices. Agents have been operating in the West with considerable success, and are now working their way East.

Major John W. Powell, Director of the Geological Survey at Washington, addressed the Chamber of Commerce yesterday explaining his plan for the proposed redemption of arid lands in the West by irrigation. About one-half of the lands of the United States, he said, exclusive of Alaska, were arid.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 5.--A bold and successful robbery was perpetrated in the City Hall late yesterday afternoon. A man entered the Controller's office and, stating that he was foreman of fire engine No. 15 at Black Rock, asked for his pay order. He was given it.

The managers of the New-York Bible and Fruit Mission yesterday re-elected last year's board of officers. The officers were: President --Mrs. Henry C. Davis; Vice Presidents--Mrs. Rebecca Collins and Mrs. William C. Mott; Corresponding Secretary--Mrs. Edward Tatum; Recording Secretary--Mrs. Anna B. Day; Treasurer--Miss Alletta Lent.

WASHINGOTN, Dec. 5.--The Republicans in Congress, excepting the pronounced silver men, are not at all prompt in forming and expressing opinions about the report of Secretary Windom. By and by there will be a flood of opinions, and it is perfectly evident that if the Secretary calculated to devote attention to another topic than the tariff ...

Dockstader's Theatre, where "The Tallapoosa," a comic opera, was produced Tuesday evening, was closed last evening. A notice posted on the door announced that, "owing to the sudden illness of Mr. Dockstader, there would be no performance."

English capital to the extent of $100,000,000 is about to be invested in this country in a single enterprise--a project that throws far into the background in the matter of comparative importance every financial scheme of so-called European "syndicates" that has been exploited.

John Modler, a farmer living near Lansdowne, Ontario, was burned to death Wednesday night. His dwelling caught fire and he set about saving his children, all of whom he carried from the burning building with much difficulty. He then returned for some valuables and did not reappear. His charred remains were found in the ruins yesterday.

PITTEBURG, Dec. 5.--The Monongahela House, one of the oldest and most famous of America's hotels, caught fire this morning, and within two hours the structure had been damaged to the extent of $100,000.
HEATHVILLE, Va., Dec. 5.--Capt. Russell, in command of the Virginia steamer Ida Augusta, had an exciting but bloodless encounter with an oyster-dredging vessel near Hog Island today.

The Washington Memorial Arch fund is growing slowly in spite of the distraction of public attention by the fund for the big fair. A more general collection of small contributions is hoped for to furnish the $38,000 still needed.

EAST TAWAS, Mich., Dec. 5.--The Miner House took fire this morning from a defective chimney. Prompt work on the part of the firemen saved the west portion of the hotel, but the rest of it was destroyed.

Chief Officer Cusick and thirteen of the crew of the steamship Edith Godden, which foundered off the Jamaica coast on Nov. 20, arrived here yesterday on the steamship Atalanta from St. Ann's Bay. The Godden sailed from Montego Bay for this port at 5 P.M. on Nov. 20.
ALBANY, Dec. 5.--There were 8,050 deaths in New-York State in October, according to the monthly bulletin of the State Board of Health.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 5.--A special dispatch from Middlesborough, Ky., to the Manufacturer's Record reports the sale of 260,000 acres of coal and timber land near that place, to English capitalists, who, it is stated, contemplate the establishment of one of the largest coal, iron, and steel enterprises in America at Middlesborough.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 5.--The annual report to the Legislature of the South Carolina Railroad Commission shows that in June, 1888, there were 19,134 miles of road in the State, and in June, 1889, there were 20,934 miles, an increase of 180 miles. The physical condition of the roads was much improved.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 5.--The funeral of Gen. Stephen R. Smith will be held at 2 o'clock Saturday afternoon, and the burial will be with military honors.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 5.--The suit of Dr. Nathan R. Gorter against Robert Garrett for $25,000 for professional services, which has been pending in court, was settled to-day. Dr. Gorter offered to compromise for $18,000; the proposition was accepted and the money paid.

The death of Jefferson Davis removes the most conspicuous figure in that civil war which more than any series of events since the independence of the United States decided the destinies of the American people.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5.--Edward Silcott, cashier of the Sergeant at Arms of the House of Representatives, has fled, carrying off about $72,000 of the funds intrusted to his care.
BOSTON, Dec. 5.--The total amount of insurance involved in the Thanksgiving fire as officially reported to date is $2,304,900. Additional insurance returns are appended:

Among the corporations in Missouri that are in danger of losing their charters because they have failed to comply with the anti-Trust law of that State is a stove company whose factory is in St. Louis.
Dr. Joseph D. Bryant of the Health Department read a paper that bristled with facts and figures before the Academy of Medicine at 12 West Thirty-first-street last evening.

Thomas Brennan, a lawyer, who was charged by William C. Davidson of 280 Broadway with grand larceny, was discharged on his own recognizance yesterday by Judge Gildersleeve in the Court of General Sessions.

S. Goldbach Co., manufacturers of cigars at 207 East One Hundred and First-street, have failed and confessed judgments to H. Geisenheimer for $5,898 and to J. Simons for $4,117, on which Deputy Sheriff Burns has taken possession of the factory. The firm began business Oct. 1, 1887.

The Board of Review of the National Trotting Association ended its session for 1889 at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel, yesterday afternoon by deciding that Mr. De Noyelles was in the right in his controversy with Nelson, and it ordered the latter to pay back $750 to the Hartford track and to remain suspended from the Circuit until the sum be paid.
NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 5.--Jake Kilrain reached Richburg, Miss., last night, to stand his trial for prize fighting. The trial will commence Monday, Dec. 9.

Vincent Ambrose Russell was shot in the abdomen by the accidental discharge of a pistol which he was trying to take from Peter Paul White in Guttenberg, N,J., Oct. 19. Russell, who was drunk when shot, died in a hospital in this city.
NEW-ORLEANS, La., Dec. 6.--Mr. Davis died at 12:45 this morning.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 5.--The Young Men's Democratic Club of Canton, Ohio, celebrated the second anniversary of President Cleveland's tariff message to Congress to-night with speeches, a banquet, and ball. Col. C.S. Brice and other well-known Democrats were present.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., Dec. 5.--Gov. Green's new Monmouth County Water Company, it is thought, has run against a snag.
LONDON, Dec. 5.--The British gunboat Watchful is stranded at Lowestoft, county of Suffolk. The Watchful is a composite vessel of 560 tons and mounts four guns.

MELROSE, Kan., Dec. 5.--Four Kiowa Indians came from the reservation Tuesday night and by some means obtained a quantity of whisky. They became very drunk and started to take the town in true Western style, and City Marshal Snyder attempted to arrest them.

The meeting yesterday of the special committee of the Senate, to consider the affairs of the annexed district, developed nothing much to the purpose, except that the residents and property holders of the district are by no means agreed upon the course that ought to be pursued.

Something has happened during the last few days to stir up the men who want to succeed Charles M. Stafford as United States Marshal in Brooklyn, and the candidates, Robert Fielding and Frederick Cocheu, have been flying around town like chickens on a hot gridiron.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 5.--The Rev. W.R. Dale, pastor of the Seventh Baptist Church and one of the editors of the Christian Index, the Baptist organ of Georgia and Alabama, was to-day fully identified as J.O.H. Nuttall, a notorious bigamist who figured in the public prints in 1880. Several months ago a North Carolina printer who came to Atlanta met the Rev. ...
LONDON, Dec. 5.--The action brought by Mrs. John W. Mackay against the proprietors of the Manchester Examiner for libel in publishing an article charging that prior to her marriage ...
ALBANY, Dec. 5.--The following are comparisons of the reports of the railroads named for the past two years:
A fair for the benefit of the Home for the Destitute Blind, at Tenth-avenue and One Hundred and Fourth-street, was opened yesterday at the Hotel Brunswick.
The British Admiralty has just discovered that a most inopertune time has been selected for adding so largely to the naval strength. Broad Arrow says:

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 5.--The manufacture of steel in the South, which hitherto has not been attended with much success, is to be engaged in by the Southern Iron Company, a new corporation with a capital of several million dollars.

William Cooper, an aged beggar, who lived at 656 Water-street, this city, and who has been a familiar figure on the East Twenty-third-Street Ferry boats for many years, was run over and killed by a wagon on one of the boats late on Wednesday night. The pole knocked him down and both his legs were broken by the wheels passing over them.

The committee who are to make things pleasant for the Pan-American delegates and their party when they visit this city met again in the Governor's Room at the City Hall yesterday, Chairman Cornelius N. Bliss announced that a printed programme had been prepared, and this was read by Secretary T.C.T. Crain. It filled out the skeleton programme proposed at Wednesday's meeting.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 5.--One of the most brilliant social events ever held in Princeton took place in University Hall this evening. The occasion was the annual cotillion of the Senior Class. Immediately preceding the assembly the College Glee, Banjo, and Mandolin Clubs gave a concert in the Second Presbyterian Church.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 5.--Chairman Michener and Secretary Milliken brought the Republican State Central Committee to town to-day, but the response to the Chairman's call was not so general as had been expected and the attendance at the meeting was not large.

Mrs. C.F. Ober delivered an address before the Woman Suffrage League last evening in the parlors of Mr. John W. Lovell's residence, 4 Lexington-avenue, on the educational aspect of the suffrage movement. Mrs. Lillie Deveroux Blake presided, and Mrs. Mary Seymour Howell, Mr. Justus Wood, and Prof. Gunton made a few remarks. Among the others present were Emily L. Wakeman, Docie C. Goss, Hannah Allen, Carrie F. Lovell, Jennie McAdam, and Bertha Johnston.

Patti, "ever fair and ever young," to use the language of her favorite poet, entered NewYork again yesterday to begin another series of farewell appearances. With her was Signor Nicolini, the perennial Manfred, two Mexican dogs, and some servants.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 5.--The first account of D. Herbert Hostetter, administrator of the estate of Dr. David Hostetter, who died over a year ago, was filed to-day.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Dec. 5.--The firman granting amnesty to Cretan insurgents is published. The decree reduces the number of members of the Cretan National Assembly from eighty to sixty; repeals the law which allows one-half of the customs revenue to be administered ...

The annual election and monthly dinner of the Baptist Social Union of Manhattan Island took place last evening at Delmonico's. The large dining hall was draped with American flags in honor of the subject which had been announced for the union's postprandial discussion--"The Influence of the Colonial Life and Times upon the Present"--and some earnest and patriotic sentiments were expressed.

John Devlin, a wealthy Brooklyn contractor, obtained an attachment from Justice Platt yesterday against all money belonging to George Swift, a fellow-contractor, and now in the hands of the National Transit Company. Swift is doing a bit of contract work for the company amounting to $270,000, and Devlin is his banker.

Dr. John S. White, President of the Berkeley Athletic Club, said to a TIMES reporter in regard to the criticisms that are being made by Yale men on the management of the recent football game between Yale and Princeton:

A visit to the immense establishment of Edward Ridley Sons, 309-321 Grand-street, will more than repay the shopper in quest of novelties in the line of dry and fancy goods and Christmas gifts. Toys, games, and dolls are found in delightful plenty.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 5.--Robert McCoy and Will Hicks, negroes of Lowndes County, were noticed to be in possession of a large sum of money, and were arrested to-day, and at once confessed to the murder of Capt. Hughes and wife of Clinch County for the purpose of robbery.
The St. Nicholas Society, which to-night has its annual banquet, last evening transacted the more serious business of its annual meeting at Delmonico's.

Mayor Grant told the other members of the Board of Estimate and apportionment yesterday that he was heartily in favor of acquiring for the city the land and buildings on Ward's Island used now by the Commissioners of Emigration. The people sent there by this board could be taken care of by the city.
RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 5.--Lieut. Gov. Massey to-day laid before the Senate a letter from Messrs. T.P. O'Connor, Donal Sullivan, and H. Campbell, Irish members of the British Parliament, ...

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 5.--One of the largest and most important civil service examinations ever held here is set for Saturday. At that time an examination for departmental and railway postal clerks will be conducted by Special Agent F.M. Higgins.
The only objection ever made to the civil service law that was worth any attention is that it is not practical.

All of the teachers in the primary department of Grammar School No. 50, of which department Miss Susan Wright is Principal, have united in formal charges against the latter, accusing her in nineteen specifications of violations of the manual of the Board of Education.

A new style of horseshoe has been patented by two Wisconsin men. It comes in sections and fills a long-felt want. The trouble with horseshoes heretofore has been that they brought good luck all in a lump.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 5.--The Board of Canvassers of this city will have a knotty problem to solve at their meeting next Monday night to canvass the results of the late election. The next City Council stands a tie, politically, unless the Democrats can manage to upset the election of John Clay, Republican, in the Fifth Ward, and this they profess to be able to do.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 5.--Gen. John W. Noble, Secretary of the Interior, and Russell B. Harrison arrived here this morning. Secretary Noble says his visit has no political significance, and is entirely of a private nature, simply to look after some personal business affairs. Mr. Harrison's visit is also of a strictly business character.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5.--Louis Arrington, District Master Workman of the combined District Assemblies Nos. 143 and 149, Knights of Labor, was at the Windsor Hotel this afternoon, and when questioned about the future movements of the striking glassblowers said:
Attorney General Tabor has rendered an opinion on the venison law, in which he holds that venison killed before Nov. 1 may be legally held in possession or sold up to Dec. 15.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 5.--This was the closing day of the Bruce sale of thoroughbreds, and thirty-six horses changed hands for $12,025, an average of $334.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 5.--The labor unions of Cedar Rapids last night adoptod resolutions opposing the re-election of Senator Allison because he has always favored corporations and never did anything for the laboring men during his long term in Congress; because he has ...

The November-December issue of the American Antiquarian pictures a smoking pipe of dark gray slate, in which bowl and stem are very distinct, which was found in the Flamenco mine in San Salvador, Central America.

The Kings County Prohibition General Committee met last night in the Johnston Building, on Flatbush-avenue, Brooklyn, and after filibustering for over three hours expelled James Morton, the wealthy Scotch baker and one of the most influential members of the committee.

District Attorney Ridgway received a dispatch from Albany yesterday stating that Gov. Hill had refused to grant a respite to John Greenwall, who is to be hanged in RaymondStreet Jail, Brooklyn, this morning for the murder of Lyman S. Weeks.
The condemning of the United States frigate Brooklyn causes one of the old and historic ships of the navy to disappear from the navy lists.
The fascinating and ferruginous frankfurter has enlarged its sphere of pernicious activity this Winter and may now be daily seen exposed for sale along the busy thoroughfares away down town.

According to reports from reliable sources the cause of the Dolphin's detention in port is the absence of a rapid-fire gun which several days ago was shipped to the Brooklyn Navy Yard, but of which no trace has since been found.
ALBANY, Dec. 5.--In the Court of Appeals to-day the following business was transacted:

The purchase of $1,000,000 of Government bonds yesterday by the Treasury added some vigor to bull confidence in the closing hour of the market, and there appeared something like buoyancy throughout almost the entire list. On all sides there seems now to be a wellgrounded faith in the continuance of ease in the money market. Foreign exchange is finally at a point where even gold may be imported without any loss of consequence.

The Albany Argus declares that THE TIMES is in error in assuming that those who demand a general registration in this State as essential to the working of the Australian method of voting desire "an annual personal registration throughout the State, such as is now in operation in New-York City and Brooklyn."

Cruel fate and the vigilance of Statesman Thomas F. Gilroy brought an inglorious end to the secret campaign of that ingenious gentleman, Mr. james M. Lyddy, who, before the last election, tore himself from his legal pursuits to make an attempt to capture the office held by Recorder Smyth.

The large dormitory of the New-York Orthopedic Dispensary and Hospital at 126 East Fifty-ninth-street was fragrant with flowers and bright with the happy smiles of some twoscore convalescent little patients yesterday afternoon, when the ladies and gentlemen who have labored for a decade to foster this deserving charity assembled there to hold their annual meeting.
The petition for a commission to lay out the route of another elevated railroad in Brooklyn was presented to Mayor Chapin yesterday by Henry J. Cullen, Jr.

The guarantee fund of the World's Fair hasn't yet crept up to the five-million-dollar limit. The Mayor's office received only $1,314 yesterday. Not counting the $9,254 already published in THE TIMES and credited to the Mayor's office, the Committee on Finance reported for yesterday's receipts the sum of $3,260. According to the books of the Chamber of Commerce $162,088 is needed to make up the five millions.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 5.--The most active day's business in grain charters in the history of this port was that done yesterday. Nine steamships were chartered to load full cargoes of grain to Cork for orders in the months of January, February, and March. The total charters call for over 80,000 quarters, or about 650,000 bushels of grain.

Judge Wheeler of the United States Circuit Court yesterday decided that James Hope, the noted burglar, must be given two days to get out of this State and could not be held by the Sheriff of Cayuga County, who had arrested him on an indictment for breaking jail in that county.

The Star Theatre was filled yesterday afternoon by the enthusiastic admirers of Mrs. Parnell, the occasion being a benefit tendered her by Mr. W.J. Scanlan. About $877 was realized. Between the third and fourth acts Mr. Scanlan, after repeated calls, addressed the audience.

Henry A. Blake's friend, whose absence from home had brought dismay to his family, as told in yesterday's TIMES, made his appearance yesterday morning and was surprised to learn that any one had been worried on his account.

Gen. Austin Lathrop, Superintendent of State Prisons, was in this city yesterday. He had a difficult office to administer ever since he was appointed, owing largely to the frequent and unreasonable changes in the law. But he nevertheless keeps his temper and looks prosperous under it all. He said to a TIMES representative yesterday:

LONDON, Dec. 6.--A dispatch from Zanzibar announces that Emin Pasha has met with a probably fatal accident. Being near-sighted, he walked out of a window by mistake and fell on his head, fracturing his skull.

Mrs. Olive E. Friend, Mrs. Emily Howard, Orrin A. Halstead, and George Halstead, the quartet who were implicated in the electric sugar refining swindle, stood up before Recorder Smyth in Part II. of the Court of General Sessions yesterday and changed their former pleas of not guilty to guilty of grand larceny.

The new vessels now building for the Canadian Pacific Railroad, and destined to run on the Pacific side of the great route about to be established between England and India, are to be filled with gun platforms.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Dec. 5.--The Niagara River fishermen below the Falls are in a quandary as to how they will eke out an existence hereafter. One of their number, John W. Gillett, has been sued in the Supreme Court to recover ...
Despite the constant kicking against Deacon Richardson his railroad company continues to make money.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Dec. 5.--At the meeting of the Orange Lake Ice Yacht Club to-night Gardner Van Nostrand presented the club with a gold cup costing $250, to be known as a challenge cup, the winner not to be compelled to race more than once in a season for it. The cup is being made in New-York.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 5.--The William Means and John R. Decamp Metropolitan Bank case was called in the United States Court this morning, but it was like the play of "Hamlet" with Hamlet left out. Mr. Means was not there, but John R. Decamp, who might be likened unto the Laertes of this tragical comedy, was on hand. Judges Sage and Hammond were on the bench.
The White Star steamship Teutonic, which arrived yesterday from Liverpool, was detained somewhat by severe weather. Westerly storms prevailed the greater portion of the voyage.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Dec. 5.--The General Term of the Fifth Judicial District has filed a decision affirming the judgment of the court below in the interesting case of Hurlburt against the Rome, Watertown and Ogdensburg Railroad Company, a suit involving questions of the respective rights and duties of railroad companies and passengers.

PARIS, Nov. 19.--The exiled Parisians are coming home fast. That in itself is not astonishing, for in any case, with or without the crowd, a native-born cannot remain long happy outside the Boulevard atmosphere; so this is not extraordinary; but the civility of the coachmen is a revelation. It is as good and refreshing as convalescence from a malignant fever.

PORT ARTHUR, Ontario, Dec. 5.--Considerable excitement was caused here yesterday, when a bailiff, at the instance of a tax collector, seized a locomotive and seventeen cars, the property of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company, for taxes due from the company. The whole train, some of the cars of which are full of freight, was side-tracked.

Tickets to the Amateur Athletic Union's annual boxing and wrestling championships, to be held in the Metropolitan Opera House Dec. 19, are in great demand, and the boxes in the Opera House are near1y all disposed of. Tickets can be obtained at the New-York Athletic Club's house, 104 West Fiftyfifth-street, and at the office of the Sporting Times. Entries close to-morrow.

The movement to prevent fire insurance companies, foreign and American, from reinsuring their risks in companies not subject to American law, received a set-back at a special meeting of the New-York Board of Fire Underwriters held on Wednesday.

A workingmen's mass meeting to urge Congress to have the World's Fair in New-York was held last evening at the Cooper Institute, under the auspices of the Central Labor Union, the Central Labor Federation, and the American Federation of Labor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5.--A proceeding has been instituted before the Inter-State Commerce Commission by the New-York Board of Trade and Transportation against the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, the Pittsburg, Fort Wayne and Chicago Railroad Company, and the Pittsburg, Cincinnati and St. Louis Railroad Company. The complainant in this case alleges as follows:

Judge Lawrence, in Supreme Court, Chambers, decided yesterday that the order of arrest against Col. John O'Byrne cannot be vacated, and the Colonel therefore finds himself in precisely the same position occupied by Graham McAdam, who last Spring declined to answer questions put to him by the Commissioners of Accounts in the market investigation.
BOSTON, Dec. 5.--The squadron of evolution is now announced to sail on Saturday. The vessels are now all coaled up except the Boston, which will finish coaling to-morrow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5.--When the International Marine Conference met to-day Admiral Sir George Nares, Chairman of the Committee on Sound Signals, on which was imposed yesterday the duty of selecting fog signals for a vessel not under command, or a vessel engaged in laying or picking up a telegraph cable, reported that the committee had decided to give two new distinct signals for the classes of vessels in the condition alluded to.

In the dim, cold light of the early morning yesterday Henry Carlton, a haggard, armbound murderer, walked slowly out into the chill air of the Tombs Prison courtyard, and within thirty seconds from the time he stepped under the iron ring dangling from the hideous crossbar above him life had departed from his body.

HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 5.--The Texas Western Railroad, which for three years has been in the hands of a receiver, was to-day formally transferred to its recent purchaser, Elijah Smith of New-York, all litigation having been satisfactorily settled.

Chief Engineer Greene of the Dock Department testified before the Commissioners of Accounts yesterday. He made a capital witness. After his examination he said that he got the impression from the questions asked him that there was a suspicion as to his efficiency and integrity.

ZANZIBAR, Dec. 6.--The condition of Emin Pasha is slightly improved to-day. He, however, in addition to the injuries to his head, received severe internal injuries when he fell.

The special meeting of the New-York Yacht Club, announced to be held next Tuesday evening, has been postponed to Friday evening of next week.
