After three hours' deliberation a jury in the Court of General Sessions yesterday found Charles Wilson guilty of manslaughter in the first degree. He shot his wife in Tenth-avenue, near Eighty-first-street, last June.

Mildred Kraft, a vivacious young woman of twenty-three, who is known to have atleast three husbands alive at this time, was made defendant yesterday in a suit brought in the City Court, Brooklyn, by Edward J. Kraft, one of her victims, for an annulment of his marriage.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 6.--M. Pierro de Coubertin, a young man who has been sent to this country by the French Government to study athletics at the American universities, was in this city to-day.

LEXINGTON, N. C., Dec. 6.--The Pointer Derby of the Central Field Trial Club was finished today, and the all-aged setter stake commenced. The following is the result of the pointer Derby: Riprap beat Lady Hessien; Riprap beat Joy, Jr. For second prize: Joy, Jr., beat Flirt and won second prize. Miss Mealy was awarded third prize.

LONDON, Dec. 6.--All the evening papers have leaders on Jefferson Davis. The Glob recalls Mr. Gladstone's eulogium, including the famous phrase so much criticised at the time. LONDON Dec. 6.--The copper syndicate holds less than 130,000 tons of that metal taken from the Soci t des Metaux. It is the intention of the syndicate to maintain the price of copper at from 50 to 55 per ton.

The name of ex-Congressman Paige has been mentioned in the story of Cashier Silcott's defalcation. Mr. Paige was in the city yesterday. He belongs to the firm of Paige, Carey Co., and has an office in Aldrich Court. " I was very ...

If present prospects hold out, ready money will soon be a drug in the New-York market. The Treasury bought another big block of Government bonds yesterday, and offerings are freer than at any time in months. One party in this city, said to control directly and indirectly over $20,000,000 invested in Governments, is quoted as preparing to ask the Treasury to take the whole amount.

Somerville P. Tuck, Assistant Commissioner General of the United States to the Paris Exposition, reached this city on Thursday on the steamer Westerland of the Red Star Line. To a reporter of THE TIMES he talked yesterday about his experiences at the big French fair.

Wall-street was wholly surprised yesterday by the revelations made in THE TIMES of the plans that the great English company, with $100,000,000 at command, has in view for the development of railway enterprises and industries in general in this country. ...

LONDON, Dec. 6.--The star states that it has information that Gen. Boulanger has been engaged to lecture in the United States, and that he will deliver the first lecture of the course in the New-York Academy of Music.

There are some well-founded probabilities now that the barb-wire manufacturers are not to have so smooth an experience in establishing the big combination to be known as the Federal steel Company as they first expected.

Lew Dockstader, the well-known minstrel and manager of the recently closed Dockstader's Theatre, has written a letter from Philadelphia in which he saws that he will be in New-York to-day to make an effort toward the adjustment of his affairs. He adds that Mrs, Dookstader is completely prostrated and that he himself is suffering from the worry occasioned by his business failure.

The disappearance of Cashier Silcott with all the funde of the House of Representatives which he could easily carry away, has been followed by an examination of the accounts of the office of Sergeant at Arms, but not the slightest effort has been made to ascertain where the thief has gone, or to secure his return or the capture of the stolen money.

The title of the new Gilbert and Sullivan opera is "The Gondoliers; or, The King of Borataria." A dress rehearsal of it was given in London yesterday and the first porformance will be given in London to-night. To-day an English company will sail for New-York to present the opera in this city at the New Park Theatre on Dec. 30.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 6.--The excitement which has prevailed in the Chamber of Deputies for the past few days was added to to-day by M. Janson, who, in the course of a speech, accused the Ministry of hoodwinking the public. The Minister of the Interior, he said, had acted like a fool.

Louis Susskind and Herman Cohn, the Canal-street Jewish bankers who are charged with defrauding many Hebrews of small sums of moves aggregating $50,000, were arraigned before Judge Gildersleeve in the Court of General Sessions yesterday.

An amusing anecdote of Jefferson Davis is told by Mr. Oliver Dyer, author of "Great Senators of Forty Years Ago," who is perhaps the only person in the city who has a clear remembrance of Mr. Davis as he appeared during the session of the Thirtieth Congress in 1848-9, when he was at the zenith of his Senatorial career. The steamer G. W. Clyde, which arrived yesday from Turks Island and Haytian ports, brought no confirmation of the reported trouble under the new Haytian Government. On the contrary, she brought as a passenger the new Haytian Minister to washington, Mr. Hannibal Price, who was emphatic in his declaration that everything is quiet in Hayti.

Ex-Senator Warner Miller has just concluded a Wall-street experience. It hasn't been long; it has been sufficient. He decides that he has had enough. He quits. The stock Exchange district is likely to know him no more. His friend, ex-Assistant Secretary of the Treasury Charles E. Coon, authorizes this statement.

A fair for the benefit of the new Church of St. Thomas the Apostle, on One Hundred and Eighteenth-street, near St. Nicholas-avenue,was opened yesterday by the ladies of the parish in Coleman's Hall, on One Hundred and Twenty-fifth-street, near Eighth-avenue, and will continue until Dec. 14. ...

The residence of Lewis E. Cook, one of the managers of Barnum Bailey's Great show, at 10 Taylor-street, Newark, was entered by burglars yesterday morning and $2,000 worth of jewelry belonging to Mrs. Cook was carried away. Mr. Cook is in Europe.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 6.--This morning Messrs. Powderly, Wright, and Beaumont, representing the Knights of Labor, met the Demands Committee of the Farmers and Laborers' Union, and the basis of federation between the farmers and the Knights was agreed upon.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 6.--A bill intended to prohibit the sale of Western dressed beef in this State was introduced in the Legislature to-day, It prowides that no beef that has been killed for more than twenty-four hours shall be sold in the State. The fine prescribed for violation of its provisions is not less than $100 nor more than $500.

The World's Fair Committee on Legislation met yesterday afternoon in THE TIMES Building. There were present John C. Calhoun, W. E.D. Stocks, F.B. Thurber, Alonzo B. Cornell, James E. Tappin, Ambrose Snow, Elihu Root. and H.S. Mendelson.

The Germans have a paculiar tenderness for Lessing because with him their literature, regarded as something more than merely curious for students of letters, bagan to put forth works that other nations could admire.

McGinty, the baby hippopotamus, is dead, and Mr. Richardson, the taxindermist of the Museum of Natural History, has skilfully removed the poor little fellow's best suit of clothes preparatory to stuffing them for exhibition in the showcase alongside of Crowley.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Dec. 6.--Six deeds have been filed in the Clerk's office of Lackawanna County, Penn., at Scranton, conveying that number of tracts of coal lands to parties interested in the New-York, Ontario and Western Railroad Company's new branch to the coal fields, known as the Ontario, Carbondale and Scranton Railroad. The Babies' Hospital, a charitable institution, which from its very nature appeals strongly to the generous people of this city, was formally dedicated yesterday afternoon. ...

CHICAGO, Dec. 6.--Mrs. Fannie C. Collier, wife of Frank H. Collier, the well-known attorney, filed a petition in the Probale Court to-day asking that a conservator be appointed to take charge of her husband's estate.

Gen. Francis W. Palfrey of Boston,, widely known as a historian, died in cannes. France, on Thursday, aged fifty-eight years. He graduated in the Class of '51 from Harvard College and received the degree of Bachelor of Laws in Harvard Law school in 1853. He served through the entire rebellion as a volunteer infantry officer, and in 1865 was made Brigadier General of volunteers for gallant conduct.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 6.--commodore J. K. Mitchell died last night, aged seventy-nine. He had lived here in seclusion since the war. He commanded the Wyoming prior to the war, during which he was a Commodore in the Confederate Navy.

The Hotel Kolb, an immigrant boarding house at 61 Greenwich-street, is kept by Fred kolb, a Hungarian. Three weeks ago an immigrant named Edmund Yanell was sent, it is alleged, to Kolb's house by Morris Silberstein, a clerk in the Landing Bureau at Castle Garden.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Dec.6.--Charles Backman of the Stony Ford Stock Farm has carried out the intention expressed at the time of the death of the famous trotting brood mare, Green Mountain Maid, of erecting a suitable monument to the memory of the "great mother of trotters." LISBON, Dec. 6.--The Portuguese Charge d'Affaires at Rio Janiero has been instructed to maintain semi-official relations with the provisional Government pending the recognition of the republic by Portugal. This recognition will be given when a constitution for the republic shall have been definitely adopted.
RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 6.--Here, in the former Capital of the Southern Confederacy, the announcement of the death of the Hon. Jefferson Davis is received with manifestations of the deepest regret.

A gentleman who is somewhat interested in the progress of the work now going on upon George Vanderbilt's palace on the summit of one of the peaks of the Blue Ridge in conversation with a TIMES reporter yesterday gave some interesting particulars about a place which will be, when completed, one of the most beautiful homes in the world.

WASHINGTON, Dec., 6.--The Indianapolis Journal is the home paper of the President. It is one of the few papers that he is allowed to read unreservedly, and that he reads pretty thoroughly.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 6.--Had some awful catastrophe occurred, evidences of general and sincere sorrow could not have been more plentiful than they have been in this city to-day. Jefferson Davis is dead, and his death has cast a shadow over the whole city in which he breathed his last.

Rabbit and quail Runners have had a little better weather for their favorite sport recently, and the golden opportunity was not allowed to pass by many. Indeed, every bright day the merry crack of the breech-loader was heard all over Northern New-Jersey. If every report meant a dead bird or rabbit, the slaughter would have been immense, but, fortunately for the came as well as the powder and shot dealers, many were misses.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 6.-- The present remarkably open Winter, with its green pastures and running brooks unfettered by ice, throughout Connecticut, induces Manasseh Goodwin, an old resident of Litchfield, to write to a weekly paper that one of the severest Winters he ever knew of opened in a similar manner just fifty years ago.

OTTAWA, Ontario. Dec. 6.--The Chinese question promises to attract great attention in the House of Commons next month, as a result of the demand of the British Columbia salmon packers for free Chinese labor. The urban population of the Province has made strong counter-protests against any modification of the Chinese restriction act.

PORTLAND, Mo., Dec.6.--The Advertiser this afternoon publishes letters from the Mayors of Maine cities, County Attorneys, and prominent Republicans on the subject of ballot reform as applied to this State. All except four replies favor the adpoption of the Australian system.

A Michigan Republican Justice, Judge Grove of the Supreme Court, has decided, first, that there is nothing in the Constitution to prevent the Republican Party from sending an idiot or an ignoramus to Congress; and, second, that it is no libel for a newspaper to call the candidate and prove him to be such. The case was an extraordinary one.

ALBANY, N. Y., Dec. 6.--Samuel Spencer, a Quaker, who conducted pickling works and roomed in the dilapidated building, 7 Exchangestreet, was found dead in his shop Tuesday morning with his throat out. He had a wound back of the ear and one on the cheek, a black eye, two cuts on the left forearm, and two fingers on the right hand were slashed.

Wells, a real estate owner and dealer who has represented the district in various official positions, and who spoke as the mouthpiece of the Taxpapers' Association.

Some time will pass before we shall hear the last of that most picturesque incident of the recent Ohio campaign, the use of the fictitious ballot-box contract and of the forged signatures thereto attached.

Jolly St. Nicholas descended upon the city of his adoption yesterday, and after having the most royal time in hearing himself well spoken of on every hand, ended the evening at Delmonico's, where he and 280 of his favorite sons closed the festival with a very big dinner.
LONDON Dec. 9.--The steamship Alesia, (Fr., ) Capt. Vallat. from New-York Nov. 14, are at Marseilles yesterday.

Wall-street assassinated Gov. Hill yesterday. It had been a good while since anybody of consequence had been dispatched for the sake of a stock jobbing profit, and the killing of Gov. Hill was a testimonial to the new vigor which, it is proclaimed, is coming into Wall-street.

MANSFIELD, Ohio, Dec 6.--The biggest business transaction of the year in this city was completed last night by the Barr Cash and Package Carrier Company of this place and the Lamson Store Service Company of New-York.

John Theodore Wild was the name marked on a plain stained-good coffin that was carried out of Raymond-Street Jail, Brooklyn, yesterday morning, but the body within it was that of John Greenwall, who at 7:30 o'clock had explated on the gallows the brutal murder of Lyman S. Weeks.

Judge Wallace, sitting in the United States Circuit Court, heard argument yesterday in a suit brought by Mr. Richard S. Newcombe, as administrator of the estate of Isaac Bernstein, against the Louisiana State Lottery Company for something over a million dollars, representing a one-sixth interest in the original company.

One of the Jersey City papers last evening published a statement to the effect that great frauds had been discovered in the pay-rolls of the Cattle Bureau of the Federal Government, and that investigations are now on foot.

PARIS, Dec. 6.--Miss Winifred Davis is prostrated by the news of her father's death. She sails for home next week.

BERLIN, Dec. 6.--Delegations of coal miners from Bochum, Gelsenkirchen, and Dortmund, Westphalia, assembled at Essen to-day and decided to submit to a meeting of miners to be held Sunday a resolution providing for a fresh strike, with a view to compelling the masters to discontinue the lock-out against the men who were prominent in organizing the last strike.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 6.--The Sheffield Scientific school is to have a long-needed campus next Spring. The ground cast of North Sheffeild will be graded and laid out into eight tennis courts and a baseball ground. The lot south of East Sheffield will probably be destroyed to a similar use later.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 6.--Mr. R.R. Haliday, late Cashier of the First National Bank at Mount Gilead, pleaded guilty of embezzlement in the United States court to-day, and was sentenced to the Ohio Penitentiary for seven years.

Health Commissioner Joseph D. Bryant read a paper last night on the disposition of stable refuse before the public health and hygiene section of the Academy of Medicine. He said that there are 60,000 horses in the city below One Hundred and Thirty-fifth-street, and the refuse amounted to about nine hundred thousand pounds daily.

SAN SALVADOR, Nov. 9.--The revenue of the Government of San Salvadore shows a considerable increase for the first nine months of 1889 over the corresponding period of 1888. The receipts up to the end of September amount to $2,968,740 against $2,510,049 for 1888, an increase of $449,691. The country is prosperous and the crops are good.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 7.-August Schattenberg, Secretary of the School Board, shot himself this morning at his residence on Reservoir-- avenue, because of the discovery of crookedness in his accounts. Schattenberg raised the bill of a Boston publishing house from $8.34 to $808.34 and drew the money.

Edward O'Halloran, a salesman in the employ of A. McBride, a New-York tea merchant, was recently fined $2 by the Union Hill, N. J., authorities for peddling without a license. His custom was to solicit orders one day from a regular round of customers, and deliver the next. This was held by the authorities to be peddling, and so the fine was imposed.

WASHINGTON. Dec. 7.-The sassion of the PanAmerican Conference to-day was the most satisfactory held so far with respect to the amount of business transacted. The entire report of the Committee on Committees was approved, there being but little debate on the matter.

Efforts are being made by both the New-York League and the New-York Players' Clubs to secure the services of Michael Tiernan, the clever right fielder of the Giants. Since the season closed he has been sojourning at Mount Clements, Mich., and up to date has refused to sign a contract with either organization.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec 7.-Fred W. Williams, a Senior in the Yale Scientific School, has just died at his home in Norwich, Conn., of typhoid fever. He was taken sick while at college a few days before Thanksgiving and was sent home. He had been studying hard and took but little exercise. while in college he lived at the "Closter" on Grove-street.

Civil Engineer Henry S. Craven of the United States Navy died yesterday morning at the Naval Hospital, Brooklyn. Congestion of the lungs was the immediate cause of death. Though stationed at the navy yard, Brooklyn, he was under orders to go to Pensacola the first of the coming year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7.--About twenty-five hundred people assembled in Capitol Park this afternoon and say the Princeton champion football team defeat a picked local eleven by a score of 57 to 0. A number of well-known people and a fair sprinkling of ladies were in the grand stand. The local men played a plucky up-hill game, but were greatly overmatched by Princeton's invincible rush line and "Snake" Ames's fine running.

LONDON, Dec. 7.--England awoke this morning to find everything white with snow, and though there is no likelihood in the air of a heavy fall, the effect is arctic enough to bring these islands into line with the rest of Europe, where what promises to be an exceptionally severe Winter has set in in good earnest.

The Right Rev. John Tnigg, retired Roman Catholic Bishop of Pittsburg, Penn., died at Altoona yesterday. On Thursday he was taken with a congestive chill, and he never rallied. He was conscious up to within a few minutes of his death, and the end was calm and peaceful.

The inter-class football championship of Columbia College was decided yesterday afternoon at the Berkeley Oval. The Seniors won by a score of 8 to 0. C. W. Cutler of the Law School was chosen referee and A.C. Gildersleeve, also of the Law School, recently elected Captain of next year's football eleven, was umpire. The Sophomores won the toss and chose the westerly goal.

ALBANI, Dec. 7.-New-York City is to have another iron girdle about its upper awards. It is to be seven miles in length and is to be constructed by the New-York City Suburban Surface Railroad Company, which was incorporated to-day with $500,000 capital.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 7.-Fully 20,000 people, of all ages, colors, conditions, and opinions, filed into the Council Chamber at the City Hall to-day and gazed upon the calm and peaceful features of Jefferson Davis. The face is but little different from its aspect in life. The plentiful white hair, the full white beard, and the distinct features are just as they were often seen by the populace of New-Orleans.

The past week witnessed the departure of the North Atlantic squadron, consisting of four vessels, for the West Indies. PARIS, Nov. 23.--From M. Rouff THE TIMES receives a few valuable hints as to the very latest creations of his house. The trousseaux of Mlle. Uzes and of the Princess Sophie for a time so absorbed the attention of the establishment that it seemed impossible for less important items to meet with easy satisfaction; but the special organization of M. Rouff soon regulates the demand.

The cozy chapel of the Leo House, at 6 Statestreet, was well filled yesterday afternoon on the occasion of the ceremonies of blessing the house. Festoons of evergreens hung about the walls, and over the door was written in German "St. Rafael's Verein--for the Protection of German Catholic Immigrants."

POUGHKEEPSIE, Dec. 7.-The offering of a gold cup by the Orange Lake Ice Yacht Club, to be given to the winner of a twenty-mile ice yacht race, open to all comers, has excited much interest here and at Hyde Park, where the fastest ice yachts in the world are owned, and the Orange Lake Club will find Poughkeepsie and Hyde Park represented on the occasion referred to.

The New-York Athletic Club's handsome city club house at Fifty-fifth-street and Sixth-avenue was crowded from bottom to top with ladies yesterday afternoon. There were a thousand of them and they had responded to Invitations issued by members of the club to attend the first ladies' day entertainment for this season.
All the royal family of England, with the single exception of the Queen, have now visited Barnum Bailey's show in London, and have expressed their unqualified delight at the performances.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 7.--The students of Rutgers College, New-Brunswick, engaged in a sign rush here last night, which came near terminating disastrously for those taking part in it.

Nathaniel Niles, ex-President of the Tradesmen's National Bank, who has been indicted for renting a house which was used for immoral purposes, appeared at the District Attorney's office yesterday. To-morrow he will plead and furnish bail for his appearance for trial.

CHESTERTON, Ind., Dec. 7.--The New-York limited express, west bound, over the Lake Shore and Michigan Southern Railroad, was wrecked at Dune Park, a sand-shipping station thirty-five miles from Chicago, last evening at 8 o'clock. The accident was caused by a misplaced switch, which threw the passenger train into a train of empty sand cars standing on the side track.

VALPARAISO, Nov. 2.--Great dissatisfaction arises from the manner in which the Immigration Department has been administered. The performances of the double-screw ferryboat Bergen of the Hoboken Ferry have been watched with interest by local mechanical engineers. The boat was built and launched at Newburg in the Spring as an experiment.

RED BANK, N.J., Dec 7.-The members of the North Shrewsbury Ice Yacht Club are just now greatly interested in the predictions of the Signal Service Bureau. They are patiently waiting for the announcement that the coming Winter will be wet and warm, and if such an announcement is made by the weather sharps the yachtsmen are confident that they will have a good iceboating season.

Col. Hulings Post, No. 176, G.A.R., of Lewistown, Mifflin County, Penn., will hold a fair and festival beginning on Dec. 10. Some time ago letters were sent to several prominent men of the country asking them to contribute something to be voted off at the fair.

Boscobel, the Rev. Henry Ward Beecher's beautiful home at Peekskill-on-the-Hudson, has been sold by Phillips Wells, real estate dealers to Mr. Thomas M. Stewart of this city for $75,000.

DUBUQUE, Iowa, Dec. 7.--Two freight trains came together head on yesterday at Durange, a little station on the Chicago, St. Paul and Kansas City Road. Conductor Berry of St. Paul and Fireman John Hickey of this city were instantly killed. Conductor Berry was literally ground to pieces.

White, the resignation of J.B. Winslow, and the removal of the Rev. E.C. Bolles to New-York.

Patterson was standing at the Delaware Bank counter this morning clipping coupons from bonds which he kept on deposit there, an unknown man seized Mr. Patterson's deposit box, containing about $15,000 in securities, andrau out and away. Peter Cullom, a tailor at 426 First-avenue, is eighty-four years old, but is yet the peer of many younger men in strength. BUFFALO, Dec. 8.--The canal season opened this year with brighter prospects for the boatmen than they have seen for several years. They were wise enough, too, this year to profit by the mistakes of other seasons, and they therefore have not had the sorrow of witnessing the good things that might have been theirs pass into the hands of others.

CONNELLSVILLE, Penn., Dec. 9.--Marion Crowel, a young machinist, shot and killed his friend Joseph Porter in cold blood this afternoon. There was no cause for the killing except whisky. Cowel got drunk to-day and started for Dunbar with the avowed intention of shooting his friend. When they met he asked Porter to drink.

William N. Riddle died in St. Vincent's Hospital yesterday afternoon at the age of fortytwo years. His career was out of the ordinary. There are few men of prominence in Pennsylvania who did not know him. It was in that State that most of his life's story was spun out. He was President of the Penn Bank of Pittsburg when it went down in a sensational wreck that was far reaching in its effects.

MILLERBURG, Ohio, Dec. 9--A case that interests nearly the whole of Holmes County, and is destined to be notable in the judicial history of Ohio, as it will stir up untold minor litigations and animosities, has just been heard by Judge Nicholas.

CHEMNITZ, Saxony, Dec. 9.--There is a strike of the dyers here for an advance of wages. Fifteen hundred have quit work.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9.--The work of refining sugar was commenced to-day in Claus Spreekels's immense new sugar refinery on the Delaware River, at the foot of Reed-street, in this city. The capacity of the refinery is 2,000,000 pounds of sugar every twenty-four hours.
Peter Claussen, a lineman, was killed yesterday afternoon by a shock from an electric light wire while at work on a pole at the corner of One Hundred and Fifty-sixth-street and Thirdavenue.

BUFFALO, Dec. 9.--Surveys have been about completed for one of the most satisfactory of proposed improvements which have grown out of the establishment of a free park at Niagara Falls. To make it complete, however, needs the co-operation of the Canadian Government.
The performance of "The Flying Dutchman" at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening was pitched on a high key of excellence.

Harvey Kennedy, for twenty years one of Wall-street's most prominent figures, died early yesterday morning at the Union League Club. He was in vigorous health on Sunday, and his death yesterday was from heart disease, from which hitherto it had never been suspected he was in danger.

PARIS, Dec. 9.--In the Senate to-day M. Le Breton asked if the Government, before beginning to negotiate new treaties of commerce, would consult the agricultural societies. Minister Tirard responded that he would consult both the agricultural societies and the commercial bodies.

The United States steel dispatch vessel Dolphin sailed yesterday to join Admiral Gherardi's flag in the West Indies. She was detained in port by the delay in arrival of a rapid-fire gun recently shipped to her from the Washington Navy yard.

The members of the Real Estate Exchange are beginning to boom the Washington Memorial Arch fund, and good results are expected. In this course they are following the example of their President, Mr. E.A. Cruikshank, who some time ago headed a subscription list.

The Emperor of Russia and the Germ an Emperor are each having a new yacht built. The latter's is to be very fast, so that he may be able from it to command and direct naval manoeuvres--a science in which his imperial Majesty believes himself a past master. The Emperor of Russia's boat, which is called the Polar star, is remarkable for nothing except its great size and magnificent accommmodations.

Lee and had a long chat with his excellency, Mr. Danforth, who is a strong friend of Gov. Hill, says that Hill controls the New-York Democracy now more than ever, and that he is sure to be the Presidential nominee in 1892.

A circular which is a sort of warning to banks has just been issued by the freight department of the Pennsylvania Railroad. It relates to the payment of drafts which the shipper makes on the consignee and which he sends through the banks attached to the bill of lading, the latter being the bank's collateral.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 9.--The Presbyterian Review, the last number of which was published a few months ago, is to have a successor, which is to be called the Presbyterian and Reformed Review.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 9.--The Rev. Sam Small has made application for admission and ordination in the Protestant Episcopal Church. His application is being considered by a committee of ministers, and doubtless will be favorably received. Mr. Small has been a minister of the Methodist Church, but his family are members of the Episcopal Church.

ALBANY, Dec 9.--Mrs. W.H. Manning, the bride of but a month who, with her husband, was a passenger on the first section of the night express that was telescoped by the second section at Yost's, on the Central-Hudson Railroad, Sept. 27, has recovered sufficiently from her severe injuries to proceed to Boston, where she is visiting friends.

Charles Lenz, the spellbinder who brought suit against the Republican State Committee through Chairman John N. Knapp for $2,500 for work done during the last Presidential campaign, has secured a settlement, and another suit from another orator is said to be pending.

Although there has been no very cold weather so far this season, dealers in furs are not discouraged, for they look forward to a cold snap about Christmas, which will boom the trade. The real cold weather, they say, seldom comes on before the middle of December.

HAMILTON, Ontario, Dec. 9.--A rumor was current here to-night, and was generally believed, that the police had arrested Cashier Silcott at the Grand Trunk Station as he was leaving here for Montreal. This is authoritatively denied, and the police say they do not know how such a story started.

Yesterday was a weather record breaker. The books of the Signal Service Bureau show no temperature as high as yesterday's, 57 , for Dec. 9 for the last eighteen years, or since the establishment of the station in this city. At Hudnut's pharmacy the temperature at 3:30 P.M. was even higher, registering 61 .

The New-york Ballot Reform League originated in a resolution which was unanimously adopted at a special meeting of the Reform Club, held on Monday, the 28th of last October. This resolution instructed the Reform Club's Committee on Electoral Reform to confer and co-operate with other organizations favoring the principles of ballot reform.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9.--Mayor Cregier, Gen. Crook, Postmaster Sexton, and President Peck of the Auditorium Company, and other members of the Reception Committee, took a special train to Western-avenue and Eighteenth-street early this morning, where they awaited the coming of the Presidential train.

E. Berry Wall evidently has no wish to become an inmate of Ludlow-Street Jail, and fears that such a result of the examination in supplementary proceedings, under which he has writhed for some time, may be possible.
The call is out for the regular monthly meeting of the County Committee of the County Democracy at the Cooper Institute to-night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9.--The investigation of the dressed beef business was resumed this morning by Senator Vest's special committee in the rooms of the Senate Committee on Commerce. Senators Vest, Coke, and Farwell were present.

For a long time since the Russians have made great efforts to obtain a concession for the construction of a telegraph line botween Kiakhta, in Southern Siberia, and Pekin, and recently they thought they had been sucessful. The Chinese Government seems, however, to have changed its mind unexpectedly, and it is now asserted on food authority that China has definitely resolved to grant no such concession.

Presiding Justice Van Brunt of the Supreme Court yesterday granted an order permitting the sale of the All Souls' Church memorial of Henry Anthon, D.D., on the north side of Forty-eighth-street, between Sixth and Seventh ...

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 9.--Edwin F. Fletcher was shot and instantly killed in Murfreesborough at 10 o'clock this morning by Frank B. Selph, a law student. The tragedy occurred in the office of Leland Jordan, a prominent attorney, under whom Selph had been studying for some time.

Under the auspices of the American Geographical Society last night in Chickering Hall Miss Amelia B. Edwards, the English novelist and Egyptologist, gave a lecture on recent discoveries in the land of the Pharaohs. In introducing Miss Edwards to her big audience Judge ...
Bidel, the Paris menagerie manager, has agreed to pay 28 damages to the father of the little girl who was injured by one of his bears.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 3.--That instructive and important volume forthcoming annually, "The Connecticut State Register," is now in course of preparation for 1890 by the Secretary of state, R. Jay Walsh. It will be issued in a few weeks.
An advertisement in the Philadelphia Times offers a reward of $1,500 for the return of a package containing $8,500 to Mrs. A. Oppenheimer, 174 East Ninety-sixth-street, New-York.

The committee of Presbyterian clergymen and laymen which was appointed a few weeks ago by the New-York Presbytery to consider the advisability of the revision of the Westminster Confession of Faith made its report yesterday in words which will, should its recommendation be adopted, go far toward reconciling the moderate liberals and conservatives.

HARTFORD, Dec. 9.--The factory inspection laws in this State which have been in operation for two years have resulted much good in the manufacturing communities. The new Factory Inspector, William S. Simmons of Killingly, who assumed the duties of his office the 1st of July under Gov. Bulkeley's appointment, has completed his report for the five months, showing that a thorough inspection has been made of 255 factories, employing 40,000 operatives.

Miss Marie Wainwright and her company reached this city from Toronto yesterday, and will devote the week to reciting and preparations for the production of "Twelfth Night" at the Fifth-Avenue Theatre next Monday. This is Miss Wainwright's first season as a lone star, and she talked very cheerfully of her experience and her prospects to a TIMES reporter at her apartments in the Gilsey yesterday.
"Where is Farmington-avenue?" asked a stranger on arriving at the Hartford (Conn.) station the other day.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9.--Making the round of calls upon the wives of the Justices of the Supreme Court monopolized the attention of society this afternoon.

Whitney Co., dry goods commission merchants at 73 Worth-street, suspended payment yesterday and made an assignment without preference to David A. Boody, banker, at 57 Broadway. The firm is composed of James W. Whitney, Joseph B. Whitney, and James A. Knapp. Bradstreet's reports the liabilities at $5,00,000 of which $450,000 is said to be on single-name paper and $50,000 on acceptances.

The Trustees of the Colored Orphan Asylum and Association for the Benefit of Colored Children held their fifty-third annual meeting yesterday at the residence of Mrs. Augustus Taber, 244 East Fifteenth-street. The Board of Officers was re-elected as follows: Mrs. Augustus ...

PITTSBURG, Dec. 9.--Mrs. Byron F. Gilkinson, a handsome young woman of eighteen Summers, is at the Hamilton Hotel, this city, in a sorry plight. Last Saturday her husband and his brother, James Gilkinson, were sent to the workhouse for thirty days for defrauding the ...
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9.--Among the cases before the United States Supreme Court to-day were the following:

The steamships Aurania of the Cunard Line and La Normandie of the French Line, which were due Sunday evening, arrived yesterday morning, and reported having met with severe westerly gales accompanied by high seas. The steamers were retarded somewhat by the storms, but received no injuries.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 9.--Harvard's friends have been very generous to her during the past year, and now the results of their generosity have begun to show themselves in the form of the new and much-talked-of gate, and in additions to the buildings owned by the college.

The Brooklyn police are looking for Charles Lund, a conductor on the Jay and Smith Street Railroad and Secretary of the Brighton Association, the benevolent organization to which nearly all the drivers and conductors belong.

All the departments, with the single exception of the Seventh Judicial District Court, had their requisitions for stationery in when the Board of City Record met yesterday. Supervisor Kenny explained that the change in the Clerkship of that court and Judge Monell's illness were undoubtedly the cause of the delay, and the requisition will be received later.

William O'Brien, who was butler to Secretary of State Frelinghuysen under the Administration of the late ex-President Arthur, who has been suffering from apoplexy and paralysis at Bellevue Hospital since Friday last, died at the institution last night. The body will be forwarded to Washington to-day. O'Brien had a snug fortune, and owns a large amount of real estate in the capital.

The people of this town have not yet become so callously accustomed to electric light wire accidents but that a sputtering, sizzling, flaming wire banging over their heads and carrying in its 1,000 volts possible death and destruction will attract a throng very quickly.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 9.--A reminder of the gigantic footprints of prehistoric monsters in the red sandstone of the Portland quarries on the Connecticut River has been presented to the Trinity College Cabinet here by Erastus Brainard Bulkeley of the Class of '90.

The shipments of flour, grain, and provisions from Chicago to the seaboard by the lines in the Central Traffic Association last week aggregated 47,704 tons, against 39,245 for the preceding week, an increase of 8,459 tons, and, against 59,623 tons for the corresponding week last year, a decrease of 11,919 tons.

A boy with a message for Ralph Kellar, an insurance agent with an office in the Stewart Building, called to deliver it yesterday afternoon at 4:15 o'clock. He was directed to Room 157, fourth floor, opposite the office of the fugitive lawyer, Col. John O'Byrne. The boy tried to open the door, but it was fastened.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9.--Whatever else Speaker Reed may be, he is no laggard. It has appeared to him to be desirable to get the House at work upon something. In order to do that, the House must have committees, and, in their order, these committees are three--on Elections, which passes upon the title of claimants for seats; that on Ways and Means, which indicates how ...

Sister Mary Kelly of the Webster-Street Roman Catholic Convent, at Pittsburg, Penn., tried to commit suicide yesterday by jumping from the window in the third story of a house on Wylie-avenue, Pittsburg. Her movements attracted the attention of passers-by, and she was prevented from carrying out her design. She is about twenty-eight years of age, and is believed to be insane.
It is the popular belief in Europe that the present epidemic of influenza is the forerunner of an epidemic of Asiatic cholera because cholera followed a similar epidemic in 1847-8.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 9.--Secretary Mohler of the State Board of Agriculture has finally become convinced that fraud has had much to do with the alleged business of sugar making in Kansas during the past, and he will at once begin an examination into the methods of mill men.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9.--The action of Congress on Secretary Tracy's recommendations for the immediate construction of eight armored battle ships will be awaited with much interest. Whether Congress will authorize the full number is doubtful, but there is little doubt that at least part of them will be provided for. The Secretary would ...
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec.9.--A Greensburg (Ky.) special to the Times says: "Jack Turner, who, last Wednesday, Killed Motley Williams, son of the Hon. D.M. Williams, was lynched near here last night.

ALBANY, Dec. 9.--In no department in the State service has the work increased so rapidly of late as in that of the corporation clerk in the Secretary of State's office. The increase is not so marked in business corporations as in societies and clubs. For the privilege of filing certificates of incorporation a fee of $1 is exacted ...

About two hundred members of the Union College Alumni Association held a business meeting and dined at Delmonico's last night. W.H.H. Moore presided at the business meeting and was elected President of the Association.

CITY OF MEXICO, Dec.2.--The exportation of wheat from the State of Sonora to Liverpool is beginning to attract some attention, as an indication of the development of the country and its resources by enterprise and improved means of communication. El Economista Mexicana gives the exact figures of the operation, as doubt had been expressed as to the possibility of any profit remaining to the exporter.
The steamship Alenc of the Atlas Line arrived yesterday from Port au Prince and other West Indian ports. Her officers say that when they left Hayti all was quiet.

The committee having in charge the preparations for the reception to be given the PanAmerican delegates in this city next week met in the Governor's Room in the City Hall yesterday. Chairman Cornelius N. Bliss announced that sixty of the delegates and others in their party had sent acceptances of their invitations, and several more were expected.

There is a bit of a sensation among the members of the Ohio Society that grew out of the election of officers last Friday night, and has been keeping the members talking since. Most of the members had no idea that there was to be any opposition to the regular ticket, and hence there was not a great rush of voters to the polls.
RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 8--At a caucus of Democratic members of the Legislature tonight, the following State officers were nominated without opposition; First Auditor--Morton ...

FRANKFORT, Ind., Dec. 9.--The Chicago limited express between Cincinnati and Chicago on the Louisville, New-Albany and Chicago Road was wrecked shortly after noon yesterday, half a mile south of this city.

The Palazzo Morosini, in the Campo San Stefano at Venice, is for sale, with the whole of its contents. This palace remains precisely as it was, in every respect, 200 years ago, when it was the family residence of a Doge. It is a unique example of the typical home of a great Venetian patrician of the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries.

The free admission system which has been inaugurated at the track of the New-Jersey Jockey Club has resulted in more than doubling the customary attendance at the track, and yesterday afternoon between four thousand and five thousand people were present to speculate on the six races run over a sloppy course.

A crash of glass at the show window of the jewelry store of Mills Coleman, at Grand and Mulberry streets, at 8 o'clock last evening attracted the attention of the numerous pedestrians on the sidewalk.
The big wholesale drug house of McKesson Robbins, 91 and 93 Fulton-street and 80 to 84 Ann-street, was badly damaged by fire shortly after midnight this morning.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 9.--The athletic managers at Yale University are already planning for the coming baseball season, and at the beginning of next term the Winter training will commence. There is plenty of material, and the college will be able to retain at least the baseball championship.

Christian Frink and several other property owners sent a letter to Mayor Grant yesterday showing their delight over the decision of the Board of Street Opening and Improvements to curtail the limits of High Bridge Park.

Tammany Hall, through the commissioners of Accounts, is reaching for the Department of Parks and the District Attorney's department. Those two important branches are in the possession of County Democrats, and Tammany does not like it.

LIMA, Nov. 11.--The last three days have been given up to rejoicing and public festival in honor of President Caceres's birthday.

The Board of Building Examiners, who have been for a month or more considering the revision of the building laws, gave a hearing yesterday to Orlando B. Potter. He wanted the present law liberalized in regard to the construction of large buildings for mercantile purposes.

Jerome Park as a race course and the American Jockey Club as a racing association are now things of the past. The Jerome Park Villa Site and Improvement Company's stockholders settled that at a meeting held at the jockey club's headquarters yesterday afternoon.

There was just a quorum at the monthly meeting of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge Trustees, held yesterday afternoon at their office in Brooklyn. At the suggestion of Superintendent Martin it was voted to purchase the lot on High-street, adjoining the machine shop, in order that necessary enlargement of that establishment may be made.

The suit of the Atlantic-Avenue Railroad Company to recover $15,000 from T.S. Johnson and A.I. Dupont, alleged to be rent due for the use of railroad tracks on Central-avenue, Brooklyn, was dismissed yesterday by Justice Pratt in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn.

LISBON, Dec. 9.--Dom Pedro to-day visited the Polytechnic School and attended the lectures on chemistry and physics, examined the classes and inspected the mineralogical specimens with a great interest.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 9.--The Cranford Casino Association, an organization devoted to the development of athletic sports and the promotion of social intercourse among its members, composed of prominent residents of Cranford, has fixed its articles of incorporation with the Clerk of Union County. The capital of the association is placed at $25,000.
Secretary Wilson of the World's Fair Finance Committee was almost despondent yesterday. The guarantee fund had not been lifted to the five-million-dollar level.

The rooms of the Single Tax Club in Livingston-street, Brooklyn, were well filled last evening by those who are taking such an active interest in the endeavor to promote ballot reform. Among them were Thomas G. Shearman, Fred W. Hinrichs, ex-Senator Griswold, S.B. Duryea, William H. Williams, Benjamin F. Estes, Philo W. Schofield, E.C. Curley, William Potts, and O.F. Burton.
LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Dec. 9.--In the women's ward at the penitentiary a revolt took place this morning which resulted seriously to a guard. As a result a matron and her assistant were forced to resign.
PARIS, Dec. 9.--There was a very fierce debate in the Chamber of Deputies to-day over the motion of M. Deroulede that the Chamber declare valid the election of Gen. Boulanger, ...
ZANZIBAR, Dec. 10.--There is no news to-day from Emin, and this understood to mean that all goes well.

BUTLER, Penn., Dec. 10.--At 9:15 o'clock this morning Butler was shaken from centre to circumference by a nitro-glycerine explosion at the Butler Torpedo Company's magazine, two miles south of Pittsburg.

ELBERFIELD, Dec. 10.--At the Socialist trials here the prisoner, Roettinghoff, revealed the existence of three clubs at Barmen, which is the very populous manufacturing district at the other end of the long main street of this place. The story of a railway called the Mexican Pacific, between Frontera, the Tabasco seaport, and Tonala, the only port of Chiapa on the Pacific, is believed by gentlemen familiar with Mexican railroad methods of signify very little.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 10.--The ideal Hoosier exists no longer as the chief inhabitant of Indiana, but has taken himself far away from the centres of population and dwells not at all within the range of those who would seek him in cities and towns of the State to which his sobriquet clings.
WATERBURY, Conn., Dec. 10.--During the past twenty years a notable transformation has taken place in the methods of Connecticut dairy farming.

Sugar Trust stock broke over 6 points yesterday. Further information as to the plans of refineries outside of the trust gave Stock Exchange speculators the opportunity to smash trust quotations. Not much work was necessary to precipitate the slump; the stock seemed almost ready to go down of its own weight.

LEXINGTON, N.C., Dec. 10.--The All-Aged Setter Stake of the Central Field Trial Club was finished to-day with the following result: King's Mark beat Roger and won first prize; Chance beat Roger and won second prize; Roger was awarded third prize.

The Rev. Dr. J.F. Avery, pastor of the Baptist Mariners' Temple, corner of Henry and Oliver streets, complains of various petty annoyances from his neighbors, which have steadily grown until they have become, as he says, utterly unbearable.

There was a meeting of the nut and bolt manufacturers at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel yesterday, at which a considerable amount of routine business was done by this powerful trade combination. The question of prices for the various grades of work done by the different factories ...

Maria Stelz, the widow of William Stelz, has begun suit in the Supreme Court, through her lawyer, George Kracht, to have measured her dower right in the property at 204 East Fiftieth-street, the deed of which was taken in 1886 in the name of her husband and Minnie ...
At a meeting of the Bar Association last evening it was resolved to investigate Judge Henry W. Bookstaver's connection with the Flack case with a view to presenting the matter to Legislature.

Things were in a simmering state in the Dock Department tangle yesterday. Mayor Grant had no opinion to give. He said that he had not yet finished examining the evidence sent to him by the Commissioners of Accounts.

ABILENE, Kan., Dec. 10.--The First National Bank of this city has suspended business. At the close of business last night it was apparent that the suspension must occur, and this morning its affairs were placed in the hands of the Deputy Controller of the Currency for settlement.
Palestine Commandery, No. 18, Knights Templar, of this city, start on a pilgrimage today as the guests of Poughkeepsie Commandery, No. 42.

It is about time for the entrepreneurs to stop and think Mr. Abbey's latest importation of London gayety is likely to put a large and respectable portion of this public in a meditative mood. We surely have enough that is inane and vulgar of our own, and there is no excuse for importing more.

RED BANK, N.J., Dec. 10.--The New-York and Atlantic Highlands Railroad was sold at Sheriff's sale at the Globe Hotel this afternoon. The road was built a few years ago by residents of the communities through which the road passes, ...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10.--The dispatch to THE TIMES of Monday referring to the hostility exhibited in the Washington Post to the civil service law has attracted the attention of a great many of the clerks in the classified service, and it has been noticed by two of the Washington papers.

SANDWICH, Mass., Dec. 10.--It is reported today that ex-President Cleveland and Joe Jefferson, through their agents, have purchased the islands in Wakeby Lake, one of the largest in the State, located in South Sandwich. The spot is most picturesque, and is admired by a great many Summer visitors to Cape Cod, the water affording excellent fishing. It is understood that they will erect a commodious clubhouse on the most central of the islands.

HALIFAX, N.S., Dec. 10.--Four American schooners--the Alice M. Strouple, Senator Morgan, Magnolia, and Agnes--arrived here yesterday. When off the mouth of the harbor they were spoken by a pilot boat. They did not pay any attention to the pilots' flag, but sailed up the harbor.

The trial of Supervisor Thomas E. O'Brien's suit to recover $50,000 damages from Contractor Thomas McCann for alleged libel was begun yesterday in the City Court, Brooklyn, before Judge Clement and a jury.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 10.--The Richmond and West Point Terminal Company held a meeting here to-day. New-York stockholders were represented by Edward Lauterbach and Gen. S.M. Logan. Mr. Lauterbach read the annual report of President John H. Inman, which says:
BOSTON, Dec. 10.--The Australian ballot system had another successful trial in to-day's municipal election. The results only confirm the favorable opinions created at the State election.

There are at present over 600 seamen aboard the United States receiving ship Vermont. Of this number fully 560 are either native or naturalized Americans. It is the finest body of men that has been seen at the Brooklyn Navy Yard since the close of the last war.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10.--High officers of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company said to-day that until they have an opportunity to speak before the commission they will say nothing in regard to the suit brought by the New-York Board of Trade and Transportation against the Pennsylvania Railroad before tha InterState Commerce Commission.
ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 10.--The first session of the thirteenth annual convention of the NewYork State Dairymen's Association was held this afternoon in the Court House in this city.

SAN JOSE, Nov. 24.--The late political excitement has entirely subsided. Senor Esquivel, the defeated Presidential candidate, has left the country for Guatemala. The new Cabinet is giving perfect satisfaction, and the liberal and sound judgment of Senor Ricardo Jimenez is trusted, although his tendencies are rather clerical.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Dec. 10.--The Board of Trade has voted unanimously to recommend the consolidation of the United States Navy and Revenue Marine, as provided for in the bill drawn by Senator William E. Chandler now before Congress.

ALBANY, Dec. 10.--The annual report of Superintendent of Public Works Shanahan on the tonnage of the State canals has just been completed. The whole number of tons of freight carried during the past season was 5,370,369, a ...

The sixth annual Christmas sale of the Working Girls' Vacation Society opened in the Ortgies Art Gallery, on Fifth-avenue, between Thirtyfourth and Thirty-fifth streets, yesterday, and will continue through to-day. It is a very attractive place. All the decoration is of a kind to suggest Christmas, and the articles for sale are beautiful and of considerable value.

Larry Keegan, an oiler employed on the steamship San Marco, which arrived in port a few days ago, went on a spree the day he reached the city and kept it up. He was discharged yesterday for drunkenness, and two of his comrades started to take him home in a wagon. On the way they stopped at a saloon, and while they were in the place Keegan died.
Here's a new swindling scheme: John Lindo, a saloon keeper to 576 Ninth-avenue, was called upon yesterday afternoon by two men, one of whom said he was an inspector from the Bureau of Incumbrances.
The large wholesale coal dealing firm of Alpers Swarthout, whose offices are in the Washington Building, 1 Broadway, are in serious trouble.
The Inter-State Commerce Commission began at Washington yesterday the hearing in the longpending complaints of George Rice against a number of railroad companies.

Capt. S.T. Farnsworth of the schooner Avis, who was injured in the collision of his vessel with the steamer Providence on Sept. 26 last, died yesterday at City Island. The Captain was holding the wheel at the time of the accident, and one of the spokes entered his body and mangled him in a frightful manner. He was landed at City Island, where he has since remained. He belonged in St. John, N.B.

Henry Foh, who was leading the cow that created such a disturbance on the corner of Eightieth-street and First-avenue Monday afternoon, was brought before Justice Welde yesterday morning in the Harlem Police Court.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Dec. 10.--Report has been received here to the effect that the steamer Michigan has been wrecked on Enterprise Rock, about five miles from Roche's Harbor, which is situated about seventy-five miles north of Seattle, on Puget Sound.
A decree of divorce on the ground of desertion was granted in the Circuit Court, Chicago, last Saturday, to Mrs. Wilson Waddingham from her husband, the Chicago millionaire.

The Rev. and Mrs. Frederick H. Northrop of Beloit, Wis., started Monday to engage in missionary work at Maravavad, India. Mrs. Northrop was formerly Miss Nina Alcau, whose associations with the Salvation Army created a sensation about two years ago. At that time she sold her jewels and silk dresses and donned the uniform of the Salvationists, leaving a good position and friends to engage in missionary work in New-York and Brooklyn.
LIMA, Ohio, Dec. 10.--The body of the Hon. J. H. Rathbone has been lying in state in Castle Hall of Lima Lodge to-day and carefully guarded by a detail of knights from the local lodge.

Two young fellows of the Bowery stamp have for some time past been "makin' bid dust" by a rather clever little scheme, which, however, is of such a petty nature that the people whom they dupe are satisfied to kick themselves for their credulity and say nothing.

The announcement in yesterday's newspapers that officers of the Tennessee Coal and Iron Company had instituted a suit for heavy damages against the company's ex-President, John H. Inman, was a surprise to Wall-street.
Capt. Henry Gouge, founder of the Atlantic Yacht Club, and for some time its measurer, has written a letter to THE TIMES, in which he discusses the subject of yacht measurement.

All who are interested in the port of Liverpool must be aware that the retention of the ocean passenger trade by that port will depend very much in future upon the facilities offered for the landing of passengers in the docks or at piers where their luggage can be examined and easy access to railways be obtained.

At the meeting of the Academy of Anthropology yesterday Gen. Charles W. Darling of Utica read a portion of a very comprehensive paper on "The Prehistoric Archaeology of America."

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 10.--Rome has decided the celebrated case of the Convent of Mount St. Ursula in this city in favor of Sister Alphonse, the deposed Mother Superior.
At present English is practically an unknown tongue at the Vatican. The Pope can neither speak it nor read it. Cardinal Rampolla, the Secretary of State, is in the same plight.

The training ship Jamestown sailed from Newport yesterday on her Winter cruise to the Windward Islands. She will remain at sea twenty-five days before making any part. She will go as far south as Trinidad.
One of the most eminent jurists in the country remarked when Chief Justice Fuller was confirmed that the position was still vacant.
It has been quite the custom at the recent meetings of the Society of Amateur Photographers for some one to take a flash-light picture of the audience.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10.--Sir Julian and Lady Pauncefote started the social ball to-night by an elegant reception to the International Marine Conference.
The importance of classifying the convicts in the State prisons, as the law of this year, recently quoted in THE TIMES, provides, is evidently greater than many people suppose.
From interesting statistics published in the Taranaki Herald, it appears that the progress of New-Zealand has attained considerable dimensions during the past thirty years.
ALBANY, Dec. 10.--The State Workingmen's Assembly met in the courtroom, of the City Hall to-day. A large number of representative workingmen from different parts of the State were in attendance.

ALBANY, Dec. 10.--The novel case of Jennie P. Fosdick against her husband, C. Baldwin Fosdick, which created considerable talk in Newport and New-York society, was decided in the Second Division of the Court of Appeals today in the wife's favor.
The investigation of the Dock Department by the Commissioners of Accounts has not been so conducted, at any stage of it, as to command the confidence of the public.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind Dec. 10.--The Indianapolis Presbytery, after a long discussion of the proposed revision of the Confession of Faith, has referred the matter to a committee with instructions to report at the meeting next April. The majority of speakers, and they were many, favored a revision, but they differed widely on the specific changes proposed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10.--The bond offerings accepted to-day were as follows: Registered fours, $750,000, $25,000 deposits. $100,000, $150,000, $9,000, $250,000 deposits, and $800 at 127; coupon tours, $100, $10,000, $30,500, and $3,600 at 127; registered four and a halfs, $50,000 deposits, $5,000, $6,000, $700, $71,000, and 9,300 at 104 5/8.
LONDON, Dec. 10.--The steamship Runic, (Br.,) Capt. Thompson, sld. from Liverpool for New-York to-day.
PARIS, Dec. 10.--The influenza, or grippe, is extending widely throughout this city. One hundred and thirty employes of the Central Telegraph office are now ill with it.

Mr. De Witt J. Seligman will, in all probability, send his resignation as a Commissioner of Education to Mayor Grant to-day. Commissioner Seligman says that it is impossible for him to continue to give the time to Board of Education work which he has been giving for more than five years.

TORONTO, Ontario, Dec. 10.--The city detectives are under the impression that Silcott, the defaulting cashier of the Sergeant at Arms' office in Washington, is here, and two officers have been busily engaged all day in searching for him. They watched two well-known hotels and searched the registers of half a dozen other resorts, but so far their search has been unavailing.
RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 10.--The most important election bill ever introduced in the Virginia legislative session was presented in the House to-day by Mr. Flood, the Democratic member for Appomattox.

WATERTOWN, S.D., Dec. 10.--A mixed train on the Manitoba Road ran off the track to-day near the south shore, twenty-two miles from Watertown. Six cars and a combination car were precipitated down an embankment, instantly killing Engineer James P. Haines, Fireman John Kirlahen, and Brakeman John Rooney, all of Benson, Minn.
Baron Nathaniel de Rothschild's shooting party at Schillersdorf, in upper Austria, bagged 2,520 brace of pheasants, 2,600 hares, and 210 brace of partridges in seven days' sport.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 10.--Mr. Elliot Danforth, the Democratic Treasurer-elect, and Gen. James Otis Woodward, the Chief of Ordnance of New-York, who have been booming Gov. Hill down here for the Presidential nomination, left for Washington to-night. They intended going to Raleigh, N.C., but the prolongation of their visit here prevented them from doing so.

BUFFALO, Dec. 10.--This week there is a large amount of hard wheat in store here--over 3,100,000 bushels. This is the largest amount which has been held at the close of navigation since 1885, and would be amply sufficient for our needs if it were only to stay here.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 10.--The opening of the Poughkeepsie Bridge has given rise to many rumors about the consequent lessening of freight rates on the coal that it brings into New-England, but none of them seems to be well founded.
WASHINGTON, Dec. l0.--The United States Supreme Court adjourned to-day until Thursday at 12 o'clock.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 10.--When Mrs. Betsey Bradley, a somewhat eccentric widow, died about a year ago, the bulk of her property ($350,000) was bequeathed, to religious and charitable institutions. The will was contested by Mrs. Gustavus Eliot, a niece of the testatrix, on the ground of insanity, and the case was pending in the courts. The matter was compromised to-day, however, the contestant accepting $25,000 in lieu of her claim.

The consumption of horse flesh has increased enormously during the last year in Berlin and Vienna, the meat being in great demand by the working people, who can buy it at the rate of 2d. per pound. Between seventy and eighty horses are now slaughtered every day in Berlin for the market.

BOSTON, Dec. 10.--There was a lively commotion in Harvard-square, Cambridge, this afternoon, caused by a "dead" telephone wire. Paulus Verholy, an Austrian, was arrested at Newburg, N.Y. last night for bigamy, His first wife and her three children have come to testify against him, having just arrived from Europe. Verholy, after coming to America four years ago, married a girl at Low Point Dutchess County, and went to Newburg to live. By the second marriage two children have been born.

LONDON, Dec 12.--The amnesty granted by the Sultan of Turkey to the Cretan insurgents and political offenders does not include those who were tried by court-martial and condemned prior to the issuing of the firman granting amnesty. Mr. Straus is a brother of Oscar Straus, ex-Minister to Turkey, and is a man of good business ability and many business connections.

The order of B'nai B'rith has taken a prominent part in the Hebrew educational fair, now in progress at the American Institute Building. It is represented prominently in the manage ment and at nearly every table and booth. Next Monday evening, however, the order will come to the front. At that time it will have an especial and distinctive gathering at the fair, at which its members are expected to be present in full force.

William Seebacher, a clerk in the office of the Receiver of Taxes, has been dismissed from his position for not paying over at once money given him by friends for the payment of taxes.

The Bergen estate in Bay Ridge, consisting of about one thousand feet frontage on the bay, was sold yesterday to Frederick A. Chase, representing a New-York syndicate, for $168,000.

MADRID, Dec. 12.--Senor Castelar said in a interview that the events in Brazil had been no surprise to him. He believes that the example will be followed in Portugal sooner or later, but not in Spain, beacause in Spain the Regent during the King's minority, keeps Liberal Ministers in office, and has allowed Sagasta to establish universal suffrage. He thinks the Brazilian republic is stable.

BERLIN, Dec. 12.--The influenza is spreading through the country. The administration of justice in the courts is suspended because all the Judges are down with the epidemic. It is proposed to close all the schools, especially at Dantzic, where at least half the children are affected.

BOSTON, Dec. 12.--A quiet earthquake would have produced no more commotion on Statestreet to-day than the news that F.S. Mordaunt Co. investment brokers of 7 Exchange-place, have skipped the town and left numerous unsettled debts behind them.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 12.--Charles C. Ford, the advertising agent of this city, is in financial straits, having met with heavy losses during the past year. He has sent a circular to his creditors proposing a compromise of 20 cents on the dollar.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 12.--Large numbers of people visited Metairie Cemetery to-day to visit the tomb of the Benevolent Association of the Army of Southern Virginia, in which repose the remains of Jefferson Davis.

SYDNEY, Dec 12.--The present session of the New South Wales Parliament was called especially to provide for the Government service, and the elaboration of the budget has been the main point of interest.

Early last summer a New-Englander moved out to a small town in Arizona and announced his intention of opening up a first-class grocery. He had a number of bills posted up, dwelling particularly on the fact that the business was to be square and above board.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Dec. 12.--A Winnipeger who just arrived from the Pacific coast tells of a thrilling accident to the Canadian Pacific through express in the mountains on Saturday last. A rail gave way at a point on the mountain side high above the Columbia River.

The plant of the Wicks Manufacturing Company, at South Worcester, Mass., way sold at auction yesterday in a mortgagee's sale to the mortgagee, Charles Fletcher of Providence, R.I., for $20,000. This sale was due to the foreclosure of a thirtythousand-dollar mortgage given to Mr. Fletcher by Joseph Wicks in March, 1889. This company made an assignment for the benefit of its creditors a short time ago.

Edward N. Dickerson, the noted patent lawyer, died early yesterday morning at his country residence, Wave Crest, near Far Rockaway. While he was not confined to his bed until a few days ago, he had been in poor health for some months and had withdrawn from active practice.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Dec. 12.--The seventeenth annual convention of the State Grange closed here to-night. There were about 250 delegates present, representing 374 granges or lodges, with a membership of 12,000.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 12.--The annual report of the Free Public Library Association of this city for the past year shows a gratifying increase in the patronage of the library. During 1888 there were 20,374 books in circulation, while this year the circulation ran up to 34,569, or an average of 116 daily.

The South Side Gun Club of Newark, N.J., defeated the Amersford (Long Island) Gun Club in a clay pigeon shoot yesterday afternoon. The score was: South Side, 292 killed, 83 missed; Amersford 244 killed, 131 missed. A team of fifteen from each club shot in "blocks of five."

The Hon. Charles T. Saxton, Senator-elect and sponsor of the ballot reform measures in this State which have so greatly interfered with Gov. Hill's peace of mind during the last couple of years, was in this city yesterday, and as usual found many opportunities of freeing his mind on the one subject above all others in which at present he seems to be interested.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 13.--The great feature of the anniversary of the Philalethean Society at Vassar College this evening was the address of the Hon. Chauncey M. Depew.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Dec. 13.--A young farmer named Almond Bruce, while returning from the city last night, met with a peculiar accident. He was overtaken by a team of runaway horses, smashing his wagon, and throwing him underneath the wreck in the road.

CITY OF MEXICO, Dec. 7.--The increasing interest taken in this country by English capitalists is making itself felt more and more every day, and consequently the foothold and influence gained by England to the exclusion of the United States is becoming more pronounced.

ROBERT BROWNING lived long enough to see a very sharp distinction drawn between "the BROWNINGS." Ludicrous as it seems to us now, thirty years ago he and his wife were ranked together and criticised together, so far as such an uncritical association did not preclude the possibility of criticism.

PURVIS, Miss., Dec. 13.--Judge Terrell called this morning the case of the State of Mississippi against Jake Kilrain for prize fighting and assault and battery. District Attorney Neville was ready to proceed. Col. J.B. Deason, a prominent attorney of the county, and A.T. Perryman, were ready as counsel for the defense.

The Nineteenth Century Club listened last night to three addresses about the "Construction of a Play." The speakers were Bronson Howard, Dion Boucicault, and Brander Matthews. The audience was a large one.

More than one hundred enthusiastic Alumni and friends of Wesleyan University assembled at Clark's, in Twenty-third-street, last evening to celebrate the twenty-first annual meeting and dinner of the Wesleyan University Club of this city and to welcome President Bradford P. Raymond, the newly-elected head of the university.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 18.--The Atlanta and West Point Railroad has notified Controller General Wright that it was exempt and would not pay the tax on sleeping cars which was imposed on all roads by the last Legislature.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 13.--There has been considerable discussion of late in regard to the opposition of Archbishop Ireland and other Catholics to the confirmation of Gen. T.J. Morgan as Commissioner of Indian Affairs.

Eight-year-old Fred Britner of 530 West Forty-fifth-street was run over by a beer van yesterday afternoon and was crushed to death. The driver, August Trendle of 535 West Fiftyseventh-street, employed by Schaeffer Sons, was arrested.

LONDON, Dec. 13.--The strike of the men employed in the gashouse of the South Metropolitan Company was effected peaceably. Twelve hundred men who were engaged to take the strikers' places entered the works under escort of police. A crowd outside the works hooted them. The pickets posted by the strikers to intercept these men were outwitted, and were unable to obstruct their entrance.

John A. Belvin, the wealthy tobacconist, of 168 Duane-street, who disappeared suddenly on Nov. 30, returned to his home, 372 Halseystreet, Brooklyn, yesterday. No one was allowed to see him, and at the house it was said he was ill and under the care of a physician.

LONDON, Dec. 13.--The Dean of Westminster has telegraphed to the family of Robert Browning, offering a place in the Abbey for the burial of the poet; but it is probable that the offer will be declined, and that Mr. Browning had himself arranged for his burial in the same grave with his wife, at Florence.

Capt. John W. Farrand of San Domingo died suddenly of pneumonia on Thursday at the Stevens House. Funeral services were held in Trinity Church at 5 o'clock last evening.

ST. JOHN, N.B., Dec. 13.--The Council to-day voted a subsidy of $10,000 a year for twenty years to James D. Leary of New-York for the costruction of a dry dock at St. John. Certain Philadelphia capitalists and other New-York capitalists offered to do the work for a subsidy of $5,000, but their offers were rejected.

The list of Mayor Grant's 300 organ grinders is filling up rapidly. More than 215 licenses have already been issued. Most of these licensed grinders had their organs out yesterday, and people who enjoy their music had all the opportunity they wanted to hear the old-time favorite airs ground out again. Those persons who have no appreciation of the hand organ sighed and gave thanks that the street band is still under cover.

Some of the little speculators who lately have been dabbling upon the bear side of Sugar Trust stock were given a scare yesterday, and there was a lively covering of short contracts by traders whose "lines" generally comprise as much as 200 or 300 shares at a time. This movement was of consequence enough to lift the stock's quotation about three points, all of which gain, however, was not maintained.

LONDON, Dec. 13.--The mangled body of a woman has been found among the ballast of a vessel at Middlesborough, shipped at Millwall. The hand has been round elsewhere.
