A letter has been received by the Royal Geographical Society of London from Mr. Stanley giving some of the geographical results of his remarkable expedition. A few extracts were read at a recent meeting, and the whole will be published in the December number of the society's "Proceedings."

John H. Inman gave a dinner at Delmonico's last evening to Henry W. Grady, E.P Howell, W.A. Hemphill, and S.M. Inman of the Atlanta (Ga.) constitution, which was an unusually elaborate affair. Unfortunately, however, for the entire enjoyment of those present, Mr. Grady was unable to be with the party.

The State Examining Board, appointed recently to inquire into and report upon the military and executive ability of Capt. A.W. Belknap, Seventy-first Regiment, completed its labors yesterday with the exception of its findings and decision.

The Stevens High School football team won the pennant of the Inter-Scholastic Football Association on the Washington Park grounds. Brooklyn, yesterday, by defending the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn, by a score of 6 to 0. No points were scored by either side in the first half.
MONTREAL, Dec. 14.--W.J. Davidson, son of the senior member of the wholesale grocery firm of Davidson Fletcher, St. John's N.F., who had visited Boston and Montreal to get...

The ingratitude of Kings and the ingratitude of democracies have often supplied the text of historic or political sermons; the ingratitude of readers and spectators, from Shakespeare's day to our own, is at least as notable and memorable.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 14.--Milton Young has sold to Ed Corrigan of Kansas City the brood mare Una., thirteen years, by War Dance, dam by imported Knight of St. George, and the mare Square Dance, ten years, by War Dance, dam by imported Mickey Free, he paying $2,500 for the two.

Our old and esteemed friend the Congressional Record comes up smiling for the fifty-first round. The reappearance of the paper at this time fills a long-felt want, and its cheerful countenance is gladly welcomed. The contents are varied, well chosen, and admirably arranged.

FORT DAVIS, Texas, Dec. 14.--North and east of this point, stretching far away to that strip of nondescript soil known as "No Man's Land," is the remnant of the so-called Great American Desert, designated on the maps and in the geographies as "Llano Estacado," or Staked Plain.
JOHNSTOWN, Penn., Dec. 14.--The heavy rains of the past twenty-four hours have raised the rivers to an alarming height. At 3:45 P.M. the bridge across the Conemaugh at Woodvale was washed away.

None of the Justices of the General Term of the Supreme Court came down to the Court House yesterday. Charles E. Hughes and Paul D. Cravath, lawyers representing respectively the United States and Brush Electric Light...

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 14.--Canadian bankers are opposing the movement in favor of the adoption of the American national banking system after the bank charters expire in 1891. They declare that the existing plan of securing note circulation and managing banks generally should be continued.

Gazing into shop windows is not in these days the exclusive privilege of our country cousins. Instead, it is the daily amusement of such countless thousands of New-York's very own that the down-town street blockades are repeated upon the up-town pavements, often on no very small scale.

A clever capture has just been effected at Genoa of a notorious Buenos Ayres bandit of the name of Ippolito Andre. He headed a gang of desperadoes in that country, whose robberies within the last few months are said to amount to 1,000,000f.

The tract of land extending from Fort Hamilton to Bath Beach, consisting of 225 acres and having a water frontage of 3,000 feet, has been sold to a syndicate of which Edward Egolf is the representative for about $400,000.
CANAJOHARIE, N.Y., Dec. 14.--A heavy snowstorm is prevailing in the Mohawk Valley today, which promises excellent sleighing for to-morrow.

Many philanthropic ladies of this city have prepared a petition to the retail dealers of this city to grant extra pay to their female employes for extra work required during the season of holiday trade. The petition has been circulated by committees of young ladies, ...

An appeal for aid comes from St. Benedict's Home. The institution shelters destitute colored children, and is supported solely by voluntary contributions. At present the home can accommodate only thirty-six, and daily unfortunate homeless children are turned away from its doors.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14.--The Philadelphia League Club to-day engaged Joseph Mulvey of last season's team, and the contract has been sent to Mr. Young for approval. Mulvey had previously signed a Brotherhood contract. Col. John J. Rogers, Secretary of the Philadelphia Club, has sent a letter to John M. Vanderslice...
Rufus Martin, a dealer in railroad supplies at 15 Broad-street, received injuries in a runaway accident on Friday afternoon which will probably prove fatal.

Excellent shooting was done at the Seventh Regiment Armory last night, and ten members carried off the prizes for the Armory Omnibus Match of the Seventh Regiment Rifle Club with good scores.
A new illustrated weekly periodical devoted to social news and current topics covering the field in New-Jersey adjacent to New-York City made its appearance yesterday on the Jersey railroads.

As a poet Mr. Tupper enjoyed more favor with the general public than with the critics. His peculiar verse has been a frequent theme for the satirists, and yet the attacks upon him only seemed to confirm his hold over the masses. He lacked genius and inspiration, but there was a kind of oracular air about his utterances which greatly impressed those who did not examine beneath the surface.

The end of the hunting season is painfully near for those who love to tramp over the fields and through the woods with a light breech-loader over their shoulders. In NewJersey the protecting hand of the law intervenes between the gunner and the lively rabbit or swift-flying quail next Monday.
TORONTO, Dec. 14.--Meat is said to be dearer in Toronto than in any other market in this continent. This is owing to the syndicate that buys up live stock and prevents local competition.

Two minor branches of the doll industry form distinct trades--the making of shoes and eyes. The shoes are made from the waste material of children's ornamental shoes and boots; but this branch is a smaller one than that of eye-making...

Harlem is soon to have a new theatre, and an exceedingly handsome one at that. By next September the various "combinations" will have to take into consideration the new Columbus Theatre, which will be conducted in connection with the Harlem Opera House.

Richard Croker, Tammany's chieftain, will be back in the city this week. He has been down in North Carolina taking a rest. It was a pretty good time of the year for him to be away, for although there is not much going on in politics just now, there are plenty of the officeseeking gentry about who would like the exclusive use of Mr. Croker's ear often enough to keep him busy.
A well-dressed man standing on the rear of a Broadway car a few days ago handed the conductor a ten-cent piece in response to a call for "fare."

On the 9th inst., before the Emperor and the imperial family, Mr. Edison's agent--who by his name and also from the musical selections he presented is a Portuguese--exhibited the phonograph, and all present expressed great satisfaction with the results.

At the request of the Geographical Society, Capt. Binger last night lectured at the Sorbonne on Central Africa, which he explored. He went alone through vast regions, following the example of Livingstone, who was as harmless to the negro as he was courageous.

The other day a gentleman and two ladies were traveling from Stourbridge to Birmingham, says the Birmingham (England) Times, and the gentleman made cigarettes for the three, the ladies putting theirs with modest assurance.

The funeral services of Oliver R. Kingsbury, the veteran Treasurer of the American Tract Society, took place at his late residence, 239 West Fifty-fourth-street, yesterday morning at 10:30 o'clock. The Rev. John R. Paxton of the Forty-second-Street Presbyterian Church conducted the services and spoke with feeling of...

The enforced retirement from the stage of Lawrence Barrett is a lamentable incident of the theatrical week. Mr. Barrett is in the prime of life, and he has looked forward to many more years of zealous artistic work.
ALBANY, Dec. 14.--The State Canvassing Board met to-day in the office of the Secretary of State. The returns are in from all the counties in the State except Rensselaer.

BOSTON, Dec. 14.--A message received from the European Union of Astronomers announces the discovery of a faint comet by Prof. Borrelly. The following is the discovery position: 12:31 Greenwich mean time, right ascension, 18 hours 7 minutes; north declination, 48 52'. Its daily motion in right ascension is 18 minutes; in declination. 1 .

In yesterday's storm of snow and sleet and cutting wind the Brooklyn Montauks laid the cornerstone of their new clubhouse, in course of erection in Eighth-avenue and Lincolnplace, facing the plaza of Prospect Park.

A train plunged through the open drawbridge across the Hackensack at Little Ferry, N.J., yesterday, and three of the hands employed upon it lost their lives. It belonged to the New-York, Susquehanna and Western Railroad, and consisted of thirty loaded coal cars.

A very complete souvenir publication entitled "Our Firemen" has recently been issued in connection with the entertainments to be given at the Metropolitan Opera House on the evenings of Dec. 17 and 21, to raise a fund to take care of the sick and injured firemen and fire patrolmen of this city.

An agreeable variant on the time-worn story of the mother who managed to save her child from the eagle's nest after two men had failed in the attempt, was reported yesterday. Mrs. Miles, of St. Peter-street, Hackney, left her two...

The first meet of the Albany County Fox Club was held on Monday. Major Balch was master of the hunt, and there was a field of sixteen horsemen and two ladies--Mrs. Bowditch, a most graceful ridor, and Mrs. Harris. There was a brilliant array of horses and carriages. The chase was west of the city. A second meet will be held this week.

The Maryland Historical Society has received a letter from the executors of the late James Howard McHenry, offering to deposit with the society the public papers of James McHenry, M.D., who was during the Revolution one of...

A notable event in society was the reception given by Mrs. John H. Watson yesterday at her residence, 67l Fifth-avenue, on the occasion of the debut of her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Rowe Watson. The handsome parlors, decorated with palms and masses of roses, were filled with guests.

DUBLIN, Dec. 14.--The Earl of Zetland, the new Viceroy of Ireland, arrived at Kingstown this morning and immediately proceeded to this city. A royal salute was fired upon his arrival here, and he received a remarkably enthusiastic reception.

At Wloolawek, in Poland, a man named Pawlikowski has just died at the age of 115. He fought through Koseiusko's wars and through Napoleon I.'s Russian campaign. He was working in the fields up to last year. His father is said to have lived to the age of 126, and one of his brothers died at 116. He leaves three sisters aged 102, 99, and 93, respectively.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14.--To-day's bond offerings accepted were as follows: Coupon 4s, $100, at 127; registered 4s, $650, $100,000, $25,000, $41,000, $402,500, $100, $10,000, $25,000, and $200,000, at 127; coupon 4 s. $150.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 14.--Mrs. Jefferson Davis and her stepdaughter, Mrs. Hayos and the party of the household left this afternoon for Beauvoir, the Davis homestead, on the Gulf shore. She will remain there about a month to arrange her affairs, when she will return, with Mr. and Mrs. Hayes to their home in Colorado.

The first freight-classification rate sheet of the new Pennsylvania, Poughkeepsie and Boston Road goes into effect to-day between Slatington, Penn., and Campbell Hall, N.Y., where connection is made with the New-York, Ontario and Western Road. Heretofore the New-England and Northern New-York business at Slatington was handled by...

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Dec. 14.--Mannell Co. of this city control 22,000 acres of the finest quality of farm lands in Essex County, Vt., close to the Canadian line, on which it is the intention to found a colony of Scandinavian farmers, and a member of the firm will go to Norway the first week in January to bring emigrants thither, while the firm will send an agent to Sweden for the same purpose.

Edward Verbreska, forty years old, the janitor of the flats at 199 West One Hundred and Thirty-fourth-street, while taking out ashes from beneath a small elevator yesterday, was killed by a twenty-five-pound iron weight falling on his head. The rope to which the weight was attached had become rotten. Verbreska was married and had one child. Coroner Schultze took charge of the case.
Some years ago a class of children in the Dallas Academy, the public school of Selma, celebrated the anniversary of the birthday of Jefferson Davis.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 14.--To-day the Hon. W.J. Blackburn, editor of a Republican newspaper and formerly member of Congress from Louisiana, prints a letter which he received from Jefferson Davis, and which is believed to be among the last of the epistolary work of the "Father of the Confederacy." While Secretary Tracy was making his official tour on the Despatch several months ago, THE TIMES was the only paper to give the principal reason of his visit to Newport, which was mainly to look over the available sites for a war college building, and the assertion was made that it would again revert to Coaster's Harbor Island.

The centennial celebration of the first sitting of the United States Supreme Court will be held in this city on Tuesday, Feb. 4, under the auspices of the General Committee of One Hundred of the New-York State Bar Association. A good deal of the preliminary work has already been done.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 14.--A special from McKeesport, Penn., says: "Since the death of Searle there has been considerable stir in aquatic circles, and it is probable now that rowing will start as soon as the season will permit with the greatest sweepstake race that ever took place in the history of aquatics.

For the first time since the charges of immorality were brought against the Rev. Dr. Rylance, rector of St. Mark's Protestant Episcopal Church, by certain members of his congregation through Vestrymen William V. King and Nicholas Quackenbos, the doctor will occupy his pulpit to-day.

Car No. 99 of the Eighth-avenue line was at Canal-street and West Broadway yesterday morning when the king bolt broke, and the team dragged the reins from the driver, George Hanford, and ran east on a gallop.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 14.--Gen. Steele, commanding the First Brigade, N.G.S.N.J., who for two or three years has refused to order elections in the First and the Orange Battalions for the election of Lieutenant Colonels of those battalions, has at last, upon the advice of the...

DETROIT, Dec. 14.--Shipments of iron ore by water from the Lake Superior mines show the season's work to have been unprecedantly large, the total figures being 6,804,511 tons. This is 2,182,564 tons in excess of the lake shipments of 1888. The shipments by rail for the year have been not less than 300,000 tons more.
LISBON, Dec. 14.--Dom Pedro to-night gave audience to three of his former Ministers. It is reported that he approves of Viscount Preto's proposed manifesto.
BOSTON, Dec. 14.--The official returns of the city election for Mayor are as follows: Hart, 31,130; Galvin, 25,722. Mr. Hart's plurality is 5,408.

Gen. Frederick Townsend has presented to the Trustees of the Albany Academy a rare and valuable decoration, to be worn by the successive Majors of the cadet battalion. It is a portion of the cross of the Legion of Honor, consisting of the crown and the pendant, beautifully mounted on a gold plate, to which is attached a gold bar and ribbon.

Columbia this year is earlier in the field with her tug-of-war work than in any previous year. Ever since Nov. 1 the candidates for the various class teams have been in training at the Columbia Grammar School Gymnasium.

The American Federation of Labor, which has been holding a national convention in Boston during the past weak, is made up of trades unions and includes, for the most part, the most intelligent class of workmen--those engaged in the more or less skilled labor of the various mechanical industries of the country.
NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 14.--The Supreme Court of this State has given a decision which affects the Newport cottagers materially in the matter of convenience while going to and from New-York.

This morning I dug out an interesting fact at the Pension Office. It is that the widow of Jefferson Davis is at once eligible to receive a pension by reason of her husband's services in the Mexican war. "Of course," said the official with whom I talked, "her name will not be placed upon the roll unless she makes a regular application in due form, like anybody else."

In the matter of actual business accomplished the real estate market during the last week was without important feature. The apathy of buyers, as reported a week ago, still continued, and at this time there seems to be no definite prospect that it will be relieved until after the opening of the new year.

A dispatch from Troy, N.Y., to-day stated that the Citizens' Steamboat Company had decided to sell out for $1,000,000 to an English syndicate. President Joseph Cornell, when seen by a TIMES reporter yesterday afternoon at his residence, 26 West Forty-ninth-street, said that this story was made out of whole cloth.

This town was more effectively in darkness lastnight than at any time since the electric are light was introduced into street illumination here. A new industry has made its appearance in the hotel corridor which, from the satisfied expression of the proprietor's face, seems to pay handsome profits. The man does not confine himself to any one locality, but is found now in one familiar corridor, now in another.

The season could not be much gayer at its height than it has been during the past week. Rarely has December brought such a rush and whirl, and if the rate of progress of the past week is maintained there will be few persons left to witness the closing hours of the Winter gayeties on Feb. 19.

The last of the Autumn course of lectures given under the auspices of the State Department of Public Instruction was delivered yesterday morning by Prof. Albert S. Bickmore in the lecture room of the American Museum of Natural History.

BERLIN, Dec. 14.--The success of the centre party in the vote in the Reichstag relieving all theological students of the obligation to military service has stirred up a good deal of a breeze in the upper world of politics, and Prince Bismarck complains in regard to it that the highest interests of the Government service are neglected for personal interests of individaal deputies.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 14.--The report has been received here that Representative-elect Shipley of Guthrie County is lying in a critical condition at his home near Yale from the results of the bites he received in his recent difficulty with W.I. Edwards, and is not expected to live more than a few hours. The Grand Jury of Guthrie County has returned an indictment against Edwards.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Dec. 14.--Jose Maria Belmonte was fatally stabbed in a duel yesterday by Juan Recendes. The stabbing occurred on the Grower ranch. The men were in love with the same lady and agreed to fight it out with knives. Recendes escaped.

Many years ago, while on a walking tour in the West Midlands, I came to a river, and guessed that it was Shakespeare's Aven in its course through Warwickshire to meet the Severn near Evesham, in Worcestershire.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 14.--Clarence W. Ashford, Attorney General of the Sandwich Islands, a Canadian by birth, is here. He says the Hawaiian Government recently engaged Dr. Lutz, an eminent authority on skin diseases, to make a study of leprosy, with the object of seeing if a cure can be effected.
LONDON, Dec. 4.--Within the past fortyeight hours Mr. Gladstone has delivered three set speeches, the reports of which are roughly equivalent to two whole pages of fine type of THE NEW-YORK TIMES.

LEXINGTON, N.C., Dec. 14.--The last heat of the All-Aged Pointer Stakes of the Central Field Trial Club was run to-day. Mr. Edward Dexter's Pontiac beat Dr. C.E. Michel's Bannerman, and was awarded third.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 14.--With a look of determination upon his expressive features and a flash of excitement in his eyes at the prospect of a vigorous political contention that he so dearly loves, Senator Anthony Higgins appeared in Superior Court yesterday afternoon to champion the right of the Republican politicians of Wilmington to cast votes by proxy...

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Dec. 14.--A most peculiar burial took place here yesterday afternoon. On the 26th day of November last Dr. John W. Bartlett died in Los Angeles, Cal. In accordance with the terms of the will and oft-repeated wish of Dr. Bartlett his remains were cremated.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 14.--It is now generally conceded by the river coal operators of the Monongahela Valley, who gave options on their entire property to Mr. W.P. Shinn for a New-York syndicate, that a sale will not be negotiated.

A recent visitor to St. Helena draws a picture of the state of affairs there which is certainly far from creditable to the Government: "The island is left in a derelict state, as if it were one of the assets of a bankrupt empire, with powerful batteries and no garrison; a good harbor without a dock; a port of call unrivaled in position, without telegraphic or even proper postal facilities."

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 14.--The steamship Indian, building for Henry Winsor Co., Philadelphia, was launched at the Harlan Hollingsworth Company's yard Thursday.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 14.--This afternoon about 3:15 o'clock George W. Evans, alias William Franklin, alias Ladyhand George, a notorious and daring sneak thief, entered the United States Express Company's office, 164 Gravitystreet, and attempted to steal a package containing $10,000 in currency awaiting shipment...
AMHERST, Mass., Dec. 14.--The second of the serial of indoor handicap meetings occurred this afternoon at Pratt Gymnasium. There were three events--fence vault, running high kick, and pole vault.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 14.--J.M. Graves was today appointed temporary Receiver of Akers Brothers, millers and dealers in grain. Last evening Akers Brothers made a sale of their stock of raw material and manufactured products...

Lincoln College has recently purchased a picture of John Wesley which has been pronounced on competent authority to be either the original or a replica of a picture painted by James Williams and sold by him Sept. 10, 1743.

The Pan-American delegates will come to town to-morrow, and the committee that proposes to make their stay a pleasant and profitable one had its final meeting in the Governor's Room at the City Hall yesterday.
No volume in this series of admirable biographies has been awaited with the interest that has centred in Mr. John Morley's.

LONDON, Dec. 14.--A heavy fog prevailed here to-day. It was feared, owing to the fact that it was necessary to burn gas during the day, that the supply would not prove adequate because of the strike of the gas workers. These fears proved groundless, however, as the supply was well maintained.

The Washington Memorial Arch fund received yesterday $25 from S.F. Jayne, $25 from W. E. Callender, and $5 each from Hamilton G. King, A. Jacobi, M.D. and Charles Place, making the total fund $61,935.31.

Patrick Sullivan, a fireman in the employ of the Manhattan Electric Light Company, was killed yesterday morning by an electric shock at the company's works, at Avenue B and Eightieth-street. He was carrying an incandescent electric lamp at the time, but as he was alone when he received the shock which killed him the precise details of his death will probably never be known.

GREAT FALLS, N.H., Dec. 14.--A bold attempt was made last night to rob the Great Falls National Bank. At about 6 o'clook Assistant Cashier Buffum started the time lock and went home. Cashier Stickney remained talking with a man about a business matter.

The effort of the Homeopathic Medical Society to have the present medical board of the Ward's Island Hospital dissolved, because half a dozen of the twenty-four members are not active members of the society, made no perceptible headway yesterday.

Charles Wilson, who was sentenced to twenty years' imprisonment by Judge Martine for the murder of his wife, Louisa, on the night of May 19 last, attempted suicide in his cell yesterday morning by taking a quantity of Paris green.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 14.--John H. Rauch, Jr., who has for some time past conducted a savings bank in the eastern section of the city, is reported to have disappeared. The depositors in the bank were composed mainly of poor persons, and the average amounts were from $3 to $20.
EATONTOWN, N.J., Dec. 14.--The appointment of A.B. Nafew to the position of Postmaster of this village has caused no end of comment. Mr. Nafew, who is a druggist, received his commission last week.

I learn on reliable authority that the Russian Gagarin Navigation Company has obtained from the Servian Government the authorization to establish large petroleum depots in the Danubian port of Gladova.

The disappearance of two girls from Tottenville, S.I., has been the source of a great deal of gossip in that village. Both were domestics. Cecilia Anderson was employed in the house of Capt. C.C. Ellis, a widower, who owns a towboat and has an office at 60 South-street, New-York...

A dispatch from Providence says that Secretary Tracy has officially authorized the naming of the sea-going torpedo boat No. 1, now nearing completion at Herreshoff's works, at Bristol, the Cushing, in honor of Commander William P. Cushing, who blew up the Confederate ram Albemarle, at Plymouth, N.C., in 1864.

Professional runners are now training in England for the Sheffield Handicap, to be contested during Christmas week. These contests between the fastest professional runners in the world are the greatest events of their kind that take place nowadays. Professional running has fallen off considerably in this country since the days of such men as L.E. Myers...

The glee club quarter will be composed of the following men: First tenor, J.L. High, '91; second tenor, W.H. Hildreth, '92; first bass, C.E. Hildreth.'92; second bass, O.B. Merrill (leader,) '91. An octet has also been formed of last year's glee club members. Preparations are being made at present for the Christmas tour, from Dec. 25 to Jan. 10.

Sir Edward Guinness, the well-known brewer and head of the great Irish firm, has placed in the hands of Lord Rowton, Mr. Ritchie, President of the Local Government Board of London, and Mr. Plunket, First Commissioner of Works, a sum of 250,000, ($1,250,000,) to be held by them in trust for the erection of dwellings for the laboring poor.

The 1st of January, 1890, will be signalized by the accession of a new nation to the number of those now enjoying independence. It will be a small nation in point of numbers, but it will not be wholly without influence.

The cheese trade between America and this country is a very large one. Last year we imported 813,000 hundred weights from the United States and 668,000 hundred weights from Canada, making together 1,481,000 hundred weights, and this year the figures promise to be as large.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14.--The big sash and door manufacturing firm of C.J.L. Meyer Sons Company made a voluntary assignment to-day to J.B. Goodman. Besides a five-story factory on the north pier the assignment involves a branch concern at 307 and 309 Wabash-avenue, where the company did an extensive business in wooden mantels and grates.

Civil Justice Ambrose Monell of the Seventh District Court died last night about 7:30 o'clock, at his residence, 152 East Sixty-firststreet. He had been ill since early in September. For several weeks before his death the physicians in attendance had given up all hope of his recovery.

As an examine of the groveling, senseless servility of many of the papers, I may point to a telegram which was printed last week announcing that Prince Alfred of Edinburgh "had the misfortune" to wound a German officer while out shooting near Coburg. I should think that the "misfortune" was on the part of the victim of the young Prince's awkwardness.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 14.--R.S. Veech of the Indian Hill Stock Farm has contracted with the owners of Axtell to have that famous young trotting stallion serve seventeen Indian Hill mares at $1,000 each. This is the highest price ever paid for the services of a stallion in this country.

LONDON, Dec. 14.--To English-speaking races the death of Robert Browning marks this week with a signet of its own and makes all other topics trivial. There still is too much truth in the familiar gibe that to stir England to the very core nothing serves so well as the death of a popular...

The approach of Christmas has begun to make lively work for the army of people employed in the Post Office, and it what has been done during the past week in the money order department can be taken as a criterion, there will be a large increase this year in the amount of Christmas business.

The great railroads of the East are confronted with a weighty problem. It is agreed that the commercial development of the near future will assume enormous proportions. It is also agreed that the inadequacy of the present paltry terminal resources of the several great systems will be one of the first demonstrations of its growth. Hence the problem.

Three months ago, after a brief wooing, Nicola Peruharmie, a coarse young Italian tailor of perhaps twenty years, induced sixteen-yearold Alvena Amabile to marry him. Last night he tried to shoot her, and failing, put a bullet into his own head.

A very beautiful fan has been painted by Mile. Abbema for the new Princess of Monaco-- lately the Duchesse de Richelieu. The fan is to be presented by the Monagesque maids and matrons to their Princess on the occasion of her entry into the delightful dominions of her husband.

At a meeting of the Executive Committee of the athletic organizations on Tuesday night it was decided to build a new baseball cage. An exceedingly enjoyable evening was had by some seven to eight hundred members of the Liederkranz Society last night at the clubhouse in Fifty-eighth-street. It was an evening of social intercourse, refreshments, and music for the main members of the society and their friends.

TUCSON, Arizona, Dec. 14.--The trial of the seven men on the charge of robbing Paymaster Wham of the United States Army of $26,000 last May, was concluded to-day, and the jury rendered a verdict of acquittal as to all of the defendants.

The "Authors' Readings," under the auspices of the American Copyright League, to be held at the Brooklyn Academy of Music to-morrow evening, promise to be of unusual interest, not alone to people interested in the question of copyright, but to the public generally.

The residents in the neighborhood of One Hundred and Forty-fifth-street and Eighth-avenue will soon be relieved of the noise and dust caused by the elevated railroad engines taking coal at that point, as the pockets are to be moved to the Harlem River district.

TACOMA, Dec. 14.--For six weeks I have traveled steadily over the plains and through the forest-clad mountains and on the clear, cold water of this most promising State. Years ago I traveled throughout the region in canoes, on horseback, and on foot.

The Football Association, which has hitherto administered all football affairs at Cornell, has disbanded. It was too large and clumsy for effective work. This leaves football in the hands of the four Directors elected by the respective classes. The Directors are in a dead-lock over the election of a manager for next year. Hatcher and Sanger, both '91, are the candidates, each having 2 votes.

Cassidy, charged with arson in the first degree in setting fire to a building owned by the Catholic Protectory and occupied by Frank Magner at Westchester, which was begun last Tuesday, was brought to a close yesterday, the jury returning a verdict of not guilty, after being out twenty-one hours.

PARIS, Dec. 14.--Camille Dreyfus and M. Laguerre, both members of the Chamber of Deputies, had a misunderstanding to-day. Friendly relations between them are discontinued, hostile messages have been exchanged, and the duel is fixed for to-morrow.

Senator Zeb Vance is a big man, but when he tackles the civil service law he is overmatched. In the course of events Senator Vance will retire from the scene of action, but the civil service law has a grip on perpetuity.

Last week 751 births, 233 marriages, and 640 deaths were recorded at Sanitary Headquarters, and the following cases and deaths from contagious diseases were reported: Typhoid fever, 21 cases, 7 deaths; scarlet fever, 71--5; cerebro-spinal meningitis, 2--3; measles, 55--3; diphtheria, 118--28.

Braving the clouds and snow yesterday morning a large audience, composed largely of ladies, listened to the lecture on "The Avesta and the Religion of Zoroaster" by Dr. A.V. Williams Jackson at Columbia College. The lecturer's words were listened to with rapt attention, and all were greatly pleased with the entertaining manner in which the ancient Oriental religion was treated.

The first considerable snowstorm of the season in this city set in yesterday forenoon. It came without warning. The storm centre formed rapidly in the lower lake region, and then moved swiftly eastward toward NewYork. It began storming here almost as soon as anywhere, and the air was thick with snow all the afternoon.

World's Fair matters were dull yesterday. The subscriptions credited at the Chamber of Commerce amounted to $16,025 for the day, of which sum $14,002 has already been acknowledged in THE TIMES. The grand total credited by the Chamber of Commerce for the guarantee fund is now $5,040,745.

In spite of a blinding snowstorm the races announced for yesterday at the track of the NewJersey Jockey Club were run off at the Elizabeth track. There was little of sport in it and it was surprising to most people that sportsmen like the Messrs. Dwyer would consent to the running of races over their trach with such weather conditions.

LONDON, Dec. 14.--To-day was the twentyeigth anniversary of the death of the Prince Consort. The Queen, accompanied by the Prince of Wales and other members of the royal family, visited the sarcophagus at Frogmore, in which the remains of the Prince are interred. Her Majesty spent a long time in prayer at the mausoleum. She was deeply affected and wept most of the time she remained there.

Money drop pers are no other than gamblers who contrive that method to begin play. It is an almost obsolete practice, and its twin cheat, ring dropping, not less disused. "What is this?" says the dropper.

The English have been enjoying a jubilee during the past fortnight over the launch of the new cruiser Blake. The vessel was launched at Chatham Dock Yard amid much enthusiasm. The British public is inclined to believe that the Blake is the most powerful adjunct her Majesty's navy has received in modern years.

The troubles of Aunt Lottie, the name by which Mrs. Charlotte Hobby is endearingly known, are engaging the attentive sympathy of many of the old residents on Staten Island. Aunt Lottie has lived there for more than fifty years, going there as the bride of a young shipbuilder when that trade was worth following.
Marcus R. Mayer started for Chicago last night to hold a consultation with Mr. Abbey before proceeding to Mexico in advance of the big Patti opera company.

Daniel Callahan, forty-five years old, a junk dealer who lived at 352 Madison-street, had a habit of tasting the contents of bottles he brought home in his junk bag. On Friday afternoon he put up a soda water bottle to his lips and took a drink.

Joe Donaghue the skater, left Newburg, N.Y., yesterday for Minnesota, where he intends participating in all the amateur events of the season including a series at the coming carnival. His first races will be at Minneapolis. Later he will go to St. Paul.

No news was received yesterday from the missing boatman, David Dillon. Little doubt is now entertained among his fellow-boatmen that Dillon has been lost. The passengers of the White Star steamship Germanic, which arrived on Friday, reported having seen a boat on Thursday morning about 360 miles east of Sandy Hook. This is too far out to have been Dillon's boat.

In an article printed in THE TIMES last Thursday, on "Improved Trade in Spain," the types made the erroneous assertion that the imports and exports for 1887, 1888, and the nine months of 1889 amounted to $17,460,000, $17,700,000, and $19,900,000, whereas the figures should have been $174,600,000, $177,000,000, and $199,000,000.

Hoboken (N.J.) Catholics are considerably excited over the selection of the Rev. Father Lehner as pastor of St. Joseph's Catholic Church. Some time ago the Rev. Father Dominick began to minister to a little colony of Italians in the city.

The success of the Bal Poudre, which was given at Lehmann's Hall last January by subscription, has induced a number of the more prominent men to issue invitations to society to subscribe for a similar event to be held on Jan. 16 next. As this will probably be the only costume ball during the season, every effort will be made to make it a success.

A writer in the North China Herald, discussing the causes of the increase in the population of China, and the increasing energy of the Chinese race which enables it to absorb other peoples and always to conquer in the struggle for existence, remarks that the native statistics show that it was not until the end of the seventeenth century that the population went beyond 60,000,000.

He takes on some points a different view of the matter from that of the correspondent in Ottawa.

The Cleveland ship yards have practically all the contracts they can fill in the next eight or ten months. The fame of the Cleveland yards grows steadily. The Cuyahoga is destined to be the Clyde of the great lakes.

A dispatch from St. Louis says the ex-champions are now in Texas and have completed arrangements for a trip to California. Latham left the team at Denver and returned to St. Louis. He is now busy playing a double game. He denied that he had signed a Brothernood contract, and offered to sign with St. Louis, providing Von der Ahe would pay a back salary claim of $900.

George McGuire, a boy fifteen years of age, became violently insane yesterday at his home, 216 East Thirty-sixth-street, and had to be removed to Bellevue Hospital. The lad's mother has had much trouble, and the last affliction is more than she can bear.
The passengers of the Long Island Railroad are taking steps to compel that company to reduce its rate of fare to 2 cents a mile. The present rate is 3 cents.

Fordinand S. Hynes, a young clerk, was found dead early yesterday morning, lying in the water of the Thistle Factory dam, two miles below Ellicott City, Md. He had been last seen alive by several companions on Friday night near the dam. It is supposed that in the darkness he fell into the water and met his death.

VENICE, Dec. 15.--The expressions of grief and sympathy called forth by the death of Robert Browning recall the similar expressions on the death of Wagner. Browning refused to the last to believe that he was seriously ill. Every day, whatever the weather, he went in an open gondola to Lido.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Dec. 15.--Negotiations have been entered into whereby the People's Fire Insurance Company assumes the risks of the Amoskeag Company, exceeding $4,000,000. The transfer of property will be made at once. The Manchester City Fire Insurance Company has decided to continue in business.

LONDON, Dec.16.--The strike of the employes of the South Metropolitan Gas Company has proved a failure, the company having filled all the strikers' places with non-union men. There have been no disturbances and work at the gas house is proceeding quietly.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec.16.--The Supreme Court to-day, refused a new trial in the case of Louis Claire and John Gibson, convicted of the murder of the Hon. Patrick Mealey on New Year's Eve two years ago. The killing grew out of the strong political animosity engendered by the campaign of that year, and the accused were convicted and sentenced to imprisonment for life. They will now be sentenced to the penitentiary to serve out their terms.

The training ship Portsmouth will sall for the West lndies some time this month. Her officers are very anxious to get off, though it is generally believed that the vessel will be detained in port for two or three weeks.

READING, Penn., Dec.16.--The new Philadelphia, Poughkeepsie and Boston Railroad began running trains from Slatington to NewYork to-day as was announced last week. There were eight trains in all-four passenger and four freight, the latter including coal cars.

The members of the Commonwealth Club ate a very good dinner at Morello's. West Twentyninth-street, last night, and afterward listened to the Hon. D. Foulke of Indiana, who delivered an interesting address upon "Present Political Problems."
OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec.16.--The agitation in Manitoba and the Northwest to abolish separate schools and French as an official language promises to result in trouble.

VIENNA, Dec. 16.--The Chamber of Commerce of this city has taken a census of opinions concerning the representation of Austria at a World's Fair in the United States. It has consulted all the trades guilds, the industrial corporations, and over two hundred leading firms. The general sense of the answers is in favor of participation, and the Government is urged to appoint a commission to make an early organization of the national exhibit.

Every Thesday evening a recruiting detail will be on hand and the officers charged with the work will be Prepared to give all the information desired. The new appointee promptly filed his bond, took the oath of office, and immediately entered upon the duties of the position. Edward Murphy, Jr., brewer, and James Fleming, wholesale liquor merchant, are the bondsmen of the new Superintendent.

About fifty years ago three brothers, Stephen V., William H., and Albert T. came to this city as lads and entered the store of their half-brother, Benjamin Albro, who then had one of the alrgest grocery stores in the city, at the corner of Division and Eldridge streets.

O'Brien drew the note to his own order on Nov.9, payable in thirty days, and on its back placed the names of his mother, Mrs.Mary O'Brien, and of Senator O'Connor.

The natives of the Fiji Islands have taken up cricket through the efforts of an enthusiast, Mr. Wallington. They like the game much, although they do not like to confine themselves to the orthodox eleven on each side. They play their matches with forty or fifty aside, or tribe against tribe.

BOSTON, Dec. 17.--No 'busses have been seen on Boston streets to-day for the first time in more than twenty years. The old Citizens' Line of Coaches is no more. The rattletebang of the great wheels will no longer vie with the bells of the street cars of the city in warning pedestrians of the approach of the conveyance.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 17.--The engagement of marriage of J. Byron Taylor of this city and Miss Emma Gertrude Flower is made public. The ceremony will be held at the residence of the young lady's parents in Washington, D.C., Thursday, Jan. 2, 1890. Miss Flower is the only daughter of Congressman Roswell P. Flower of New-York, and is nineteen years of age.

The new steamship Russia, the latest addition to the Hamburg-American Line's fleet, arrived here yesterday for the first time. She was built especially for carrying freight and emigrants, and will maintain a speed of thirteen and a half knots an hour at a cost of only fifty tons of coal a day.
PITTSBURG, Dec. 17.--Dr. Emannel Schnitzer, an uncle of Emin Pasha, is visiting in Pittsburg, and tells an entertaining story of the explorer's boyhood days and earlier history.

SPOKANE FALLS, Washington, Dec. 17.--A. P. Sedge, a prominent man here, had a narrow escape from death while on a hunting trip in the mountains in Northern Idaho. For several days the party camped at a ranch, when they decided to go on to another ranch.
It is stated that Mr.Campbell of the British Consulate General in Seoul is at present exploring the frontiers of Corea.

Daniel Montague, a lineman in the employ of the United States Illuminating Company, had a narrow escape from sudden death while attending to his duty at Broadway and Chambersstreet yesterday morning. As it is, he lies in the Chambers-Street Hospital bruised and maimed by reason of a terrible fall.
The fourth musical service of the United Choir of the Collegiate Reformed Dutch Church of this city was held in the Reformed Dutch Church, Fifth-avenue and Forty-eighth-street, last evening.

BERLIN, Dec.17.--The Superintendent of the mines in tha Saar district has informed the men that the eight-hours' shift is included in the labor regulations; that equality of wages is not practicable, but that increased pay shall be given to men who are not able to earn a living on the pay heretofore given. Despite the concessions made to the miners in this district, the strike is under fall headway.
The announcement in the papers that Bushey Park "has been placed at the disposal of the Emperor and Empress of Brazil by the Queen" is unfounded.

The steamship Arizona of the Guion Line, which was due here Monday morning, arrived at Quarantine last evening. She was delayed by head winds, which prevailed the greater por tion of the voyage, and were accompanied by high head seas. No accidents were reported as occurring on board during the trip.

Dealers in provisions are far from regarding favorably the muggy weather of the last few days. To them it means not only physical discomfort, but a failure to make expected profits on their goods, and in some cases there results to them an actual loss.

ZANZIBAR, Dec.17.--The Mansourah, the yacht of the Khedive, will probably sail on Tuesday next with Stanley, Emin Pasha, and others for Cairo.

AMESBURY, Mass., Dec.17.--Mr.Whittier's eighty-second birthday is being observed very quietly here at his home. The public schools are having exercised appropriate to the day, a flag raising being a feature at the Whittier School. Mr.Whittier is in his usual health. He has received a few callers and many letters and gifts.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17.--It is now a fact that two of the biggest beef and cattle firms in the country, the Munroe of Boston and the Hammond Company of Hammond, Ind., have united, and that in the amalgamation the live cattle industry has lost one of the heaviest dealers, while the dressed beef industry has been increased by one.

The financial embarrassment under which the city of Elizabeth, N.J., has existed for so many years, growing out of the extravagance of city officials in 1870 to 1876, is so well known as hardly to require repetition.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Dec. 17.--The action of the Boards of Trades and Chambers of Commerce in the Northwest and along the Atlantic seaboard, relative to the proposed strengthening of the naval establishments through the measures now before Congress, has been followed by the strong support of the Chamber of Commerce in this city.

BOSTON, Dec. 17.--Santa Fe Mining Company affairs take on a new phase. Mr. Leonard Lewissohn, who was to succeed the Hon. Jay A. Hubbell as President, declined to accept the office at yesterday's meeting of the Directors. The condition of Mr. Lewissohn's health is given as the reason.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment continued the work of preparing the final budget for 1890 yesterday. The Department of Public Works was the first to come in for attention.
LONDON, Dec. 17.--Mr.Parnell arrived at Nottingham to-day. There was a great crowd at the railway station, and he was greeted with mingled groans and cheers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17.--The decision of the Inter-State Commerce Commission in the case of Frederick A. White against the Michigan Central Railroad Company and the Lake Shore and Michigan Southern Railway Company was announced to-day.

BALTIMORE, Dec.17.--The Maryland Legislature will convene for its session of ninety days at Annapolis on the 1st of January. The preliminary work is being mapped out, and unusual interest is taken in it because of the important questions that will demand action.

AMORY, Miss., Dec. 17.--The second series of the Southern field trial Derby was run to-day. The day was most favorable to good work, which was taken advantage of, and the dogs did work that was equal, if not superior, to any ever done in a field trial.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 17.--The mutilated body of Martin Loftus, a former resident of Plainfield, was found on the Central Railroad track at Gateville, near Bound Brook, last night.
ALBANY, Dec. 17.--By the decision of the Court of Appeals, handed down to-day, William N. Alberti recovers $25,000 damages from the New-York, Lake Shore and Western Railroad Company.

Mr.Jacobus is one of the most popular Republicans in the city of New-York. He has always been regarded as one of the wheel horses of the party, but his efforts have never been appreciated by a State or National Administration until the present time.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 17.--John H. Stevenson is a well-known patent attorney of this city and an enthusiastic apostle of the protective tariff.
It was a bad day for sight-seeing yesterday, a day when the drizzling rain combined with the mud in the streets to operate disagreeably against excursions about the city.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Dec.17.--Oliver L.Barbour, the famous compiler of law reports and authority on the same, died this evening at his residence in this place, after a long illness, aged seventy-nine.

The acceptance of tenders from the Palmer Shipbuilding Company, Messrs. Laird Brothers, and Messrs. J. G. Thompson, for the construction of four of the armor-clad ships recently designed at Whitchall, completes, it is said, the tonnage for the British Navy which will, for a time at least, be intrusted to the private shipbuilders of the country.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 17.--This morning Robert S. Dalton, employed by the Lake Shore Railroad, went to the top of the train shed to measure a skylight for repairs.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 17.--A conference of leading colored men of the State was held here to-night to memorialize Congress to pass a national election law and to make an appropriation for locating the colored people on lands of the West.

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 17.--Part of the victory is won for the Cornell crew when Courtney agrees to act as coach. This he has done to-day, rejecting several handsome offers from other clubs, for he has a great deal of interest in these sturdy Corneilians, who have added so much to his reputation and have so emphatically shown the soundness of his views on rowing and training.

Yesterday's stock market was dull, but it was not weak. Few stocks declined even fractionally, while many scored advances more or less substantial. Perhaps, after all, what Wallstreet feels sure of--that only dullness is to rule till after the holidays--may not come true.
Mr. A.M.Palmer has secured the New-York rights to Gilbert and Sullivan's new opera. "The Gondoliers," and all that pertains to the production of that work in this city will be under his management.

Judge Lawrence, in Supreme Court, Chambers, on the application of Harold P. Brown, L. E.P. Carr, and C.A. Mitchell, granted an order yesterday requiring the Board of Health to show cause, on Friday next, why a mandamus should not be issued compelling them to abate the nuisance of high-pressure currents on electric-light wires.

ALBANY, Dec. 17.--Arthur H. Rowe, the architect who was connected with the reconstruction of the new Assembly celling, has filed a claim with the State Board of Claims for $1,700 as a balance due him of the two-thousand-five-hundred-dollar compensation voted him by Speaker Cole's special committee. Luke F. Cozans of New-York is the claimant's attorney.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17.--The body of the late Franklin B. Gowen, the lawyer and financier, whose tragic death in Washington so startled the community, was deposited in the grave at Ivy Cemetery this morning.

The little Crown Prince of Germany seems to have inherited some of the qualities of his father. The Prince was driving out with his governess. As usual, the Germans cheered the boy or lifted their hats to him as he passed, to which the young Prince replied by raising his bonnet.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Dec. 17.--The British schooner Mary, which arrived yesterday from Cape Broyle, N.F., with a cargo of fish, was seized to-day by Collector Presson for discharging her cargo without a permit. The penalty is $1,000, and the case has been referred to the authorities at Washington.
Saturday's snowstorm afforded the first opportunity for the practical demonstration of the utility of the new electrical sweeper for street car tracks.

Following in the wake of the Class of '90 the Columbia Juniors will hold their annual Christmas ball Friday evening in the college library. All debutantes of the season are expected to be present, and a general good time is looked forward to.

The fourth annual dinner of the Massachusetts Agricultural College Club of New-York was held last night at the Arena, 41 West Thirtyfirst-street. There were many non-resident graduates present as guests.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 17.--The Fall term at Yale will end to-morrow, and the students will have a vacation until Jan. 7. The lengthening of the recess to nineteen days is in compensation for the shortening of the Thanksgiving recess to a single day. The change was made last year, and proved very acceptable to the students, especially to those living in the West.

Clubs are already arranging for the season of 1890. Passengers going up town took the elevated road, taxing it to its utmost capacity. The bridge crossing Park-row was packed, and for a time a crush was feared. Several policemen from the Oak-street station, however, took charge of the crowd and prevented any accident.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 20.--The mutiny which started yesterday among the soldiers of this city was suppressed to-day by prompt and decided action by the commanding officers. It was not permitted to advance far enough to assume very formidable proportions.
New-York Cornellians will enjoy their tenth annual banquet at the Hotel Brunswick this evening. Some notable after-dinner speakers will be present and the reunion ought to be a very merry one.

ALBANY, Dec. 20.--James H. Manning to-day sent Gov. Hill a brief note saying: "I hereby resign the office of Civil Service Commissioner." William A. Poste also resigned his office of First Deputy Attorney General.

The six lectures of Dr. Amelia B. Edwards at the Peabody Institute drew together the largest audience of the season. The hall was crowded, standing room being at a premium. The distinguished Egyptologist was received with great cordiality, and many attentions were shown her while in Baltimore. At all the lectures the university was largely represented. Miss Edwards said she would like to see Johns Hopkins devote more attention to Egyptology.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 21.--Michael Brennan, the young man who tried to kill Order Clerk Ellis at the Singer factory yesterday, was arraigned the morning at Police Headquarters. He pleaded not guilty.

LONDON, Dec. 21.--The motion for a new trial of the action for damages brought by Mr. William O'Brien against Lord Salisburg for slander has been dismissed. Mr. o'Brien had charged that Lord Salisbury, in a speech, had accused him of inciting to murder and robbery. The ground on which a new trial was asked was that the jury who returned a verdict for Lord Salisbury were misdirected.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 21.--The Senate to-day reconsidered its action of yesterday by which it rejected the bill from the House repealing the civil rights law, and by a vote of 25 to 4 passed the measure and ordered it to a third reading, thus assuring its final passage.

Dr. Kimball's mission in the basement of the City Hall made over a hundred children and a number of adults mindful yesterday of the Christmas season. The room which Dr. Kimball has used on Saturdays for many years was decorated with a Chrismas tree. At 11 o'clock the children trooped in and were presented with woolen undergarments and fruit. At 2 o'clock a number of families were supplied with potatoes, hominy, rice, and other articles.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 21.--H.M. Bigelow and W. D. Guthrie of Boston, who have been here for several days negotiating, this afternoon obtained options on the five breweries of this city. They represent the English brewery-buying syndicate.
HASTINGS, Neb., Dec. 21.--A bad wreck occurred on the Burlington and Missouri Railroad at the station of Sutton yesterday, thirty miles west of Hastings.

Alger of Michigan, who will go with them over the district covered by the East Tennessee Coal and Iron Company. The party will also visit many points of interest in the South.

Soldiers are proverbially generous, and so no one will be surprised to learn that six companies of the Seventh Regiment have contributed $322 to the Washington Memorial Arch fund. FALL RIVER, Mass., Dec. 21.--Material for an additional magazine article upon the civil war may be found in a New-Bedford store window, where is displayed a collection of valuable relies from the Monitor, which disabled the Merrimac on March 9, 1862.

HIRRISBURG, Penn., Dec. 21.--The trappers of Pennsylvania are now getting things in order for the coming Winter. Traps are being broughy out from the hayloft and pigsty, and the unwary muskrat, skunk, mink, or other quadruped will soon be captured.

Letter Carrier John F. Corley will not be on duty to-day. When he was delivering his route on Lower Broadway yesterday morning he sprung a stale chestnut of the "McGinty" variety on Frank J. Jenney, the young man who runs the elevator at 160 Broadway. He was done up so badly that he had to place himself under the doctor's care.

ROME, Dec. 21.--Signor Ragazzi, the Italian Envoy in Abyssinia telegraphs that King Menelek and Queen Taitri were crowned at Autoto, Nov. 3. Menelek decorated Ragazzi and gave him a message to Signor Crispi, notifying him of the coronation. This event naturally tends to an expedition for the subjection of Tigre to the new King's authority.

CANTON, Ohio, Dec. 21.--The jury in the case of Ira Smith, the twelve-year-old boy, who has been on trial here for manslaughter, returned a verdict of guilty this morning after being out all night. Young Smith shot and killed a girl last Summer, and claimed that the shooting was accidental.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. Dec. 21.--The Spring Lake and Sea Girt Company has purchased all the property of the Sea Girt and Spring Lake Beach Land and Improvement Companies, including the lake at Spring Lake Beach and Wreck Pond. The company has a capital of $700,000. Electric light, sewer, and water systems are to be completed in time for use next season.

Herschel was defending the character of astronomical science in view of an error of nearly 4,000,000 miles in estimating the sun's distance, the correction was shown to apply to an error of observation so small as to be equivalent to the apparent breadth of a human hair at a distance of 125 feet.

The death is announced of William Archer, father of the late F. Archer. William Archer, who died in the neighborhood of Cheltenham on Saturday in his sixty-fourth year, was a native of that town, and was apprenticed at an early age to a trainer near Birmingham.

John Barclay is a truckman who has grown comparatively rich in carting precious metals for Wall-street houses to the docks of European steamers for shipment abroad. On Friday Barclay sent one of his trunks to the banking house of Zimmerman Forshay, at 11 Wallstreet, and took therefrom 101 bars of silver, each of which weighed about 75 pounds and was worth about $1,000.

The Australian ballot system is gaining a foothold in Ohio. Some of the ablest men in the State have been and are giving it consideration. A meeting has already been held in Cincinnati by the leading men of both political parties to consider the law. As the system becomes better understood it is likely to make many friends.
ALBANY, Dec. 21--The jury in the case of the Watervliet election inspectors to-day returned a verdict of not guilty.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 21.--Nearly three hundred thousand bushels of corn went from here to-day in steamers bound for Europe. This port is doing an unprecedented export business in corn.

The report from the Navy Department at Washington that the Harlan Hollingsworth Company of shipbuilders would move their place of business from Wilmington, Del., to Sparrow's Point, near Baltimore, created a great deal of comment here. A special dispatch to the Sun from President Gause of the Harlan Hollingsworth Company says there is "no foundation for the rumor, and no such removal was ever contemplated."

TOMS RIVER, N.J., Dec. 21.--The mixing house of the United States Dynamite Company's works, about two miles north of here, was destroyed by fire this morning. William Thompson was burned to death and Robert Madkiff so seriously burned that is recovery is doubtful.

The new Lenox Lyceum, at Madison-avenue and Fitty-ninth-street, will be opened on Thursday evening, Jan. 2, when Theodore Thomas and his orchestra will perform a de lightful programme. It is as follows: Liszt's Second Polonaise, Mendelssohn's "Melusina" overture.

GLEN EYRE, Penn., Dec. 21.--The West Orange Gun Club to-day beat for the second time the famous Blooming Grove Gun Club. The score was--Orange, 118; Blooming Grove, 109. The shooters of Pike County took their defeat with the utmost good nature, as they could afford to, and at once offered a handsome silver pitcher to any club that would do it again.
BETHLEHEM, Penn., Dec. 21.--A disastrous wreck occurred on the Lehigh Valley Railroad at Laurys Station, about 3:30 o'clock this morning.

Several thousand gypsies of Croatia held an open-air indignation meeting yesterday at Odra to protest against the vexations measures of the Croatian authorities, who desire to put a stop to their roving habits, and who, for that purpose, threaten to set fire to the gypsy encampments.

Since the old gymnasium was fitted up as a machine shop in 1881 by President Morton, Stevens students have felt the need of a place for gymnasium training during the Winter, and men addicted to field sports or on athietic teams have suffered particularly. NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 21.--In naval circles here the article in last Sunday's TIMES on the question of naval training schools has been a fruitful theme of discussion, bringing out a number of opinions strongly opposed to the building of barracks on shore for training apprentices.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21.--The Grant Locomotive Works of Paterson, N.J., are to be moved to Chicago and established in the southwestern part of the city, on part of a section of land comprising 651 acres, which was sold to-day at auction for nearly $700,000.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 21.--Freight train No. 90, on the Pittsburg, Fort Wayne and Chicago Railroad, near Lima, Ohio, broke in two to-day and the rear half crashed into the train following. Conductor Jones, Brakeman Moran, and William Sherman of Lima, asleep in the caboose of the runaway train, were all iujured, Sherman probably fatally. Sixteen cars, a caboose, and the engine of the second train were wrecked. The road has been blockaded all day.

HALIFAX, N.S., Dec. 21.--The steamer Beta, from Havana, reports Dec. 6, in latitude 33 north, longitude 72 west, passed the three-masted schooner Jennie Rosalene of Port Jefferson, N.Y., waterlogged and abandoned. The census of 1890 of the State of New-Jersey, it is believed, will show a population approximating 1,500,000. In 1870 it was 908,149; in 1880, 1,130,892, an increase of 222,743. In 1885, by the incomplete census taken by the State Assessors, it was 1,278,133. A similar ratio for the past five years would bring the figures up to nearly 1,500,000.
BERLIN, Dec. 21.--The Emperor has been so ill as to be compelled to keep his bed since Thursday morning. He arose for the first time to-day and received official reports.

In 1850 Lima, Peru, was one of the loveliest and laziest of cities. No finer climate could be found in the world. The people were gay, cordial, generous in their nature, and exceedingly hospitable. Life was a succession of balls, picnics, processions, and feasting.

READING, Penn., Dec. 21.--Colebrook Furnace No. 1, near Cornwall, Penn., where six men were killed several months ago, resumed operations to-day. The widows and children of the dead employes have been well taken care of by the millionaire owner, Robert H. Coleman. Mr. Coleman's furnaces, a halfdozen in number, are now all in full operation.

James Holroyd and five of the fiteen Trustees of the Komuk Club resigned during the week. This club was started several years since on a grand scale, having a handsome house on Washingtonavenue. Because of bad management prior to Mr. Holroyd's administration the club has lost caste. A new organization will be started from the live mambers in the club.
NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 21.--The races here today were run with these results: FIRST RACE.--Three-quarters of a mile. Flirt won, with Probus second and Puente third. Time-- 1:15 .

The Lawtey people certainty struck a good thing when they went into strawberries. Five years ago the gross receipts from that season's crop were $75. Last year, with 175 acres in berries, the net receipts, according to the Lawtey Strawberry Growers' Association's report, were $82,000. This year they have 225 acres planted, and the strawberry is still rampant upon their banner.

Like most of 'Henrik Ibsen's plays, "A Doll's Home," as the name is translated from the Norwegian for tha American stage, or "Nora," as it it called on the German, is before everything else a play to read.

Not a few of our readers will share the deep regret with which we announce the death last evening, at his residence near Croydon, after an illness of elevan weeks, of Mr. MacDonald, the manager of this journal.

LONDON, Dec. 21.--Although we are almost treading on the toes of Santa Claus, there is much less than the usual talk about or preparation for Christmas. Here in England, at least, there is no special reason why this should be so.
BOSTON, Dec. 21.--The circular giving rights to the Union Pacific and Oregon Short Line stockholders will probably not be issued for some days.

HARTFORD, Dec. 21.--The new field for women which has been opened in this State under official sanction is sure to give employment to a considerable number of intelligent workers in the end.

Three gentlemen who have grown gray is the service of this city, not in positions considered "fat," but at hard, constant work in the Controller's office, have been notified by Controller Myers that their years incapacitate them for their work, and on Jan. 1 their resignations will be accepted.

CITY OF MEXICO, Dec. 22, via Galveston.-- The announcement of the success of the Mexican loan created considerable excitement here. The press took up the question, and demanded an explanation from the Government, which has been denying that negotiations for a loan were on foot.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Dec. 22.--When William M. Rysdyk's Hambletonian, the great sire of the most famous of American trotting strains, died on his owner's farm, at Chester, in 1876 Mr. Rysdyk (himself since deceased) buried the old horse on the sightly summit of a knol near the Erie Railroad station and in full view of passing trains.

A new steamship for the New-England and Savannah Steamship Company arrived here yesterday. She is named the Kansas City, and she was built at Roche's yard at Chester, Penn. She is of iron, and is divided into several watertight compartments.

The Rev. R. Heber Newton talked to a very large congregation at the morning service yesterday at All Souls' Church upon "The Scientific Idea of God and the Spiritual Vision of a Heavenly Father."

The clergymen of Richmond are discussing the question of funerals; whether funeral sermons are proper; whether Sunday funerals should be discouraged; whether extravagant funeral displays should be discouraged.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22.--There is only one member of the Fifty-first Congress without an assignment to committee duty. That man is Mr. Cheadle of Indiana. He was assigned by the Speaker to a place, a not very conspicuous one, on the Committee of Claims. At the beginning of the last Congress Speaker Carlisle had given him the same place, and he then declined it.

William Maher and John Welch, members of the Ale and Porter Brewers' Union, were arrested Saturday evening upon the complaint of James Lawlor, a liquor dealer whose place is on the corner of Second-avenue and Thirty-second-street.

Amateur photographers, to whom a dash of rain now or then or a muddy tramp has no terrors, are at present taking a few landscape pictures near the city, and are indulging in midday excursions to that time-honored realm of amateur experiment, the Bronx region. In Summer the Bronx is lined with beautiful foliage.

Dr. John V. Sweeney of 147 Greenwich-street feels almost sure that he has two patients who are suffering from the Russian grippe. They are Mrs. Coxe, who lives at 79 Washingtonstreet, and one of her children.
In Clarendon Hall last evening the Addison Literary Society, formerly the Hebrew Literary Union, debated the proposition "That Negro Suffrage is a Menace to the Perpetuity of the Union."

The twenty-first anniversary services of the Presbyterian Hospital were held yesterday afternoon in the South Reformed Church, Fifth-avenue and Twenty-first-street. Many friends of the institution were present, and more than usual interest was taken in the proceedings on account of the flery ordeal through which the hospital had passed. The Rev. Dr. Roderick Terry, pastor of the South Church, presided.
Mrs. Christopher Sinclair died in the Chambers Street Hospital yesterday afternoon from the effects of a stab in the abdomen inflicted by her husband.

The demoralizing effects of the Administration of President Harrison are visible more plainly in Brooklyn than in any other portion of this country, for they have occasioned over there something that has not occurred for years --a political fight in midwinter.
CAPE HAYTIEN, Hayti, Dec. 14.--The Port au Prince papers have already published several editorials on the subject of the suspected or alleged territorial designs of the United States.
THE NEW-YORK TIMES of Dec. 16 gives a complete account of the recent bloodless revolution in Brazil, from the pen of an eye witness of the progressive course of events.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., Dec. 22.--John A. Howland, ex-Collector of this place, who was arrested on Friday night on a charge of embezzling $2,700, spent yesterday in the custody of Constable Woolley.

Elton A. Fay, who took an overdose of cocaine at the lodging house, 108 Bowery, early on Saturday morning, died yesterday in the prison pen at Bellevue Hospital. His body was taken to the Morgue, but it will doubt less be claimed and properly buried, as he was widely esteemed, in spite of the aimless life he had led for many months.

Ex-Postmaster General Thomas L. James talked yesterday to a large audience at the Young Men's Christian Association Building, Twenty-third-street and Fourth-avenue. His talk was a brief answer to the query put so often, "Why do not the young men of the present day attend church?"

LONDON, Dec. 22. The British Government has asked the Turkish Government for copies of the court records of the trial of Moussa Bey, presumably with the intention of instituting an inquiry into the case.

PAWNEE CITY, Neb., Dec. 22.--The Nebraska State Bank of this city assigned yesterday for the benefit of creditors. D.F. Hempstead and S.E. Smith, the cashier, name here two years age from Mendota, Ill., and purchased the bank, which was then well established.

Dec. 29, 1887, two days after the funeral of Daniel Manning, his eldest son was appointed Civil Service Commissioner by Gov. Hill. The Democracy of the Nation was represented in paying tribute to an illustrious leader at that funeral.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 30.--Fifteen days have elapsed since the empire was overthrown, and the authority of the provisional Government which took its place and proclaimed the republic has not met with the slightest show of resistance in any of the twenty provinces.

A department of philology will be organized is connection with the Brooklyn Institute during the month of January. About eighty members of the institute have signified their intention of joining the organization, and a number of philologists of Brooklyn and NewYork are interested in the movement.

WATERBURY, Conn., Dec 22.--Connecticut farmers are now waging a vigorous warfare in the interests of self-protection. Oleomargarine is one of the questions that now challenge their unqualified opposition, and a strong sentiment has crystalized in favor of legislative redress.

On Saturday and Sunday afternoons Mr. Francis Lathrop exhibited at his atelier, on South Washington-square, the stained-glass windows that won a gold medal at the recent Industrial Exhibition in Philadelphia. They are meant for Princeton College, and are intended as a memorial on the part of Mr. Henry G. Marquand.

Services in commemoration of the reorganization of the Welsh Baptist Tabernacle of this city were held yesterday at the Calvinistic Methodist Welsh Church in Thirteenth-street. The morning service was in Welsh and was conducted by the Rev. Dr. J.W. Williams of Hyde Park, Penn.
WHEELING, West Va., Dec. 22.--Peter Raymond and John Lewis were drowned to-day in New River, near Hinton, Somers County.

From latest reports it appears that the questionable transactions of Cameron Clark, the railroad contractors, who were arrested for stealing about $10,000 from the Kinderhook and Hudson Railroad Company last week, were not confined to Columbia County. It has come to light that they have been raising money on worthless checks in Poughkeepsie.
LISBON, Dec. 22.--The man-of-war Yorktown of the United States squadron of evolution had not arrived here up to noon to-day. Admiral Walker reports that her non-arrival is due to severe weather.
The final football match in the Shelton Cup series, played under association rules, did not take place on the Ridgewood Baseball Grounds yesterday, the Paterson Thistles failing to appear.

FALL RIVER, Mass, Dec. 22.--The first six months of profit sharing with its employes, announced by the Bourne Mills last May, will end next Saturday. It is believed that about 300 hands will have a share in the division.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22.--The rules of the road as finally adopted have been printed by the International Marine Conference for distribution.

An overheated range in the kitchen of the New-York Hotel set fire to the woodwork of a window near by shortly after midnight Sunday, and a little blaze started up. The building in which the kitchen is situated is an isolated one in Mercer-street.

A number of prominent Hebrews of this city held a meeting last evening at the Florence Building, which resulted in the organization of a society to be known as the Montefiore and Lady Judith Hebrew Association of the City and County of New-York.

The steamship Lassell arrived yesterday from Rio Janeiro and was moored at Martin's Stores in Brooklyn. Capt. Rendle says that he brought no passengers and that no one applied for passage on the vessel.

The price to be paid is $70,500 for the tract of sixty acres, or $1,175 per acre.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22.--The week before Christmas is not one to which theatrical managers look forward with any degree of pleasure, as business is sure to be light. Still, the Chicago playhouses seem to have suffered less than usual the last week, and had it not been for the powerful competition of Italian opera at the Auditorium the week would have been a fairly prosperous one.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Dec. 22.--The Sydney Herald of Nov. 5 says that, according to a letter received from Capt. Woodhouse of the trading schooner Elma Fisher, the boat steerer Nelson, of the schooner Enterprise of Sydney, and three of the native crew of the Enterprise were killed and eaten by the cannibals of the Soloman Islands.

Fred Rockwood, George Morris, and Daniel Donohue, three prisoners awaiting action by the Grand Jury, broke out of Kent County Jail, East Greenwich, R.I., yesterday afternoon, making a breach in the wall with an iron bar wrenched from the bedstead. They have not been recaptured.

PARIS, Dec. 22.--Dr. Damaschino, a leading physician, is dead. His death was due to influenza and weakness of the heart. This is the fifth death from influenza since the outbreak of the epidemic, three deaths from the disease having occurred at the St. Cyr Academy and one at the Polytechnic School.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 22.--Mr. Carroll S. MacGill of this city has nearly accomplished the feat of eating thirty quail in thirty days. The task grew out of a wager that Mr. MacGill could not eat a quail every morning between 10 and 11 o'clock, the birds to be cooked in any style he might wish.

the Hon. Thomas Coggeshall, for fifty-four years Postmaster at New-Bedford, was held at the residence of his nephew, Mayor Thomas Coggeshall, in this city, to-day. This was his native place. His son and three nephews, by request of the deceased, acted as bearers.
