TORONTO, Ontario, Dec. 24.--A special cable dispatch to the Globe denies, on the authority of Sir Charles Tupper, the statement telegraphed from Ottawa to the effect that the modus vivendi with the United States in the matter of the fisheries would not be renewed by Canada owing to President Harrison's failure to act.

The New-York Hospital presented an extraordinary appearance last night for an institution with which bright and cheerful scenes are seldom associated. The spirit of Christmas Eve pervaded the wards and galleries of the great refuge for suffering and invalid humanity with all its potent charm and cheer.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 24,-On this the eleventh day of the Winter meeting, the track was fast and the attendance good. Col. R. W. Simmons returned from New-York, and officiated in the judges' stand to-day for the first time this season.

CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., Dec. 24.--The firemen were kept hard at work from 9 o'clock last night until 8 o'clock this morning. They responded to four alarms, three caused by incendiary fires and one by an accident on the NewYork Central Railroad.

Chief Brooks of the Secret Service Division has had his men at work night and day for months in the effort to unearth a gang of expert connterfeiters who have been driving a thriving trade in shoving the queer in this city.
HARRISBURG, Penn., Dec. 24.--Belva Lockwood was in this city on Sunday. She was on her way to Freeland, Luzerne County, where she lectured last night.

ROME. Dec. 24.--The Pope in receiving to-day the College of Cardinals, said: "In these times, when the Church is assailed and persecuted because it is the great stronghold of faith and truth, it is a consolation to know that among the children of the Church themselves there is perfect unity.

CANAJOHARIE, N.Y., Dec. 24.--The wellknown Hotel wagner in this village has been closed. Mrs. Benjamin N. Disbrow of NewYork, the guardian of the children of the late Norman T. Wagner, ordered all the windows to be boarded up, and all the guests have departed.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 24.--Carroll S. MacGill to-day finished his task of eating thirty quail in thirty days and won his wager. He began on Nov. 25, and each morning since reported at the same place and partook of the quail. He says hereafter the quail and himself Will be strangers, as he has had enough.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Dec. 24.--A runaway accident occurred near Vienna, ten miles east of here, last night.

Ernest Goungsky an Austrian, sixty-three years old, died suddenly yesterday morning on the sidewalk iu front of 447 Sixth-avenue. Death was probably due to heart disease. He has long been a familiar figure in the neighborhood of the Hoffman House, where he was known as "Max." He obtained this sobriquet from having served under Maximillan in Mexico.

Joseph Stott, forty-three years of age, a jewelry merchant, of Providence, R.I., who has bean ill for some time, left his house yesterday morning and went to the track of the old co.ony Railrcad, waited for the Shore Line train, placed his neck across the rails, and was beheaded. He leaves a widow.

TIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 25.--The approach to the bay of Rio de Janeiro, the entrance past the frowning fortress of Sants Cruz and Sugar Loaf Mountain, and the ever-varying, always beautiful, and sublime views of the bay and its surroundings are well worth a long and wearlsome sea voyage.

A duck belonging to a Rockland man was frozen into a pond the other night; and was found in the morning with just her head out of the ice. The ice was broken and the duck freed, apparently none the worse for her cold night out.

BOSTON, Dec. 24.--A seizure of liquors just made by the Surveyor's Department of the Custom House brings to light a system of smuggling which is an innovation on the conventional style of importing contraband goods in vessels.

The annual meeting of tue American Geological Society will be held in the American Museum of Natural History this week, beginning at 10 o'clock to-morrow morning and at the same hour Friday and Saturday. the sessions will be open to the public, and arrangements have been made so that luncheon can be procured in the museum building.

A case of the influenza was reported from Bellevue Hospital last night, the first one reported as admitted there. Last night Andrew Conan, a coachman about fifty-two years old, walked into the hospital and complained of feeling ill. He was examined and was found to be suffering from influenza.

MONTREAL, Dec. 24.--The police authorities here have discovered Silcott, the absconding Treasurer of the United States House of Representatives.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24.--A dispatch from Milwaukee says: Milwaukee at the present time is the eastern terminus of a flour blockade that extends as far west as Minneapolis, and bids fair to last for several weeks.

WATERBURY, Conn., Dec. 24.--A peculiar formation of rosin has been dug out of the earth at Union City by Naugatuck railroad laborers, who have been removing a sand bank for purpose of filling for the new freight depot at Naugatuck.

VALLEJO, cal., Dec. 24.-A boat containing eight sailors from the United States Fish Commission steamer Albatross and a crippled newsboy left the Albatross at Mare Island Navy Yard last night and started for Vallejo.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21.--Secretary Windom this afternoon issued an advertisement, inviting proposals for the privilege of taking fur seals upon the islands of St. Paul and St. George, Alaska. Bids will be received until Jan.23, The concession runs for twenty years from May 1, 1890.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24.--Christmas Day in the White House will be a merry one, without one tinge of sorrow or regret in so far as the President's two little grandchildren are concerned. For days past the mysterious bundles which have been arriving have been secretly stowed away in every available place, until now the cupboards, presses, bureau drawers, and wardrobes throughout the mansion are bulging with gifts for the White House little ones.

VICTORIA, B.C., Dec. 24.--Capt. L. Angerstein of the wrecked steamer Idaho complains that since he has been in this port he has found the most avaricious set of robbers it has ever been his misfortune to run across.

THE TIMES'S Lisbon dispatch of yesterday formed an absorbing theme of conversation among navy officers. What might have appeared a very ordinary matter to some was animportant one to many engineers, since it was conclusively shown that the new ships of the navy are not expensive coal burners.

Col. John C. Calhoun, President of the NewYork Southern Society, started, two days ago, for Atlanta, Ga., to attend the funeral of the late Henry W. Grady. The members of the society have felt very keenly the death of the distinguished young Georgian.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24.--The Signal Service Bureau is advised of the approach of a cold wave. It is now in Dakota, and is moving in this direction at a rate which will land it here to-morrow or the day after with a temperature of about 15 above zero. It will affect the States Minnesota, Wisconsin, and Illinois, and later will spread to the States eastward.

CHICAGO, Dec. 25.--Christmas Day here, like the Winter of which it is a part, has been a most unusual one. It has been bright, clear, and warm, the thermometer indicating in the neighborhood of 60 above zero in the shade in the outlying suburbs.

It is a pleasant sign of the times that so many papers are calling for ballot reform. These journals voice the sentiment of the better class in all parties. The stability of our institutions must in a great degree depend upon our elections, where the voter can express by his vote his preference for candidates. And this cannot be done without a secret ballot. Let the reform go on; the faster the better.

Men from the mining districts of Baker County report an abundance of snow, and all locomotion from one point to another is by snowshoes. This is welcome news, for it assures a prosperous mining season for 1890, and thousands or dollars that have for ages been locked up in the treasure vaults of Mother Earth will find their way into the hands of people, to be distributed into the channels of trade.
The Sacramento Bee sent a reporter to Woodland last week to report a sensational criminal case. He got along all right until Friday morning, when he went to a restaurant for breakfast.

Satiety prevailed in all New-York's Americanplan hotels yesterday. Proprietors and chefs exercised their combined ingenuity and exhausted their joint resources to furnish feasts that would not be readily forgotten, either on account of the delights to the palate in eating or the distress in digesting.

GENEVA, N.Y., Dec. 25.--Prof. Brooks, Director of Smith Observatory, discovered a new comet this evening. Its position is as follows: Right ascension, 18 hours 23 minutes; declination north, 34 degrees 40 minutes, with a slow westerly motion. The comet is bright and telescopic. This makes the third comet discovered this year by Prof. Brooks.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 25.--A man answering in most particulars the description of Silcott, the Washington forger, has been traced to this city, but is believed to have left last night for the West.

For some time past a gang of men had been attempting, under conditions of much peril, to repair one of the big Birmingham Corporation gasholders. The Prospect Harriers held a most successful cross-country run on Long Island yesterday. The start was made from the Manhattan House, Sixty-fifth-street and Fourth-avenue, Brooklyn. J.J. Lloyd and E. Hjertberg were the hares. They had ten minutes start of the pack, which left at 4 o'clock.

The remarkable warmth of the sun and the mildness of the atmosphere yesterday set every one to asking if such another Christmas Day was ever known in New-York. No affirmative answer was made, and the popular conclusion was that the weather was phenomenal for the 25th of December.

At the last meeting of the Kings County Medical Society of Brooklyn, Dr. John G. Johnson of Brooklyn read a paper on disease germs and disinfectants. In treating of consumption Dr. Johnson stated that one-third of all our people who died between the ages of fifteen and twenty-five are carried off by consumption.

John Regan, age seventeen years, was found bleeding and unconscious last evening at a lonely place on Eister-avenue, in Newark. He had been horribly maltreated and kicked about the head and face. It is feared that he cannot live. There is no clue to the assailants.
Charles Albert Ashburner, the geologist, whose death occurred in Pittsburg yesterday, was born in Philadelphia Feb. 9, 1854.
Zion's Advocate of Boston has been investigating the matter of church finances in Maine. After reading its revelations we are surprised that there are not more closed meeting houses on our hillsides.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 25.--At a late hour tonight news was received here of trouble in Clarksville between officers and a colored mob, two members of which were shot, one being fatally and the other seriously wounded. Fears of a riot are entertained, and citizens are taking steps to defend themselves.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 25.--Miss Anna C. Jones, the daughter of the Rev. Sam Jones, the evangelist, was married here to-day to Mr. C. Graham, with whom she had eloped from Cartersville, Ga., her father's home.

HARTFORD, Dec. 25.--It has fallen to the lot of Judge Carpenter of this city to prepare the opinion of the Supreme Court in both of the cases concerning labor troubles which have come before that body for final arbitration.

Mrs. Catherine Daly, aged forty, of 37 Jackson-street, upset a kerosene lamp early yesterday morning. Her clothing caught fire, and she was so terribly burned that she died two hours after her removal to Bellevue Hospital.
The Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Road has been experimenting with gasoline with a view to using it in the lighting of cars.

The ten lectures on Shakespeare which are to be delivered under the auspices of the Chicago Kindergarten Association are not less wisely assigned to eminent and eloquent scholars and speakers than well appointed in relation to time.
ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 25.--The people of Atlanta have determined to erect a monument to the memory of Henry W. Grady.

General Freight Agent Paul Morton of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad has resigned his position and will leave the service of the company Feb. 1. Mr. Morton's successor as General Freight Agent of the Burlington and Quincy will be Mr. Thomas Miller, at present General Freight Agent of the Burlington and Missouri at Omaha. Mr. Miller, it is understood, will be succeeded by Mr. George H. Crosby.
Not long ago an Atlanta young lady was about to be married--she is married now, may Heaven bless her and keep active the business tact with which she is endowed.

The St. Petersburg correspondent of the London Times telegraphs with regard to Gen. Trepoff, whose death has been briefly noticed: "He was one of the most remarkable men of the time of Alexander II. The Netherlands-American steamship Amsterdam, which arrived at Quarantine late on Tuesday evening and came up to her dock yesterday morning, had a remarkably stormy voyage, during which a portion of her cargo got adrift and was damaged to the amount of several thousand dollars.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Dec. 25.--The house at North Hatfield occupied by Mrs. James Fisk, Jr., was burned last night, together with four barns, which contained several tons of tobacco and many farming implements.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25.--This was the mildest Christmas Day in this vicinity for years. The air was warm and moist and the sky was slightly overcast with light clouds most of the day, though no rain fell, except in the early morning.

Philadelphia had last year eighty preventable deaths a week, and every week had one hundred and sixty people lying ill from causes which could have been prevented by good water, sound sewers, and solid pavements. This is a heavier tax than the entire cost of the City Government thrice over.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 25.--One year ago Henry Grady wrote for the Constitution an editorial entitled "A Perfect Day." It was a Christmas editorial full of beauty and brightness, and was much talked of by the press of the country.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Dec. 25.--A riot occurred today at Jesup, fifty-seven miles south of Savannah. Two white men were killed, two others seriously wounded, and several negroes are reported killed. The Georgia Hussars Troop of the First Regiment of Georgia Cavalry sent two detachments of men to Jesup to-night, and more trouble is apprehended.

There will be a mass meeting held under the auspices of the Canal and Harbor Protection Union, at Cooper Union, on Jan. 24, to protest against exactions in the port of New-York, and the manner in which shipping is driven away. Protests will also be made against discrimination by railroads against canal shippers, and State grain elevators will be favored. Mayor Grant has been asked to preside.

The fire in the Presbyterian Hospital has caused the Commissioners of Charities and Correction to order an inspection of Bellevue Hospital with a view to the prevention of fire there. Chief Bonner and Battalion Chief Fisher are making the inspection, and, it is understood, will report in favor of several changes. A recommendation for a permanent fire drill will also be made.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 26.--The stern-wheel boat H. Hanna Blanks snagged and sunk this morning at a point twelve miles above Monroe, on the Ouachita River. She had 2,000 bales of cotton on board, which will be saved. She was valued at $10,000, and is insured for two-thirds of her value. She was built in Cincinnati and is nine years old.
LONDON, Dec. 26.--Four ironclads have left Malta under orders to proceed to Lisbon to be present at the ceremony of the proclamation of King Carlos 1.
ST. PAUL, Dec. 26.--Great crowds of Catholics arrived in St. Paul to-day from all over the Northwest, drawn hither by the consecration ceremonies which will be solemnized at the cathedral to-morrow.

BUENOS AYRES, Nov. 21.--The crops in the republic give splendid promise, and if the weather remains favorable the farmers are looking forward to more than making up the losses of the last two years.

She has not been in good health for two years past, although up to the hour she ratired there was nothing in her condition to awaken uneasiness among her friends, Mrs. Thomas passed away as quietly as did her distinguished husband nineteen years ago at San Francisco.

Ex-President Grover Cleveland has been appointed referee, to succeed Hooper C. Van Vorst, in the suits brought against the city by Louisa D. Kane and others for damage to their property along the North River by the filling in by the Dock Department.

Some of the Italian tenants of 10 Rooseveltstreet had a Christmas party in the rooms of Thomas Logarmarcino, and they invited in some of the neighbors, includlng Peter Papodentie and Andreas Yeamances.

LONDON, Dec. 26.--The town of Aci Reale, in Sicily, was shaken by an earthquake yesterday. Several houses collapsed and many persons were buried under the ruins.

Money on call was subjected to another squeeze yesterday, loaning at one time as high as 16 per cent., with business at the close of the day at 15 per cent. There was something of a surprise in this to the average Wall-street man, though in banking circles there seems now a general disposition to expect no substantial or lasting ease in the money market before the middle of next month.

Treasurer William R. Stewart of 54 Williamstreet acknowledges the receipt of the following additional subscriptions to the Washington Arch fund: W.H. Webb, $100; Mrs. D.W. Fenton, $10; previously acknowledged, $63,076 71; grand total, $63,186 71.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26.--The Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives began to-day a series of hearings of persons interested in the tariff who wish to influence...

MARSHALLTOWN, Iowa, Dec. 26.--The TimesRepublican's Toledo (Iowa) special says: "The main building of the Western College was burned early this morning, only a part of the library and the contents of the treasury being saved. This was one of the finest college buildings in the State. The loss is $150,000; insurance, $22,500. It is not known how the fire originated.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26.--To-day's bond offerings accepted were as follows: Registered 4s, $1,000, $2,000, $1,000, $2,000, $75,000, and $600 at 127. Registered 4 s, $1,000 and $5,000 at 104 5/8 Coupon 4 s, $5,000 at 104 5/8.
The Messrs. C.R. Flint Co. of 142 Pearlstreet have a cable from Rio Janeiro advising the rate of exchange at 25 1/8d. A cable was been received from Para quoting exchange at 24 d.

A correspondent writes to ask who will succeed the Duke of Cambridge when he retires from active work. Lord Wolseley, he says, is too unpopular, the Duke of Connaught too junior, and Sir Frederick Roberts is an Indian officer.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Dec. 26.--The schooner Norseman arrived to-day from the Grand Banks having on board Capt. Whittle and six men of the British schooner Sparrow Hawk of Hamilton, Bermuda, abandoned in a sinking condition on Dec. 23, forty miles southwest of Whitehead, N.S.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 26.--The Runnymeade Stud Farm, Paris, Ky., has bought of D.D. Bell Lexington, the colt Hueneme, a yearling, by Billet, dam by Virgil. The price paid was $3,500.

BUFFALO, Dec. 26.--Veranda thieves worked the house of John Bush to-night and secured $3,000 worth of jewelry. While the family was at dinner the burglars secured access to Mrs. Bush's jewelry casket and stole a diamond cross valued at $1,200, a black onyx pin with diamond settings valued at $500, a pearl necklace and earrings valued at $1,000, and a finger ring with diamond and garnet setting valued at $300.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26.--City Solicitor Warwick to-day officially decided, that the eight-hour law is applicable to the departments under the control of the City Government.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26.--Provisions were bearishly inclined to-day. For some unaccountable reason speculative offerings overburdened the market, and in the face of a better demand for product and an improvement in Hogs prices ruled lower. It was certainly a discouraging day for holders, though business was quite active and in futures resonably interesting.

Two French painters, MM. Delort and Pierre Carrier-Belleuse, have received an order from an American company to paint a panorama of the two great journeys of Henry M. Stanley through Africa--first in search of Livingstone and next for the relief of Emin Pasha. The panorama is intended for the approaching exhibition in the United States.

VALLEJO, Cal., Dec. 26.--The United States cruiser Charleston went into commission today at the Mare Island Navy Yard. Commander Louis Kempff formally turned the cruiser over to Capt. George C. Remey.
Chief Judge McAdam of the City Court yesterday refused to punish Theatrical Manager Edward E. Rice in a suit brought against him for debt by Alfred S. Seers, who is a judgement creditor.

MACON, Ga., Dec. 26.--The report of a riot at Barnesville is erroneous. It arose from the unprovoked murder of a negro of excellent character by four drunken white men who met him on the railroad track. The authorities are doing their best to arrest the murderers, who were strangers in the community.

Mr. John R. Dos Passos, the well-known lawyer, is lying dangerously ill at his home, 18 East Fifty-sixth-street, from the effects of an accident which befell him in Washington three weeks ago.
In response to the many requests at Palmer's Theatre box office, Richard Mansfield has consented to give "King Richard III," at the matinee to-morrow.

BELVIDERE, N.J., Dec. 26.--The people of Anthony, Hunderdon County, are agitated over the mysterious death of Mrs. Martha Waiters, whose body was found lying in a path leading to a spring yesterday. Her hair was disheveled, and she was almost destitute of clothing.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 26.--Eloquent words from life-long friends, delivered to a mighty assemblage of people who loved him and admired him, was the tribute Atlanta paid to the memory of Henry Grady to-day.

Alexander Thompson, who has been in State Prison, at Sing Sing, nearly half a year, will probably be a free man in a day or two. Thompis a sailor, twenty-six years old.
The schooner David Crowell was struck by a heavy squall at 2:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon while passing Steep Rock, Hell Gate, and capsized.

Yesterday was a day of meteorological surprises. It began with a Springtime morning; then came a Summer thunderstorm; then as perfect a June day as one would care to see in the month of roses, and then a gale blowing forty-eight miles an hour.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 26.--Senator Washburn, who arrived here this morning to spend the holidays, is feeling elated over the prospects for the passage of measures for the improvement of the waterways in the Northwest.
The showing made by the engines of the Yorktown during the vessel's passage to Europe appears to give great delight to engineer experts advocating the general adoption of the triple-expansion engine.
LOS ANGELES, Cal., Dec. 26.--The heavy rain of the past few days continued last night, and the levees on the Los Angeles River have broken through in half a dozen places.
The tenth annual hospital collection is now going forward in the busy haunts of commerce, and will fittingly culminate with a general offering in the churches next Sunday.

James Russell Lowell was not present at the banquet of the Boston Merchants' Association on Thursday, Dec. 12, where ex-President Cleveland made the speech on civll service and ballot reform that has attracted much attention.

Judge Patterson of the Supreme Court yesterday granted an injunction in the suit of M. Gernsheim Co. against the Houston and Texas Central Railway Company, the Central Trust Company, C.P. Huntington, and others, restraining the defendants from issuing $10000,000 of new stock under the Houston and Texas Central reorganization plan until the determination of the pending action.

The Manhattan Elevated Railroad Company is generally adopting on all its lines a new automatic block safety signal, which is the invention of Roadmaster Robert Black.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 26.--The Pittsburg Southern Coal Company, the syndicate of large river coal operators of this city which was formed three years ago with a capital stock of $1,000,000, will go into liquidation at once, and the thirteen firms comprising the company will hereafter do business on their own account.

The funeral of the Rev. Father Edward J. O'Reilly took place yesterday from St. Stephen's Roman Catholic Church, Brooklyn. The services were conducted by Fathers McCarty, Flannery, Carroll, and Reddington.

BISMARCK, Dak., Dec. 26.--Gov. Mellette says that South Dakota will be obliged to close up some of her institutions. The receipts of the State will fall so far short of the expenses that there is apparently no other alternative.
In Steinway Hall last evening The Goldey, a society whose object is to develop literary tastes, gave its fourth annual entertainment.

The annual report of Health Commissioner Griffin of Brooklyn, made public yesterday, contains a mass of figures by which the population of that city is estimated at 843,602. The number of deaths during the past year was 18,379, a rate of 22.10 per 1,000. This is a slight decrease from the rate of the preceding year.
About 6 o'clock last night a fire was discovered on the third floor of 21 Ann-street. It spread very rapidly, and it was found necessary to send out two alarms.

The laborers who worked on the Third and Seventh avenues subways for Sub-Contractor Hugh J. Reilly, since the subways were finished last Saturday night, have found a great deal of fault because they were not paid off more rapidly.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 27.--The Novoe Vremya criticises the attitude of the French Government toward the conversion of the Egyptian preference loan as showing a disregard on the part of France for the lot of the fellaheen without advancing the prospect of British evacuation.
Not a day passes but some subscriptions are received to help swell the Washington Memorial Arch fund.
The Record of American and Foreign Shipping, (New-York,) published by the American Shipmasters' Association, has been issued for 1890.
Mr. A.M. Palmer announces that the new Gilbert and Sullivan opera. "The Gondoliers," will receive its first presentation at the Park Theatre on Jan. 7.
We are gratified that ex-President Cleveland, in his speech at Boston, declared himself so strongly in favor of ballot reform.

James Harrington, a truck driver, whose home was given ae 315 East Ninety-ninthstreet, was instantly killed yesterday afternoon at 3 o'clock by a twenty-pound stone thrown from a blast.
The first number of Kate Field's Washington has been received in this city dated for publication Jan. 1, 1890, and headed by an engraving of the Capitol in Washington.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Dec. 27.--John M. Gardner, counsel for the Miss Mary L. Mowatt suits, returned home last night from Oaxaca, Mexico, where he has been in the interest of his client.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Dec. 27.--At 1:30 o'clock this morning the Union Pacific steamer Oregon ran into and sunk the British ship Clan McKenzie at Coffin Rock, on the Columbia River. Charles Austin and Matthew Reid, two colored sailors, were instantly killed.

VIENNA, Dec. 27.--Court Aloys Karolyi de Nagy-Karoly, formerly Austrian Ambassador to Great Britain and Germany, died suddenly on his estate, at Pressburg, Hungary. He was hunting on horseback. When found his neck way broken. It is not certain whether he was attacked by apoplexy and fell from his horse or whether he fell and broke his neck.

The Sailers and Firemen's Union met last evening at 26 Albany-street and adopted a circular that is to be sent out to-day to ship owners and to the Mercantile Exchange. It asks them to appoint a committee to meet a committee from the sailors and firemen on Jan. 14, for the purpose of deciding upon a uniform rate of wages to be paid to scafaring men.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 27.--The counsel entered in the contest over the will of Millionaire Christopher Meyer announced the complete settlement of the case in court to-day, and the three Jersey proctors were each given $25,000 counsel fees. The estate is worth $6,000,000.

William A. Poste, for the past six years Deputy Attorney General, and John A. Sleicher, editor of an illustrated paper in this city, are at present the only members of the State Civil Service Commission. Both were recently appointed by Gov. Hill, though the views of neither of them on the subject of civil service reform are very well known to the public.

James Kitchen, a broker doing business at 26 Broad-street, went into the Astor House rotunda on Thursday night and ordered half a dozen oysters. After eating them he refused to pay for them on the ground that the charge was excessive.

The Board of Audit of the New-York Central Co-operative Association of Fast French Lines met in the Hotel Brunswick yesterday morning at its last session this year. There were present C.P. Leland, auditor of the Lake Shore Rail way; William Nicholson, auditor of the Fall...

A Christmas festival was given to the children of the Sunday school of St. George's Church last evening in the church edifice in Stuyvesant-square. Bright faces were everywhere, and the church was decorated with evergreens and Christmas trees. Fully 1,500 children filled the body of the church to overflowing.

Special Treasury Agent John P. Brooks is making it hot for the circulators of bogus coin just now, and the counterfeiter who expects to make any money out of the nefarious business must be very sharp to escape the trained men whom Agent Brooks has on their scent.

The cornerstone of the chapel of St. John's Episcopal Church at Yonkers was laid yesterday afternoon by Bishop Potter, with appropriate ceremonies. The new building will be a handsome one, built of granite, and costing $50,000. The chapel is to be west of the church building. The Rev. Alexander B. Curver is the rector of the church.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27.--The Committee of the International Marine Conference on General Division 12--a uniform system of buoys and beacons--submitted a report to-day to the conference.
There is no doubt that Mr. Cleveland has a very strong hold upon the people, and strange as it may seem his popularity appears to be steadily increasing.
The Board of Estimate and Apportionment, with its Tammany majority, found yesterday that Controller Myers, Country Democrat, had more economical ideas on some appropriations than Mayor Grant himself.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Dec. 27.--A disastrous cave-in of the earth's surface occurred this afternoon at 4 o'clock in the town of Plains, three miles north of this city. The affected parts cover an area of 130 square yards and is situated in the slope of a hill. The beautiful Catholic Church of the Sacred Hart stands...
Eighteen families live in the five-story tenement house 715 Tenth-avenue. At 7:15 o'clock Christmas night a fire was discovered and extinguished in Harris's shoe store in the block.

The American Geological Society held their second day's session yesterday at the American Museum of Natural History. After some preliminary work the reading of papers was resumed. Prof. James Hall, State Geologist, gave a sketch of the early geologists, from the lives of whom he drew many examples of encouragement for young geologists.
The Passaic County Agricultural Society today announces what will probably be the first race for two-year-olds of 1890; the youngsters will be yearlings up to next Tuesday evening.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 27.--There is considerable trouble on the Cincinnati Southern RailRoad, caused by the discharge of twenty Brotherhood conductors and one Brotherhood brakeman.

MONTREAL, Dec. 27.--United States Senator Leland Stanford, the California millionaire, is in Montreal spending the holidays. He is accompanied by Mrs. Stanford and will remain about a week, and will then return to Washington to attend to his duties in Congress.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27.--The following bond offers were accepted to-day: Four per cents registered-- $20,500 and $25,000 at 127.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 27.--This city was the scene this morning of an event of more than ordinary interest to churchmen in the consecration of three new Bishops with all the august rites and imposing ceremonial of the Roman Catholic Church. The ceremony was conducted by Archbishop Ireland, assisted by the Most Rev. Thomas L. Grace.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27.--A good many persons were heard by the Ways and Means Committee during the seven solid hours of to-day's tariff sitting, and all wanted the tariff left as it was or increased. Some Michigan stove makers were heard by telegraph in favor of leaving mica on the free list, but protection was the one thing argues for by all the speakers.
By her counsel, Mr. Charles W. Fuller, Mrs. Evangeline L. Hamilton yesterday filed her answer to the suit brought by her husband, Robert Ray Hamilton, to annul their marriage.

A dull-witted New-York paper makes the statement that Grover Cleveland will move to Connecticut so that the State of New-York will be relieved from the embarrassment of having two Presidential candidates. What is the matter with moving Hill to New-Jersey? Mr. Cleveland is not bothering himself about the aspirations of other people.

BURLINGTON, Iowa, Dec. 27.--Not in the memory of the oldest inhabitant, except in the memorable Winter of 1863, has been such peculiarly warm weather as this locally is experiencing at present. For the past two weeks the mercury has ranged at about 50 above zero, sometimes going very much higher.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Dec. 27.--A terrible accident occurred on the Frazier River road yesterday. Six young men out sleigh riding were driving along the road, when a tree fell, cruhing the sleigh, killing four of the occupants and the horses. The names of the dead are: James Lawson, C.D. Campbell, Joseph Locke, and J.V. Bodwell. The other two escaped with severe bruises.
SCOTTDALE, Penn., Dec. 27.--A collision occurred between two freight trains in the deep out just south of Moyer Station, about three miles south of this place, on the South west road, this afternoon.

Gov. D.E. Hill went driving yesterday afternoon, visited a theatre in the evening, and later attended a reception given by Mrs. Sutton, a sister of Edward S. Stokes, in the Hoffman House. Mrs. John A. Cookerill received with Mrs. Sutton, and there were many guests.

WILLIAMSPORT, Penn., Dec. 27.--A terrible accident happened at 3:15 this afternoon on the Market-street bridge. In putting up the fourth span of the bridge one of the hangers which uphold the flooring and are suspended from the iron trusses above was not finished by bolting to the flooring on account of the nuts not fitting,
The managers of St. Luke's Hospital, 17 West Fifty-fourth-street, are feeling decidedly happy over their improved financial condition.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 27.--The estate of the late Dr. James H. McLean was sued to-day for $995,000. The plaintiff in the case is William Jackson, and the defendants are L.F. Campbell and J.B. Crane, surviving executors of the J.H. McLean estate, the last named being also administrator of the estate of Mrs. J.H. McLean, who died shortly after her husband's demise.

LISBON, Dec. 27.--The programme for the great festival, to-morrow, is as follows: His Majesty Carlos I. will proceed, at 11 A. M., to the palace of Necessidades and there, before the assembled Cortes, take the oath of office.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 27.--David T. Boyd, a New-Haven boilermaker, aged twenty-three years, disappeared from Leetes Island on Christmas Day, and much alarm is felt for his safety.

LONDON, Dec. 27.--The British squadron of action has been ordered to rendezvous at Gibraltar in order to be in readiness to move at once to Lisbon. The Temeraire has already arrived, and the Colossus and Benbow left Malta this afternoon. This is interpreted as indicating that the Government no longer apprehends that a quasi warlike movement will add to the irritation already existing or stand in the way of a peaceful solution of the troubles.

PUNXSUTAWNEY, Penn., Dec. 27.--A week ago proceedings in lunacy were instituted in the case of P.W. Jenks, a lawyer of this place. Since then Mr. Jenks has given his daughter a judgment note for $10,000 and brought suit for divorce from his wife.

The Jewish Socialists and Anarchists of this country have been holding a convention for the purpose of starting a paper to promote the welfare of Jewish workingmen and the cause of Socialism and Anarchy in general. KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 27.--An Atchison, Kan., special says: "Senator John J. Ingalis, who is at his home here spending the holiday vacation, was seized with a cold last night, this morning developing mild symptoms of Russian influenza. The attack is not serious, however, although it compelled Mr. Ingalis to cancel an engagement to address a teachers' association at Topeka to-day."
Mr. R.D. Porter has commenced the erection of an elegant hotel, to be known as the Hotel Porter, on the site of the burned McNulty saloon, on Falle-street, near Second.

Christmas proved a fine day for the gunners. Indeed, it was one of the best of the whole season. Many sportsmen were out in the Great South Bay shooting the late ducks, and many more tried to find it there were any rabbits and quail left on Long Island and up along the Harlem Railroad.
The stormy weather which has lately prevailed at sea is evidently keeping back a large fleet of ocean steamers now due or overdue at this port.

SAN SALVADOR, Nov. 30.--Railroad construction is proceeding in this little republic, and, as fast as the resources of the country will permit it, we shall receive the benefit of better communication and the development that will follow the laying of the rails.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 27.--N.S. Kronglicoff and A.B.T. Kondzatovitch, Russian civil engineers, are in this city on their way from Japan, via British Columbia, to Montreal.

The steamship The Queen of the National Line caught fire in her hold yesterday afternoon. The flames were extinguished before more than $200 damage had been done. The Queen is the vessel on which Dynamiter Mooney created a sensation two years ago. Last year she had her officers' quarters fired, and many of her valuable nautical instruments were destroyed.

FORT SULLY, S.D., Dec. 27.--Reports of a massacre of settlers in this vicinity are unfounded. Squatters have been moving upon the reseravation in the lowlands along the Missouri, and the Cheyenne Sioux have made ugly threats, but the whites have not been molested. There are four computers of the Twelfth United States Infantry here, who are able to quell any outbreak in a few hours.

ROCHESTR, N.Y., Dec. 27.--The Eastman Company has just been organized, with a capital of $1,000,000. The incorporators are George Eastman, Henry A. Strong, John H. Kent, Edwin O. Sage, and Brackett H. Clark of this city, and Harris H. Hayden of New-York.

This annual report of the Richmond and West Point Terminal Railway Company was issued to shareholders yesterday in pamphlet form. President John H. Inman congratulates his security holders upon the material improvement of their property's physical condition and the rapid growth fof business.

Tammany Hall's little prospecting tour into the Dock Department was begun in earnest before Mayor Grant yesterday afternoon. Of course there was an interested assembly of politicians in the Mayor's office to watch things.

Jake Gaudaur, the carsman, writes to the Boston Herald declining to row at Point of Pines, as the condition of the water there is unfavorable to him, but says he will row either Hanlan or Teemer on Lake Quinsigamond for $1,000 a side any time before July 4, or will make a race with both. PARIS, Dec. 27.--The influenza is spreading and is very fatal. The large numbar of deaths is exciting grave apprehensions. The number of deaths from all causes Christmas Day was 318. For several years the average for that day has been 200. It is reportod this morning that 580 deaths from the disease have occurred within twenty-four hours. The papers print this report, but some of them doubt the figures, claiming that they are too high.

CITY OF MEXICO, Dec. 27.--Reports have been current here to-day and yesterday that the concessionarire of the projected Bank of Fomento had met with such strong opposition to the scheme in Europe that he would be compelled to abandon it and forfeit the earnest money, $200,000, deposited in the national Bank here.

The deaf-mutes held their annual charity bail at Maennerchor Hall last evening under the auspices of the Manhattan Literary Association, an organization of deaf-mutes founded in 1864. Preparations for the execution of condemned murderers in this State by electricity instead of by the gallows are rapidly approaching completion. The decision of the Court of Appeals on the constitutionality of the law providing for the new method of execution is expected to be handed down within a month. But, however soon it comes, it will probably find the machinery for carrying out the law pretty complete.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Dec. 28.--The floods of the last few days have caused the river to change its course a few miles below this city and to cut a new channel, thus turning the water on the fruit lands. The owners claim their property has been damaged to the extent of half a million dollars, bulkheading the stream, and that the city of Los Angeles is responsible.

THE NEW-YORK TIMES publishes extended and interesting correspondence, by A.M. Gibson, from Rio de Janeiro. The letters of Nov. 19 and 22, appearing in THE TIMES of Dec. 16, giving the history of the revolution and the antecedent events, and the letter of Nov. 28, published yesterday, which contains an elaborate account of the natural resources of the new republic, deserve to be read and preserved.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 28.--Carnegle's lower Union Iron Mills are closed down on account of a strike of the puddlers, who refused to work the iron furnishes by the firm, claiming that the material was too strong. NEW-CASTLE, Penn., Dec. 28.--S.J. Wilkinson, son of wealthy parents in Baltimore, Md., attempted to commit suicide here to-day by taking morphine pills. When found he was wandering on the streets in a semi-conscious condition, and will not likely recover.

PARIS, Dec. 28.--The recent mortality in the city has been as follows: Wednesday, 318; Thursday, 393; Friday, 344. The sudden drop from the figures of Thursday to those of Friday is taken as an evidence that the epidemic is on the wane.

A red scar extending from the chin to the eye on the right side of the face of Antonio San Marco, who on Saturday night shot and killed Vincenzo Perfelto at Grand and Mulberry-streets, was plainly observed when he was arraigned in the Tombs Police Court yesterday.

The trouble on the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad between the company and their employes is assuming alarming proportions and may end in a general tie-up throughout the entire Erie system. The locomotive engineers are not alone in the matter, but have the hearty backing and co-operation of the firemen,....

BALTIMORE, Dec. 29.--Mr. Robert Garrett is in very poor health. At times he is very much depressed, and occasionally becomes very excited. He is still at his country home, "Uplands," near Catonsville. His friends have not been encouraged by reports from his physicians, especially as he has been unwell off and on for more than two years.

Such a fine Christmas for taking pictures has seldom been taken advantage of by the amateur photographers as that just past. Not a few took pictures simply as a memento of the bright, clear, balmy weather.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 29.--A Wheeling (West Va.) special says: "Another wreck is reported on the Chesapeake and Ohio Road at Fort Gay, Wayne County. Thirteen freight cars out of a freight train of seventeen cars were broken up. Fireman Leighton was killed and Engineer Murray seriously injured."

As Americans we are not conscious of the few illustrious men of pure science born to as. They are not many, it is true, not more than three, but among them Asa Gray holds the most conspicuous plane. And yet Gray was far from being a man of mere abstractions. He rather took pride in the practical side of his lifelong labors.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Dec. 29.--No further particulars have been received to-day regarding the Chesapeake and Ohio wreck of yesterday. Hale Morrison, the dead mail agent from this city, was brought here this morning and buried this evening.

The wholesale desertion of the New-England farming regions is attracting general attention. It is admitted that the places of the retiring natives will be filled. Foreigners, and especially Canadians, are even now drifting to these abandoned farms. The most interesting question growing out of this exodus concerns the New-Englanders themselves.

An investigation was made by Inspector Brown, in the service of the Board of Electrial Control, yesterday, of a rumor which had come to the ears of Expert Wheeler that one of the high-tension electric light companies had a lot of underwriters' wire on West-street painted...

AUBURN, N.Y., Dec. 29.--When the congregation of the First Presbyterian Church of this city was seen coming from the church at 11:30 o'clock this morning, half an hour after the time for the morning service to commence, many wondered at the cause of the short service.

KEY WEST, Dec. 22.--The negroes of Key West are Republicans, as a rule, though a gentleman told me that they are a singularly "uncertain quantity" at the polls--varying from $1 at 9 A.M. up to $12 at 2 P.M., and always voting where there was most money up.
ZANZIBAR, Dec. 29.--The Consular Court has heard the evidence of Mr. Stanley and Lieut. Bonny in the Emin Relief Committee's action against Tippoo Tib.

The Rev. R.D. Sproull, pastor of the NobleStreet Presbyterian Church, at Noble and Lorimer streets, Brooklyn, has been much grieved because the church services on Sunday were not more largely attended.
WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Dec. 29.--A shock of earthquake was felt at Silver Lake, Northwest Territory, yesterday. At one place a small stable fell from the effects of a shock.
NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 29.--Samuel Eugene Scudder, alias Samuel Eugene Johnson, a colored hostler, attempted murder and suicide last night. Two years ago he married Nancy Ann Van Giesen.

A leather bag was placed in front of Police Justice O'Reilly in the Tombs Court yesterday morning, and half a dozen leather experts tried to tell the Judge what it was made of and how much it was worth.

A dispatch from Hadley, Saratoga County, to Police Superintendent Campbell of Brooklyn yesterday announced the capture there of young Howard Tarrell, accused of complicity in the death of Lillie Cook from malpractice.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 29.--The tragic death of Mrs. Robert Stewart, who jumped off a Brooklyn Annex boat on Saturday and was drowned, has greatly shocked the community here, where the dead woman was greatly respected.
OPORTO, Dec. 29.--Dom Pedro has received many telegrams of condolence on the death ofhis wife. Among them was one from Queen Victoria.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 29.--Many holders of Western mortgages in this city have been thrown into a flutter by the receipt of circulars informing them that their interest will not be paid when it falls due, on Jan. 1. New-Brunswick.

At yesterday's meeting of the Central Labor Union the Committee on Outside Communications presented a letter from the Harbor and Canal Protective Union asking the co-operation of the central body in asking for reduced wharfage.

The Prospect Harriers have decided to postpone the New Year's Day team race for a banner and extra prizes until Washington's Birthday. The reason given is that a sufficient number of entries has not been received. The Harriers will hold a paper chase on New Year's Day, however, the start to be made from the Mauhattan House, Fourth-avenue and city line, Brooklyn, at 10 A.M.

On Saturday morning, while the cattleboat Colden was loading a steamship lying at anchor in the harbor, with cattle, one of the sprightliest of the animals escaped and plunged overboard. After swimming about aimlessly for some time the animal headed toward Bedlow's.....

The Tempe (Arizona) News man had a delinquent advertiser who refused to settle. The advertisement was taken out and replaced by the following: "This space was taken by --, He owes $--for it and won't pay. Look out for him." The advertiser got mad and obtained an injunction restraining such publication, but Judge Kibbey dissolved the injunction.

A special praise service was held yesterday afternoon in the South Church, Fifth-avenue and Twenty-first-street, at which Bach's Christmas Oratorio, Parts 1 and 2, was rendered, the special soloists being Mrs. Sarah Baron Anderson, contralto, and Mr. Charles Herbert Clarke, tenor. The Beethoven String Quartet also participated in the service, as did the full church choir and quartet, under the direction of Mr. Gerrit Smith, the organist. The church was crowded.

Even Mark Tapley would have found it difficult to be cheerful up on the road yesterday. It was not only chilly and damp but dark and clouds, and enjoyable driving was spoiled by mud of the consistency of paste. The outward conditions were bleak and depressing, and few days this Winter have been so quiet.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29.--Alexander Beck Son, carpet manufacturers, of 1,517 Whartonstreet, this city, made an assignment yesterday for the benefit of their creditors to Charles A. Furbush, of M.A. Furbush Co., woolen goods manufacturers of this city. The assignee estimates the liabilities at $130,000, and the assets at barely $100,000.

Sea voyages in which men are shown grappling for life with the dangers of storm, ice, and ocean currents are always delightful, but especially so when they have an air of homely truth and come, as it were, alive from the lips of those who have been in the battle.
Steamship State of Nevada, (Br.,) Stewart, Glassgow 16 ds., via Larne with mdse, and passengers to Austin Baldwin Co. Arrived at the Bar at 10:30 P.M.

WHITEHALL, N.Y., Dec. 29.--Franklin Fishler, editor of the Whitehall Times, whose name has been mentioned in connection with the State Civil Service Commissionership made vacant by the resignation of James Manning of Albany, says he is not a candidate for the position, and has had no conversation with Gov. Hill in reference to the matter.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 29.--The recent warm weather has been the cause of some unusual Winter scenes in and about NewBrunswick.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 29.--Notwithstanding the fact that Senator Nevius is one of the Phelps camp followers, and that the Senate is believed to be peculiarly sensitive to the Sewell influence, all the signs point to Mr. Nevius's selection for the Presidency of the Senate.
ST. PAUL, Dec. 29.--Winter weather is reported as having set in generally throughout the Northwest. Heavy snow has fallen over a wide area, and trains will undoubtedly be delayed at many points.
Gov. Hill has taken the New-York State printing from the Albany Argus, owned and edited by the son of Daniel Manning, because that paper has been, and is, friendly to Cleveland.
The early Spring styles are neat and shapely, with no prominent changes. In derbys the proportions are small with crowns runing from full to medium round.

Nothing more forcibly demonstrates the rise of the United States Navy than the interest taken in it by foreign contemporaries. A year ago all allusions to the American naval force savored of the sarcastic. To-day the case is different.

A genuine game of hurling, such as is played on the commons about Irish towns, was seen yesterday on the Monitor Baseball Club's grounds at Weehawken by a large crowd. The woods in which the grounds are situated echoed...

COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 29.--The Coroner's inquest into the death of the eight negroes who were lynched at Barnwell yesterday morning was held last night at the scene of the tragedy. It was a terrible sight which the jurymen looked upon.

The relations between capital and labor are such, both in this country and in Europe, that most thinking men who are in a position to initiate a fresh departure are casting about for some means to improve those relations. A musical and literary entertainment was given last evening under the auspices of the Seligman Solomon Society in the chapel of the Hebrew Orphan Asylum, at One Hundred and Thirty-eighth-street and Tenth-avenue.
TROY, N.Y., Dec. 29.--Pitcher John O'Brien of last season's Cleveland Club is very low in this city with typhoid fever and is not expected to live.

DETROIT, Dec. 29.--A. Tribune special from Hancock, Mich., says: "A calamity not surpassed in the annals of the country oocurred at 3 o'clock this morning at Hurontown. A family named Gross, consisting of the parents and eight children, with a visitor, were consumed in a...

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 29.--The opinion expressed at Trinity College concerning the stone that was seen to fall in Seymis-street in Hartford on the night of Dec. 10 is that it belonged to one of the falling bodies from "outer space" which are known as me teorolites, meteors, or aerolites.
Lethbridge has gone wild over fox hunting. The first experience of this invigerating sport which the citizens of Lethbridge have enjoyed was on a recent Sunday.

LONDON, Dec. 29.--There was an active demand for money during the past week. Discount rates were firm at 4 and 3 . The Stock Exchange loan rate to next account is 6. The settlement on the Stock Exchange is proceeding. Dealings were few. In spite of the dearer money, prices were steady.

Every effort is being made by the managers of the Old Guard Ball, which will be given on Jan. 23 at the Metropolitan Opera House, to make than event eclipse in brilliancy those of the past. Gilmore has promised that his band shall play the latest foreign military piece, while Bernstein's orchestra will furnish the dance music. The reports of the sub-committee in charge of the preparations already assure its success.

People who chanced to take a horse-car ride up State-street Christmas afternoon were treated to something that, as the dime museum orator says, "they may not have a chance to enjoy again in a lifetime."

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 29.--The Hon. Sherman S. Rogers, local member of the Committee of Five appointed recently by the National Civil Service Reform League to examine into the management of the Federal civil service, today says:

GRAFTON, West Va., Dec. 29.--While Joseph Griffith, a prominent Taylor County farmer, was sitting by his bedroom fire before daylight Friday morning sewing on a button, he was fired at five times by an assassin.
BERLIN, Dec. 29.--Hamburger Correspondent says it has reason to believe that fresh military credits will be asked by the Government from the Reichstag.

Dwight L. Worsley, who was prominently implicated in the exposure of the Robertson Juvenile Guardian Society a number of years ago, is again before the public, this time in connection with a charity fraud known as the Home Relief Association of the City of New-York.

The boiling over of a pot of grease in Frank Juliano's restaurant, at 505 Fulton-street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning, caused a fire which spread on each side and for a time threatened to destroy considerable property. The flames were finally extinguished before they had done much harm.

John Baehr, an Alsacian cook, twenty-seven years old, who lived with his mother in a apartments in a tenement house in the rear of 244 West Thirty-second-street, committed suicide on Saturday night by cutting his throat with a razor. He had been out of work for two months and had been sick.

"These yarns you hear about the terrible prices men had to pay for groceries and clothes and shoes in early days in California are a whole lot more interesting than truthful," said an old timer yesterday.
WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Dec. 29.--The "grip" has struck Winnipeg.

CITY OF MEXICO, Dec. 29, via Galveston.-- Telegrams from the republic of San Salvador, received here to-day, state that the revolutionists in the Department of Cuscatlan are retreating before the Government troops sent against them, that the Government forces are in hot pursuit, and that the revolution is of no importance.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 29.--Ex-Gov. William P. Kellogg has arrived in this city for the holidays. TO THE TIMES'S correspondent the sagacious old chieftain said he had nothing more to do with politics and enjoyed the privilege of speaking as a private citizen.

The first of the Augustus Graham Sunday lectures was given at the Brooklyn Institute last night. Dr. Edward Orton, President of the University of Ohio, was the lecturer, his subject being, "The Scientific Method as Applied to Man." He declard that in the last 300 years a new chemistry and a new geology had worked wonders.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 29.--Ice dealers throughout the State are beginning to be thoroughly alarmed at the prospect of no ice harvest this Winter. With the 1st of January at hand and not a pound of ice cut, with the days of sunlight ready to increase in length rapidly, and with not a pond even skimmed over with ice, the outlook is far from encouraging.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29.--Mr. Valente, the Minister of Brazil, has read with a good deal of distress some of the reports and comments concerning the situation in Brazil that have found their way into the papers of the United States, and particularly the stories of the reported "plan lering" of the late Emperor.

Manager Pitou is not going to introduce Robert Mantell to this city in his speutacular production of "The Corsican Brothers" until the play has had the benefit of thorough rehearsals by means of numerous performances in other cities.

Mayor Gleason has lodged a complaint with the Board of Education of Long Island City against Principal Burdick of the First Ward School of that city, asking for his removal. The charges will be investigated on Jan. 7.
The Cunard steamship Etruria was the only European steamship that arrived here yesterday.
Dr. A.R. Goodrich of Vernon, ex-State Treasurer, has been for some time engaged in collect ing portraits of the Treasurers of the State to be placed in the Treasurer's office at the Capitol.

The Coney Island Jockey Club has issued its circular for 1890. It is a most elaborate affair. On the covers are handsome pictures of the finishes of the Realization and Futurity Stakes, showing the positions of Salvator, Tenny, Chaos, and St. Carlo.

BOMBAY, Dec. 29.--The native congress at its final meeting confirmed the resolutions previously adopted and appointed a committee to press its views upon the English people. The Mohammedan delegates asked for time to cansult their coreligionists on certain questions.
Oliver Brady, for several years Assistant Superintendent in the wholesale stamp department of the New-York Post Office, died suddenly yesterday morning at 216 East One Hundred and Ninth-street.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 29.--Clarence Conwell, aged twenty-six years, a freight conductor, and Frank Orell, aged twenty-one years, a fireman, were struck by a Philadelphia, Wilmington and Baltimore Railroad passenger train here last night. Conwell died this morning and Orell is badly injured.

Among the passengers of the steamship Etruria of the Cunard Line, which arrived yesterday from Liverpool, were Sir Spencer St. John, British Minister at Mexico; Sir John Swinburne, the Viscount de Chabannes, Lionel E.G. Carden, British Consul at Mexico; W.S. Graff Baker, Dr. J.W. Chesholm, Dr. Huntley, Capt. William Oliver, F.A. Kursheedt, William Salomon, and Alfred J. Pullman.
The congregation of the Hedding Methodist Episcopal Church, on East Seventeenth-street, enjoyed a reunion anniversary yesterday.
"This talk about introducing copper cents in San Francisco reminds me of the attempts made to bring five-cent pieces into circulation in Virginia City." said Gen. Daniel O'Connell.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 29.--The World's Fair Executive Committee has elected Gov. Francis, Mayor Noonan, ex-Gov. Stannard, Col. Charles H. Jones, and Mr. E.S. Rowse, all members of the committee to represent St. Louis before the Congressional World's Fair Committee.

A large and distinguished company of Englishmen assembled in the botanical theatre of University College, London, on Dec. 18, to witness the unrolling of a mummy from Upper Egypt. A letter from a subscriber at Saitillo, Tenn., complains about the miserable mail service, whereby he is unable to get the American for many days after it is mailed from this office.
NASSAU, N.P., Dec. 23.--General business is dull. The sponge market, however, is brisk and full prices are maintained.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 29.--Frank H. Brussman, a dry goods clerk, of Pittsburg, and Mrs. Lizzie Spohn of St. Louis were married by Father Gregory, of this city, last Thanksgiving Day, after a friendship and acquaintance covering a period of thirty years. Their life romance has just come to light.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Dec. 29.--Dr. Henry B. Watson, a prominent physician of this village, has begun suit in the Supreme Court to recover $10,000 for malicious prosecution against George T. Campbell, a well-known Republican.

A New-York business man was returning from a visit to Atlanta, Ga., about eight years ago. On the train was Henry W. Grady, who was then only about thirty years old, but whose influence was already apparent in Georgia affairs.

The sermon preached by the Rev. R. Heber Newton at All Souls' Church yesterday morning was particularly appropriate to the last Sunday of the year. Mr. Newton spoke against lugu brious piety, taking for his subject "The Laughter of the Soul."

Senator Jacob A. Cantor and Assemblyman Joseph Blumenthal were yesterday afternoon tendered a reception by the officers and managers of the Hebrew Sheltering Guardian Society at the asylum, Eleventh-avenue and One Hundred and Fifty-first-street. A feature of the affair was the formal presentation to these legislators of engrossed copies of resolutions adopted Oct. 6 in recognition of their efforts at Albany in behalf of the society.

Since THE TIMES commenced its advocacy of the establishment of a corps of coast pilots for the navy no little interest has centred in the class of men to which this reference has had special bearing. It is not generally known just what constitutes a pilot, and from what particular body of men selections could be made for the responsible positions advocated being opened in the navy.
LONDON, Dec. 29.--The epidemic of influenza continues in Paris, and there are no signs of an improvement. In Munich the disease is increasing.
TROY, N.Y., Dec. 29.--Jonas S. Heartt, the wealthy car wheel manufacturer, cannot live until morning. He is suffering from pneumonia, which followed a slight attack of the grippe.

One of the most remarkable and one of the most joyful events of all the Christmas time was the festival tendered to the little children of the stage last night at Tony Pastor's Theatre and Tammany Hall. For weeks a committee has been at work collecting toys, candies, clothing, and money for these tiny people.

It is over twenty-one years since the Pennsylvania eight-hour law was passed, and the City Solicitor of Philadelphia has just been called upon for an opinion whether it is applicable to city departments.

By the will of John Henderson, who spent most of his life in Flushing, L.I., $2,000 is bequeated to St. George's Brotherhood, Flushing, for the erection of an Episcopal chapel at Bay Side; $1,000 to St. George's Church, $1,000 to the College Point Mission Chape, $1,000 to St. George's Sunday school, and $10,000 to the Flushing Hospital.

After combating financial difficulties for several weeks Forquer Brothers of Bayonne, N.J., have been forced to make an assignment for $20,000. John and James Forquer are the members of the firm and Counselor James Benny is assignee. The firm did a large business in coal, ice, and feed. Papers are ready for filing to-day, when the exact status of affairs will be known.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29.--Christmas week was less satisfactory to the Chicago theatrical managers than usual. As a rule business was but little above the average and the Christmas matinees were wretched. The evening performances on that day drew crowded houses and helped to even up the week somewhat.

It was early yesterday morning before the Amateur Athletic Union finished the work of revising the rules pertaining to the different events. Some important changes were made, and in consequence the delegates proceeded very slowly.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29.--Charity, Justice, Brotherly Love, and Fidelity clasped hands today when the handsome new building of the Philadelphia Lodge, No. 2, Benevolent Protective Order of Elks, was dedicated.

At the annual election of the Dry Dock, East Broadway and Battery Railroad Company, to be held on Jan. 14, an effort will be made by some of the stockholders who are dissatisfied with the management of the company's affairs to put in a new President and Board of Directors.

LAWERENCE, Mass., Dec. 29.--About noon today the body of Miss Sarah F. Nichols was found frozen in the ice of the Merrimac River, about a mile above the upper bridge. The body was drawn ashore by the police.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 29.--The Department of Astronomy at Brown University will soon be one of the working departments of that institution. It will be warmly welcomed.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 30.--A special convention of the Presbytery of Elizabeth, presided over by the Moderator, the Rev. Dr. Teal of Westminster Church, was held this afternoon at the Third Presbyterian Church.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 30.--The Cedar Rapid Gazette, the leading Republican paper in Eastern Iowa, is out with a severe arraignment of Senator Allison's public record.

ALBANY, Dec. 30.--It looks somewhat as if Gen. Husted was preparing to throw one of those double back somersaults for which he is famous. It will be determined this week probably whether he will perform this acrobatic feat, for he has issued invitations to the members of the Committee on Rules of the Assembly of 1889 to meet him in this city on Friday next at 12 o'clock.
Contractor John Cornwell, Jr., who is engaged in the work of laying the Croton water mains through West One Hundred and Twentyfifth-street, seems to have gotten himself into trouble.
RONDOUT, N.Y., Dec. 30.--A letter has been received from Chief Engineer Greene of the steamer City of Kingston, formely of this port, under date of Barbadoes.
The annual report of the Kings County Charities Commissioners shows that there were supported by the county last year 11,105 paupers at a cost of $515,576.13.

Gardner, the English carpenter who, with his family, has been detained at Ward's Island by order of the Board of Emigration since Sept. 12 last, will have an interesting termination to-day. PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30.--Mrs. Caroline Coleman, aged forty-five years, an actress, was found dead in her room at 603 Arch-street, this city, this afternoon. She had been addicted to the use of opium, and it is thought she either accidentally or intentionally took an overdose of the drug.

ALBANY, Dec 30.--Gov. Hill will receive the public generally on New Year's Day at the Executive Chamber between 11 and 12 A.M. He will receive personal friends and acquaintances at the Executive Mansion between 3 and 5 P.M.
Thomas McGreevy of Montana is at the Gilsey House. Prof. S.P. Langley of Washington is at the Brevoert House.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Dec. 30.--On the night of Nov. 1 the store occupied by John H. Lawrence, the principal merchant and country produce dealer at Emmonsville, Sullivan County, was destroyed by an incendiary fire with most of its contents. The property was found to have been heavily insured and suspicion was excited that Lawrence had a guilty knowledge...

PARIS, Dec. 30.--During the performance of "Jeanne d'Arc," by Sarah Bernhardt, last night, the pyre used in the play became ignited from the surrounding fire. Mme. Bernhardt, who was on the pyre, received no injury from the fire, but fainted. Two scene shifters were seriously hurned while extinguishing the fire.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30.--There was an active demand for Cattle to-day and prices ranged higher. Both shippers and local trade operated with freedom, and as the receipts were limited sellers were in a position to get better prices than have prevailed of late.

John R. Patterson, aged twenty-seven, who was shot accidentally, it is claimed, by William Tobin, in Jack Francis's saloon at Dobbs Ferry on Christmas Day, died at his home on Sunday night. Coroner Nordquist took his ante mortem statement on Christmas afternoon, when the wounded man said the whole affair was an accident, and that the pistol was dischared while they were wrangling for possession of it. The three foury-story brownstone buildings at 68, 70, and 72 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn known as the Water View Flats, were partially destroyed by fire about 1 o'clock yesterday...

Charles W. Bligh, a United States weigher, was put on trial in Judge Lippincott's court, Jersey City, yesterday, for bigamy. In 1878 he married Julia Walters at Brooklyn. Two years ago he secured a divorce from her in the...

The Daily Register and the Law Journal, which have been fighting in the courts for nearly two years for city pap, have consolidated, and will hereafter he issued by the "New-York Law Publilshing Company."

ROCHESTER, Dec. 30.--The General Term of the Fifth Department this morning handed down a decision in the case of Kemmler, the murderer condemned to death under the new law providing for the execution of criminals by electricity, a law which the court holds to be constitutional. Judge Dwight writes the opinion.

HAVANA, Dec. 30.--Last evening thousands of people assembled on the grounds of the Club Almendares to witness a firemen's exhibition, the object of which was to raise funds for the Fire Department. For the purpose of the exhibition a two-story wooden building had been erected, which was to be set on fire.

The members of Steinwehr Post, G.A.R., held a secret, but spirited, meeting last evening at Beethoven Hall to elect a successor to Coroner Levy, the Commander of the post, who had sent in his resignation. There were a large number of the comrades present, as it had been...

The select committee of the United States Senate on the transportation and sale of meat products met at the Hoffman House yesterday morning. The committee consists of George G. Vest of Missouri, Chairman, and Messrs. Plumb of Kansas, Manderson of Nebraska, Farwell of Illinois, and Coke of Texas. The two last named were not present yesterday.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 30.--The Academy of Music, in course of erection on Thirteenth-street and Washington-avenue, fell in a heap at 10:30 o'clock this morning. One workman had a rib broken.
Myer Silberman, a jeweler, thirty-three years old, committed suicide yesterday afternoon by shooting himself in the left breast with a revolver while alone in his room, at 5 Orchardstreet.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 30.--George Westinghouse, the head of the Westinghouse Electric Company, returned to-day from New-York, and announced that his company was about ready to supply the metropolis with a new system of are lighting.

John G.H. Meyers was appointed attorney for the collection of arrears of personal taxes yesterday by Corporation Counsel Clark. He succeeds Henry Bischoff, Jr., who was elected Judge of the Court of Common Pleas on the Tammany ticket at the last election. The appointment takes effect to-morrow. Mr. Meyors is about forty years of age, is a Tammanyite of the Seventeenth District, and is Secretary of Tammany's Committee on Organization. The salary is $4,000.

The Committee of the United States Senate on Relations with Canada visited this city yesterday for the first time since its appointment before the Congressional recess last Spring, and gave a hearing to persons interested in one of the Federal Court rooms in the Post Office Building.

Edward C. Moller, who blew out his brains at his home in Hudson-street, Hoboken, Sunday night, had been much depressed by the loss of two children within a week early in the Spring. He had also made a number of luckless speculations in Wall-street. The two causes combined to drive him to the cup, and he had been drinking freely just before he killed himself.

VIENNA, Dec. 30.--Emperor Francis Joseph has created Chevalier Gautsch von Frankenthurn, Minister of Worship and Education, a Baron, and has transferred Gen. von Welsersheimb, Minister for the National Defense, to the upper house of the Reichsrath.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 30.--William Hyde of West Haven was to have been married to Miss Nellie Conlon last Tuesday evening, but just before the appointed hour he disappeared and nothing has been heard of him since. Hyde was a Protestant and Miss Conlon was a Catholic. Great opposition was made to the marriage, and it is supposed Hyde ran away on that account.

ROME, Dec. 30.--A Papal consistory was held to-day. The Pope delivered an allocution, in which he emphasized his censure of the Government's Eccleslastical Trusts bill, and condemned the deposition of the Bishop of Altamura, Italy.

For the first time in many a day money loaned in Wall-street yesterday at 40 per cent. It was once last week up to 35 per cent., and at various times during the past year has scaled 25 per cent, but the 40-per-cent, quotation had not been reached till yesterday.

The arrival of the cold wave from the West did not prevent people from going to the Clifton race track yesterday, where the last races of 1889 were run over its track. The crowd was even larger than usual for a Monday, and the betting was lively all through the ring.

The Washington Memorial Arch fund still continues to grow, and has now reached the amount of $64,388 21. Treasurer William R. Stewart of 54 William-street yesterday received $100 from Joseph Jefferson, the actor, and through the World $25. Those who have charge of the fund feel pride in the steady increase which has marked its course from its beginning.

Congressman "Tim" Campbell's friends and followers attended the reception of the Oriental Club, of which he is President, at the clubhouse, 443 Grand-street, last night. Sixth District statesmen and statesmen from other districts were plentiful in the big crowd, and there was good cheer enough going round to make the exCongressman's smile bigger and broader than usual.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 30.--Word comes from the Indian Territory that two notorious Indian desperadoes, named Red Lendall and Choctaw Pete, heavily loaded with tanglefoot, took possession of the town of Tishwawa on Christmas Day and carried things with a high hand. After nearly killing the Town Marshal, when he attempted to arrest them, they emptied a drug store and tried to ride their horses into the hotel.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 30.--The Thomas men to-night for the first time give some figures on the Senatorial situation. Mr. Thomas's first lieutenant says that he will receive thirty votes on the first ballot, and that the other ten necessary to nominate him are promised on the second or third ballot. The second choice of almost the entire field, he claims, is Mr. Thomas, who will on the first ballot have a decided lead.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30.--Chemicals and the fine arts occupied the attention of the Committee on Ways and Means to-day, and a good many persons were given a chance to say what sort of a tariff they would like.

The year has been a busy one for the churches. The list of conferences, assemblies, conventions, synods, is a long one, and there have been some interesting discussions, among which that in the Presbyterian Church (Northern) on revision of the Westminster Confession has attracted most attention.

Tammany Police Justices again had their own way at the annual meeting of the magistrates at Jefferson Market Court last night. Two new Clerks were appointed and two of the old ones were told they could stay.

Mrs. Honiola Parkes, who was a sister of Imre and Bolossy Kiralfy, and the favorite premiere danseuse of the "Black Crook" company, died on Christmas Day at her residence, 357 East Forty-ninth-street.
Steps have been taken to organize a German American Trust Company in Brooklyn, with $500,000 capital, with an office near Broadway and Myrtle-avenue. About half the stock has been subscribed.

LONDON, Dec. 30.--The Marquis of Salisbury has completed his answer to the Portuguese note. The silence of Consul Johnston encourages the opinion that he is organizing to oust the Portuguese from their new positions. The Marquis is seriously ill.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 30.--The construction of the will of the late John Guy Vassar came before Judge Barnard to-day. The complaint was made by the executors of the will--Oliver H. Booth, Edward Van Kleeck, and Benjamin M. Fowler.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 30.--It is announced that in April next Andrew Carnegie will secure a majority of the stock of the Pittsburg and Western Railroad Company. It is understood that the entire holding of Eastern people is included in this deal.

The Madison-Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church was the scene of a pretty military wedding at noon yesterday, when Miss Margaret Louise Cornell, daughter of J.B. Cornell, became the wife of Lieut. Charles Gould Treat of the Fifth Artillery, United States Army. The church was profusely decorated with palms, roses, and potted plants, and was crowded with the friends of both families.

LONDON, Dec. 31.--Cora Kennedy, the American poetess, has died at Ospedaletto, in Italy.

Post Office Inspector G.W. Wilde yesterday arrested James P. Wright, a letter carrier in the Richmond (Va.) Post Office, charged with robbing the mails. A portion of a rifled letter was found on his person. Wright was formerly a Methodist minister.

Mayor Grant yesterday carried out the programme that he laid down for himself at Saturday's meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment, and asked the Board of Health to remove James S. Coleman, Commissioner of Street Cleaning. But Mr. Coleman did not wait to see what the Board of Health would do...
