The Sinking Fund Commissioners met yesterday and appointed Chamberlain Richard Croker and Controller Myers a committee to report upon the advisability of using Harlem Market Square, at One Hundred and Twenty-first-street and Third-avenue, as a site for a municipal court building.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 30.--Thomas Kennedy, the senior patrolman of the New-Haven police force and one of the most widely-known policemen of New-England, died at his home in this city to-day of brain paralysis. He had been ill about a year, and for a short time prior...

Judge Lawrence has denied the motion of Col. William W. Dudley's counsel to vacate an order for substituted service of an order for his examination before trial of the libel suit brought by him against the New-York World for the publication of his notorious "blocks of five" letter. Judge Lawrence says that as long as Col. Dudley keeps without the jurisdiction of the court he must not ask favors of it.

The officers of the Court of Common Pleas yesterday presented Judge George M. Van Hoesen with a floral horseshoe, on the occasion of his last appearance upon the bench. Judge Van Hoesen sat upon the General Term Bench with Judge Bookstaver, and the horseshoe rested in front of him. His term of office expires to-day, and on Monday next Judge Henry Bischoff, Jr., will take his seat.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30.--In the International Marine Conference this morning the report of the Committee upon General Divisions 9 and 12 of the programme was submitted to the conference and adopted.

BOSTON, Dec. 30.--Insurance Commissioner Merrill is out in an open letter to President W.H. Beers of the New-York Life Insurance Company, one of the three largest life insurance companies in the world, pointing out...

BALTIMORE, Dec. 30.--The Maryland Jockey Club to-day definitely decided to disband and to distribute the proceeds of its property at Pimlico among its members, 230 in number. Oden Bowie, R.C. Hall, and John S. Gittings were appointed Trustees to dispose of the property, valued at about $60,000. The club has been in existence twenty years, and was obliged to forego the last Fall meeting on account of the multiplicity of tracks in NewYork and New-Jersey.
Albert Meiser, the youthful Brooklyn Anarchist who on Sunday morning tried to kill his former employer, Baker Stedefeder, was arraigned before Justice Kenna yesterday.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 30.--The Duquesne Club, the leading social organization in Pittsburg, will New Year's Day throw open the doors of its magnificent new clubhouse on Sixth-avenue. The building is of brick, with brownstone front. When entirely completed it will have cost nearly $250,000, which sum was raised upon bonds. Throughout it is equipped in the most thorough manner.

BERLIN, Dec. 30.--The statistics show a great increase in all maladies attendant upon the influenza. For the third week in December there were 37 deaths from laryngitis, 122 from inflammation of the lungs, and 10 from pleurisy.

DETROIT, Dec. 30.--An election of some significance took place at Windsor, Ontario, opposite this city to-day, when Sol White, citizen, was chosen Mayor by acclamation. Mr. White is an avowed and earnest advocate of annexation, and he is the first man elected to office in Ontario on a political annexation platform,...

HARTFORD, Dec. 30.--At the annual meeting of the Hartford Yale Alumni Association here this evening it was decided to raise a fund from the Hartford graduates of the university for the benefit of the Medical School. The Rev. Joseph M. Twitchell was appointed Chairman of the...

ALTOONA, Penn., Dec. 30.--Three carloads of Pinkerton detectives passed through here this afternoon for Watson, a mining town six miles from Punxsutawney, Penn., where it is said trouble is feared from the striking miners.

Manipulators of the money market ruled Wall-street yesterday. The call loan rate was put up as high as 40 per cent., which fact, along with the announcement that the Bank of England discount rate was advanced, gave stock market bears opportunities that they did not fail to use. Nearly every stock on the list was assailed; most of them yielded.

James S. Coleman's letter of resignation as Street-Cleaning Commissioner reached Mayor Grant yesterday morning, and he did not wait long before accepting it. The following letter was soon on its way to the Commissioner's office:

The United States Government a few years ago adopted the system of licensing sutlers in the various homes for disabled soldiers in the country to sell liquors to the inmates. It was believed that by furnishing good liquors it would prevent the old soldiers from being poisoned by the vile compounds they purchased outside at saloons in the neighborhood.

Ex-Mayor Fernando Wood in September, 1876, conveyed to his son, J.L.R. Wood, certain real estate at Bergen Point, N.J. The transfer was without consideration. About that time the son, at the request of his father, exchanged this property with one Shaw for a parcel of Sixty-third-street property, then subject to several mortgages.

There was happiness after all in Wall-street at the close of the year. The money squeeze of Monday, with its attendant depression of stock quotations, had altogether disappeared yesterday. Instead of 40 percent., loan rates were down to 6 percent. Stocks which declined sharply on the day before were yesterday not only firm, but buoyant. Indeed, 1889 in Wall-street went out in almost a blaze of glory.

There is a very curious state of things said to exist in Washington with reference to the prosecution of those zealous members of the Old Dominion Club who sought to elicit from the employes of the Federal Government substantial aid for Gen. MAHONE when he supposed that he was running for Governor in the State of Virginia.

Burning apartment houses in Upper Madison-avenue and the frantic struggles of tenants to escape and save their effects gave the Harlem firemen and police a lively job yesterday morning. The fire was a furious one, but those who fought it prevented any fatalities or serious accidents and confined the flames to a comparatively small field of property.

The people who had the entree to Trinity Church last night were fortunate. They, at least, were privileged to listen to the chimes, which rang the old year out and the new year in, in comparative comfort. Without the streets abutting upon Broadway and the main thoroughfare were packed with a multitude or pushing, screaming, horn-blowing humanity.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31. -- La grippe has made its appearance in the Post Office. Postmaster Sexton has a touch of it, and four of five heads of departments and between thirty and forty clerks are laid up with it.

According to the estimates of the Treasury Department the debt statement for December will show a reduction for that month of about $4,000,000. This makes a total reduction for the six months since July 1 of a little over $24,000,000, or $7,500,000 less than for the corresponding period of 1888.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- The attention of the fashionable world was monopolized this afternoon by the fancy dress ball given by Mr. and Mrs. John McLean to the young friends of their little son, Edward Beale McLean. Mr. and Mrs. McLean stood in the broad hallway to receive the children as they descended the stairway, and presented them to young Master McLean, who wore a simple white sailor costume.

The course of Mr. COLEMAN in resigning his position as Commissioner of Street Cleaning in the face of the charge that he had failed in his duty to the city could be regarded only as a serious mistake if it were not a logical sequence of his mistaken policy in the administration of the department.

NICE, Dec. 31, -- Mary Anderson received reporter to-day and said: "I want the report denied that I am about to play in 'The Tempest.' I wish it distinctly understood that I have no intention of returning to the stage, at least for an indefinite period."
LONDON, Dec. 31. -- Minister Robert T. Lincoln is still with his family at Versailles. His son is slowly recovering.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 31. -- Judge Brewer announced in a recent interview that he owed his appointment to the Supreme bench largely to the efforts of Senator Allison in his behalf. He no doubt told the truth. When, therefore, the news dispatches announced Mr. Allison as one of those voting against Judge Brewer's confirmation there was very general surprise.
Senator Butler of South Carolina came up from Washington yesterday and joined his associates of the Committee on Relations with Canada, whose sessions were continued at the Hoffman House.

HALIFAX, N.S., Dec. 31. -- The Allan Line steamer Nestorian, Capt. France, after a stormy passage of twenty days from Glasgow, arrived in port last evening. Her Captain reports the weather experienced as something fearful, gale upon gale of hurricane force being encountered up to longitude 40 west. The seas were very heavy and washed over the deck from time to time in a very dangerous manner.

Chicago, Dec. 31. -- There was continued firmness in the Cattle market to-day. The demand was not as sharp as on Monday, but it called for a larger number of Cattle than were on sale and therefore the advantage remained with sellers. They held their cattle at a further advance of 10c., and anything at all desirable brought about that much more than on the previous day.

The latest -- would we could say the last -proposition for making the country rich by act of Congress comes from a journal bearing the curious title, The Financier. It is "to pass a law and print $500,000,000 in greenbacks in excess of the present issue, and as fast as printed expend the same sum in macadamizing the country roads all over the United States."

The Republican members of the Ohio Legislature have recently been advised repeatedly in the Commercial Gazette by Mr. HALSTEAD that they ought not to give ex-Gov. FOSTER a complimentary nomination for the office of Senator, and now Mr. FOSTER replies at some length, and says that Mr. HALSTEAD never has been a safe counselor.

After days of tedious figuring and discussion the Board of Estimate and Apportionment finished its work on the city's budget for 1890 at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon. At yesterday's meeting of the board the last touches were given the estimates, changes were made here and there, and the figures were gone over for the last time. Fifty-six hundred dollars was appropriated for additional stenographers in the Supreme Court on the mandamus of the Judges.

The Governor of the State of New-York must have had the native hue of his resolution considerably sicklied over with the pale cast of thought if he has read the comments of the press in the country at large upon his action in superseding the Albany Argus by the Albany Times as the official State paper.

If the State is to get more than a fair proportion of its revenue from this city for the present year it will have to sue for it. The Board of Estimate and Apportionment, justifying its action in a long list of whereases, has included in the city and county tax levy the sum of $4,519,641 83 for State purposes, instead of the 5,698,248 89 which will be demanded by the State authorities.

Jockey Garrison and his father-in-law, Judge McMahon of Sheepshead Bay, who have been in co-partnership under the name of McMahon Co. in the ownership of about twenty race horses, the most notable of which are Eolian and Cyclops, agreed at Howe Hummel's office on Saturday to a dissolution of co-partnership.

SCRANTON, Penn., Dec. 31. -- George Shippey, the murderer, who escaped from the Wyoming County Jail at Tunkhannock two weeks ago, was captured late last evening in the mountains north of this city, near a place called Mount Pleasant. The capture was made by a party consisting of Lyman McCarty of Greenfield Edwin Coray, Frank Howell of Uniondale, and Danber Westgate of Herrick.
" Milk is down." That is the cry which will be familiar with purveyors of the fluid in this city and vicinity before this week has expired.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 31. -- The Democratic caucus met to-night and selected the following nominees: For President of the Senate -- Robert F. Brattan of Somerset County; for Speaker of the House -- John Hubner of Baltimore County. They will be formally elected by the two branches of the Legislature when it begins its biennial session of ninety days to-morrow.
PITTSBURG, Dec. 31. -- W.S. Mallory of the iron firm of Mallory Brown of Chicago, speaking of the iron business to-day, said:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- This was the last day's session of the American Historical Association, and was given up to the reading of papers on Southern history after Gen. Carrington had delivered an address upon the subject of the Flathead Indians.

Yesterday was Register Slevin's last day in office. He took care of one of his friends before getting out by appointing John McDonough, a Grand Army man and a Third District Tammanyite. Custodian of Conveyances in place of Jurgen Johansen, who was removed. The salary is $1,500, and the new man is not likely to be disturbed for some time.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Dec. 31. -- A fatal wreck occurred at Kokomo this morning on the Pan Handle Railway, one mile north of the station. Train No. 13, north bound, Conductor Thomas Lamb, left the junction a 2:13 A.M. schedule time. When about a mile north it met train No. 14, south bound, in care of Conductor V.D. Noland. It was running about fifty miles an hour.

Strange proceedings are of such frequent occurrence in Westchester County, owing mainly to the political lines drawn between the Protestants an the Catholics, that sensations of an ordinary nature fall very flat. There was an investigation secretly carried on yesterday, however, under the special orders of the County District Attorney, the developments of which will create a profound interest.

ROME, Dec. 31. -- The Pope at yesterday's consistory said he was rejoiced at the building of Catholic universities at Washington, Ottawa, and Fribourg. Catholicism, he said, prospered under the favorable laws of America and the equity of the men who administered them in that country. His joy at this prosperity rendered the grief Italy caused him more striking by contrast.

the different lines covering freely. Compared with Monday's closings, prices showed an advance of 21/2c. on January Pork and Short Ribs and May Lard, 71/2c. on May Short Ribs, 5c. on January Lard, and 10c. on May Pork.

PITTSBURG, Jan 1. -- Allegheny City politician have been exercised not a little to-day over a personal encounter which occurred last night between two well-Known members of Councils in front of the City Hall W.W. Speer, one of the Councilmen, is a millionaire plow manufacturer and is generally looked upon as United States Senator Quay's choice for the Republican nomination for State Senator from the Allegheny district.

CITY OF MEXICO, Jan. 1, via Galveston. -- Treasury statistics of exports for the fiscal year ended June 30 last show total receipts of $60,158,423, against $48,885.908 in the previous fiscal period, a gain of $11,272,514, which is the result of the increased prosperity of the country.

SCRANTON, Penn., Jan. 1. -- General Master Workman Powderly sounds the keynote of ballot reform for 1890 in a long and vigorous article on the Australian system of voting, published this afternoon. In answer to those who allege that the system is not American, Mr. Powderly says:

The career and the character of THEOPHILUS C. CALLICOT are pretty well known to the people of New-York, but we have thought it worth while to recite somewhat in detail the story of his life in order that our readers may better understand the nature and value of the services rendered to the Democratic Party by the man upon whom Gov. HILL has conferred a conspicuous mark of official and political favor.
In the Albany correspondence of the Commercial Advertiser we find the following biographical sketch:

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 1. -- Gov. Hill held a public reception in the Executive Chamber this morning between the hours of 11 and 12 o'clock. A large number of ladies and gentlemen availed themselves of the opportunity to present the compliments of the season to the Governor, among them being representatives from three Albany military companies, the Burgesses and Jackson Corps, and the Albany Academy Cadets.

There were evidences yesterday of the approach of a Renaissance in the some-time neglected custom of New Year's calling. Throughout the residence district, the Murray Hill, Madison and Fifth avennes, and Central Park quarters, the door-bell card-basket, the bete moir of intending callers, was conspicuous by its absence.

Seven Italians made a concerted attack last night upon Charles Walker, a negro, in front of the tenement house at 232 Sands-street, Brooklyn, where Walker lives, and slashed him almost to death. The building has always been a headquarters for negroes, but an Italian, known as Luigi, recently bought it, and he set about getting rid of the negroes.

The appointment of civilians as Second Lieutenants in the army will be revived early this year, two names having been already selected by President HARRISON to be sent to the Senate, and one or two others being likely to follow. The vacancies certainly exist and advantage can be lawfully taken of them.

The disturber of the peace of Scranton, Penn., is one of the most determined and relentless misanthropes of whom history bears record. The very notion of a steam trombone makes humanity shudder. In its best estate the trombone, when inflated merely by the unaided power of the human lung and its note deepened merely by the extent of the human arm, is a somewhat lethal utensil.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 4. -- The immediate future here is assured, but what will happen in the course of a year cannot be safely predicted. That there is danger ahead, which may prove to be very serious, a prudent, reflecting man who knows the people can clearly foresee. Possibly it may be avoided, but the probabilities are most decidedly the other way.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 1. -- Several hundred newsboys returning from their annual New Year's dinner almost created a riot on Fifth-avenue this afternoon. They first attacked a crowd of Italians and Hebrews, and then turned their attention to the non-union gripmen and conductors on the Pittsburg traction road.

Wagner's "Lohengrin" was performed at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening for the first time this season. It served to introduce Herr Heinrich Vogl, one of the tenors of the company, and a Wagner singer of experience and repute. He has been suffering from sickness since his arrival in America, and cannot fairly be said to be at his best yet.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 1. -- At a meeting of the window glass manufacturers of Ohio and Indiana yesterday the prices named at Findlay on Nov. 12, 80 and 5 per cent. off on single strength and 80 and 10 per cent. off on double strength glass, were reaffirmed.

ALBANY, Jan. 1. -- Some fact and a great deal of fancy has gone forth to the world since Gov. Hill dictated the appointment of the Evening Times of this city as the "State newspaper" in the place of the Argus, a newspaper whose Democracy was the Democracy of Jefferson, Jackson, and Tilden, and whose loyalty to its party was never questioned.

Our correspondence from Rio de Janeiro indicates that the only thing certain about the future of Brazil is that there is no chance of a restoration of the empire or of monarchy in any form. But for the present there is no republic there, but only a provisional Government, which is in effect military rule and nothing else.

A regular holiday crowd was at the Clifton track yesterday afternoon, and the racing was, as it should have been, up to the holiday standard. The favorites were bowled over in all but two of the races, but this didn't prevent people from feeling fairly happy. In the clubhouse this happiness was intensified by the pleasures of an elaborate lunch, and the little New Year has his health drank copiously.

Yesterday the Sun, in an Albany dispatch, stated the position of Gov. HILL on ballot reform with a positiveness that was evidently meant to convey the impression that it was authoritative. With an iteration intended to give it emphasis, the dispatch said: "Gov. HILL will sign no ballot reform bill that will disfranchise a single voter.

A few pigeon-shooters gathered at Erbs's grounds in Newark, N.J., yesterday and amused themselves at shooting at a few live birds. As the crack shots were down at Long Branch, no attempt was made to get up any regular matches at Newark. The rain and fog had a depressing effect upon the pigeons, and they did not like to leave the traps.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 1. -- The Elizabeth City Council for 1890 organized to-night by the election of ex-Judge Patrick H. Gilhooly Democrat, as President, that gentleman receiving 14 votes. W.R. Corbin, Republican, received 10. Councilman Campbell, Democrat, bolted the caucus nominee for City Clerk, ex-Alderman James J. Manning, and voted for E.L. Coleman, Republican. Four ballots were taken, each resulting in a tie.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 1. -- The royal palace at Laeken, a suburb of this city, has been nearly destroyed by fire. Princess Clementine, the daughter of the King, had a narrow escape from being burned to death. Her governess was suffocated.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 5. -- The most important action of the provisional Government during the past week was taken by the Minister of the Treasury in determining reissue Treasury notes to the different banks upon the deposit of national securities. Six thousands contas were given to the Banco Nacional and 4,000 contas to the Banco da Brazil, making in all 10,000,000 of milreis.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 1. -- The House of the Legislature, which meets Jan. 13, is a tie, and the Republicans are making some threats of demanding the Speaker of the House, claiming that unless this is granted they will prolong the dead-look, and thus defer the inauguration of the Democratic Governor. This threat will frighten nobody.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 1. -- Mr. Frederick Goodrich, formerly of New-York, and manager of the Richmond Granite Quarry, who was mysteriously injured in some way Dec. 21, died in his room at the Exchange Hotel this afternoon. Early on the morning named Mr. Goodrich appeared in the rotunda of the Exchange Hotel with his face partially hidden from view by his overcoat collar turned up.
CAIRO, Jan 1. -- The Khedive's Government will not accept the proposition made by France in regard to the conversion of the preference debt, and the conversion is consequently postponed.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 2. -- Judge Barnard to-day filed his decision in the matter of the construction of John Guy Vassar's will. He decides that the Baptist church of Poughkeepsie, having raised enough to pay off a fifteen-thousand-dollar mortgage, is entitled to the $10,000 given it by Mr. Vassar, and that the gifts to the several corporations of sums of money subject to the payment of annuities are good.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 2. -- An autopsy made today on the body of Mr. Frederick E. Goodrich, who died yesterday at the Exchange Hotel presumably from wounds he had mysteriously received, satisfied the Coroner that death had resulted from pneumonia. A Coroner's jury found a verdict accordingly.

The year 1890 promises to be an important one in the history of the navy of the United State. The authorizing of eight new battle ships and five torpedo boats will mark a distinct era in the construction of war ships for this country, in as much as we have in the past contented ourselves wholly with protected cruisers and light-draught gunboats.

No committee of Congress in many a long year has listened to arguments and facts so important and significant as those brought before the Ways and Means Committee yesterday. The session was devoted to the question of the duties on wool. The principal "witness" was Mr. F.P. BENNETT, the editor of the American Wool Reporter of Boston.

There is a great deal to be said in favor of the proposition lately brought forward by the junior officers of the Naval Service for the relief of the Ensigns. There are over one hundred and eighty of these young officers, some of whom have been in this grade for eight years, and, including their term of four years at the Naval Academy, have been in the service for sixteen years.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 2. -- The Senatorial pot has boiled very lively to-day, and the hosts of Millionaire Thomas have been in high glee, claiming not only the nomination of their favorite, but the withdrawal of Mr. Brice from the field before the caucus.

NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 2. -- The British steamship West Cumberland, Capt. Myles Kirkpatrick, bound from Merrypool, England, to Vera Cruz, which put into Lambert's Point this afternoon for coal, had on board the Captain, crew, and two passengers of the schooner Millie G. Bowne, which left Boston, Mass., Dec. 7, and which was abandoned Dec. 22 after she had been wreck for ten days.

Mrs. Hannah B. Southworth, the woman who shot and killed Stephen B. Pettus in Fulton-street several weeks ago, is critically ill in the Tombs. The physician in attendance, Dr. Chetwood of the city staff, said last evening that she had been severely ill ever since she entered the prison. Her blood was very much impoverished, and she had been suffering from chronic bronchitis before she sprung into her later notoriety.

Influenza was a factor in three cases of suicide reported at the Coroners' office yesterday. Mrs. Margaret Steneck, wife of John D. Steneck, a hatter at 1,309 Broadway, was attacked by the ailment on Tuesday. It was not a serious case as the disease goes, but she was asthmatic and nervous, and the new trouble affected her greatly.
Since the union of Italy the point has been considerably blunted of THACKERAY'S famous lines:

The New Year's Ball, about which so much has been said and written, and which was to be the most notable event society has taken part in these many years, proved to be an unqualified success at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. There were very nearly eleven hundred persons in attendance, and they represented the wealth of the city in a most markedly thorough way.

HARTFORD, Jan. 2. -- The improvement of farm lands is one of the most important problems now agitating public attention in Connecticut. Its discussion during the past three months has occupied more space in the press of the State than has been given to it for years back. There is marked interest in the subject in the cities and organizations of business men, including the Hartford Board of Trade.

KEYPORT, N.J., Jan. 2. -- George A. Campbell of this place is the first person in this section of the country to die from the effects of the grip. Mr. Campbell was taken ill about a week ago with the disease, which rapidly developed into pneumonia, and at 2 o'clock to-day he died. Mr. Campbell's wife and children are all down with the disease, as are also about twenty-five other persons hereabout.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Jan. 2. -- The west-bound mail train and a local accommodation train on the Central Railroad collided in a thick fog twenty miles west of Savannah this morning. The local was standing on a side track waiting for orders. Both engines were wrecked, and six passengers slightly injured.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 2. -- One of the means by which Senator Allison hopes to secure his re-election to the Senate came to the surface to-day. A letter was received here from a leading Democrat in a northwestern county which recites the visit to that locality of a Democrat from one of the eastern counties of the State, who is evidently in Mr. Allison's service and under Mr. Allison's pay.

Miss Josephine F. Beuclair, one of the teachers in the primary department of Grammar School No. 50, testified last night before the committee appointment by the Board of Trustees of the Eighteenth Ward to investigate the charges made by the teachers against Miss Susan Wright, the Principal. Miss Wright was present, accompanied by her counsel, Nelson J. Waterbury.

BOSTON, Jan. 2. -- The two branches of the Legislature met in joint convention at about noon to-day, and the oath of office was administered to Governor-elect Brackett and Lieutenant Governor-elect Haile, and a proclamation was made by Secretary of State Pierce. Gov. Brackett then read his inaugural address.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 2. -- The Connecticut Grand Lodge of Masons will hold its annual session in this city on Wednesday, the 15th inst., the conclave lasting for two days. The annual address will be delivered by Grand Master John H. Swartwout of Stamford.

It is a curious concurrence of circumstances that makes JAMES W. HUSTED of Westchester County the predestined Republican candidate for the Speakership of the Assembly, without a rival, just one year after he made a futile attempt to attain that office for the sixth time. Last year FREMONT COLE had no difficulty in defeating his aspirations, and came to Albany as the most popular member of the Assembly.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 2. -- The heavy rainstorm of yesterday and last night sadly demoralized all kinds of electric wires in this city, and it was not until after midnight last night that they were brought into proper working order. The telephone was especially exasperating, it being almost impossible to get communication over it, and several serious accidents were occasioned by electric light wires.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2. -- The wedding this evening of Miss Annie Iredell Rogers, daughter of the late William W. Rogers, to Green B. Raum, Jr., son of Commissioner of Pensions Raum, at the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. James, was one of the prettiest ceremonies of the season. The Rev. Dr. Nichols, pastor of the Church, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Morton, Pastor Emeritus of the church, performed the ceremony.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 2. -- The announcement telegraphed from Pittsburg several days ago that a new open-hearth process for making steel had been invented has attracted considerable attention. It is difficult to get anything definite about the matter. Charles Adams of this city, the veteran iron man, who organized the Cambria Iron Company, and who has had charge of some of the largest plants in the country, is the inventor of the process.

LENOX, Mass., Jan. 2. -- The cottagers are here in large numbers to enjoy the holiday sports. The town has put on an exceedingly lively appearance, and the cottagers who are here with their numerous guests are enjoying the Winter sports, which consist principally of skating, and driving about the country, although there is no snow and the roads are frozen and rough.

George Henry Boker, the poet and dramatist, ex-United States Minister to Turkey and Russia, died at his home in Philadelphia yesterday morning of an affection of the throat, from which he had been suffering for a long time. He was first prostrated about eight weeks ago, but no alarm was felt about the ultimate result among his family and friends, as it was supposed the disease would yield readily to medical treatment.

FINDLAY, Ohio, Jan. 2. -- The window glass manufacturers of the United States have at last effected a "combine" and formed a pool by organizing themselves into a syndicate, with a capital of $800,000, the headquarters of which is to be in Chicago. The pool is to take all the window glass produced by the factories in the combine and dispose of the same at the following fixed prices:

The Guttenberg race track had an unusual crowd yesterday to see six races run, and the crowd present had plenty of sport. The second race was a complete surprise to all the wise ones, however, for it was won very handily by Nita, who was considered so little of a factor in the race that the bookmakers laid odds of 15 to 1 against her.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- The marriage of Miss Emma Gertrude Flower, daughter of Representative Roswell P. Flower, to Mr. John Bayard Taylor of Watertown, N.Y., was solemnized at 5 o'clock this afternoon at the Flower family residence, 1,735 I-street.

TORONTO, Jan. 2. -- The separate school election for Trustees, which took place here yesterday, is causing much comment in Canada. The Roman Catholic clergy opposed the use of the ballot for the election of Trustees for their schools, and all who offered themselves for election on the ballot platform were defeated. Several priests were returned as Trustees, defeating men who were in favor of the ballot.

In several large cities within the last two or three years competition in the business of supplying illuminating gas has been completely suppressed by speculators who have obtained control of the several companies and have afterward issued large quantities of stock or bonds upon the combined properties.

ALBANY, Jan. 2. -- Another Cleveland Democrat has been punished. Philo H. Backus, a veteran of the late war, was discharged yesterday from position in the State Treasurer's office which he has held for eight years. He was the only remaining Democratic veteran in any of the constitutional or elective offices of the State.

Although the State Department might not be sorry to have the impression prevail that it is ready for a "vigorous policy" toward little Portugal, it is clear that the recent presence of Rear Admiral WALKER'S squadron of evolution at Lisbon had nothing whatever to do with international complications.

Lafayette Post, No. 140, G.A.R., which numbers among its members Chauncey M. Depew, Capt. Zalinski of dynamite-gun fame, and Col. Erhardt, had possession of the new Lenox Lyceum, at Madison-avenue and Fifty-ninth-street, last night. The big hall, for the first time in its history, had a military aspect by reason of elaborate decorations, the presence of 400 veterans in uniform, and representatives of the regular forces from Governor's Island and the Navy Yard.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- The Ways and Means Committee gave up its time to-day to wool growers and manufacturers. The committee room was crowded, all the members of the committee, except Messrs. Payne and Burrows -- who was reported laid up with the prevailing influenza -- being present.

The American ship General McClellan, which cleared for Hull, England, Thursday, lay off Tompkinsville all forenoon with a list to starboard that kept her lee scuppers almost to the water's edge. It was due evidently to careless stowage of her cargo, and the seamen of the adjoining vessels shook their heads ominously as they saw the condition of the ship.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 3. -- The anxiety which has been felt here for the safety of the steamer State of California was allayed this afternoon by the receipt of a telegram from First Officer Stevens, sent from Bowen's Landing, about seventy miles north of San Francisco, stating that the steamer had broken her shaft, but was otherwise uninjured and all on board were well.

The long dead-lock in the Board of Police Commissioners was broken yesterday by the election of CHARLES F. MACLEAN to the Presidency with the help of the vote of Commissioner VOORHIS. This seems to be the first fruit of Mr. VOORHIS'S break with the County Democracy, and may possibly be taken as an indication of his purpose to act henceforth in harmony with the Tammany members of the board.

While suggestions of various sorts have been made for the purpose of procuring the retirement of the numerous army officers who have been duly recommended for this purpose but have long been compelled to await vacancies in the limited lists, one of the most noticeable is contained in the bill introduced into the House by Mr. CUTCHEON.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- The statement was published to-day that Representative William D. Kelley of Pennsylvania was suffering from a cancer just below the rear of his jaw. While it is true that the Judge has a throat trouble of a cancerous nature it is not a new development, as he submitted to a surgical operation for the removal of this growth in 1883. There has been, however, a renewal of the trouble quite recently.

The annual report of the Department of Public Instruction of this State, of which A.S. Draper is Superintendent, will be transmitted to the Legislature Jan. 7. It shows that there are in the State 1,803,667 children of school age -- that is, between the ages of five and twenty-one years. Of this number 1,029,411 live in cities and the others in the towns.

The complaints that have been made about the shabbiness of the official and unofficial treatment of the delegates to the International Marine Conference at Washington seem to be well founded. They are the more significant because the neglect they point out is symptomatic of the attitude of politicians toward scientific men and scientific work.

The recent performance of the Yorktown on her passage to Europe continues to be discussed. The fact that the cruiser with triple-expansion engines managed to run 200 miles per day on 19 tons of coal, while operating at the same time the auxiliary engines, electric dynamos, and condensers is considered a most excellent showing. Still, steamboat men are not inclined to yield altogether their advocacy of the compound engine.

The evidence furnished in regard to the fate of Dr. PETERS varies from day to day. Accounts of his death alternate with letters showing that he is alive and pushing for the Nile. Assuming his safety, it may be said that although his is nominally an Emin search expedition, no one imagines that on ascertaining that the man is already found and safe at the coast the searchers will return thither themselves.

CITY OF MEXICO, Jan. 3, via Galveston. -- Salvador Malo, a wealthy contractor of this city, has taken over what is known as the Fenelon concession for a railroad from the city of Oaxaca down to some point on the Isthmus of Tehuantepec. He proposes to build from Tehuantepec to Oaxaca. He expects to get the right of way through Oaxaca very cheaply and estimates that he can build the line for $8,000 a mile.

Statistician H.R. Chambers of the New-York Mercantile Exchange has completed his tabulation of the receipts and exports of butter, cheese, and eggs, and of the average price of these articles during the past year. The receipts of butter were 2,044,488 packages, as against 1,697,909 packages during 1888. The exports last year were 398,882 packages, as against 140,997 packages in 1888.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Jan. 3.--An outrage which is the subject of controversy between the authorities of North and South Carolina is reported from Spartanburg County, in this State.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 3. -- The wife of Dr. Arthur S. Kniffin, a dentist at 206 Broad-street, in this city, was found dead in her bed from the effects of chloroform this morning. Miss Emma Pursell, her cousin, the only other individual in the house, was almost unconscious from the same cause. Miss Pursell says that she heard burglars and sprang out of bed, at what hour she is uncertain.

President Henry A. Oakley of the Howard Insurance Company said yesterday that he was pleased to see THE TIMES attack the packing-box nuisance. "The chapter on the subject in this morning's issue," said he, "was timely and in the right spirit. You will do the public a great service by getting some one in authority to supplement your efforts by removing this menace to property.

LANCASTER, Penn., Jan. 3. -- The Intelligencer of this city, formerly edited by the Hon. W.U. Henzel, Chairman of the Democratic State Committee, under the caption. "The Kind of a Senator They Send," tells a rather interesting story about Montana's new Republican Senator. The Intelligencer says:

The influenza has taken such a hold on members of the Police Department that Superintendent Murray yesterday informed the Police Commissioners that he was apprehensive of a serious crippling of his force. There are 357 reported ill from influenza. The Superintendent recommended that some of the men on "detailed duty" at courts and elsewhere be compelled for the time to do regular patrol work.

The eighth anniversary of the McAuley Cremorne Mission, 104 West Thirty-second street, will be celebrated Sunday afternoon and evening with appropriate ceremonies. The Revs. J.R. Payton, D.D., and S.H. Virgin will speak at the afternoon service, at which a choice musical programme will be rendered by eminent artists. In the evening the Revs. Henry Van Dyck, Frank Russell of the Evangelical Alliance, and Gen. Clinton B. Fisk will address the meeting.

ALBANY, Jan. 3. -- The session of the Legislature promises to begin in a very lively manner in the matter of rapid transit for New-York City. Two bills will be introduced on Tuesday, one from Gen. Husted, representing the Republicans, the other from Mayor Grant, which will be introduced by Senator Ives, representing the Democrats.

President John B. Day of the New-York League Club said yesterday that there was no truth in the statement that Connor had refused to sign a League contract. Mr. Day says that he never asked the big first baseman to affix his signature to a document. They talked over the matter in a casual way, and Connor never made use of the assertion credited to him.

WATERBURY, Conn., Jan. 3. -- The game season in Connecticut closed with last year. It is generally admitted among Nutmeg sportsmen that less game has been bagged during the past three months than during any hunting season of recent years. Partridges have been fairly plentiful, but woodcock and quail have been scarce.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3. -- Willis Gaylord, for years a heavy manipulator of railroad securities and organizer of railroad corporations committed suicide some time last night or this morning in a cell in the untried department of the county prison here. When the keepers went their rounds this morning, Gaylord's cold corpse was discovered in his cell, and Sheriff Krumbhaar, who had the custody of the prisoner, was at once notified.
BERLIN, Jan. 3. -- The international electric exhibition, to be held at Frankfort, has been postponed until the Spring of 1891.

Those members of the incoming Kings County Repubican General Committee who favor the re-election of Franklin Woodruff as Chairman met in caucus last night in Waverly Hall, Myrtle-avenue and Waverly-place, Brooklyn. They filled the hall, and on the only vote taken 181 names were recorded. The General Committee consists of 405 members, and Woodruff will therefore have to have 203 to elect.

During the past year certain active spirits among the artists of New-York have been hard at work on the promotion of a scheme which may bear important results to the fine arts in America. This is the establishment of a body to be called The American Fine Arts Society, in a new building devoted to art purposes only.

At a meeting of the Boxing and Wrestling Committee of the Amateur Athletic Union, held at the office of the Sporting Times yesterday, it was decided to give Patrick Cahill of the Scottish-American Athletic Club a trial. Cahill's entry to the recent competition of the union was rejected, and he was not allowed to compete.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 3. -- There were some sensational developments in the Senatorial contest to-day. Two local railroad ticket scalpers threw a bomb into the Brice camp. They presented themselves to Mr. Brice and demanded payment for old tickets issued to brokers by the Lake Erie and Western Railway Company before the reorganization.
LONDON, Jan. 3. -- The influenza is spreading among the London police force. It prevails especially among those officers who are doing duty in the eastern part of the metropolis.

One of the most largely attended weddings which has taken place in Brooklyn this season was that of Miss Helen Force, daughter of William Force, and Theodore L. Cuyler, Jr., son of the Rev. Dr. Theodore L. Cuyler, at the Lafayette-Avenue Presbyterian Church, Lafayette-avenue and South Oxford-street, on Thursday afternoon.

The statistics given by Mr. DRAPER, the Superintendent of Public Instruction in this State, are really startling. The number of children of school age in the State last year was 1,803,667. The number of children who attended the public schools during any part of the year was 1,033,813, while the average daily attendance was 637,489.

There is magic for most people in the idea of owning an orange grove, and thousands of Northern men would be willing to try orange growing who would no think twice about any other branch of agriculture. Perhaps it is on account of the beautiful appearance of the fruit, but more likely because of the wonderful profits that are supposed to lie hidden away at the roots of the orange trees.

A PLAY IS AN ANIMATED PICTURE. -- I remember that during the rehearsal of "The School for Scandal" I was impressed with the idea that the performance would not go well. It is always a difficult matter to bring a company of great artists together for a night and have them act in unison with each other; not from any ill-feeling, but from the fact that they are not accustomed to play together.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 4. -- Members were pretty well tired out with the Senatorial contest to-day, and after the work of organization of the two houses had been completed many went home to rest over Sunday. The situation here has settled down greatly during the past twenty-four hours. The withdrawal of Forbes and Belleville from the Speakership race, while voluntary on their part, was forced by the conditions which pervaded the contest.

UNITED STATES STEAMER YORKTOWN, HORTA, Fayal, Dec. 18.--It is already known under what pleasant auspices the squadron of evolution left its own coast, shunning the inclemencies of Winter, to seek in milder European waters a solution to various problems of naval tactics that in our day are largely matters of theory.

The Executive Committee of the World's Fair Committee on Legislation met yesterday afternoon in the offices of Mr. Chauncey M. Depew at the Grand Central Station. There were present Mr. Depew, Abram S. Hewitt, W.E.D. Stokes, Ambrose Snow, Elihu Root, W.C. Whitney, F.B. Thurber, A.B. Cornell, H.S. Mendelsohn, Joseph Liebmann, and James W. Tappin.

Chris Whelan came out from the theatre in a state of mental exaltation; the play he had been seeing was tragic and the hero heroic -- very heroic, very noble and self-sacrificing. In the auditorium the women had all been crying their complexions oft, and the men, who were just as much moved, had had the additional excitement of trying to look as if they were not.

D'Oyly Carte's new opera company, which is to present Gilbert and Sullivan's new comic opera, "The Gondoliers; or, The King of Barataria," at the New Park Theatre, at Thirty-fifth-street and Broadway, Tuesday evening, was among the arrivals by the Fulda of the North German Lloyds Line from Southampton yesterday.

Many a closet shelf is burdened just now with unframed engravings and etchings, the gifts of friends whose thoughtfulness or poverty left the framing to be done by the recipient. Those who have been thus favored may growl at the expense involved, but they have much to be thankful for in being permitted to use their own judgment in the selection of the frames.

NEWPORT, R.I., Jan. 4. -- Following the lead of New-York, Newport's Winter society people had a grand New Year's ball Thursday night. Ward McAllister was not present and did not arrange the event, but it was very successful nevertheless, thanks to the efforts of William R. Hunter. The ball was a subscription affair, and subscribers were numerous, so that it was successful financially as well as socially.

The Narragansett Club opened its house in West Fifty-fourth-street three years ago, and the anniversary of that event was celebrated last night with a big reception and two barrels of Narragansett punch. The reception attracted great attention from the politicians, especially of the Taminany kind. So did the punch.

Sven Martin Fraunken, a Swedish saddler, who for a long time had permitted his German wife to support him by doing laundry work, killed her and his three-year-old daughter some time between Jan. 1 and yesterday, and concluded his series of crimes by killing himself as the police were about to discover the bodies of his victims.

The New-York Athletic Club's second ladies' day for this season, observed yesterday in the clubhouse, 104 West Fifty-fith-street, was in every way as enjoyable and as well attended as the first one, held last month. About a thousand ladies, the relatives and friends of members of the club, visited the clubhouse in the afternoon and were entertained by an athletic programme similar to the ones carried out on previous ladies' days.
During the twenty-four hours ending at noon yesterday there were reported 234 deaths, of which 61 were from pneumonia and 11 from influenza complicated with pneumonia, bronchitis, and other diseases.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Jan. 4. -- The William N. Whitely Company, manufacturing harvesting machinery, and claiming to have the second largest shops in the world, Krupp's Gun Works, Essen, Germany, being considered the largest, passed into Receiver Gen. J. Warren Keifer's hands to-day. Mr. Whitely lost about $50,000 in the Harper wheat deal, Cincinnati, and never recovered financially from the loss.

M. Andral, a prominent Royalist politician, to whom had been confided the task of editing and publishing the memoirs of the Prince de Talleyrand, has just died in his sixty-first year. He had been for a long time a sufferer from sore throat, which frequently rendered him voiceless. This malady was lately complicated by inflammation of the stomach, to which M. Andral succumbed in Paris.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Jan. 4. -- The holders of stock in this city in the American Building and Loan Association of Minneapolis, Minn., were surprised this evening upon learning that Frank Fargo, traveling agent of the association, who took orders in this city last Fall, had been arrested on a charge of obtaining money on false pretenses.

Senator BUTLER'S measure for the appointment of JOHN HOLLINS MCBLAIR as a First Lieutenant in the army, with immediate transfer to the retired list, appears to be substantially the same measure as the one which was vetoed by President CLEVELAND nearly four years ago, the veto attracting more attention at the time from its being the first sent to Congress by Mr. CLEVELAND.

The reorganization of the Police Board, with Commissioner MacLean as President by virtue of the vote of Commissioner Voorhis, may load sooner or later to the deposition of John J. O'Brien from his four-thousand-dollar job as Chief of the Bureau of Elections. If it does, the downfall of the once powerful chieftain of the Eighth will be about complete.

Locomotive building has evidently not been quite as large in the year just ended as it was in the year preceding. The falling off in the product has not, however, been serious. In 1888 we reported 2,180 locomotives built by 17 firms. In 1889 we find 1,860 built by 16 firms. The product of the firms not reporting would probably not raise the output to 2,000.

ALBANY, Jan. 4. -- Gov. Hill finishes his annual message to the Legislature this evening. It contains about 20,000 words. Much space is devoted to ballot reform and to reapportionment of the legislative districts of the State.

ALBANY, Jan. 4. -- The figures given below are compiled from the reports of 28 of the principal railroads of this State for the year 1889. Of this number 18 show an increase in gross earnings over 1888 aggregating nearly $2,500,000, while 10 show an aggregate decrease of nearly $500,000. The net gain in earnings by these roads is therefore about $2,000,000.

The Mayor must be aware that it will be no easy matter to find a successor to Mr. COLEMAN who will see to it that the streets are not only cleaned but clean. State Engineer BOGART'S refusal to take the office both illustrates and increases the Mayor's embarrassment. Mr. BOGART, could he have accepted the office, would have attended to the business of cleaning the streets as it has never yet been attended to.

On the 30th day of June, 1889, at Rome, in the palace of the Quirinal, King Humbert signed the decree which ordained by Article I. "the definitive text of the Penal Code bearing the date of this day is approved, and will be put into force commencing Jan. 1, 1890."

FORTRESS MONROE, Va., Jan. 4. -- Superintendent S.C. Armstrong declares that the dispatches from Washington giving the impression that about half of Hampton's and Carlisle's returned Indians die at their homes are incorrect. He says: "Only six out of the hundreds who have come to this school since 1884 have died at home up to date. Of those who came previously sixty-six have died at home.

BERLIN, Jan. 4. -- The State Council is convened for Wednesday next. Prince Bismarck, though still suffering from a recurrence of his neuralgia, is certain to be present. The reassembling of the Reichstag for the last eventful days before dissolution and the reopening of the Landtag compels this general Ministerial meeting.

The late FREDERICK BALSIR CHATTERTON was an alert, aggressive, but not over-successful British theatrical manager. It was his aim, of course, to "give the public what it wants," but he seemed to lack the faculty, which many common and vulgar men possess, of exactly gauging the public taste.

THE JAVANESE DANCERS. -- They were neither noisy nor abandoned. The music was slow, regular, and savage only in timbre. It tortured the nerves in an insidious and unsuspected way only -- like certain forms of Chinese punishment, which at first seem wholly bearable -- and did not assail them violently, as did that of the Spanish and Egyptian virtuosi.

WHEN DID LEPROSY COME TO EUROPE? -- We have no certain knowledge as to the manner in which leprosy vas conveyed into Europe, but there is evidence to the effect that in the last century B.C. the disease had established itself in the Roman Empire. Its subsequent spread throughout Europe can easily be accounted for; wherever the Roman eagles went the germs of the disease would necessarily accompany them.

The announcement that Gen. HUSTED, the predestined ruler of the Assembly for the coming session of the Legislature, has a bill all ready to introduce on the opening day which will afford a solution of the rapid-transit problem for this city is at least a significant recognition of the pressing need and the urgent demand for action on the subject.

A meeting of the Board of Fire Underwriters is to be held next Wednesday to consider a plan for the regulation of fire insurance commissions. A committee of the board, appointed a long time since, has prepared a plan, which is now in the hands of the printer, but will be in the hands of members of the board long enough before the meeting for them to give it careful consideration.

GAMBLING AND BURGLING. -- Gambling and burgling always occupy a good deal of public attention during the course of a year. There is not a very obvious connection between the two, yet the subtle moralist may find an association. Both are pursuits of men who ought to be otherwise, and more profitably, engaged.

The people of this city will have very little patience with Tammany efforts to interfere with the Aqueduct Commission. Since it was constituted as at present they have had confidence in it, and there has been every evidence that it is faithfully guarding the city's interests and striving to have the aqueduct finished in the most perfect manner and as expeditiously as possible.

The Hamburg correspondent of the London Times gives the following full account of the collision between the steamers Leerdam and Gaw Quan Sia, and the sufferings of their wrecked crews and passengers:

NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 4. -- Interest in the reports sickness among the Yale students will be renewed by a circular which has been sent out to graduates of the college. It bears the signature of President Dwight, and may be taken as the Faculty's official statement of the sanitary condition of the university buildings and as an answer to the widely-circulated reports that typhoid fever was prevalent among the students.

CAMBRIDGE, Jan. 4. -- The regular recitations were resumed yesterday, and every student was obliged to register some time between 9 and 12 o'clock in the morning. Each class had a special room, and the person in charge of the room gave each student a blank to fill out with his name, class, and the name and hour of recitation of his first course. The attendance at recitations was, in consequence, very good.

In an editorial article in THE TIMES of Monday, Dec. 30, on the trouble in the American Board, the intimation is made that Mr. Covell (whose case gave rise to the editorial) made two statements of a contradictory nature, one in reply to Dr. Alden, which has been made public, and which seems to favor the hope of a future probation, the other in private to Dr. Storrs, in which this hope is ignored.
Mr. Barlow was deaf to any tempting book not American. The inspiration of his fancying was love for the New World lore, not books.

-- Daddy Jake the Runaway and Other Stories. By "Uncle Remus," Joel Chandler Harris. New-York: The Century Company. -- When you see on the cover not the American eagle but that much more useful bird the buzzard giving the tip of his wing to "Brer Rabbit," and the two dancing a regular breakdown and "Uncle Remus" on the top of the picture "a-larfin'," then you may "be sho'" some fun's up.

The dead body of a man supposed to be James S. Welty of Gettysburg, Penn., was found in the lake at the foot of Madison-street, Chicago, yesterday morning. Welty was a member of Corporal Skelly Post, G.A.R., at Gettysburg. On his person were found a pocketbook containing a bunch of keys, three knives, a Gettysburg First National Bank book, and 20 cents in money.

Chief among the topics calculated to command attention at the coming convention of the National Guard Association of the United States at Washington, in February, is the recommendation of the Adjutant General of the Army, Brig. Gen. J.C. Kelton, looking to the greater efficiency of the National Guard and suggesting a plan for closer relations between the volunteer and regular branches of the service.

The stakes of the New-York Jockey Club, which closed on Thursday last, have received a most liberal lot of entries. Although the entries from the Western cities are not all in as Yet, Secretary Kock announces the receipt of the following entries up to noon yesterday: In the two-year-old class the Galliard received 120 entries; the Larchmont, 96; the Anticipation, 91; the Van Nest, 90; the Debutante, 106, and the Casanova, 81.

A HOT DAY IN INDIA. -- My dwelling, the magistrate's house, was fallen into disrepair, and that year the landlord, on commencing the annual patching up, found the beams which supported the heavy flat roof completely tunneled out by white ants. This meant four months in the hands of the workmen, and the Judge kindly offered me quarters during the slow process of re-roofing.

The Duc de Broglie has met with a singular misadventure. It is well known that the former Ambassador of France at the Court of St. James's has occupied himself with historical studies since his political party has been out of power. His principal work during the past few years has been a series of historical and diplomatic studies in which he has undertaken to relate the struggles of Frederick II, and Maria Theresa.

In the death of Miss Julia Thomas a week ago last Friday, of pneumonia, at her home, 32 West Twenty-sixth-street, devotees of physical training for women lost an enthusiastic worker and well wisher. Miss Thomas caught a heavy cold while lecturing upon her work in Chicago recently, and finally returned home Dec. 10 suffering from bronchitis. Pneumonia followed and she died on Dec. 27.

A highly-intelligent reader of THE TIMES, who avails himself of intervals of relief from nursing the "grip" to reflect on the origin of the fascinating disease, wishes us to call on the scientists to make a series of observations on recent and actual atmospheric conditions, to determine whether our unfortunate planet may not, so to speak, have collided in space with this universal trouble.

LEXINGTON, Va., Jan. 4. -- The stockholders of the Pittsburg and Virginia Railroad to-night elected ex-Gov. Fitzhugh Lee President. This line will connect the ore beds or Virginia with the furnaces of Pittsburg. It will be built at once.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- Gen. and Mrs. H.G. Wright gave one of the most charming teas of the season this afternoon from 4 to 7 to announce the debut of their pretty young granddaughter, Miss Wooten of New-York. Mrs. Wright's gown was a handsome one of pansy-color satin, brocaded in light bouquets, with a fall of thread lace abont the throat and wrists.

Mr. David B. Hill is actively using the patronage and influence of the New-York Governorship to control the delegation from that State to the next Democratic National Convention. His success is very doubtful, for he will cease to be Governor in 1891. His term expires in that year, and if he attempts a third term he will almost certainly be defeated.

There has been no more grotesque exhibition before the Ways and Means Committee in the course of its investigation into the tariff than that recently made by the Hon. GALUSHA A. GROW of Pennsylvania, who once held the chair that Major MCKINLEY aspired to occupy in the present House.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- Sir Julian Panncefote, the British Minister, has received a petition from the Rev. T.M. Joiner of Holly Springs, N.C., for redress for injuries received by himself and wife at the hands of a mob at Holly Springs last month. He states that he is a British subject, and that he and his wife were giving religion and other instruction to the negroes at Holly Springs.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 4. -- The local membership of the Grand Army of the Republic has had a very material increase during the past week, yet the different posts comprising that important body of Federal veterans appear to be experiencing anything but a sensation of happiness.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 4. -- The local membership of the Grand Army of the Republic has had a very material increase during the past week, yet the different posts comprising that important body of Federal veterans appear to be experiencing anything but a sensation of happiness.

THE BEAUTIES OF ANDALUSIA. -- As regards her stature and mold, the Andalusian girl is almost invariably a petite brunette, and although not all are plump, and many are too stout, the majority have exquisitely-symmetrical tapering limbs, well-developed busts, (flat-chested women are almost unknown in Spain,) and the most dainty and refined hands and feet.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 11. -- The military character of the provisional Government is not concealed. On the contrary, all the decrees issued in the name of the chief of the executive power run as follows: "The Marshal Manoel Deodoro da Fonseca, chief of the provisional Government of the United States of Brazil, constituted by the army and navy in the name of the nation."

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 11. -- The military character of the provisional Government is not concealed. On the contrary, all the decrees issued in the name of the chief of the executive power run as follows: "The Marshal Manoel Deodoro da Fonseca, chief of the provisional Government of the United States of Brazil, constituted by the army and navy in the name of the nation."

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 5. -- Still the murder of Mrs. Myra Kniffin, the young wife of Dr. Arthur S. Kniffin, the Broad-street dentist, is baffling and perplexing mystery. If Emma Purcell, her cousin, killed her, she is a woman of nerve and with wonderful control of mind. If the husband was in any way concerned with her death, he, also, has made no sign.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Jan. 5. -- At a meeting of La Ligue des Patriotes, held this afternoon, the society arrayed itself strongly in opposition to a resolution adopted by the Catholic Centennial Congress recently held at Baltimore, Md. The congress said that "National societies, as such, have no place in the Catholic Church."

Our Washington dispatches this morning give the statement of a prominent Southern Republican member of the House as to the conduct of the Republicans of his stripe in the Speakership contest and since. It will be remembered that just before Congress met it was given out that a certain number of Southern Republicans had formed what in New-York political slang would be called a "combine" to control the Speakership.

MACON, Ga., Jan. 5. -- Willie Wallace, the notorious outlaw of Harris County, was rescued from jail in Hamilton at 3 o'clock this morning by a large number of masked men. The party rode into town on a full gallop, and hastily threw out guards on every road leading into Hamilton. Ten horsemen were posted around the residence of Sheriff Kimbrough.

One of the largest Trusts has boldly undertaken to test the temper of Congress and the people by arbitrarily raising the price of its product about 10 per cent. It is the National Lead Trust, composed of the manufacturers of white lead, that has thus challenged the Ways and Means Committee and the high-tariff men who profess to be opposed to combinations.

Paul Blouet, (Max O'Rell,) the clever Frenchman who lectures about civilized people and things and writes sketchy books like "Brother Jonathan," landed yesterday from the steamship Celtic after a tempestuous, tedious, and disagreeable voyage, and sought rest and seclusion in the Everett House. He is going to make a four months' lecture tour, beginning in Boston this evening.

It will be better all around if the discussion of the new Rapid-Transit bill starts from facts rather than from conjectures. It is not true that Mr. CLEVELAND drew the bill. Neither is it Mr. HUSTED'S bill, and it may first be introduced in the Senate, of which Mr. HUSTED does not happen to be a member. It is misleading, therefore, to call it the Husted bill.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5.--It is evident to any one who attends the meetings of the Ways and Means Committee that are being held from day to day to hear suggestions from manufacturers and consumers--very few of the latter--that the Chairman of the committee, and presumably the other Republican members, are resolved to take the Senate Tariff bill as the basis of the bill which is promised to be brought in about Feb. 1.

An explosion was heard on Liberty-street, just below the big Mutual Life Insurance Building, shortly after 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon and almost immediately dark smoke was seen to curl up out of the basement of 55, a five-story brick building. Engine Company No. 4 is housed opposite and there was no delay in the sending out of an alarm.

The people of Hempstead, L.I., do not like the idea of the Brooklyn Water Works invading their town. The officers of the town have written a communication to Mayor Chapin relative to the extension of the conduit from Rockville Centre to Massapequa. They speak plainly, and the courts may be appealed to. The town claims that the water streams are the town's alone, and in the communication sent Mayor Chapin The Town Board says:

The author's aim in this volume is to give valuable information to three classes -- teachers who are desirous of imparting additional zest to their lessons in geography; next, to pupils devoting their attention to a ceremonial education, and, last and not least, to merchants who are of sufficient intelligence to understand how study may be of benefit to their daily pursuits.
-- Reports from London say that nearly twenty thousand copies of Lord Tennyson's new volume, "Demeter and Other Poems," were sold there within a week of publication.

The post traders, past and present, are to meet to-day in Washington, to devise ways and raise means to oppose the policy of the War Department in regard to canteens. Less than a year has elapsed since this new policy was announced, yet canteens have already been established at a great many posts and are steadily increasing in number.

The Congregation Shaaray Tefila held its annual business meeting yesterday afternoon in the Trustees' room at 127 West Forty-fourth-street. The congregation's present minister, the Rev. F. De Sola Mendes, was re-elected for a term of five years.

The reader would be misled did he think Mr. Ballou's volume contained a record of original observations and impressions; or that it was a result of travel in unfrequented Alaskan regions. It is rather a treasury of facts already collected by others, accompanied by occasional comments on the familiar incidents of the well known tourists' route to Alaska and return.
" Heavenly Patterns of Life versus Working Models" was the theme on which the Rev. R. Heber Newton spoke to the All Souls" Church congregation yesterday morning.

ALBANY, Jan. 5. -- There is a grand opening for some independent and fearless member of the Assembly on the Republican side to win what politicians term "imperishable renown" by standing up in his place on the first day of the session and exposing the weaknesses in Gen. Husted's new set of rules, which were snapped through the Assembly of 1889 on the last day of the session.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5. -- There was a slight recovery from the holiday dullness at the Chicago playhouses the last week, and business was much better on the average than during the preceding week. The New Year's matinees were fairly good, and the evening performances that day were well attended. The attractions have been above the average, and there was one new production, "Captain Fracassa," given by the McCaull company at the Chicago Opera House.

It is a curious argument against any reform that it will not bring in the millennium, yet this is about what certain objections to ballot reform amount to that are extremely well received in some quarters. The type of foe to reform who is entirely devoted to the object sought, but who cannot approve any specific method because it will not fully, certainly, and forever accomplish that end, is a very old one.

The first of the lot of 15-inch guns contracted for with the Pneumatic Dynamite Company, for the defense of New-York and Boston, will be finished during the present month. The guns are being made at Cold Spring, N.Y., by the West Point Foundry. This firm has the contract for furnishing the tubes and valves. The gun carriages are completed.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 5. -- Last Friday there happened to be in Pittsburg, ostensibly on private business, a number of Republican leaders. Among the number were: Secretary of the Commonwealth Charles W. Stone of Warren and Thomas W. Phillips of Newcastle, ex-State Senator J.W. Lee of Franklin and ex-State Senator Lewis Emery, Jr., of Bradford.

There was a large attendance yesterday morning at the South Third-Street Presbyterian Church, in Brooklyn, on the occasion of the celebration of the fortieth anniversary of the installation of the pastor, the Rev. Dr. John D. Wells. Over the pulpit hung a large floral star. The service was conducted by the pastor. Dr. Wells was assisted by the Rev. M. Stimpson.

LONDON, Jan. 6. -- The Times's Lisbon correspondent says that a Brazilian paper reports that the Government at Rio Janeiro intends to expel the Russian Envoy in consequence of Russia's refusal to recognize the republic.

Although the road, especially the Seventh-avenue portion of it, was in very fair condition yesterday, being just soft enough for speeding and stopping just short of unpleasant muddiness, a very small crowd came out to take advantage of it. The sloppy state of the Park drives and the threatening rain clouds were mainly responsible for the many stay-at-homes, and throngs of pedestrians were cheated out of the usual Sunday driving panorama.

WATKINS, N.Y., Jan. 5. -- Lawsuits and politics are becoming strangely mixed in Schuyler. Some time ago Irving W. Cole, a brother of ex-Speaker Cole, and Waldo F. Bishop, a prominent young Democratic lawyer here and ex-District Attorney of the county, instituted proceedings in the Surrogate's Court to compel the accounting of ex-County Judge Oliver P. Hurd as executor of the estate of James H. Daily, late of the town of Hector.

The expectation that our war vessels now in West Indian waters will take part in the revenue difficulties on the San Blas coast is probably doomed to disappointment. The action of the North Atlantic squadron with regard to Colombia is likely to be precisely what during the last three or four years it has been with regard to Canada.

Of the 207 deaths in New-York City recorded during the twenty-four hours ending at noon yesterday, three were returned as due to influenza. This was a decided falling off from the record of the grip's victims on the previous day, when 11 deaths from the epidemic were reported.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 5. -- The Royal Society of Northern Antiquaries of Copenhagen, through its Secretary, Sophus Miller, has deeded that ancient monument, Dighton Writing Rock, near Taunton, Mass., on the east side of the Taunton River, in the town of Berkley, to the Old Colony Historical Society of Taunton. The deed has been formally recorded, and American savants and historians will look out for this world wonder, this tablet of fact, centuries hereafter.

The Society of Friends held an interesting and well-attended meeting at the meeting house, Fifteenth-street and Rutherfurd-place, at 11 o'clock yesterday morning. The principal speakers were Serena Minard from Canada, John J. Cornell of Rochester, and Margaretta Walton of Pennsylvania. Mr. Cornell's address was on "What Shall I Do to be Saved?" and was listened to with particular interest.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5. -- The meeting of the Knights of Malta of the Chapter General of New-York and the Grand Commandery of the Ancient and Illustrious Knights of Malta in this city, which convened at Broad and Vine streets last evening, remained in session until early this morning, and, had not the police been called in, the meeting most probably would have resulted in a free fight.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 13. -- There are many curious customs observed by the Brazilians. Funerals are notable in that for a young unmarried lady, coffin, hearse, and the livery of the driver must be bright scarlet, the four white horses drawing the hearse must be covered with scarlet nets, and scarlet plumes must deck the horses' heads.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 5. -- Last night, at 6 o'clock, the names of Baron d'Este, Baroness d'Este, and Miss de Noue appeared on the St. James Hotel register. The Baron had come to Baltimore for the purpose of being married here, but he changed his mind and slipped over to Philadelphia yesterday morning, was married by Archbishop Ryan and was back in Baltimore that night.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- Senator Frye will introduce, Monday, a bill "to promote the postal and commercial interests of tile United States." An abstract is as follows:

The bills to provide rapid transit for New-York City which the dispatches have announced were to be introduced in the Legislature this week have been the subject of much speculation. It can be stated, however, on the authority of men who make it a business to keep themselves informed on the subject, that the projects are yet in a very early stage.
ALBANY, Jan. 5. -- Senator Saxton arrived in town late last night, and this afternoon afforded THE TIMES'S correspondent an interview, and also a synopsis of the changes in his Ballot Reform bill.

The unknown young man who shot himself through the right temple in front of 13 East Second-street on Saturday night, was operated on by Dr. William F. Pluhrer at Bellevue Hospital yesterday afternoon. The bullet had passed entirely through the brain and had broken the skull on the left side of the head, but had not passed through the scalp. It was taken out on that side.

Senator FRYE will to-day introduce two bills to give subsidies and bounties to American ships. One of them gives $6 and $4 per mile for each outward voyage to two classes of vessels respectively. The first class are to be iron or steel steam vessels of at least 4,000 tons, and a minimum speed of eighteen knots; the second of 2,000 tons, and a minimum speed of fourteen knots.

It was almost like an equine resurrection at Clifton yesterday to see "the iron horse," old Barnum, carrying racing colors to victory once more. This magnificent old gelding has now entered upon his eleventh year, and to all appearances he is about as good now as he was a half dozen years ago, in spite of the fact that he has been subject to more abuse and maltreatment than any horse living.

The dispute about the management of the Ward's Island Hospital seems to have narrowed to a question of the power and privileges of the Homeopathic Medical Society which insists that the staff of the hospital shall be manned from its own members. There is nothing in the law or in usage conferring this privilege upon the society.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- The Supreme Court of the United States to-day rendered an opinion in the important customs case of William H. Robertson, Collector of the Port of New-York, plaintiff in error, against Charles A. Edelhoff and Emil Rinke, brought here on appeal from the decision of the United States Circuit Court for the Southern District of New-York in favor of the importers.

A course of lectures was begun at Cooper Union last night that is calculated to stimulate greatly the general interest in the work of archaeological exploration, in Egypt particularly, and in the monumental remains of the ancient civilizations of the world in general. It was the first of a series of six illustrated free lectures by Miss Amelia B. Edwards, Honorary Secretary of the Egyptian exploration fund.

There was a reception, with singing, dancing, and accordion playing at Mrs. Cunningham's, 206 Eighth-avenue, Sunday night, and the liveliest of the party were her daughter Lizzie and Mary Fallon, daughter of a truckman of 749 Sixth-avenue, who was visiting her. The girls slept together, and after they retired romped in such a gay fashion as to call for rebuke from Lizzie's mother.

There is a brand-new Board of Aldermen in town. It came to life at 12:10 P.M. yesterday and looks as though it might last the year out with ordinary good luck. It is a little bit better looking than last year's, but it can't count much on that. The old board met at 10 o'clock yesterday morning for the express purpose of going out of business.

The new commission to try cases of condemnation of the easements to property along the lines of the elevated railroad in this city convened yesterday for the hearing of the cases that ex-Judge Leo C. Dessar had consented to have them pass upon, Commissioners Armstrong and Loew, who have had long experience in this kind of work, dropped nonchalantly into their accustomed places and assumed expectant attitudes.

CITY OF MEXICO, Dec. 29. -- As it had been announced that Mr. Windom was preparing a a project favorable to the white metal -- so favorable that the market had become distinctly animated during the past two months -- the financial world was expecting something more practical, and above all, more suitable for the definitive benefit of the silver production.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- Silk and sugar were the two topics considered by the Ways and Means Committee at to-days hearing on tariff questions, and before the sitting was over the Republican majority of the committee learned that there was a great deal of opposition in their own party to the giving of a direct bounty to sugar growers.
