A pretty and fashionable wedding was that at high noon yesterday in the Church of the Heavenly Rest of Miss Edith Godfrey, daughter of Charles H. Godfrey, and Charles Livingston Hyde. The handsome Christmas decorations of the church were still in place, and their dark-green tints formed a perfect background for the banks and clusters of white roses and chrysanthemums that made up the wedding decorations.

Few people went to business in Wall-street yesterday without expecting further trouble in the money market. In banking circles, at the close of last week, indeed, it was rather freely predicted that abnormal tightness must continue for some time to come, new year disbursements, it was contended, being hardly likely to exert any beneficial effects before the middle of this month.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 6. -- Mr. McMahon injected additional energy into his Senatorial canvass to-day. A number of gentlemen well known to local politics arrived, and are devoting their energies to the McMahon interest. There is a slight smell of the old Vallandigham fight in their talk. They still feel that they have a grievance, and have opened the urn in which the memory of the old chief was embalmed.

The multiplication of new investment companies and limited liability corporations in London during the past year has led to some expression of anxiety by financial authorities in England as to the outcome of this notable movement of capital. But we do not understand that any alarm has been excited on account of the character of recent investments of English capital in American industries.

Charles H. Applegate, a handsome, well-preserved, and well-dressed man with the appearance of a gentleman, occupied a cell at Police Headquarters last night. He had been arrested at his well-appointed home, 153 West One Hundred and Twenty-sixth-street, for swindling many people by means of forged checks, in which he had done a land office business for over a year.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Jan. 6. -- The Tuscarora Reservation is all excitement over the verdict of the Coroner's jury in the case of Alexander Williams, the Tuscarora Indian who it was supposed was murdered by his wife and whose dead body was found in his house Christmas morning. The jury say that he came to his death by poison administered by his own hand.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Jan. 6. -- Capt. D.C. Ballentine, who first mentioned the Hon. John W. Bookwalter's name in connection with the Senatorship, received a letter from the cosmopolitan to-day, in which he withdraws from the contest. He virtually opposes the election of a rich man to the Senate, and thus takes a stand in favor of the Hon. John McMahon of Dayton, the poor man candidate.

Quietly and secretly, without any trumpet blaring whatever, a movement was undertaken yesterday which its projectors believe will more successfully boom New-York as the place for the World's Fair in 1892 than anything that has hitherto been done in this direction.
The following bill, drawn by John Jay Knox, President of the National Bank of the Republic, is to be submitted to Congress:

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 6. -- A railroad war between the Housatonic and Consolidated lines was begun yesterday over certain disputed territory at a point a short distance south of the station here. The land is owned by the Housatonic company, and over it the main tracks of the Consolidated Railroad run. The Consolidated pays a certain annual rental for the right of way.

A body of sixty ladies and gentlemen was brought forward at the Church of the Paternity last night by Mr. George F. Bristow in a performance of "The Messiah." The representation of Handel's oratorio on his occasion was significant as occurring on Twelfth Night, or "Little Christmas," and chiefly notable for the excellent work of the chorus.

GENTLEMEN: It is the Mayor's duty "to communicate to the Board of Aldermen at their first meeting in the month of January each year, and oftener if he shall deem it expedient, a general statement of the condition of the city in relation to its government, finances, and improvements, with such recommendations as he may deem proper."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- The President sent to-day the following nominations to the Senate:

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 6. -- Another reduction in the through rates to New-England and Canadian points was announced by the Burlington Road this afternoon, to take effect Jan. 9. The rates are the same as those quoted by the Soo line, which are to become effective to-morrow, on the basis of $22 60 first class and $20 second class to Boston.

The Trustees of Columbia College met yesterday. The date of the inaugural ceremonies for the installation of President-elect Seth Low was changed from Tuesday evening, Feb. 4, to Monday morning, Feb. 3, on account of the conflict with the Centennial exercises of the United States Supreme Court on Feb. 4.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Jan. 6. -- By the wrecking of a work train on the Fail Brook Road near Wellsborough, Penn., last night, three men were killed and sixteen others injured. The accident was caused by the collapse of a bridge while the train was passing over, and the cars and men and tools were precipitated into the creek. The engine and tender passed over safely, became detached from the cars, and remained on the track.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6. -- Simon Deimel applied in the Circuit Court to-day for a receiver for the furniture house of R. Deimel Brothers, the most extensive manufacturers of parlor furniture in Chicago, if not in the country. The business has been conducted by Rudolph, Joseph, and Simon Deimel, the latter having charge of the New-York branch. Frank A. Helmer was appointed receiver in bonds of $100,000.

The annual meeting of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club will be held in the clubhouse, 7 East Thirty-second-street, next Saturday evening at 8:30. The most interesting business to be transacted will be the consideration of the proposition to classify yachts for racing according to their racing lengths. The members will vote on this subject for the first time.

HARTFORD, Jan. 6. -- While the Legislature in this State has not furnished a fruitful field for parliamentary precedents and rulings, the new compilation which is to be published this year not containing more than forty in all, its history as a parliamentary body is not lacking in interest.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 6. -- An important decision, the effect of which will be to close one of the refineries of the Sugar Trust, was rendered to-day by Judge Wallace of the Superior Court. It was in the case of The People against the American Sugar Refinery Company. The findings were as follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- In its third annual report, submitted to Congress to-day, the Inter-State Commerce Commission make recommendations looking to the amendment of the law in the following particulars:

A decision was rendered by the Supreme Court of the United States yesterday in a case that ought to make the tariff tinkers of the country blush, if their hardened cheeks have not become incapable of that demonstration of emotion. It is what is known as the "Ribbon case," or the "Edelhoff case," and arose under the Tariff act of 1883.

The first and possibly the most radical change that is proposed by Gen. Husted's new rules for the Assembly relates to the very initial stage of all legislation -- the introduction of bills. I have seen by the dispatches that the General proposes to modify them, but not knowing whether the report is true or whether it is one of his rases, I will adhere to my original intention to say something on this point.

I have the honor herewith to submit a statement, prepared by the Controller, of the financial condition of the city, pursuant to the provisions of law, which require such statement to be made each year by the Mayor to the Common Council:

Col. Robert W. Leonard was unanimously elected Major of the Twelfth Regiment, N.G.S.N.Y., last evening. Major Leonard is a well-known stock broker in this city. He enlisted in Company B, Seventh Regiment, May 7, 1860, went to the war, returned, and went out again as Adjutant of the One Hundred and Sixty Second New-York Volunteers.
The mail advices from Greytown by the steamship Hondo, which arrived yesterday, contain satisfactory intelligence of the progress of the Nicaragua Canal work.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 6. -- The American Baseball Association held a session here to-day. The delegates in attendance were Chris Von Der Ahe of St. Louis Zach Phelps and L.C. Parsons of Louisville, President S.H. Pennypacker, Treasurer W.H. Whittaker and Manager Sharsig of the Athletics of Philadelphia, Manager Charles H. Morton of Toledo, Vice President Ralph Lazarus and Manager Buckenberger and George K. Frazer, one of the prospective owners of the Syracuse Club.

BURLINGTON, Iowa, Jan. 6. -- The most startling changes of weather that have ever been known in this locality have occurred within the past week. New Year's Day the river here was perfectly clear of ice. Inside of the next twenty-four hours it was blocked tight and could have been crossed on foot. Twenty-four hours later not a vestige of ice remained in the river, and all day Sunday pedestrians tramped about with coats off.

The managers of the Hudson County Jockey Club have decided that on and after to-day the price of admission to the track will be fixed at S1 for each person. The entries and weights for to-day's races are as follows:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 7. -- This has been a busy day with aspirants for the Senatorship and their positive friends. The Cincinnati Enquirer force yesterday interviewed every Democratic member of the Legislature and placed him as an adherent of one or the other respective candidates or in the non-committal column. Brice had 21 adherents, McMahon 8, Charley Baker of Cincinnati 7, and Thomas 6.

MORGANTOWN, West Va., Jan. 7. -- Physicians sent by the county into the mountain district along Cheat River, in which diphtheria was reported to be epidemic, tell horrible stories of suffering. The people are now suffering from epidemics of two diseases, diphtheria and the more dreaded "black tongue." The latter has broken out in the last two weeks, and about thirty deaths have occurred, the patients presenting a terrible experience.

Almost the only important subject dealt with by the Governor in his annual message is what he is pleased to call "electoral reform." He sets out with an effort to relieve himself from the responsibility of the failure to provide for a State census, or "enumeration of inhabitants," in 1885, and to secure a reapportionment based thereon, but in this he is not successful.

Both branches of the Legislature were organized yesterday in strict accordance with the caucus programmes, and both adjourned to next Monday after hearing the Governor's message and going through a few preliminaries. In the Assembly the amended rules were adopted without opposition, but no bills were introduced. In the Senate, however, a beginning was made in the introduction of bills and some important measures were submitted.

There is war among the Republicans of the Twenty-first Assembly District. The factional disturbances that have been a long time brewing came to a head last night in a general engagement, in which the young Republicans achieved a signal victory over the Plummer-Englehart machine. But it was not a decisive victory.

LOUISVILLE, Jan. 7. -- Municipal elections in this city are held under what is known as the Wallace law, which was passed by the Legislature two years ago, and which is fashioned after the Australian system. The law provides than the vote shall be by secret ballot, and the clerk of election in each precinct is provided with a stub book of ballots containing the names of all candidates for the various offices.

At the annual meeting of the New-York Historical Society last evening in the society's hall, corner of Second-avenue and Eleventh-street, President John A. King announced the gratifying fact that the building fund now amounted to the very respectable figure of $256,343 35, and that for months the Executive Committee had been actively engaged in the search for a suitable site for the new building.

The third annual report to Congress of the Inter-State Commerce Commission, now composed of Thomas M. Cooley, William R. Morrison, Augustus Schoonmaker, Walter L. Bragg, and Wheelook G. Veazey, forms a pamphlet of 109 printed pages.

It strikes us that Commissioner GILROY misconstrues his official relation to the work of the Aqueduct Board in regard to surveys for reservoirs. In his capacity as Commissioner of Public Works he has nothing to do with judging or deciding what reservoirs are needed or when they shall be constructed. That is a matter that rests with the Aqueduct Commission, but it is made dependent upon him for the necessary surveys.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- Tho President sent the :[ollow:n nominations to the Senate tcday:
BERLIN, Jan. 7. -- The Dowager Empress Augusta, widow of the Emperor William I. of Germany, died at 4:20 o'clock this afternoon. The cause was pneumonia, following an attack of influenza.

Mr. Caldwell, who has acted as starter since the beginning of the Winter racing at Guttenberg, was ill yesterday, suffering from the prevailing epidemic. So J.C. Carr of the Executive Committee handled the starter's flag, and gave pretty general satisfaction. Raising the price of admission to the track had no perceptible effect on the crowd in attendance, for the betting ring was packed uncomfortably, and the bookmakers has all they could attend to.

Interest in the World's Fair was reawakened yesterday. Everybody seems to realize that the crisis is at hand. New-York's fate will be practically decided next Saturday, when the arguments in its favor will be made before the special committee of the Senate at Washington. The nearness of the hearing would seem to allow but very little in the way of preparation. But in the last twenty-four hours a prodigious amount of work has been done.

Doubtless the report of the special committee of the Senate to that body will be decisive of the question when and where the fair to commemorate the discovery of America shall be held. We have already sot forth the reasons why it is impossible that any fair which has not the positive sanction and the active encouragement of the Government can deserve to be called international, or can give any promise of being successful.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 7. -- The Middlesex County Grand Jury this afternoon brought into court indictments against three of the men concerned in the election frauds in the Sixth Ward of this city. Two of the men indicted are Democrats -- Joseph Hayter, a Coronor, Justice of the Peace, and official court interpreter, and Thomas Tenneson, who was the judge of election at the poll where the frauds occurred.

MADISON, Wis., Jan. 7. -- By the Cooper election law all the officers whose duty it is to designate polling places are compelled to provide shelves or compartments, which are furnished with such supplies or conveniences as enable the voter to prepare his ballot screened from all observers. A guard rail or partition is so constructed that only persons within its limits can approach within five feet of either ballot boxes or shelves or compartments.

The three-masted schooner Dame, now in this port, is the vessel which for fourteen months lay high and dry below Sandy Hook point. The Dame put to sea some three years ago in the face of a heavy blow. The wind at the time permitted of an offing being made, but the schooner was hardly clear of the Scotland Lightship when a les shore was made off the Jersey coast.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7.--The first State dinner of the season was given to-night by the President and Mrs. Harrison in honor of the Cabinet.

The persons who gave to DE LESSEPS the vast sums that have been spent on the route of the projected Panama Canal and in connection with that undertaking very naturally would like to know how much the assets of the bankrupt company on the isthmus are worth and whether it will be possible to complete the unfinished ditch.

NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 7. -- With the opening of the Winter term at Yale University to-day Osborn Hall, the splendid new recitation building, was dedicated. The meeting was held in the large hall of the building at 9:30 o'clock. The principal feature of the opening was an address by President Dwight, who paid a high tribute to the generosity of the donor, Mrs. Miriam A. Osborn of New-York.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 7. -- Post Commander Jacob Gray, in mustering in a colored post of the Grand Army of the Republic, is supposed to have done so in retaliation for the action taken by the three white posts here in disapproving his action in taking part in the Davis obsequies. The first resignation that resulted was that of Capt. H.C. Bartlett of his commission as Adjutant General of the department.

Aaron Claflin, one of the oldest and most successful wholesale dealers in the boot and shoe trade in this city, died early yesterday morning, after a short illness, at his residence, 143 Montague-street, Brooklyn. He was born in Milford, Mass., Feb. 20, 1807, his father being John Claflin, a farmer and tradesman of that town.

Commissioner Gilroy contributed a letter yesterday to the small controversy in which he has become involved with the Aqueduct Commissioners, and in it he gives his reasons for not having completed the surveys, plans, and specifications for the reservoirs, as to which he was interrogated by the board last Saturday. Mr. Gilroy says:

CITY OF MEXICO, Dec. 29. -- Mexican shipowners have avoided the consequences of the action of the United States Treasury in enforcing the aw compelling shippers in Mexican vessels to pay a discriminating duty of 10 per cent. on imports into the United States ports by changing the nationality of their vessels nominally, and are now making use of the Colombian and other flags.

ALBANY, Jan. 7. -- The annual report of the retiring State Treasurer, L.J. Fitzgerald, was transmitted to the Legislature to-day by his successor in office, Elliot Danforth. The condition of the Treasury on the morning of Jan. 1 is thus set forth:

Mr. Charles F. MacLean, President of the Police Board, attended a meeting of the Health Board yesterday. President Wilson was there, but is yet suffering from influenza and was muffled up to the ears. Sanitary Inspector Tracy put in a paper on the prevailing epidemic. He says in substance that the sudden increase in mortality is due apparently to influenza, as the deaths occur in every part of the city.

By the decision of Judge WALLACE of California in the case of The People vs. The American Sugar Refinery Company it is again affirmed that the Sugar Trust is an unlawful organization, and the defendant corporation is deprived of its charter for having entered that Trust. The case closely resembles that in which the Sugar Trust, or one of its corporations, has been made a defendant in this State.

In yesterday's market there was evidence again that the squeeze in money is over. Funds loaned in abundance at 5 per cent., many transactions were at 4 per cent., and the highest rate of the day was 6 per cent.

ALBANY, Jan. 7. -- The one hundred and thirteenth session of the Legislature began to-day, in the House under smooth and auspicious circumstances, in the Senate with the disturbance that inevitably occurs whenever Lieut. Gov. Jones attempts to address that body. Gen. James W. Husted of Peekskill was elected Speaker of the Assembly for the sixth time, and Charles A. Chickering of Copenhagen, Lewis County, was re-elected clerk.

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 7. -- Gen. Thomas Ewing of New-York City was the central figure at the annual meeting of the Kansas State Bar Association held in this city to-night. Gen. Ewing was the first Chief Justice of the Kansas Supreme Court, and to-night he met for the first time in nearly thirty years his former associates on the bench -- Ex-Justice L.D. Bailey and S.A. Kingman, both of whom are still residents of Kansas.

Bernard Brady, a contractor, secured a verdict in the Superior Court yesterday against the city for $42,792. In 1883 and 1884 Brady paved Ninety-fifth-street, between Tenth-avenue and Riverside Drive. On the measurements of City Surveyor Herman K. Viele he collected $79,676 96 from the city. Afterward Brady claimed that the returns of the measurements were incorrect, and he brought suit against the city for $99,635 81.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- A good deal of indifference to the amount of taxes assessed, and a wide difference of opinion as to the merits of the internal revenue system, were the chief features of the tobacco men's remarks before the Ways and Means Committee to-day. Some cigar manufacturers were emphatic in demanding the abolishment or the whole system, while others were equally vehement in asserting that such a course would ruin their business.

HARTFORD, Jan. 7. -- The Connecticut secret ballot law does not specifically designate the style of booth to be used at elections, the selection being left to the Selectmen of each town. The statute simply provides that the rooms or booths to be used by the electors shall be supplied with necessary conveniences for arranging ballots and placing them in envelopes; also that they may contain ballots for the use of the electors.
BERLIN, Jan. 7. -- An official report states that 600 officers and soldiers at Ulm, 450 at Ludwigsburg, 130 at Stuttgart, and 115 at Hellbrunn are suffering from influenza.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7. -- The Northwestern passenger rate war is spreading. The west-bound reduction went into effect to-day, making the rate from Chicago to St. Paul $9 first-class and $7 second-class by all lines. Furthermore the Chicago and Northwestern, in connection with the Union Pacific, reduced its rates to Montana and Northern Pacific coast points, by way of Omaha, to meet the competition by way of St. Paul.

You begin to-day a new period of law making, confronted with responsibilities inherited from previous Legislatures and facing public questions well deserving your careful consideration and your intelligent disposition. Some of these I desire to resent to your attention, bespeaking for them that faithful and impartial deliberation which a proper sense of official responsibility demands, and hoping that their discussion may have some influence in securing your wise action.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 7.--The authorities planned arrest and hoped for a confession in the Kniffin murder case to-day. Courage was lacking to make the arrest. The confession failed to appear. Lest something might be done to be regretted it was thought best to risk the dangers of delay in a case that seems to need nothing so much as firm and decisive action.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7. -- Walter George Smith, a rising young laywer of this city, a son of the late Thomas Kilby Smith, and Miss Elizabeth J. Drexel, eldest of the three daughters of the late Francis A. Drexel, were married this morning in the little Roman Catholic Church of St. Dominick at Holmesburg, a suburb of this city.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 8. -- Several years ago Andrew Carnegie presented the city of Allegheny with a fres library. The building, a handsome granite structure, which has cost $250,000, is now completed and ready for the formal opening. It contains a library, art gallery, and music hall. It was erected under the direction of a citizens' committee, of which James B. Scott is Chairman.

An application on behalf of the Rev. Edward Kenny, rector of the Church of the Holy Nativity, was made yesterday by Hoffman Miller to Justice O'Brien in Supreme Court Chambers for a mandamus to compel Benjamin N. Winans, Henry W. Plant, and other Vestrymen of the church to attend the meetings of the board. The affidavits presented on both sides disclose a serious disagreement and wide breach between the members of the church.

Tammany's Committee of Five, appointed to reorganize the Third,Twelfth, and Fifteenth Districts, met at the wigwam last night and took up the question of the Twelfth. Somehow or other the braves from this district did not take kindly to the idea of being investigated or reorganized. The General Committee of the district has a number of little contentions in it.

The displacement of Mr. JOHN H. OBERLY by Gen. T.J. MORGAN as Commissioner of Indian Affairs has already created some trouble for Mr. HARRISON'S Administration and is likely to create more. While Mr. OBERLY was exceptionally suited to that office, Gen. MORGAN was also spoken of very highly, and since his appointment has secured the warm approval of many of those who are interested in Indian education and improvement.

FLEMINGSBURG, Ky., Jan. 8. -- The Methodist, Baptist, and Presbyterian churches of this place decided to observe the week of prayer in a series of union meetings. The third meeting of the series was held at the Methodist church Monday night. A very large congregation was present, and after short addresses by the pastors, a prayer meeting was held.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 8. -- The memory of Gen. Andrew Jackson, hero of New-Orleans, was appropriately honored by the citizens of Nashville to-day. The day was bright and warm, and the morning trains brought hundreds of visitors from different cities and towns. Public and private buildings were tastefully decorated with flags and bunting, and many residences along the line of march of the procession were decked with the national colors.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 8. -- The Rev. Sam Jones the famous Georgia revivalist, began an engagement in this city Sunday and has had fair attendance at his meetings. To-night he created a real sensation by the prediction of an awful disaster, and as he spoke there was a disagreeable stillness, terrible and unnatural in so large an assembly.

MONTREAL, Jan. 8. -- A few days since it was announced here than W. Ellis Co., general storekeepers or Smith's Falls and Carleton Place, Ont., had disappeared, and as a result there was much grief among certain Montreal houses who were let in very heavily. "Ellis Co." arrived in Canada between eighteen months and two years ago, and opened up general stores at Smith's Falls and Carleton Place.

Although some enormous sums have been asked of the Fifty-first Congress for coast defense, one bill alone calling for more than $126,000,000, yet the work immediately required is comparatively limited, as the report of the Board of Ordnance and Fortication will show. Contracts were long ago given out for the forgings of 8-inch, 10-inch, and 12-inch guns, and these will come along about as fast as they can be finished at the Watervliet gun factory.

ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- 5:32 P. M. I had hoped up to this hour to be able to attend the annual banquet of the Business Men's Democratic Association, but unexpected engagements prevented me from leaving Albany. Please present my regrets to the members of the committee. I trust the entertainment will be a pleasant one.

HARTFORD, Jan. 8. -- Chief Justice Charles B. Andrews of the Supreme Court in this State has instituted an important reform in that body in regard to the announcement of decisions. For years the custom in the Supreme Court has been to announce the decision as soon as it is reached, and assign the preparation of the opinion to one of the Judges, which might be delayed for months.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- The President sent the following nominations to the Senate to-day:

The hearing given to the representatives of St. Louis by the special committee of the Senate has had the effect of putting the claims of that city to the centennial before the country in a clear and striking light. The representatives of St. Louis made a statement of their case which was all the stronger for being moderate and guarded.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal. Jan. 8. -- The latest news from the communistic colony at Topolobampo, in Sinaloa, Mexico, is brought by C.C. Remley, who joined a party from Kansas City last year. He was induced to join the colony by representations of the ideal life which was to be enjoyed at Topolobampo. Remley took his family and supplies sufficient for a two years' stay.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Jan. 8. -- Over sixty towns in Connecticut have a population smaller than the number of lunatics confined in the State Hospital for the Insane in this town. A census of this thriving colony of insanity's victims shows a population of over 1,300, exclusive of about 200 attendants. This aggregation of lunatics represents every race, color, and previous condition of mental solidity.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- The first Cabinet receptions of the season were held this afternoon, and though invitations were out for a number of teas, attention was altogether monopolized by official calls. The present Administration is somewhat remarkable for the fact that every member of the Cabinet is not only married, but the ladies of the family are all in Washington and keep open house.

It is mortifying to see a statesman who has held the position and commanded the respect which Senator EDMUNDS formerly enjoyed stooping to such a flippant and trifling treatment of the Dudley scandal as the Vermont Senator indulged in when he undertook to reply to Mr. VOORHEES yesterday. It was not only flippant and trifling, but it was clearly unfair and insincere, and was worthy of a cheap political trickster.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 8. -- The Senatorial contest has been "hot and furious" all day. At an early hour this morning the opposition determined to make another effort to combine. Earnest consultations ensued. More than a dozen names were canvassed, but it was found impossible for either of the prominent candidates to transfer his following.

BOSTON, Jan. 8. -- The memory of the sturdy old President and General, Andrew Jackson, and that of his great exploit in the battle of New-Orleans, was kept green by the Democratic State Committee around the festive board at the Tremont House this afternoon. About one hundred Jacksonians gathered at the tables, among whom were many old war horses.

Next the Secretary read the letters and telegrams of regret. Ex-President Cleveland's letter was read first, and was received with great enthusiasm, three cheers being given, and the entire company standing. The letters from the Democratic Governors who were unable to be present were also greeted with applause.

There were in circulation some interesting comparisons of the business of the Northern Pacific Railroad Company between 1886 and 1889, by which it appeared that the gross receipts of the road had risen from $11,000,000 to $19,000,000, or more than 70 per cent. The number of passengers carried in 1889 exceeded that of 1886 by nearly 1,000,000, and the tons of freight carried one mile rose in the same time from 500,000,000 to 900,000,000.

There was a considerable increase in the number of deaths reported yesterday as compared with the list of the day before. During the twenty-four hours ending at noon 250 deaths were recorded, being an increase of 15 over the preceding twenty-four hours. Pneumonia is credited with 60 deaths, consumption caused 42, bronchitis 25, influenza 4, and influenza complicated with other diseases 15.

LONDON, Jan. 8. -- In an interview to-day Mr. P.T. Barnum intimated that he might execute the plan he has been credited with of erecting a vast circus building in the vicinity of Central Park, New-York. He had subscribed $20,000 for stock in the new Madison-square enterprise. This was on condition that the building's construction would allow of an exhibition of his "greatest show."

LIMA, Jan. 8. -- The various political parties continue active in preparing for the coming elections. Appeals signed by numerous citizens in all parts of the country favoring the two foremost Presidential candidates, Col. Morales Bermudes and Dr. Rosas, are published daily. Col. Bermudes, who is the official nominee, represents the military spirit of the country.
I read in your columns the exposure of the "Home Relief Association," and was quite surprised at the position assumed by the Charity Organization Society with regard to that concern.

It was in celebration of the seventy-fifth anniversary of the Battle of New-Orleans that the Business Men's Democratic Association of this city gave a banquet at the Hoffman House last night to Govs. Horace Boles of Iowa James E. Campbell of Ohio, Phillip W. McKinney of Virginia, Leon Abbett of New-Jersey, and Joseph K. Toole of Montana, who were carried into office by the great Democratic tidal wave of last Autumn.

That very conservative Republican journal, the Pioneer Press of St. Paul, Minn., does not, or did not recently, expect much from the tariff "hearings" of the Ways and Means Committee. "The constant droning away," it said, "of parties interested in the tariff goes on forever. When it is not a man who is afraid that the duty which affects him will be raised, it is a man who wants to get it raised."

Old Boreas, who has been for several days skylarking along on the outside edge of an alleged blizzard that was said to be bearing down on New-York from the blizzard factory up in Manitoba, arrived yesterday without the blizzard. He fairly reveled in the enjoyment of getting back to New-York after such a long absence, for he raced through the street with all the skittishness of a young goat.

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 8. -- E. Kellogg, State Sugar Inspector, has submitted to the State Board of Agriculture his report regarding the frauds alleged to have been perpetrated by the American Sugar Company of Meade and Minneola. The facts relative to the doctoring of the sugar are set forth substantially as they were in dispatches to THE TIMES.
Mr. James C. Bayles, formerly President of the Health Department of New-York, has expressed to a TIMES reporter his views on the subject of street cleaning:

The Board of Education held its first meeting of the year yesterday afternoon. Mrs. Clara M. Williams, Mayor Grant's appointment in the place of Miss Grace Dodge, was in her place some minutes before the session began. The four other new members -- Eugene Kelly, Charles B. Hubbell, James W. Gerard, and William Lummis -- were all present.
BERLIN, Jan. 8. -- The Princess Bismarck has recovered from the influenza. Dr. Doellinger and the Bavarian Ministers, Lutz and Fellitzch, are getting better.
There was received by THE TIMES yesterday a blotted piece of pasteboard answering for a postal card, which bore this interesting statement:

There are many members of the Union Republican Club of the Thirteenth Assembly District who do not think that the ever-wicked Gibbs is getting enough patronage for them out of the Government. There has been much growling. Finally it has been formulated in the following resolution, which will be introduced at the next meeting it the growlers are not scared off:

The Rev. Dr. Maynard delivered the fourth of his lectures on foreign lands in Chickering Hall yesterday on "The Cathedrals of the Netherlands and Italy." The audience was large, and followed the Beeturer in his interesting descriptions of the architecture and history of Antwerp. Milan, Florence, Pisa, Vienna, the great Basilicas of Rome and St. Peter's, and he was warmly applauded.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8. -- The Managers of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company met to-day, and adjourned until to-morrow after a short session and without taking any action in reference to payment of interest on the first preference income bonds of the company. One of the first trains from New-York to-day brought to this city three prominent brokers who were "loaded for bear."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- Tobacco and farm products were the principal topics discussed before the Ways and Means Committee to-day, and some very pathetic pleas for protection were heard. The tobacco growers were unanimous in wanting big duties levied on Sumatra leaf, and some of them wanted the internal revenue taxes taken off without delay.

The eccentric Board of Electrical Control met in the Mayor's office yesterday afternoon for the first time since Oct. 15. There has not been a meeting in the meantime, probably because Mayor Grant could not see the use of calling one. Commissioner Moss was absent yesterday, suffering with the grip, but Commissioners Hess and Gibbons were on hand.

In his annual message Mayor GRANT made the encouraging statement in regard to electric wires that "by the close of next Summer it is confidently believed that every pole will be removed from the streets, and that every electrical wire will be operated under ground in properly-constructed subways." This statement must have caused considerable surprise, not to say incredulity.

The exact nature of the service that Senator EDMUNDS rendered to the Attorney General and to Mr. HARRISON by his shrewd manoeuvring on Wednesday in the Dudley case will be seen by comparing the resolution of Senator VOORHEES with the one pushed through by Senator EDMUNDS.

The organ of the American Protective Tariff League, the Tariff League Bulletin, scolded the National Wool Growers' Association four or five weeks ago because that association had asserted that with adequate protection this country could produce all the carpet wool required for use in it. Said the Bulletin:

Expert Penman D.N. Carvalho was the first witness called to the stand yesterday when the trial of the case of Mrs. Mary McShane against her brother Michael J. Duffy was resumed before Judge Allen and a jury in the Court of Common Pleas. Carvalho examined the deeds which it was alleged the Rev. Father John J. Duffy of Kingston-on-the-Hudson had executed in favor of the defendant.
MADRID, Jan. 9. -- At midnight the condition of Alfonso is regarded as hopeless. The Bishops throughout the country are ordered to offer prayers for his recovery.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Jan. 9. -- A large representative body of milk producers engaged in supplying the New-York market assembled in the Court House at Goshen to-day, under a call issued by the Executive Committee of the Central Milk Producers' Union. Delegates from subordinate unions and friends of the movement were present from many of the principal shipping points in New-York, New-Jersey, Pennsylvania, Connecticut, and Massachusetts.

The squalls which accompanied the heavy blow of Wednesday night destroyed three partially-erected buildings in Brooklyn, burying a three-story house under the wreck of a church wall, killing two people and severely injuring five others. This occurred on Throop-avenue, a few feet from Willoughby, about 4:30 o'clock yesterday morning.

Harry Lioni, who fed freaks in the Grand Museum, and who died there on Wednesday after a protracted illness, will be buried this afternoon in Calvary Cemetery from Galvin's undertaking wareroom at 471 Grand-street. The old doorkeeper at the museum could not tell much about the dead man, but he thought "Red," or Herman, on the top floor could. Herman was found in the restaurant under the roof.

UTICA, N.Y., Jan. 9. -- The Utica Jacksonians last evening celebrated the anniversary of the battle of New-Orleans with a banquet, at which local orators were very ably assisted by Secretary of State Rice and State Treasurer Danforth. The Jacksonians formed as a campaign organization in 1884, and assisted in Mr. Cleveland's victory.

The death of the Hon. WILLIAM D. KELLEY removes a historic figure from the halls of Congress. He was first elected to the House of Representatives in 1860 and has continuously served the same constituency in that body ever since the opening of the memorable Thirty-seventh Congress. It is an unparalleled record of service in that body, and Mr. KELLEY came to be known as the "Father of the House."

Mr. BECK of Kentucky, if his health permit, will shortly bring before the Senate again the question of the suspension of the laws "providing for a sinking fund for the payment of the principal of the bonds of the United States until further order of Congress." The bill for this purpose had its first reading on Tuesday and was referred to the Committee on Finance.

The suit of the National League against John M. Ward, the short stop of the New-York Club, was called before Judge O'Brien, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday. There was a big attendance of men interested in the national game, but the Brotherhood seemed to have the larger number of followers. Every seat was occupied, and when the proceedings began standing room was at a premium.
NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 9. -- Winter meeting, eighteenth day -- Weather partly cloudy and warm. Attendance good, track fast.

LONDON, Jan. 9. -- The oil vessel that caught fire at Sunderland yesterday was the British steamer Wild Flower. The Vessel was beached and the flames were extinguished. She will be repaired. The British steamer Southwold, from Kertch, whose tanks were partly filled with oil, caught fire from the burning oil from the Wild Flower and was partly destroyed.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 9. -- Jacob H. Miller yesterday filed his report as auditor in the distribution of funds in the hands of J.H. Bailey, assignee of Graff, Bennett Co. The amount distributed is $175,000. The firm, it is stated, assigned Feb. 2, 1888. The effects were the Clinton Iron Works, the Millvale Iron and Steel Works and a mill in Millvale Borough.

The Sugar Trust's troubles accumulate. Its stock in Wall-street sold down yesterday to 51 58, the lowest price it has ever touched. Only a little while ago it sold above 125. Then the $50,000,000 capital had a market value of $62,500,000. Now the value is $25,000,000, a shrinkage of $37,500,000. The "trust" scheme for creating a monopoly and treating law with contempt has proved expensive.

LONDON, Jan. 9. -- The British steamer Llandaff City, Capt. Gore, from Bristol via Swansea for New-York, before reported as returned to Queenstown in a damaged condition, arrived at Bristol to-day, where she collided with the British steamer Virent. The Llandaff City was so badly damaged that she sank. The Virent was also damaged. No lives were lost.

The Commissioners of Charities and Correction yesterday received a letter from Dr. J.M. Schley, asking an immediate decision on the Homeopathic Society's request for the disbanding of the Medical Board of the Ward's Island Hospital. They responded as follows:

Katherine B. Howe, the leading lady of the "Natural Gas" company, now at the Lee-Avenue Academy of Music, Brooklyn, appeared before Police Justice O'Reilly, in the Yorkville Police Court, yesterday as complainant against Harry W. Foss, a hotel manager of Springfield, Mass. She charged him with appropriating a gold watch, valued at $150, which she had put in his care to have repaired.

When James P. Foster, once President of the Republican League of the United States, was called as a witness in the suit that Tallmadge Martin, printers, have brought against the league for a bill of about $12,000 he was paid 50 cents for his services. He said at yesterday's hearing that this was not quite big enough pay for his work.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9. -- Provisions were unsettled to-day, and a brisk speculative business was transacted, but it was nearly all done during the last twenty minutes of the session. Previous to that time the selling of a little Lard and a moderate quantity of Pork by Hutchinson to the Anglo-American Company was about all there was to talk about.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 9. -- Calvin S. Brice was nominated to-night for the United States Senate. The caucus met early this evening and on the second ballot Mr. Brice received the nomination. Out of the 73 votes cast all but 20 were for him.

Gov. HILL has never failed in his regular messages to the Legislature to refer to the need of reform in our system of taxation, and he has uniformly shown that he has no grasp of the subject and no ability to make suggestions that are of the least value. Heretofore the substance of his recommendations has been that means should be devised for collecting from personal property its equitable share of the public tribute.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Wood, woodenware, and paper were the special topics assigned for consideration by the Ways and Means Committee at to-day's tariff hearing, but a good many other things were talked about before the sitting was finished. One feature of the day was the appearance of a very strong delegation of business men of Boston, who came to ask that wool degras should be put upon the free list.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- The marriage of Miss Rebecca Gilman Dodge to Passed Assistant Engineer Charles Whiteside Rae, United States Army, took place at noon to-day at All Souls' Church, the altar of which was banked with palms and potted plants. The Rev. Edward Everett Hale of Boston performed the ceremony in the presence of one of the largest and most fashionable assemblages ever gathered to witness a marriage in this city.

President William P. St. John of the Mercantile National Bank, who was Vice President of the Southern Society until Wednesday, when he resigned from membership in the society because it had on the previous night adopted resolutions in eulogy of Jefferson Davis, feels that the public has received a wrong impression in regard, to the motives which actuated his course, by some of the newspapers which printed only certain portions of his letter of resignation.

Sixty-nine horses ran at Guttenburg yesterday in the six races that were decided, two each having fields of fifteen The best contest of the lot was the third race, in which the first four, Count Luna, Festus, King Idle, and Cheeney, finished only heads apart. Mr. Caldwell had sufficiently recovered from his attack of la grippe to be able to act as starter, consequently the starts were good and betting lively.

HAVANA, Jan. 3, via Tampa, Fla. -- The defalcation in the Treasury Department grows larger the more it is investigated. The amount of funds missing, at first estimated at $250,000, now reaches $700,000. Many officials are implicated. There was an extensive conspiracy to plunder the Government. One of the officials under arrest is a chief of administration of the first class, and has at times acted as Superintendent General of the Treasury.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Jan. 9.--The open charges of jury bribing made in court by ex-Mayor Wilbur A. Heisley of Long Branch continues to be an absorbing topic of discussion. The press throughout the county unite in demanding an investigation of the charge that the jury in the case of the State against Clifton W. Tayleure of the Long Branch News was bribed be vigorously pushed.

HARTFORD, Jan. 9. -- The grade-crossing problem in this State will be reviewed at length in the new report of the Railroad Commissioners, which will be issued in the course of a week. The past year has been notable for a practical suspension of the State's policy relating to the removal of railroad crossings at grade, and the report will show an increase instead of a diminution of the danger complained of by the public.
CHICAGO, Jan. 9. -- As a result of the epidemic of influenza the local supply of quinine and antipyrine is almost exhausted, and a famine in those important drugs is threatened.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 9. -- The most appalling accident known here in many years occurred this evening about 6 o'clock. It was nearly time for work to stop all over the city and workingmen were expected home by their families when the report spread rapidly that there was a wreck or crash of some kind at the new bridge now under construction between Louisville and Jeffersonville.
ALBANY, Jan. 9. -- The following abstracts are made from the annual reports of the companies named to the State Insurance Superintendent here. The reports close Dec. 31, 1889:

A curious example of the survival of ignorance may be seen in the attempt of the Indianapolis Journal, on the 6th inst., to convince its readers that the Whisky Trust is a Kentucky organization, a "monopoly" having "headquarters" in "the locality represented by Mr. CARLISLE" and sustained by "Mr. CARLISLE and his associates in Congress."

Columbia's ambitious atheletes desirous of seats in the 'Varsity and Freshman eights presented themselves yesterday at the new gymnasium of the college in the basement of Barnard Hall, where they were weighed. They will not, however, begin training until the middle or the latter part of next week, as the pully-weights have not been put into place, and the rowing machines are not ready.

Persons walking down West Twenty-fifth-street, near Broadway, were surprised about 6 o'clock last night to see a gentleman rush out of the Southern Society's rooms at No. 18 and dash toward Sixth-avenue. Soon after, two other gentlemen emerged from the clubrooms. "Will you take that back?" shouted one to the other.

DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 10. -- An exciting episode occurred at the residence of Judge Cooley, Chairman of the Inter-State Commerce Commission, in Ann Arbor last evening, which, but for the coolness and presence of mind of the Judge, might easily have resulted in a tragedy.

The Rev. B.B. Tyler, pastor of the Church of the Disciples, will begin to-morrow morning a series of Sunday morning sermons on the Sible, at the church, 323 West Fifty-sixth-street. The series will continue through this and next month, every Sunday morning, ending Feb. 16. Dr. Tyler will take for his subject to-morrow morning, "Where Did the Bible Come From?"

The press of Washington does not exert a great influence upon the opinion of the country, not being even read beyond the precincts of the capital, except in the offices of other newspapers. The public men of Washington cannot be said to exist. Although the public men of the country in great part assemble in Washington, it is as strangers and sojourners, representing every part of the country except the District of Columbia.

PUNXSUTAWNEY, Penn., Jan. 10. -- There were only two families of the striking miners evicted to-day, one Hungarian and one Italian. After the Sheriff, accompanied by thirty-three Pinkertons armed with Winchesters, had thrown out an Italian family at Walston, about three hundred of their countrymen collected, and began yelling and firing into the air.

There was a largely-attended meeting of the creditors of the J.B. Sheffield Son Company and the Saugerties Blank Book Company, both of Saugerties, whose assignment for the benefit of creditors was announced last week, at the Astor House yesterday. Some sixty out of a total of about a hundred were present. W.F. Russell, President of the Saugerties Company, was chosen Chairman.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 10. -- At 12:20 o'clock this morning the bodies of three of the unfortunate victims of the caisson accident were recovered by the workmen. The positions in which they were found showed that a desperate struggle had taken place at the narrow door of escape. One negro had succeeded in pulling his body through the aperture, but death had overtaken him just when life was promised.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Jan. 10. -- "Bill" Edwards, a sporting character of this city, was shot dead in his home this afternoon. When the police arrived at the scene of the tragedy, 520 East Church-street, they found Edwards lying on his face in the hallway, blood oozing from a pistol shot in the back of his neck. In a sitting room in the rear of the hall sat Mrs. Mary Ellenberger, with whom he had lived.

QUEBEC, Jan. 10. -- The sale of Canadian salmon streams and trout lakes belonging to provincial Government took place to-day at Parliament House, when privileges to the extent of $12,000 a year annual rental were disposed of. The salmon streams on the north shore of the St. Lawrence were sold as follows:

The Brotherhood of Professional Baseball Players received a set-back yesterday when Tucker, the champion batsmen of the American Association, deserted the organization and signed an agreement to play with the old Boston League team. Tucker some time ago agreed to play first base for the new Brooklyn Club, and he was advertised as a star.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- The Pennsylvania Road and its Western lines to-day filed an answer to the complaint of the New-York Board of Trade and Transportation, charging unjust discrimination against New-York through low rates made on through shipments from Europe to the West. The defendants deny that they are guilty of unjust discrimination.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Jan. 10. -- The following news reached this city yesterday by the steamer City of Peking:
" Oranje Boven!" was the cry that filled the corridors of the Equitable Building last night and found an echo in the heart of every Dutchman who had come to the banquet of the Holland Society.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Jan. 10. -- The second annual exhibition of the Hudson River Poultry, Dog, and Pet Stock Association at the Casino in this city is fairly under way and will remain open until the 14th inst. The principal feature of the exhibition is the poultry department, in which are shown specimens of all the favorite domestic and foreign strains.

The elaborate souvenir of the performance given at the Star Theatre last Thursday afternoon for the benefit of the Greeley Statue fund embodied no contribution direct or indirect from the New-York Tribune.

The British steamship Stag, which arrived yesterday from Bremen, whence she sailed on Dec. 7, brought the solution of a mystery of the sea that for two weeks or so has been a very vital question to some people. She had on board eighteen of the officers and crew of the old ship Shakspere, which had been reported before as having been abandoned, but the fate of whose crew was unknown.

Amzi S. Dodd, one of the pioneers of the bag, gage express business in his city and well known from his connection with various enterprises, died yesterday a the home of his son in-law, Joseph Kavanaugh, 234 West One Hundred and Twenty-first-sreet

BANGOR, Me., Jan. 10. -- The thermometer has been below zero for thirty-six hours and there are six inches of ice in the Kennebec, the same on the Penobscot, and every ice field in Maine is closed to-night. With the mercury at 8 below, a gale rages off the coast which must bring distress to incoming craft.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Jan. 10. -- John G. Johnson, attorney for the stockholders and junior bondholders of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company, will to-morrow ask the court to enjoin the voting Trustees from re-electing Mr. Corbin President of the Reading. The full machinery of the law will thus be brought into play to further the ends of those who believe that President Corbin should be deposed.
Our neighbor, the Tribune, wants to know what Mr. McKINLEY is going to do with the Trusts, and asks the Chairman of the Ways and Means Committee this question:

BOSTON, Jan. 10. -- Mr. Jacob H. Schiff of New York has just made a gift of $10,000 to Harvard University for the establishment of a museum for the study of the literature, history, and remains of the Semitic peoples. This unique gift will provide for a want which every thoughtful student of history must recognize, and will entitle its founders and patrons to lasting gratitude.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Draped in black and adorned with a simple bouquet of white flowers, the desk so long occupied by Mr. Kelley of Pennsylvania this morning reminded members that the "Father of the House" had departed from their midst. The chaplain made a feeling reference to the dead Congressman in his prayer, and then Mr. O'Neill of Pennsylvania, in a few well chosen words, announced the death of his colleague.

As the Saxton Ballot bill, in the amended form in which it was introduced in the Senate on Tuesday last, has not yet been printed, we do not know precisely what changes have been made in it, but in an interview with our correspondent before the opening of the session Mr. SAXTON stated that he had decide to adopt the "blanket ballot," such as has been used in Massachusetts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- All sorts of pleas for all sorts of industries were heard by the Ways and Means Committee to-day, and while, as usual, a great majority of the witnesses wanted high protective duties, the feature of the hearing was a warm argument in favor of free raw materials.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 10. -- The case of Mary L. Mowatt against her brothers, sisters, and other relatives to regain possession of a large amount of money and real estate obtained from her by fraud, as she claims, was called in the Superior Court here this morning before Judge Barnard. This case has attracted great interest owing to the peculiar circumstances connected with it and the amount of money involved.

The Twenty-second Regiment elected Capt. John P. Leo of Company I Lieutenant Colonel last night. His majority was a scant one, however. One vote saved him, and a little stroke of good luck stood him in good stead, or he wouldn't have had any majority at all. Capt. Bartlett, who would have voted for Capt. George E.B. Hart, who was Capt. Leo's opponent, arrived a minute and a half after the polls had closed.

The survivors of the General Committee of the County Democracy of the Third District, which was so badly depleted by the desertion of Police Justice O'Reilly and his followers, met at the Cooper Institute last night and took the first steps toward filling up the big gap. There were just 18 present at the meeting. There are 220 names on the list of the committee as it stood under O'Reilly.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 10. -- At the last session of the Connecticut Legislature the sum of $1,000 was appropriated for the erection of a suitable monument in Woodbury in remembrance or Daniel Steinmitz, a foreign resident of that town, who died there during the war. The occasion for this monument is not without interest, and the inhabitants of Woodbury will unite very earnestly in recognizing it.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 10. -- A special to the Journal from Jefferson City, Mo., says: "The Secretary of State to-day revoked the charter of the 'Quickmeat' Stove Company of St. Louis. This action was taken in accordance with the provisions of the anti-trust law. The company refused to make affidavit hat it was not a member of the Stove Trust.

The third public rehearsal of the Philharmonic Society yesterday afternoon was devoted chiefly to the performance of classical music. Two symphonies were played, one at the beginning and one at the close of the entertainment. The first was Mozart's in E flat, catalogued by Kochel as Opus 543, one of the three great symphonies composed by the universal genius four years before his death.

BOSTON, Jan. 10. -- The regular monthly meeting of the Massachusetts Historical Society yesterday was of more than ordinary interest from the fact that the Treasurer, Mr. Charles S. Smith, communicated from the manuscript journal of the Rev. Dr. John Pierce some notes on the Commencements at Harvard University for forty-six years, beginning with 1803.
The papers of those who were examined for one-thousand-dollar clerkships by the Civil Service Board at the Custom House during October were marked yesterday, and the eligible list is now as follows:

Common sense triumphs over barren technicality once more in the decision of the General Term of the Supreme Court in the case of Aqueduct Commissioner DUANE. Judges DANIELS and BARRETT hold that Gen. DUANE being on the retired list of the army and now holding no office and exercising no functions under the National Government, is not disqualified from holding his present position.

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 10. -- The meeting of silk manufacturers indorsed the action of the Silk Association in New-York this afternoon, and appointed John Grimshaw, Joseph Wadsworth, and Daniel J. Sheehan a committee to prepare and have signed a memorial to Congress for passage of a bill which will remedy the difficulty. Congressman Beckwith and Senators McPherson and Blodgett will be urged to use their utmost energies to hasten the passage of the bill.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 10. -- The hearing on the injunction served on the Housatonic Railroad Company by the Consolidated Road restraining them from disturbing tracks in Bridgeport was begun to-day before Judge Hall. A large number of officials of both roads were present. E.M. Reed, Vice President of the Consolidated Road, was the first witness.

CUERO, Texas, Jan. 10. -- The boiler in the Cuero Brass and Iron Foundry, owned and operated by John Lewis, exploded this morning, killing outright David Brown, proprietor of the Gulf Hotel, and Henry Deans, and seriously wounding Mr. Perry Ward, all of whom were in the building at work. Mr. Lewis's residence, in the rear of the foundry, was badly shattered and his wife and child were injured.

ST. JOHN, N.B., Jan. 10. -- An express train for Quebec over the Intercolonial met with an accident near Jacquet River this morning. The snow plow left the track and the engine followed it and turned over. Fireman P. Gauget was taken out in a dying condition. Engineer J. McGowan, at last accounts, was still in the wreck, and is probably dead.

ANCIENT ARABIA. -- We gather that as far back as the time of Solomon a rich and cultured Sabaean kingdom flourished in the south of Arabia, the influence of which, if not its authority, extended to the borders of Palestine, and between which and Syria an active commercial intercourse was carried on by land as well as by sea.

Mr. Hamerton, about two years ago, considering the advance chemico-mechanical methods had made in illustrative art, said that the time was not far distant when all work by the hand of an illustrative character would cease. He referred principally to wood engraving. Today Mr. Hamerton's prophecy seems to have almost come to pass. The Saturday Review noticing the prevalence of the process for book illustration, finds fault with it in sone respects.

One hundred and fifty-eight members of the Seventh Regiment competed in the Sharpshooters Match in the armory rifle range last night, for the regimental grand prize and the bronze metal awarded to all officers and men scoring 65 points or better at 200 and 500 yards, seven shots off shoulder and seven shots in the prone position.

Certain members of the Union League appear to have entered into a conspiracy to make the monthly exhibitions of objects of the fine arts of constantly increasing importance. The Chinese and Japanese porcelains at one exhibition were the marvel of collectors. The Chinese jades and clossonne pieces from Japan, together with Mr. Ellsworth's Rembrandt and other old masters, made another show most extraordinary in beauty and worth.

NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 11. -- The Connecticut Shell Fish Commission will be engaged during the current month as a Board of Relief, sitting at New-Haven on Mondays and at Bridgeport, Norwalk, and other centres of the oyster trade on Fridays. Under the new State law the clerk of the board, who is appointed by the Governor and confirmed by the Senate, is now the authority in Connecticut for making assessments on oyster land for taxation.

It is not generally known that in the event of war the United States Government is prepared to use nearly every steamer flying the American flag. During the last few years the Navy Department has detailed naval boards to examine every American steamer deemed fit for war purposes and to forward to the Naval Intelligence Office in Washington all information and data collected on this point.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Jan. ll. -- Twenty years ago West Virginia, outside of the belt of counties along the northern edge of the State traversed by the Baltimore and Ohio Road, was practically without railroad facilities, and at least fifteen thousand of the twenty-five thousand square miles of its surface was little else than a howling wilderness, not to be matched outside of the plains and mountains of the far West.

THE COBRA DI CAPELLO. -- The cobra di capello, Naja tripudians, has numerous synonyms in different parts of India. It is sometimes called the spectacled or hooded snake; some are marked with a figure like spectacles; others have a single ocellus on the hood; some have no mark. The former are called by the natives of Bengal "gokurah," the latter "keautiah," but they have other vernacular synonyms in different regions.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Jan. 11. -- The other evening the Rev. E.C Cowles, pastor of the Methodist church of the town of Lapeer, Cortland County, was favored with what is known in the rural districts as a "donation visit" by his parishioners and friends. Chief among the gifts bestowed upon the worthy pastor on the occasion was a purse well filled with greenbacks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Society, that body of well-dressed, but not necessarily well-mannered, men and women who live and move and have their being in a perpetual state of disconnected thought and disjointed sentences, has passed the Rubicon. The fluttering little army of debutantes is no longer hovering on the threshold of that ever-to-be-remembered event, their first ball.

We are so accustomed to the word England in place of Britain that a title like the above leads one to expect a history of Britain under the old British. But the Rev. Mr. Church means Britannia and proposes to tell the story of the island from the earliest times down to the Norman Conquest.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 11.--The Founder's Day celebration at Cornell University to-day was sadly interfered with by the weather, but a large delegation from the Faculty and each of the four classes in the university, following an old-time custom, marched in procession past the tomb of Ezra Cornell and deposited wreaths at the base of the stone couch whereon lies the marble figure of Cornell's founder.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- The flat leather boxes that were brought along by most of the World's Fair advocates from New-York who arrived last night and this morning were opened tonight, and the spike-tailed coats were brought forth to grace the reception given by Representatives Belden and Flower to the visitors and Congress.

Recent developments in the affairs of several large corporations have drawn renewed attention to the difficulty with which the average stockholder obtains information as to the condition of his property and to the practical impossibility of his reaching such a knowledge of all the facts as shall enable him to form a reasonable estimate of the value of his asset.

Observing in Monday's issue a letter on the subject of the divining rod induces me to contribute notes based upon practical results extending over a period of thirty years, which I hope will elighten as well as interest your readers who have at various times exhibited a desire to understand this mysterious method of ascertaining the locality of water as well as metallic veins in mining regions.

On Friday evening West Twenty-fifth-street was enlivened by an occurrence rare if not novel in New-York, but the like of which very frequently intervenes to obstruct the traffic and animate the conversation of the main streets of Southern boroughs. An excited gentleman was seen running toward Broadway, hotly pursued by another excited gentleman who was taking hasty and wild snap shots with a revolver at his fleeing foe.

ALBANY, Jan. 11. -- A sharp-sighted officer in the National Guard was shocked recently at the sight of a drayman wearing one of the new State service uniforms while performing his daily work. He notified Adjt. Gen. Porter, and that official was very angry. He investigated and found that parts of uniforms as well as overcoats were being worn by National Guardsmen in New-York and Brooklyn while at work.

Whether or not our rising young men should be encouraged to enter political life depends very much upon what is meant by politics. It will hardly be denied that the term politician is not looked upon with veneration by our people, and that most men if called upon to class the individual who is labeled with that designation would not define him or describe his calling in terms of exaggerated praise.

BUENOS AYRES, Dec. 6. -- The premium on gold, the failures owing to the collapse in prices, the arrest and imprisonment of about a dozen money brokers, and the generally critical financial situation, form the chief topics of conversation. With regard to the imprisonment of the speculators or their agents, the feeling is rather one of sympathy with them, as they are looked upon by the business community as scapegoats sacrificed to appease popular clamor.

It is a rather risky venture for protectionists to cite the case of Germany in support of the prosperity attending a protective policy. It is perfectly true that the iron and steel industry of Germany has been very prosperous recently, and that this prosperity has followed the imposition of a duty.

The whole of the Austro-Hungarian cavalry is about to be armed with a repeating carbine on the latest Maunlicher system. The calibre will be eight millimeters -- the same as that adopted last year for the infantry rifle. The question as to how the new weapon is to be carried is exercising the minds of the cavalry officers here, as appears to be the case in Germany also.

The sleet of the morning and the mist and fog which followed kept racegoers from the Guttenberg track yesterday, the attendance being the lightest that has been seen at the track on a Saturday for a long time. The racing was the roughly unsatisfactory, as it was almost impossible to see the horses while they were running.

In the Field of Dec. 14 I promised to examine the present condition of American leads on this side of the Atlantic. Before doing so, however, I may state that correspondents in America inform me these leads have "come to stay"; that they are regarded as an integral part of the game; and that any one neglecting them, or refusing to make use of them, would hardly be considered a whist player in the States.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 11. -- There will be published here to-morrow a story about the deal of the Valley Railroad of Ohio with the Baltimore and Ohio which puts the transaction in a new light. Andrew Carnegie and the Pittsburg and Western are now said to be neither directly nor indirectly connected with the deal.

LONDON, Jan. 11.--It is reported here that D'Oyly Carte has received a cable from Mr. A.M. Palmer demanding the discharge of most of "The Gondoliers" company. Mr. Carte was seen to-night at the Savoy Hotel. He said there was no use attempting to disguise the fact of the failure of the New-York company, and that he was deeply mortified.

In the "Diary and Letters of Gouverneur Morris," edited by Annie Cary Morris and reviewed in THE NEW-YORK TIMES of Dec. 16, 1888, the effects produced by the horrors of the French Revolution on Morris are described. As an eye witness of many terrible scenes, M. Taine might have given Morris's testimony quite as pertinently as that of Arthur Young's.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Representative Grosvenor of Ohio has concluded that he does not want to be any longer a member of the Committee on War Claims. At a meeting of that committee this afternoon Mr. Grosvenor presented a candidate for assistant clerk of the committee. By a vote of 10 to 3 the committee elected another candidate.

GARRICK AND DIBDIN. -- In 1768 Dibdin transferred his services to Drury-Lane, where he had the usual disagreements with Garrick in regard to money matters. One would hardly be justified in applying the term "unscrupulous" to Garrick; but he undoubtedly knew the value of money better than those who served him, and it was not his fault if he got the worst of a bargain.

There has recently been some discussion in various parts of the country as to whether the Republicans in Congress would not read aright the lesson of the recent elections, and of the remarkable demands for reduced duties made by manufacturers before the Ways and Means Committee, and really undertake an honest and substantial revision of the tariff.

People stirring abroad yesterday morning found the walks in a dangerously slippery condition. The rain which fell congealed into a coating of ice which spread everywhere. Many persons went down on their own front steps, others fell on the walks and in the streets, and still others who attempted to mount the partially covered steps to the elevated railroads lost their footing there and got more or less severe bruises.

" Every one who has read Livingstone's narrative of his great journey across Africa to Angola and his return down the Zambesi to the Indian Ocean," says the London Times, (which, however, must be remembered as a highly-in-interested judge in the matter of the dispute with Portugal,) "will remember his faithful Makololo companions.

There is much anxiety among the naval cadets at Annapolis to know just how many extra vacancies will be made in the navy should the proposed measure to transfer the Revenue Marine to the naval establishment pass. It is figured out that there will be sixteen vacancies by reason of the age clause alone, but, for all causes, forty officers, at present on the active list of the Revenue Marine, will be eligible for retirement.

" Al" Daggett did not aid yesterday in shedding light in the suit which Tallmadge Martia, printers, are pressing against the Republican League. He was billed for the star witness, but no one took the trouble to summon him. An effort will be made to have him appear next Wednesday before Referee Raegener.

A significant indication of the extent of popular interest in the approaching meeting of the National Guard Association of the United States, appointed to assemble in the city of Washington on Feb. 5, is found in the fact that the far-off States, such as California, are the first to notify the officers of the association that they will be represented in the convention.

HAVERHILL, Mass., Jan. 11. -- It is safe to say that nothing has happened in Haverhill since the great fire in 1882 that has caused so much despondency as the lock-out at nine large shoe factories, which occurred at 6 o'clock this evening. In at least five of these factories the employes were receiving good wages and were contented; nor was there any anticipated trouble with the union.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Dec. 18. -- At last we are fairly ashore in "The Big Dog's Home," and a most curious place it seems to be, fully as well worth seeing as any of the more pretentious spots that I visited a year ago on the other side of the Indian Ocean. The way in which we reached the little port was the most sensational episode of our cruise.

Herr Gustav Freytag has just published an essay on Karl von Normann, former Secretary and Court Marshal of the Emperor Frederick from 1864 to 1884. The author describes how intimate were the relations between von Normann and the Crown Prince's family, who regarded him as a member of it in the true sense of the word.
GALLICISMS IN EAST SUFFOLK. -- The following Gallicisms, surviving in East Suffolk, are worth preserving:

BOSTON, Jan. 11. -- The opening of Boston's first Real Estate Exchange, in the Transcript Building, this afternoon, was made noteworthy by some comments on the prosperity of Massachusetts and the city, in spite of unfavorable conditions of competition. President Henry M. Whitney said:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- The contrast between yesterday's tariff hearing before the Committee on Ways and Means and that of to-day was very great. Yesterday thirty persons had something of interest to lay before the committee, and the room was thronged all day. To-day the committee waited nearly an hour before anybody asked to be heard, and only seven persons all told had anything to say.
RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 11. -- Gov. McKinney today sent to the Legislature a message on the State debt, in which he says:

CHICAGO, Jan. 11. -- For the last week the dead walls of this city have been adorned with large posters printed in red ink, announcing a grand athletic entertainment at Battery D next Wednesday. The wind-up was to be a contest of eight rounds, with small, soft gloves, between "Billy" Myer, the lightweight champion of the United States, and Harry Gilmore, the ex-champion.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- The following story of Lincoln, Stanton, Grant, and Vicksburg, as related by a prominent army officer, is here made public for the first time:

PARIS, Dec. 22. -- The disturbing "influence of the influenza," to use a local saying, has worked disastrously for the brightness of Christmas. Its sudden attack makes every one apprehensive of a few days' discomfort and monotonous illness, and there is scarcely any large establishment that has not paid partial tribute to the enemy.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11. -- Mr. Murat Halstead has been in Chicago for a day or two, and has delivered himself of views on a variety of subjects. Among other things he charged the Ohio Prohibitionists with defeating Foraker, characterizing them as "infernal Prohibitionists," saying they acted "like brutes," and alluding to the Prohibition vote of 26,504 as "horrible and scandalous, brutal, villainous."

Few English figures in the closing years of the eighteenth century -- a period very eminent for English figures possessed of lasting renown -- have better chances of enduring remembrance than Warren Hastings. His was the fate to enjoy, in the very misfortunes of a relentless prosecution while living, the rare and singular good fortune of acquiring a fame closely linked with memorable and lasting achievements of the English mind.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 11. -- The First Baptist Church of this city, of which the Rev. J.S. James or Germantown, Penn., has just been installed as pastor, will celebrate its first centenary in March. It is the oldest and most influential Baptist church in this locality, and stands among the first churches of the denomination in the State.

Many persons are prone to become restive under the earnest advice of their friends to endeavor to understand music, and not be contented with merely permitting it to tickle the tympanum. They wish to take music as an amusement and not as an art. Do not the daily papers call music and the drama "amusements"?

The last allocution of the Pope, in which he hurled fulminations and maledictions upon that portion of the new penal code pertaining to the abuses of the clergy in the exercise of their duties, has probably induced many of its readers to imagine and believe that Italy has instituted a system of persecution, anti-religious and anti-Catholic, and therefore anti-liberal.

BERLIN, Jan. 11. -- Public attention is concentrated to-day upon the funeral of the Empress Augusta, to the exclusion of all other topics. The threatening news from Spain, the progress in Austria of the German Czech conferences -- all seem of little moment to the people here by comparison with the grandiose pageant of an imperial funeral.

NEWPORT, R.I., Jan. 11. -- Newport is getting to be quite lively in Winter. Last week there was a big New Year's ball given by the Winter society people, and this week there has been a reception at the Newport Reading Room, a fashionable church wedding, which has already been reported in THE TIMES, and a cottage dance -- all society events and all gay affairs.

The meeting of the representatives of the various organizations of milk producers who supply the New-York markets, for the purpose of taking the business out of the hands of the middlemen and reaching the consumer directly, which was held in Goshen on Thursday, does not seem to have alarmed the members of the Milk Exchange.

It is a fact of some interest that the present epidemic of influenza is merely another centennial celebration, like our Washington inauguration centenary and the Paris Exposition to commemorate the beginning of the French Revolution.
