Just a hundred years ago the United States had a severe attack of "la grippe" very much as now.

FATHER TOM. -- What gave Burke his peculiar charm, especially with the audiences that thronged to hear him, both in this country and in America, was his marvelous dramatic power. When in Rome his Lenten discourses were attended by strangers who could not understand a single word of English, but who were impressed, nevertheless, by his wonderful action, or, rather, acting, in the sense of the word used by Demosthenes.

STAMPING OUT PROTESTANTISM IN RUSSIA. -- A Lettish peasant woman, Anna Kursemneeks by name, thirty-two years old, had originally been baptised in the Lutheran Church. The name of Anna and that of her sister had been placed upon the Greek registers in consequence of her father having been enrolled and "confirmed" as a Greek Catholic during the excitement of the former years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11.--The Rev. Mr. Ward and Mrs. Ward, the latter known to the literary world as Elizabeth Stuart Phelps, took formal possession Jan. 1 of a cottage on Georgetown Heights, which they leased for four months, paid for in advance. Before the end of the first fortnight they have changed their minds and have suddenly returned to Massachusetts.

ALBANY, Jan. 11. -- In an important report made on Thursday to Superintendent of Insurance R.A. Maxwell, Examiners Shannon and Horan declare that on Nov. 30 the assets of the Fire Association of New-York, one of the Armstrong companies, amounted to $634,961 84, and its liabilities, including capital stock, to $692,018 36.

LONDON, Ontario, Jan. 11. -- A great audieuet assembled here this evening at the Grand OperaHouse, at a meeting under the auspices of the Young Liberal Club, to listen to an address by Erastus Wiman of New-York. The subject was "The Three Futures for Canada," these being continued colonialism, annexation, or an in dependent republic.

JUNEAU, Alaska, Dec. 10. -- There is really no very accurate map of Alaska accessible to the general public. No kind of an official survey has ever been made of the Territory. Some work has been done by the Coast Survey for about four hundred miles from the northern boundary of British Columbia, but there has been no official exploration of the interior from that boundary to Mount St. Elias.

PERSIAN CIVILIZATION. -- I have been much surprised to hear even well-educated Englishmen, in recent discussions on Persia, speak of the Persian Nation as if it were completely wanting in civilization and were ages behind Europe in manners, customs, and ideas. Such a false impression of the characteristics and social condition of our good friends, the neighbors of our Indian Empire, is, I think, due to ignorance, and I fear also to insular prejudice.

This little volume is a forerunner of the large work by Henry M. Stanley setting forth all the particulars of his march from the Congo to Lake Albert Nyanza, his return almost to the Congo to bring up the supplies left under Major Barttelot, his second march and rescue of Emin Pasha, and his return to civilization by way of Zanzibar and the east coast of Africa.

When the ex-President of the Confederacy was confined in Fortress Monroe Capt. Day was Officer of the Guard. Capt. Day's sister, now Mrs. Burchenal of Richmond, Ind., paid a visit of several months' duration to her brother and laid the foundations of a friendship with the Davis family that has never since weakened. Recently she wrote to Mrs. Davis, who repelled as follows:

About three weeks ago the London Times published a short account sent by its Paris correspondent of a reported slaughter of Siberian prisoners. It was a ghastly story. Well might one have hoped that it was a wild exaggeration or utterly untrue. "Most unfortunately," says the same paper of ten days later, "we can no longer flatter ourselves with this belief.

A JOLLY FRIAR. -- A ludicrous incident occurred at Killarney Cathedral in the presence of Lord Kenmare and all the local magnates. Burke was preaching for the Presentation Brothers' Schools, and his sermon reached an unusual length. The brothers, anxious only for a good collection, began rattling the tin plates as a hint to the preacher to stop.

The Chairman of the Kings County Republican General Committee will be elected on Tuesday night, but the fight between Franklin Woodruff and David A. Baldwin for that office practically ended last night. From its inception the fight has been the most bitter one ever known in Republican circles in Brooklyn, and charges of bribery and corruption have been freely made by both sides.

The society world of the metropolis would certainly have been justified in abandoning its gayeties and retiring to the seclusion of its individual abodes during the past week, for never has gayety been carried on under more discouraging conditions. The seemingly relentless "grip" has tightened instead or loosening its grasp, and there are few households which have not had one or more members stricken.

The recent publication by a Boston newspaper of an evidently authentic statement of the earnings of a popular poet during the year 1889 has not excited nearly so much public interest as the estimate lately printed in THE TIMES of the wealth of JOHN D. ROCKEFELLER. Mr. ROCKEFELLER'S fortune is believed to exceed $129,000,000.

Whatever may be the disadvantages of the civil service in England, the Pall Mall Gazette is of opinion that it "has at the outset one great advantage over most other professions, since it requires little outlay to enter it. The home civil service is at the present time little heard of at the universities. Neither the men who enter it nor even those who rise in it are, as a rule, university men.

In some way there has got into circulation a report that the Monmouth Park Association intended to reduce the number of its stakes this year. Such a report is very far from the truth. Already fourteen stakes to be run next July and August have been closed, and there will be thirty-six or thirty-seven more to close March 1, conditions for which will be announced about Feb. 1.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Jan. 11. -- A. party of twelve or fifteen persons had a thrilling experience on the Susquehanna River at Middletown on Wednesday afternoon. E.R. Morgan-agent of the Kendall Manufacturing Company of Providence, R.I., was one of the party. A ferryboat plies the river from Middletown to the opposite side of the river.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 11. -- Macey Brothers' training and livery stable at Versailles, Ky., containing forty-five head of horses, was burned to the ground early this morning. The horses, including the highly-valued Electioneer stallion Bell Boy, were all destroyed. The fire originated in the stable, just how is not known, and when Bell Boy's hostler, who slept in the office adjoining that horse's stall, awoke, the whole building was on fire.

TORONTO, Canada, Jan. 11. -- The Toronto Mail, at one time the special organ of the Dominion Government, but now one of the most independent of Canadian journals, is devoting its energies to a crusade against the Canadian Pacific Railway, declaring that this company is discriminating against Canadian traffic in its transportation charges.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Whatever may be the fate of the Exhibition bill presented this morning to the Senate Committee on the Quadro-Centennial, the advantages of New-York as the place for holding such an exhibition have been presented with a zeal and discretion that must have made a deep impression upon the members of the committee.

A leading London West End dealer tells a representative of the London Daily News that "fully seventy per cent." of the horses sold in English markets are bought by foreigners. "He was inclined to put the percentage as high as seventh-five, which seems very high, although it will be seen that his account of the foreign purchaser agree generally with that of another eminent dealer, whose opinion we quoted in a preceding article.

The artists are so often admitted without charge to exhibitions of the fine arts that surprise has been expressed by many who wished to see the bronzes of A.L. BARYE, the "Angelus" of J.F. MILLET, and the hundred masterpieces by the landscapists of the Barbizon group, that they were compelled to pay the fee for admission.

There is a distinguished gentleman in the East who never sleeps. While all the world finds rest in slumber this gentleman lays awake o' nights building a thousand, and, perhaps, ten thousand, roads all leading to the Presidency. His name is David B. Hill, and his friends are probably not wide of the mark when they put him down as the finest wire puller in America.

Assuming that there is no constitutional obstacle in the way, the bill "to provide for an exhibition of arts, sciences, manufactures, and products of the soil, mine, and sea, in the city of New-York," which has been prepared by the World's Fair Committee to be introduced in the State Legislature, makes a very proper provision for enabling the city to do its part for the proposed exhibition.

LONDON, Jan. 11. -- I suppose that never before in the history of the world has the deathbed of any little boy been watched with anything like the interest which all Europe to-day is taking in the news from Madrid. As a subject of journalistic value the baby Alfonso dwarfs everything else, not only here in London, but in Paris, Vienna, and even in Berlin, despite the rival sensation of the Empress Augusta's funeral.

Commenting upon the recent hearing in this city before the Senate committee, the Boston Herald says it is "a little curious" that the representatives of the Gloucester fishing interests put in their case here rather than in Boston, but sees that they enjoyed here a freedom from criticism that could not have been enjoyed there.

A public debate between Lawson N. Fuller and Dr. Daniel De Leon on the merits and demerits of private or public ownership of railroads in general and of a railroad from King's Bridge to the Battery in particular will be held at the Atheneum, West One Hundred and Fifty-fifth-street, to-morrow night. Mr. Fuller is to talk for private ownership.

The army Chaplains will hardly be pleased at the promptness with which an unfavorable conclusion was reached in the Senate Committee on Military Affairs upon the bill to increase their pay. But perhaps this action was not wholly unexpected, since it is the same which was taken in the last Congress on a similar measure, and, in fact, the views of the former committee are repeated now.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 12.--The capital of Ohio is to-night crowded with visitors from all over the State to witness Gov. Campbell's inauguration to-morrow. Immense delegations are arriving on every train, and the induction into the Gubernatorial chair of the fortieth Governor of this State will be attended with the most imposing demonstrations ever witnessed here.
FRANKFORT, Jan. 12. -- On the Boerse prices were firm tlurlg th'gcek l)as.

Examiners Shannon and Horan of the State Insurance Department have raised a breeze by their report on the condition of the Fire Association of this city, published in yesterday's TIMES. They found that on Nov. 30 its assets were $634,961 84 and its liabilities, including capital stock, $692,018 36, showing an impairment of the capital amounting to $57,056 52.

There will be no more public hearings by the Ways and Means Committee on the tariff after to-morrow, but it is announced in the press dispatches that Major MCKINLEY will give "private" audience to those persons who may desire to influence the judgment of the committee as to any changes in the tariff.

No work on Russian interests in Central Asia having appeared in English within five years. Mr. Curzon thinks he has ample justification for his present contribution. Central Asia is a land of rapid and momentous changes. Applied to any civilized land, this observation might be found exceedingly trite.

At last the Coney Island Jockey Club have made public the entries to the Suburban Handicap, the great mile-and-a-quarter race which always attracts such great crowds to the beautiful Sheepshead Bay track. The list numbers sixty-eight, and includes a number of the best handicap horses in training, together with a lot of those now running at the Clifton and Guttenberg tracks, for which latter lot there seems to be no rest, Winter or Summer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- Now that the advocates of each of the cities which want the World's Fair have been given a hearing before the Special Committee of the Senate, the next move in the contest for the site will be made in the House of Representatives, at the other end of the Capitol.

The ferryboat Somerset, at present plying between New-York and Brooklyn on the Wall- Street Ferry Line, is one of the few remaining vessels of this type that saw service during the war. When the Government begin buying up vessels of all descriptions, ferryboats were taken, and many did good work on the Sounds and rivers of the South.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12. -- The pending Reading Railroad litigation and its probable outcome were freely discussed to-day wherever financial and business men met. At the various clubs the pros and cons of the case were talked over and many opinions were expressed as to the fate of the voting Trustees. While many thought that the Corbin advocates would be successful, others anticipated that the court's decision to-morrow morning would be in favor of Messrs.

LISBON, Jan. 12. -- A mob composed of students and others shouting "Down with the Ministry!" attacked the British Legation today. They demolished the escutcheon on the building and smashed the windows. The police were powerless to control them. They then broke the windows of the residences of various members of the Ministry, after which they dispersed.

The bill introduced into Congress for the payment of the sum of $13,930 to the personal representatives of the late Capt. JOHN ERICSSON, with interest at 5 per cent. from February, 1857, is intended to close the pecuniary account of the Government with the engineer to whose great abilities it owes so much that can never be expressed in figures.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 12. -- The Iowa Legislature will meet at noon to-morrow, with nearly every member in his seat. The absentees will be those who are confined to their rooms by sickness, and they include Representative Paschall, Republican; Senator McCoy, Republican, and Senator Barnett, Independent.

The annual report of the Civil Service Commission of New-York State will be presented to the Legislature to-night or tomorrow. Outside of the statistics embraced in the document, giving the number of examinations and appointments for the year, the main point of interest to the public is the fact that certain changes in the method of examining candidates have been made calculated to furnish a better test of their practical qualifications for the office sought.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Jan. 12. -- The steamer City of Worcester of the Norwich Line, from New-York for this port, is on the rocks about one-third of a mile north-northwest of Bartlett's Reef Lightship. She struck at 1 o'clock this morning, during a dense fog. Capt. Ward, the first and second pilots, and the quartermaster were in the pilot house at the time, and the four say they did not hear the lightship bell.

Gov. Hill devotes a large part of his message to the New-York Legislature to this subject. He commends very highly and very justly the election laws in New-York State, but he admits that the secrecy of the ballot is not secured, and that it is essential that it should be secured in order to protect the rights of every voter.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 12. -- Last night's news dispatches from Washington state that Adjt. Gen. and Mrs. Daniel D. Hastings of this State are the guests over Sunday of United Sates Senator and Mrs. M.S. Quay. On its face an unimportant social event, this little visit has a significant bearing upon the Republican Gubernatorial canvass in Pennsylvania.

Major William Hancock Clark, who created a sensation by shooting at Mr. Wilton Randolph, a fellow-member of the Southern Club, in front of the clubhouse in Twenty-fifth-street last Friday night, was arrested yesterday afternoon by Special Officers Kemp and Perkins of the Nineteenth Police Precinct.

According to the official report from Washington, the Senate will be asked this week by Senators TELLER and PLATT to take up the change in the rules for the abolition of secret sessions for the consideration of Executive appointments. It is possible that a new element, not altogether logical, may contribute to the success of this reform.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- Messrs. McKinley and Cannon have gone to Philadelphia to attend the funeral of Representative Kelley, and Mr. Carlisle is so ill that he is unable to leave his room. Those members, therefore, who looked for a report from the Committee on Rules in the House to-morrow and the consequent beginning of a hot partisan struggle, will be disappointed.

THE TIMES last Summer published a series of letters from the Adirondack forest region which aroused much interest not alone among those persons who live within the counties of the Forest Preserve, but also those thousands who regard the great wilderness in the northern part of the State as a sanitary retreat whose powers for good are incalculable.

Archbishop Corrigan in his sermon at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning referred at length to his approaching trip to Rome, which he said was to be made in accordance with those laws of the Church requiring Bishops to make written and verbal reports to the propaganda. The Archbishop told his people some of the things he would report to the ecclesiastical authorities at Rome as to the progress of the Church here.

SPOKANE FALLS, Washington, Jan. 12. -- H. McCrosser, better known to the sporting fraternity as "Big Mac," was shot and killed by Harry Baer, one of the proprietors of the largest gambling house in the Northwest, yesterday. Baer was in the act of ejecting a man from his house for stealing chips, when he was assaulted by "Big Mac."

ALBANY, Jan. 12. -- The annual statistical report of the Civil Service Commission, accompanied by recommendations of the chief examiner, John B. Riley, has been transmitted to the Legislature. Mr. Riley's report covers the examinations held the first eleven months of last year. He says:

The somewhat curious proposal of a Senator that Mr. WINDOM should suspend proceedings for the lease of the Pribylov Islands until he hears from Congress on the subject may be based in part on the changes which the Secretary has made in the terms of the lease. It is to run twenty years from July 1, 1890.

Last Saturday night was set apart by the architects for a reception to celebrate the close of their annual exhibition in the Fifth-Avenue Galleries. It is the fifth year of these exhibitions, which are always interesting and useful. Perhaps it may be permitted to make a suggestion, namely, that each year some specialty be taken up in order to give the exhibition point, and take from it the somewhat netrogeneous nature of the objects shown.

At the annual meeting of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club held in the clubhouse, 7 East Thirty-second-street, on Saturday evening, the Committee on Measurement and Classification or Yachts, made up of John Hyslop, A. Cary Smith, and W.P. Stephens, suggested that the amendment to the racing rules of the club, providing for the classification of yachts by their corrected lengths, be laid on the table.

While the American Geological Society was in annual session at the American Museum of Natural History in this city during Christmas week, a long, rambling statement of charges of plagiarism and incompetency against Major John W. Powell, Director of the United States Geological Survey, and Prof. O.C. Marsh, the Paleontologist of Yale University and President of the National Academy of Sciences, was hawked about among the newspaper offices.

The famous Russian swindler, "Count von Tesawin," who was recently handed over by the German police to the Zurich authorities, has been sentenced to six weeks' imprisonment for swindling, and the Swiss police have other charges against the fellow. When they have done with him he will be claimed successively by the Austrian, German, and Russian authorities, between whom he may reasonably look forward to spending the rest of his life in prison.

ALBANY, Jan. 12. -- Gov. Hill's professed change of front on ballot reform has deceived nobody here who is conversant with his methods. In the first place no one believes the Governor is sincere in his new attitude. He has simply begun to realize that his position is similar to Capt. Scott's coon; that he can't be brought down to the level of ballot reform, but "that he is getting worried like Old Nick."

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12. -- A staff correspondent of the Philadelphia Times late last evening had the first interview since the murder of Mrs. Kniffin of Trenton with Miss Emma Pursel. The interview took place at the residence of David Pursel, near New-Village, N.J. Mr. Pursel introduced the correspondent to his sister.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12. -- The Congressional committee selected to attend the funeral of the late Congressman Kelley arrived in this city today. The committee consisted of the following-named gentlemen: Senators Manderson, Cameron, and Colquitt, and Congressmen McKinley, Cannon, Banks, McKenna of California, Bynum, and Mutchler.

There is not a politician of note in this city just now who is not deeply interested in the question as to who is to succeed Jacob M. Patterson as Police Justice. So many other questions of great interest in local politics are wrapped up in this seemingly simple one that its settlement by Mayor Grant's formal decision will indicate many interesting things.

The annual report of the Superintendent of the Banking Department of the State was transmitted to the Legislature last evening. It was prepared by Deputy Superintendent Charles R. Hall and sent in by the new Superintendent, Charles M. Preston.

The Republicans will hold their primary elections in all the Assembly districts to-day, and interesting contentions are likely to arise in some of them. The machines in the Seventeenth, Twenty-first, and Twenty-third Districts have fixed it so that the polls in those districts will be open from 9 A.M. to 9 P.M. This will give enough time to do the fighting.

BOSTON, Jan. 13. -- Xavier Reiter, the great horn player, has disappeared. Mr. Reiter is a well-known figure on the streets, being a tall, handsome man, whose peculiar style of dressing gives him a rather striking appearance, but he is not seen on them just now. He is a large-bearded Bavarian, with a mane of long black hair that rests upon his shoulders.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 13. -- This has been a notable day in the history of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company. This morning Judge Hare refused to grant the injunction asked for by Messrs. Erwin and Shelmerding against the company and the voting trustees, and later in the day the annual meeting of the stockholders was held and the Corbin party triumphed.
LIMA, Jan. 13, via Galveston. -- The Peruvian Government has promulgated a law ratifying the Grace contract, which goes into immediate effect.

The hearing before Master Commissioner Bluford Wilson to determine the validity of certain bonds of the St. Louis and Chicago Railway Company was continued yesterday. The first part of the session was devoted to the testimony of Octavius B. Baldwin, President of the American Loan and Trust Company, and Robert W. Webb.

It appears that the censure we directed on Sunday against the Park Commissioners for delaying to secure the operation of a horse railroad on the sunken road through the Park at Eighty-fifth-street should rather have been aimed at the Commissioners of the Sinking Fund. The Park Commissioners had a careful estimate made of the amount that would be needed to construct the road, ready for operation, and this estimate amounted to $20,000.

PANAMA, Jan. 4. -- The Technical Commission of Inquiry, consisting of M. Germain, President and hydrographic engineer; M. Chaper, civil and mining engineer; M. Lagout; bridge engineer; M. Cousin, Belgian civil engineer; M. du Chatenet, civil and mining engineer, accompanied by M. Nouallhao Pioch, special delegate of the liquidator, M. Brunet, arrived at Colon a few days ago in the French transatlantic steamship l'Amerique.

Miss Caroline J. Cammerer of Philadelphia, a music teacher, young, pretty, and with a decidedly aristocratic upward turn of the nose at the tip, is suing aged and wealthy Clemens Muller of this city for breach of promise. The damages claimed are $100,000. Miss Cammerer is about twenty-two years old, educated, and refined.

Several members of the Staten Island Athletic Club have complained recently of the way the athletic department was managed by F.W. Janssen, Chairman of the Athletic Committee. They have charged that Mr. Janssen was negligent in what they were pleased to call his duty in regard to entering them in games, and the result has been an unpleasant strife in that club.

There is evidently a good deal of politics in the make-up of the legislative committees. The Democratic representation is cut down from the customary allowance, a process for which there was no good reason. Senator CANTOR and Assemblyman SHEEHAN are quite justified in complaining of the treatment of the minority, and it is doubtful if in the long run anything is gained by such displays of party unfairness.

A Western paper points out that a resolution passed in the Senate about a month ago directing Secretary NOBLE to furnish for the information of that legislative body copies of all the correspondence between the department and Agents McBRIDE and PICKLES concerning the opening of Oklahoma has not yet brought out any response.

There is a stirring row among the Tammany braves of the Fifteenth Assembly District. The hot has been boiling up there for some time, and last night Tammany's Committee of five on Reorganization took the cover off in the Fourteenth-street wigwam. The smoke and steam that came out will make it pretty difficult for the committee to see its way to a clear and satisfactory settlement of the trouble.

The people of the United States ought not to ask their Judges to work for board-and-clothes wages. That is practically what they pay now for services of great value rendered by men conspicuous for their learning and ability. United States Circuit Judges get $6,000 a year, District Judges get $4,000.

LISBON, Jan. 13. -- The fermentation in the streets continues. Crowds of students, in the streets of the neighborhood of the Cortes, are shouting "Viva Portugal!" "Viva Pinto!" and at a meeting of students it was proposed to wire congratulations to Serpa Pinto. At Oporto a public meeting has been called to protest against the submission to England's demands.

The seventh annual report of the Board of Railroad Commissioners of the State of New-York was transmitted to the Legislature yesterday. The present Commissioners are William E. Rogers, Isaac V. Baker, Jr., and Michael Rickard.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- Vice President and Mrs. Morton entertained the Justices of the Supreme Court at dinner to-night at their residence, on Scott Circle. A large centre piece of maidenhair fern, in a silver stand, was flanked at either end of the table by a similar stand filled with long-stemmed hybrid roses.
ALBANY, Jan. 13. -- The following are the Assembly committees announced by Speaker Husted to-night:

ELMIRA, N.Y., Jan. 13. -- Pursuant to previous arrangements, G.M. Diven of this city, counsel for Robert Ray Hamilton, accompanied by the latter, and Charles W. Fuller of New-York, counsel for Mrs. Hamilton, appeared to-day before E.O. Van Duzer of this city, the referee appointed to take testimony in the divorce proceedings instituted against his wife by Mr. Hamilton.

When the first Saxton Ballot Reform bill came into Gov. HILL'S bands in 1888 he kept it nearly a month after the Legislature had adjourned and then filed a memorandum of disapproval which treated all its features but one with contempt. He regarded the whole business as an unnecessary and mischievous innovation.
EDINBURGH, Jan. 13. -- Five Clackmannan masters in the coal mines have advanced the miners' wages 12 1/2d.

As was stated in THE TIMES a few weeks ago, Michael Welch, the well-known pitcher, will play with the Giants again next year. He signed a regular League contract yesterday and will tender his resignation as a member of the Players' Brotherhood in a few days.

The proposal to increase the pay of the non-commissioned officers of the army, which has been urged in several of the official reports and has also taken form in sundry bills before Congress, rests not only on the general expediency of making the places held by them desirable to have and to keep, but on a special ground.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- The President sent the following nominations to the Senate to-day:

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 13. -- All along the path of last evening's terrible storm large crowds congregated this morning to view the ruins. The house at 922 Mound-street, a two-story brick, where three people were killed, was surrounded by an immense throng. This house was totally demolished. Matthew McCullom, who occupied the first floor, was buried beneath the debris, and was taken out dead a few minutes after the storm passed.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 13. -- The inquest in the Kniffin murder case was resumed this morning. Police Justice Matheson was the first witness. He described the appearance of the scene of the murder in detail when he visited the Kniffin residence, and spoke of the obstruction met with at the hands of Dr. Shannon, Dr. Kniffin's assistant, when the authorities attempted to examine Miss Pursel.

WILLIAMSPORT, Penn., Jan. 13. -- Like a withered leaf, feeble in health and with hair as white as snow, is John Towlion, the hermit, who lives on the mountains of Jack's Hollow, a few miles north of this city. His cabin or shanty, as it may be properly termed, is no larger than an ordinary watch box at a railroad crossing.

CAIRO, Ill., Jan. 13. -- Eleven people were killed and sixty-eight buildings, large and small, were demolished at Clinton, Ky., at 6:20 o'clock last evening, but news of the terrible catastrophe did not reach here until to-day, when relief parties were organized and hurried to the scene. Some of these returned this evening, bringing harrowing details of the fearful affair.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 13. -- This is said to be the quietest night before a session of the New-Jersey Legislature which Trenton has ever experienced. The members of both houses are here, and in the early part of the evening the corridors of the hotels were crowded, but the usual bustle and stir attendant upon the opening of the Legislature is lacking.
Thomas Warner, an old and highly-respected colored citizen, died in this city on the 28th ult. He had been in the service of the late Hon. F.S. Lyon and that of his family for over fifty years.

Tours through different parts of the city are now being made by members of the Society of Amateur Photographers, in order to secure some fresh negatives of picturesque localities, to be shown at the lantern-slide exhibition at Chickering Hall on Feb. 5. There is a little rivalry among the young knights of the camera to gain fine specimens, as it will be an honor to have their pictures shown on the screen.

NEWPORT, R.I., Jan. 13. -- High Sheriff Easton to-day served a writ upon Lieut. Commander Longnecker, executive officer of the United States training ship New-Hampshire, on a suit by F.W. Carbery for $10,000 for alleged false imprisonment. The writ is returnable at the next March term of the Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- Secretary Windom has written a letter to the Collector of Customs at New-York, inclosing a copy of the report of Mr. W.P. Hepburn, Solicitor of the Treasury, giving the results of his investigation of immigration matters at the port of New-York and requesting an expression of the Collector's views on the subject.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Jan. 13. -- A bargeload of furniture and bedding from the stranded steamer City of Worcester was landed here this afternoon and more will follow to-morrow. "This is not done from fear that the steamer will go pieces," said Mr. Gardner, "but to prevent damage by the workmen. The wrecking tug I.J. Merritt arrived from New-York this afternoon in response to a telegram from Wrecker T.A. Scott, who desired assistance.

ALBANY, Jan. 13. -- The Legislature reconvened to-night. In the House Gen. Husted announced his standing committees, and on motion of Mr Fish an adjournment was immediately directed until to-morrow at 11 A.M.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 13. -- The wind blew about thirty-two miles an hour in this section all the forenoon. Considerable damage was done, but fortunately there was but a single life lost as far as reported this evening. That was at Homestead, this county, where a little girl named Bush was instantly killed. She was walking along the street when a shed blew down upon her and crushed her to death.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Jan. 13.--A letter has been received in this city from Capt. Howland of the whaling bark Canton, dated at sea; Dec 5, and postmarked Cape Town, which gives an account of the loss by fire of the British bark British Monarch, 1,262 tons, of Liverpool, bound from Hamburg to Sydney with a general cargo.

JOHNSTOWN, Penn., Jan. 13. -- Ever since Oct. 24 the search for the dead has been continued by the aid of liberal contributions. It was at that time, or a short time before, that the forces hired by the State were discontinued, but the howl that went up by the few who were left seems to have been well grounded, and contributions were taken up and the work went on.

The Sun's attack on the so-called Husted Rapid Transit bill and its malignant abuse of Mr. Cleveland because without his knowledge his name has been suggested as a Commissioner is very easily explained. The young man who represents the Sun at Albany, and who made these attacks on the bill and on Mr. Cleveland, draws a salary from the City Government.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 13. -- The Iowa Legislature convened at 2 o'clock this afternoon. The object of attention was the House, where it was expected a dead-lock would occur. These expectations were realized. Fifty Democrats met fifty Republicans, and proved an easy match for them. In point of generalship the Republicans were clearly overshadowed.

LISBON, Dec. 27. -- Several days in port have done wonders for the squadron of evolution. Scrubbing, cleaning, and painting have run riot, the crews have settled into routine, and Christmas is safely passed.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Jan. 13. -- The most terrific windstorm that has ever visited Western New-York swept over this part of the State between 9 and 10 o'clock this morning. It soon assumed the nature of a veritable cyclone and left havoc and destruction in its wake. The stately steeples of churches, roofs of large mercantile buildings, houses, and barns were demolished in the twinkling of an eye.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 13.--Rochester was devasted during the hours from 10 o'clock A.M. to 3 o'clock P.M. to-day by the worst gale experienced here in many years. A black cloud appearing in the South was the first premonition of the storm, that burst with indescribable fury. The Signal Service officer was watching the anemometer, which registered sixty-two miles an hour and then broke.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 13. -- The grain elevator known as the Northern Central Railroad elevator No. 3, at Lower Canton, this city, to-night is a smoldering mass of ruins. The elevator itself was worth $300,000 and was insured, mostly locally. The corn stored there is a loss of $280,000, owned by individual shippers and fully insured in small policies in local companies.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 13. -- The remains of the Hon. William D. Kelley, Pennsylvania's champion of protection, the "Father of the House," who so long and acceptably represented the Fourth District in Congress, were to-day consigned to the tomb. There was little show or display, privacy and quiet being insisted upon by the members of the dead man's family.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 13. -- Governor-elect James E. Campbell took the oath of office to-day at noon. His message to the General Assembly is comparatively brief, and touches upon a number of subjects of State and local interest. He recommends that home rule be restored to all the cities as speedily as possible, and enters into detail as to the need at Cincinnati.

It is still curiously doubtful what is the real attitude of the Administration toward Secretary WINDOM'S silver plan. It has been submitted to the Cabinet and has been more or less discussed by the astute financiess who are notoriously prominent in that body. Whether it has been approved or not, and what will be the consequence if it has been approved, there is no means of knowing with certainty.

In the midst of Winter New-York was in Summer yesterday, so far as the weather was concerned. The people of this city yesterday morning were able to walk about with unbuttoned coats in a temperature of from 63 to 67, rendered June-like by a gentle southwest wind. A suggestion to go down to Coney Island for bath seemed almost in order.

The New-York Canoe Club will give an informal reception at the fencing rooms. 19 West Twenty, fourth-street, on Tuesday evening of next week. There will be short illustrated talks on cruising, and a programme comprising ventriloquism, fencing, and music.Refreshments will be served at 10:30 P.M.The committee having the reception in charge is made up of Messrs. R. B. Burohard, F. S. Grant, Poultney Bigelow, Schuyler Schieffelin, and B.H. Nadal

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 14. -- The Senatorial fight was ended to-day, for Mr. Brice received a majority of a quorum in each branch of the General Assembly, and at the joint convention of the two houses to-morrow there will not be any balloting, but the result of to-day's work will be declared.

ALBANY, Jan. 14. -- The session of the Assembly this morning was brief and pointless. Mr. Sheehan made a puerile attempt to amend Gen. Husted's new rules, but was blown out of court, and the House, satisfied with the work, adjourned.

Some of the criticisms of Solicitor HEPBURN in his report to the Secretary of the Treasury on the administration of the Board of Emigration are quite pertinent and others are rather impertinent, but his conclusions are such as ought to hate been reached and put in effect long ago. The regulation of immigration is a national and not a State affair, and its execution ought to be in the hands of United States officials.

DETROIT, Jan. 14.--George T. Smith's Middlings Purifier Works at Jackson were placed in the hands of R.H. Emerson and Z.C. Eldred as assignees to-day, with liabilities reported at $500,000. The failure creates an immense sensation, as the company owned valuable patents connected with the flouring business, and had the world for their market. Their plant covers seventeen acres of ground, and was fitted up with the best machinery.

Since the preparations for appointing civilians to Second Lieutenancies in the army include the issue of revised rules for their examination, it has naturally been surmised that a considerable number of vacancies of this sort will be filled. It may fairly be hoped, however, that enough moderation will be exercised to avoid hampering and delaying the assignment of the class that will graduate from West Point next June.

The New-York Cremation Society met last night at Kindergarten Hall, 109 West Fifty-fourth-street, and elected its officers for the ensuing year as follows: President -- R.W.G. Welling; First Vice President -- Mrs. Charles H. Stebbins; Second Vice President -- Henry M. Taber; Corresponding Secretary -- M.B. Spezzalt; Financial Secretary -- S. Berendsohn; Recording Secretary -- Theodore Berendsohn; Treasurer -- D.W. Craig.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14. -- In Judge McConnell's court this morning the opening argument on the motion of the Cronin prisoners for a new trial was begun by Attorney Wing. The argument was altogether confined to the points already presented in the attorney's written declaration of errors.

In the batch of decisions handed down by the Court of Appeals yesterday were two in which the city may be regarded as a victor. One of them is of considerable importance, inasmuch as it settles the protracted dispute between the city and the Staten Island Rapid Transit Company to determine what proportion of the gross receipts of the ferry company should be turned over to the City Treasury in return for its franchise.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 20. -- The situation was more serious yesterday than I supposed when I closed my letter. As the steamer does not sail until to-day I can add the following fuller details:
The following business was transacted at the Exchange and Auction Room yesterday, Tuesday, Jan. 14:

TRENTON, Jan. 14. -- Gov. Robert S. Green transmitted to the Legislature to-day his third annual message on the condition of the State, with various recommendations of interest, notably upon the subject of ballot reform.

The average New-York business man has one notable characteristic. He keenly appreciates things real and tangible. He knows when his ventures are apt to be crowned with success. Disregarding airy nothings, he follows up projects which he looks upon as "dead sure."

While a cotton-laden train was running from Perry and t/arrlson 8atlon on the Houston and Txas .3ensral la.ltoa(1 in Texas .IM. ondty, the) c. olton took fire. and the train rushed lute the latter station with along and furious stream of flame followluff ir The statlou caught fire and 1 and several cars and a large quan$1y el co,ton were consumed.

LISBON, Jan. 14. -- The demonstrations of students continue to keep the city unquiet. To-day they veiled the statues of the old Portugues navigators around the Camoens Monument as a sign of national mourning. The crowd looked on with sympathy and shouted, "Down with England!" "Down with the pirates!"

ALBANY, Jan. 14. -- The East River Railroad Company flied a certificate of incorporation yesterday in the Secretary of State's office. The company is formed to construct and operate a road beginning in Brooklyn, E.D., at a point in the vicinity of South Seventh-Street, thence partly in cutting and partly under ground to and under the East River by means of a tunnel, and under lands and streets in the vicinity of Broome-street.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14. -- A Cleveland (Ohio) special says that a morning paper publishes a statement submitted by an expert bookkeeper, showing irregularities in the old accounts of the city of Cleveland aggregating about three million dollars. Nearly all of this money was paid out by the city without the approval of the Council, although the laws of the State of Ohio distinctly require that every claim be included in the regular claims ordinance.

SCRANTON, Penn., Jan. 14. -- After fifteen years of continuous duty in the Scranton Post Office and four years in the Railway Mail Service, A.H. Hartley, who has recently been acting as Superintendent of Mails in this city, has been summarily dismissed without cause, for the reason that although a Republican in politics, he has not been in harmony with the local machine.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate:

La Bourgogne of the French line steamed up to her pier yesterday morning like a veteran returning from battle. Her prow was bent and full of gaping seams where her iron plates had parted since she last left port. All the lustre had gone from her smooth sides, and in its place were scars and scratches and long dull streaks that looked as if some strong foe had tried to peel her.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 14. -- The stockholders of the Columbus, Hocking Valley and Toledo Road to-day elected the following Directors: One year -- Charles Foster of Ohio, P.W. Huntington of Ohio, and James Kilbourne of Ohio; two years -- Charles B. Alexander of New-York, George W. McCook of Ohio, and C.C. Waite of Ohio; three years -- Samuel D. Davis of New-York, Thomas F. Ryan of New-York, and C.B. Van Nostraud of New-York.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 14. -- An incident of war times was brought to mind to-day by the arrival on the Illinois Central Road of a box containing the remains of seven soldiers of the Twelfth Maine Regiment -- Companies C and 7 -- who were killed in a skirmish at Ponchatoula Sept. 12, 1862.

The Bar Association at its meeting last night, contrary to the general expectation, virtually resolved to recommend to the Legislature the impeachment of Judge Henry W. Bookstaver of the Court of Common Pleas for his connection with the Flack divorce conspiracy.

The hearing before Master Commissioner Bluford Wilson to determine the validity of the consolidated mortgage bonds of the St. Louis and Chicago Railway, numbered from 1,401 to 1,600 inclusive, was continued at Granville P. Hawes's office, 36 Wall-street, yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 14. -- In the Court of Appeals, First Division, to-day the following decisions were handed down.

The remark made by Mr. CLEVELAND the other day about the Sun seems to have irritated the editor of that touchy journal. He behaves like a man who has been flayed and rolled in sand or salt. He continues to denounce the Commission Rapid-Transit bill because he still imagines that Mr. CLEVELAND was concerned in its preparation.

Yesterday was not a very merry day in Wall-street. The stock market, so much as there was of it, was weak, and few stocks escaped a slump. A big failure in the mercantile trade was made the basis for a good deal or speculation, it being claimed that the failure's influence would be grave and far reaching.

A meeting of the congregation of the German Lutheran church -- the fashionable church of Hoboken -- has been called to consider the advisability of demanding the resignation of Pastor Eirich. The Rev. Mr. Eirich succeeded the Rev. Mr. Haferman, who was dismissed by the people six years ago because of his devotion to one of his fair parishioners.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- When the Ways and Means Committee began its tariff hearings it laid down a programme which called for a flual sitting last week. At the close of the week the committee had taken an enormous mass of "testimony" concerning nearly every industry in the United States. But there were still a good many persons who wanted to talk to the committee, and so the members met again to-day.

Mr. COMMODORE PERRY VEDDER'S ridiculous Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment has received its customary roving commission to go about at the State's expense seeking for new sources of revenue and new means of raising it. Its so-called investigations have never been of the least benefit to anybody but the committee, whose members have enjoyed many a junket to this city and to the watering places and pleasure resorts of the State at the public expense.

MCKEESPORT, Penn., Jan. 14. -- Senator Quay is being sadly badgered about the Postmastership here. The appointment belongs to Congressman Ray of this district, and Quay long ago declared that he would not interfere. When, however, the Senator succeeded so well in defeating Congressman Dalziel's man for the Pittsburg Post Office, the half a dozen aspirants for the McKeesport place quit importuning Ray and began bothering Quay.

Franklin Woodruff ended the long fight for control of the Republican machine in Brooklyn last night by being re-elected Chairman of the Kings County Republican General Committee by a plurality of 41. He succeeded in beating Ernst Nathan, John A. Nichols, Thomas C. Platt, and "Al" Daggett, not to mention such men as Senator Birkett and Congressman Wallace.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14. -- Cattle sold a trifle stronger to-day than on Monday, as the receipts showed a falling off of more than one-half, and there were indications of a moderate ran for the remainder of the week. The demand was more active than is usual on Tuesday and, so general in its character that no matter what description of Cattle a salesman had, he did not have to wait long for a buyer.

Public interest in the breach of promise suit brought by Miss Caroline J. Cammerer of Philadelphia against Mr. Clemens Muller of this city was so great yesterday that the court officers were kept busy fighting back the crowd, which tried to get into Part IV. of the Supreme Court Chambers, where the case was being tried.

Numerous responses to the special appeal of the Executive Committee of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association were received yesterday by Mr. Charles Lanier, Treasurer, 17 Nassau-street. The day's receipts were as follows:

At yesterday's session of the investigation into the charges made by the Commissioners of Accounts against Dock Commissioners Post and Matthews, Surveyor Fredrick P. Thompson was kept under a fusillade of questions by ex-Surrogate Rollins over five hours, while he explained that the vouchers for work done by and the payments to the Union Dredging Company were made only upon perfect measurements that were laboriously and accurately made by him and his assistants.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14. -- The Federal appointments made for Chicago to-day are a compromise as to the Collectorship of the Port, and a mild sort of a victory for Senator Farwell as to the Collectorship of Internal Revenue.

William Gilbert, father of William S. Gilbert, the author of "Bab Ballads," "Pinafore," and many other operettas and plays, died at his home in Salisbury, England, Jan. 2, at an advanced age. In his young manhood he lived in Italy, and was a student of Italian art and music. He wrote a book rehabilitating the character of Lucrezia Borgia, the materials for which he found in libraries in Milan and Venice.

The annual primary elections of the Republican Party were held in all the Assembly districts throughout this county yesterday, and with the exception of those in the Fifth and Twenty-first Districts and the Twenty-fourth Ward were tame enough. There was generally but little interest manifested, the tickets put forward by the district organizations going through without opposition.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14. -- Isaac L. Rice of New-York, whose name was on the opposition ticket for one of the Board of Managers of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company at the annual meeting yesterday, remained in the city to-day, and was in consultation with Lawyer John G. Johnson as to what legal steps were best next to pursue.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 14. -- Both of the Chambers looked like flower gardens when the Legislature opened its one hundred and thirteenth session in the State House this afternoon. The P.H. O'Neill Association had placed monster floral horseshoes on the desks of Senator McDonald in the Senate and of Assemblyman Mullone in the House.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- When President Harrison sent to the Senate yesterday the nomination of ex-Gov. Henry C. Warmoth to be Collector of Customs at New-Orleans he had before him a very earnest protest :against any such action.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- The Presidential reception to-night to the diplomatic corps was a notable gathering of elegantly-dressed people, among whom the officers of the army and navy, in full uniform, and the diplomats, in court costume, were particularly conspicuous. The decorations of the East Room and the Blue, Red, and Green Parlors were in the stately style usual upon such occasions.

A very important decision was rendered by the Court of Appeals yesterday in the case of the church of St. Monica against the city of New-York. The church claimed exemption from taxation for real estate in East Seventy-eighth-street on the ground that it belonged to a religious society and was used for school purposes.

ALBANY, Jan. 14. -- The Court of Appeals to-day handed down a decision in the case of The People ex rel. Cornell University, appellant, against Ira Davenport, Controller, in which the order of the General Term is modified and the Controller directed to issue his warrant for the payment to the university of all interest from the investment remaining in his hands up to the amount of the $5,000 appropriated each year, respectively.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 14. -- William Amelung, a German farmer, lives in the little town of Bridgeton, thirteen miles from St. Louis. He has a daughter, nineteen years old, and four sons. Some time ago he had a negro in his employ named Taylor Pointer. Some one told the young man that the negro had boasted that he was the accepted lover of the girl.

ST. Louis, Jan. 14. -- Correspondents who have snuffed the battle from afar, us it were, have sent out more or less blood-curdling accounts of a race war at the little village of Upper Alton, Ill. To ascertain just what the row was all about THE TIMES'S correspondent visited the seat of war and discovered a most peculiar state of affairs.

HAVANA, Jan. 15. -- The ninth game in the great chess match took place to-day. It was begun with the Evans gambit. The contest lasted four hours and twenty-five minutes, and fourty-five moves were made. Tschigorin was forced to resign.

The trouble that is just now disturbing the peace of Alton, Ill., has a moral for every Northern community. It bears a particular moral for those orators and publicists who are fond of denouncing, especially on the eve of elections, what the late CHARLES SUMNER used to call "the accursed spirit of caste," and of assuming that that spirit is confined to the white inhabitants of the States lately in rebellion.
LISBON, Jan. 15. -- At 1 o'clock this morning the police arrested seventy persons who were parading the streets and shouting, "Down with England!"

CHICAGO, Jan. 15. -- The Times's Washington dispatches indicate that Senator Farwell is grieved at the slight put upon him by the nomination of Clark, that Senator Cullom sympathizes with his colleague, and that Congressman Abner Taylor, in whose district Mr. Clark lives, is fighting mad.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 15. -- The bill which increases the salary of the Governor, with Gov. Abbett's term next week, from $5,000 to $10,000 a year, was reported from the Senate to the House this morning. It was hastily pushed through the various stages to final reading, and then put, under suspension of the rules, on final passage.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 15. -- United States Senator Ephraim King Wilson was to-day elected to to succeed himself. He got the solid Democratic vote of the Legislature in joint convention. The Republicans voted for Thomas S. Hodson, who has twice run for Congress in the First District, and who is booked for the United States District Attorneyship.

The question how far officers of the army and the navy may go in directly appealing to Congress to have their pay raised or their privileges increased is just now attracting some attention. Senator CHANDLER has introduced a resolution of inquiry in regard to the well-known bill proposed by Passed Assistant Paymaster COWIE, which has received a very large share of support among naval officers.

President HARRISON can have no motive but a personal one in seeking to give the most important Federal office in the South to HENRY C. WARMOTH. Even the President himself would not venture to claim that it is in the interest of the service or of the public. He could examine WARMOTH'S public record with a microscope without finding the faintest indication of fitness for any public trust whatever.

Steadily and surely the contributions continue to come in, so that the Washington Memorial Arch fund materially increase each day. If the Plan and Scope Committee of the late centennial celebration will adopt the earnest suggestion of their Financial Committee and contribute to this scheme for perpetuating that centennial, the balance of $4,700 they have in hand, less than $29,000 will then be required to complete this work.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 15. -- A special from New-Brighton, Penn., says: "At 3:40 o'clock this afternoon the boiler of the steam shovel used by the Pittsburg and Lake Erie Railway Company in excavating at Fallston, Penn., exploded with such force that several pieces were blown across the river and driven into the ground, a fourth of a mile away.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- Only two gentlemen cared to talk to the Ways and Means Committee at to-day's tariff hearing, and one of these confined his remarks to the internal revenue system. The committee appears to have about exhausted the supply of people who want more protection.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15. -- The managers of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company held a meeting at the company's office to-day. It was the last day of the time prescribed for passing upon the payment of interest on the preference bonds. The board formally resolved that no interest should be paid.

Miss Caroline J. Cammerer, the Philadelphia teacher who is seeking damages in the sum of $100,000 from Clemens Muller of this city of alleged breach of promise of marriage, was again on the witness stand in Part IV. of the Supreme Court yesterday.

The obstinate contest which the Democrats of West Virginia made a year ago against the title of NATHAN GOFF to the office of Governor in that State seems to be fully justified by the result of the investigation which was instituted by the Legislature. The report of the committee shows that the most outrageous frauds were committed in several counties.

August V. Lambert of Lambert Brothers, jewelers, whose store on the southwest corner of Fifty-eighth-street and Third-avenue is the most tempting one to the dishonest on the east side above Fourteenth-street, was serving a customer at 8:10 o'clock last night when he chanced to look at the front door. He saw a wiry, ill-favored young man, flashily dressed, forcing a wooden wedge into the outside handle of the door so as to bar exit.

ALBANY, Jan. 15. -- The National Guard Association met here to-day, President Austin A. Yates of Schenectady in the chair. Resolutions were offered favoring a State service medal, to be given to every honorably-discharged soldier, condemning the knapsacks now in use by the National Guard, and advocating the blanket bags used in the United States Army. Chaplain Maynard delivered a scholarly address and eulogized the citizen soldier.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- Walker Blaine, son of Secretary James G. Blaine and Solicitor of the State Department, died early this evening from pneumonia, following an attack of la grippe.

As was to have been expected, the final disposition by Mr. HARRISON of the long-delayed Chicago appointments satisfies no one except the favored parties. Senator CULLOM is completely disappointed, and Senator FARWELL is only moderately pleased. If Mr. HARRISON had set out to get good men for the two Collectorships -Customs and Internal Revenue -- without reference to politics, the feelings of the Senators would be a matter of indifference.

There is no consideration of public interest that requires an appeal to be taken from the decision of the General Term of the Supreme Court to the Court of Appeals in the suit brought to test the validity of Gen. DUANE'S title as an Aqueduct Commissioner. On the contrary, it could only work a public injury whatever the result of the appeal might be.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 15. -- Senator Allison's extreme caution, or a similar propensity on the part of his managers, is making his Senatorial campaign an object of ridicule to all old-timers. Yesterday afternoon, when Justice Rathrock's candidacy was announced, it was decided to force the issue at once, before Rathrock's forces could organize; hence the Senatorial caucus was called for to-night.

Two hundred members of the American Society of Civil Engineers yesterday attended the opening sessions of the annual meeting held in the new and attractive hall built as an annex to the headquarters at 127 East Twenty-thirdstreet. Max J. Beaker, the President, presided, and Secretary John Bogart was at his post, as usual.

Can it be possible that Mr. PLATT, foxy old THOMAS C., has been writing compromising letters to J. SLOAT FASSETT, and that the young Tammany braves have got hold of the letters? The tale is incredible, and we insist that Mr. PLATT is entitled to a suspension of judgment until Tammany produces the letters in his handwriting.

The unpleasant weather had a bad effect on the attendance at the Clifton track yesterday. The number present was smaller than it has been in several weeks, and the racing was without particular incident. The track was deep in mud, and rain, which fell at intervals, made things decidedly uncomfortable. The Executive Committee of the Racing Association did nothing in the case of St. John, the horse who was pulled by Horton on Wednesday.

It would be too cynical to suggest that the presence on the committee of the Bar Association which has in effect recommended impeachment of Judge BOOKSTAVER of so many lawyers in extensive practice betokens a full confidence on the part of that body that it will succeed in getting Judge BOOKSTAVER out.

Topics for discussion at the coming convention of the National Guard Association of the United States, which assembles in Washington on Feb. 5, have been forwarded to the Adjutant General of the several States by Col. Charles E. Bridge, Corresponding Secretary, as follows:
HARTFORD, Jan. 15. -- The Connecticut Grand Lodge of Masons commenced its one hundred and second annual session here this afternoon, Grand Master J.H. Swartwout of Stamford presiding.

ALBANY, Jan. 15. -- Thomas C. Platt deified, Gov. Hill rebuked again by his own party, and the daily disturbance between the Republican and Democratic Senators were the features of the Senate to-day. Vedder deified Platt, and the old triangular fight between Vedder, Fassett, and Cantor took up two hours of valuable time.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15.--A rule has been entered by Judge Gresham in the Federal Court requiring the officers and Directors of the Meade Van Bokkelen Company to submit to an examination before a Master in Chancery. This action grows out of certain discoveries made by Thomas Parker, Jr., receiver of the corporation.
ALBANY, Jan. 15.--The twenty-third annual report of the New-York State Board of Charities has been transmitted to the Legislature.

That is rather a queer announcement the cable makes, that several European statesmen have been remonstrating with Lord SALISBURY on his action on the Portuguese question, upon the ground that that action "would afford a pretext for republican activity in Spain and Portugal." It is not clear what "republican activity" could do to improve the condition of Portugal.

The usual crowd was in attendance at the Guttenberg track yesterday, where six races were run, the only pronounced favorite to win being Drumstick in the fourth race. The others went to horses who were well backed in the betting, however, so that the public got a good share of the money that was wagered on the result.

BOSTON, Jan. 16. -- Prof. Pickering of Harvard University discredits the Vienna cable of Tuesday which stated that "the Star of Bethlehem is again to be visible this year, being its seventh appearance since the birth of Christ." He says:

The message of Gov. Hill to the New-York Legislature declaring against the Australian or "official" ballot will create no surprise among those who have watched the career of this New-York politician. His conception of politics would lead him to oppose all kinds of reform, but especially any changes looking to the protection of the ballot box against fraud.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 16. -- At no previous time in the history of the Democratic Party in Ohio, when they were supposed to have control of affairs, have they been so handicapped as now. Virtually, neither house has had a quorum since the commencement of the session, and as time passes by, with the illness of members on the one hand and the death of others, their embarrassment increases.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- The Ways and Means Committee has at last reached the end of its formal hearings on tariff questions preliminary to the preparation of a bill to revise the present tariff laws. It is quite likely that a few persons who may ask for special hearings will be heard informally, but there will be no more public sittings.

The militia bill of Mr. MCKENNA is a simple substitute for a mass of obsolete legislation now on the statute books. It divides the able-bodied male citizens between the ages of eighteen and forty-five into two classes, organized and reserve militia, and accepts as the former class the armed and uniformed State forces now maintained.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16. -- Chicago is going to erect another million-dollar hotel The site has already been leased for ninety-nine years, and the stock, exactly $1,000,000, has all been taken, except $85,000 worth. This balance will doubtless be subscribed to-morrow, and application will be made to the Secretary of State for a charter.

The new Republican County Committee, which has 710 members, met in Nilsson Hall last night, but as in the case of last year's committee it was prevented from perfecting organization by the contention over the primary election in the fighting Fifth District. The Executive Committee met at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel in the afternoon and cut out the work for the evening's meeting, and the programme thus arranged was followed in every detail.

It is suggested that the proposed appropriation by Congress to mark the Confederate lines at Gettysburg will arouse the ire of the Grand Army post in Pittsburg, which lately denounced the monument set up to a Maryland organization in LEE'S army at that battle, and of others that take similar views about Confederate memorials on that field.

Since the beginning of the tariff hearings the majority members of the Ways and Means Committee have frequently heard appeals for higher duties and "more protection" from manufacturers who have been denounced by the high-tariff press as the "deadly enemies of the protective policy."

CITY OF MEXICO, Jan. 7. -- The Government has a distinct Eastern foreign policy, which was first disclosed by the liberal treaty of commerce, negotiated through Senor Romero in Washington, with the diplomatic representative of Japan, by which the advantages and privileges secured for Mexican subjects are decidedly substantial.

Perhaps the most interesting question in our politics at the present time is whether the Democratic Party is to go forward or backward, whether it is to pursue a reform policy or a reactionary policy. There have been for some years decided indications of a reform tendency in the party, but will it persist and become controlling upon its action? There are hopeful signs in many quarters, while there are discouraging ones in other quarters.

The Beethoven String Quartet deserves the thanks of the musical public for bringing forward at its second concert, in Chickering Hall last evening, two really Interesting and agreeable novelties. New chamber music that is worth hearing is so rare in these days that it should be received with special favor. The works made known here last night were Fibich's string quartet in G major, Opus 8, and Klughardt's piano quintet in G minor, Opus 43.

WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 16. -- The Superior Court of this county, by the unanimous opinion of its three Judges, has denied the motion made by Senator Higgins and William C. Spruance at the instance of a number of Republican politicians for a writ of mandamus compelling Tax Collector John J. Dougherty to issue tax receipts to them in liberal quantities by virtue of powers of attorney.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 16. -- Miss Laura Dixon, who shot herself in the temple last night, died at 1 o'clock this afternoon. She was doubtless deranged at the time, as the result of a quarrel she had the night before with George Weimar, her former lover. He and Miss Dixon had been engaged to be married, but they quarreled some months ago, and Weimar married a New-Brunswick girl.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Jan. 16. -- The fourth session of the Sixth Parliament of Canada was opened this afternoon.
ALBANY, Jan. 16. -- The following banking institution reports for the half year ended Dec. 31 have been filed with the Banking Department: UNITED STATES TRUST COMPANY OF NEW-YORK.

PANAMA, Jan. 16, via Galveston. -- The President of the committee which is studying the canal works in an interview with a Star and Herald reporter said the committee had found the condition of the works and plant extremely satisfactory. He denies the statement that the committee, five members of which are here, is or has been in any way influenced by the de Lesseps party.

Henry M. Jackson, who startled the officers and clerks in the United States Sub-Treasury in this city about two years ago, by deserting his post as paying teller there and decamping with a single ten-thousand-dollar gold certificate, when he could just as well have taken a million dollars, was arrested yesterday in the Allman House. Fourth-avenue and Tenth-street, by Secret Service Officer William H. Forsyth of Special Agent Brooks's staff.

CONCORD, N.H., Jan. 16. -- The Republicans of this State were never in quite so panicky a mood as at present. They felt the gathering storm which engulfed them and swept the Democrats into power in 1871 and 1873, but the clouds to-day are thicker and blacker, and the thunder peals far more ominous than then.

Surrogate Ransom and Judge O'Brien, in the Supreme Court, yesterday signed formal orders, and an end was made to the litigation over the Stewart estate. In the Surrogate's Court the petition of Rosalie Butler, praying for a revocation of the probate of Mrs. Cornelia M. Stewart's will, was withdrawn. In the Supreme Court the action of Mrs. Sarah N. Smith against Judge Hilton was discontinued.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16. -- The non-partisan element of the Pennsylvania Woman's Christian Temperance Union met in convention here to-day for the purpose of discussing the advisability of forming an independent organization. The address of the temporary President, Mrs. Harry White of Indiana County, which was read, declared:

Cooper Union has seldom contained a more intelligent or enthusiastic audience than was assembled there last night to urge along the cause of ballot reform. Every available seat in the large auditorium was occupied, and men stood two and three rows deep in the lobby. There were representatives of every shade of political opinion present except the Hill stripe.

" In appointments to every grade and department," said BENJAMIN HARRISON in his letter of acceptance, "fitness and not party service should be the essential and discriminating test, and fidelity and efficiency the only sure tenure of office." Up in the Twenty-third District the sturdy Republicans understand the precise worth of this virtuous observation.

The feature in yesterday's doings at the County Court House was the now famous Cammerer-Muller breach of promise case. A big crowd, which the officers had to handle rather roughly, struggled to get into Part IV. of the Supreme Court. Only a comparatively small proportion of the whole succeeded, but among the lucky ones were a score of well-dressed women.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16. -- The color line was drawn pretty sharply to-day in the Palmer House barber's shop. One of the colored delegates to the Afro-American Congress had gone in to get shaved. The seats were all occupied when he entered, but he patiently awaited his turn, and when one of the barbers shouted "Next," he arose and took his seat in the vacant chair. But he did not get his shave.

As might have been expected the election of Mr. CALVIN S. BRICE to the Senate from Ohio has revived the talk, for it can no longer be called a discussion, about the degeneration of that body into a millionaires' club. It was very likely Mr. BRICE that the vigorous and impulsive Mr. ALLEN O. MYERS had in view when he warned the Democrats in the Legislature not to send a millionaire to the Senate.

Archbishop Corrigan, who sails for Europe on the French steamer La Bourgogne to-morrow, was tendered a reception last evening at the Lenox Lyceum, Fifty-ninth-street and Madison-avenue, by his parishioners and friends generally without regard to creed. There were present many officials of the City Government, representatives of the judiciary, all the pastors of the Archdiocese of New-York, scores of prominent citizens and great numbers of handsomely dressed ladies.

For the last two days there h-'ve been in see* sion in the big hall of the Masonic Temple nearly two thousand one hundred dentists from all parts of the country attmnding the twentyfirst anniversary of the First Dental Dxstrlct of the State of Now-York. Last night the meetln was brought to a close by a pleasant dinner at Clark's restaurant, in West Twonty-third-treet,

LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 16. -- H. Boswell of this county has sold for $6,000 to S. Gamble of San Francisco, Cal., the bay brood mare Nancy Lee, twelve years, by Dictator, dam by Alexander's Edwin Forrest. She is noted as being the dam of the phenomenal filly Nancy Hanks, unbeaten.
BOSTON, Jan 16. -- At the meeting of the Committee on the Regulation of Harvard Athletic Sports, it was unanimously voted:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- The report of the Committee on Rules in favor of the creation of a special committee on World's Fair legislation was the cause of an interesting and earnest fight in the House to-day, which will be resumed to-morrow with increased interest by the advocates of both the competing propositions.

For the second time in its history Plymouth Church of Brooklyn has installed a pastor, but the scene in the Sunday-school room yesterday morning when the council organized to question the Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott, and to listen to his exposition of his religious belief, was very different from that in 1847, when Henry Ward Beecher assumed formal control of the new church.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 16 -- Notwithstanding the determined fight made against it by State Auditor Col. F.G. Ruffin, the Senate Committee on Railroads to-day reported with amendments, Col. H.C. Parsons's bill to incorporate the Colombian and South American Navigation Company. This is the scheme which Col. Parsons has started with the view of getting up a company to construct a railway across South America, connecting with steamships on the coast.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- The special House committee appointed to investigate the Ohio ballot-box forgery began its work this morning with all the members present except Representative Struble, who is suffering from the grip.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16. -- The creditors of R. Deimel Brothers this morning secured an order from Judge Collins which removes another obstacle placed by the insolvents in the way of an investigation. The insolvents owned half of the stock in the Leo Austrian Co. corporation, manufacturers of special articles of furniture. Attorney Levi Mayer called on Mr. Austrian to testify, but that gentleman, an advice of his attorney, Allan C. Storey, declined.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 16, -- The Mowatt will case was rushed to a finish by noon to-day. Lucy and Annie McFarland of Brooklyn testified they heard bliss Mowat say at their house that she would not give her nephews a cent and would not see them.

NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 16. -- When the class in mechanical drawing at Sheffield Scientific School entered the recitation room at noon to-day, Secretary Brush appeared instead of Prof. Honey, with whom the students had had some trouble about the buying of instruments.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16. -- A meeting of the Johnstown Flood Relief Commission, appointed to distribute the funds contributed for the relief of the sufferers by the flood in the Conemaugh Valley and in other parts of Pennsylvania, was held in the Manufacturers' Club Building, this city, to-day.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16. -- The early weak Liverpool cable to the Board of Trade counted for very little this morning, as John J. Bryant was buying all the wheat he could get hold of. During the first half hour he bought at least 1,100,000 bushels from Pardridge and others, and May wheat advanced from 81.33 cents to 81.58 cents.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 16. -- Senator Parrott called the Senatorial caucus to order at 8:10 o'clock this evening, briefly announced the purpose of the gathering, and named Senator J.B. Harsh as Chairman, who was elected without opposition. Representative Chase of Hamilton was elected Secretary, and Senator Brower move to proceed to the nomination of a candidate for United States Senator by ballot.

Nihilism is not one of Corea's afflictions, but the King of that country has of late been made the object of conspiracies against his life so persistent and frequent that even the Czar of Russia might not like to exchange thrones with him. In the accounts of the most recent of these attempts two Court officials are mentioned as among the conspirators.

The portrait of Benjamin Franklin, which was painted when that good old patriot was Minister to France, hung in the big ballroom of the Hotel Brunswick last night, with its ancient frame encircled with smilax. Below it sat President W.C. Martin, whose years have not yet deprived him of the pleasure of celebrating Franklin's birthday with his fellow Typothetae.

Two little plays translated from the French afforded a chance last night to measure the talents of an actress from Germany who appears never to have acted before in New-York. Light comedy by Scribe and Fournier may not offer many opportunities for declamation, but they show well enough whether an actor knows the stage or not.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 17. -- This afternoon the General Term of the Supreme Court was given up to an attempt to disbar Marvin Smith of Jamestown. Four hours were spent in reading affidavits, and many of these documents were of a highly interesting character. Mr. Smith says politics is at the bottom of the attempt.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 17. -- Senator Allison is still in the city looking serene and contented, and evidently quite well satisfied with the nomination the Republican caucus gave him last night. This afternoon he visited the floor of the House and took a seat on the Republican side, where he was surrounded by a number of party friends. Mr. Allison said he did not know when he would return to Washington.

UTICA, N.Y., Jan. 17. -- The Postmastership question in this city has become an interesting one and is a general topic of conversation. E.P. Bailey, editor of the Observer, a discreetly Democratic paper, is the present incumbent, having been appointed by President Cleveland three years ago next St. Patrick's Day. Mr. Bailey has made the best of Postmasters and his administration has been characterized by energy and enterprise.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Jan. 17. -- Merchants, ranchmen, cowboys, and even gamblers have contributed to the $2,000 fund which has been offered for the arrest and delivery to the committee anywhere in Johnson County, of Archie McCoomb, a range worker supposed to have brutally murdered Edna Wilson last October. The girl was the daughter of one of the first families of a prosperous agricultural and grazing region.

WORCESTER, Mass., Jan. 17. -- P.L. Labelle, a clerk employed by J.G. Vaudreuil, contractor, of 90 Foster-street, is missing, as is the sum of $800, which he has embezzled. He was engaged at a salary of $9 a week, and seemed to be attending to his duties faithfully.
