This surmise has rapidly developed to conviction upon reading the text of the treaty negotiated at Berlin last June, and now before the Senate for ratification.

As there has been a great immigration of jewelers into New-York during the last few days to attend the annual trade meetings which were held here Tuesday, what could be more in keeping with the general good-fellowship of the dealers in diamonds and the decorators of the race, as represented by the New-York Jewelers' Board of Trade, to entertain their visitors at Delmonico's last night?

NORRISTOWN, Penn., Jan. 22. -- Announcement is made here that the historic Revolutionary camp ground of Valley Forge, six miles to the west, in Chester County, will soon be sold by its present owners in the shape of building lots.

LONDON, Jan. 22. -- Mr. Gladstone, speaking at Chester, declined to criticise the course of the Marquis of Salisbury in the dispute with Portugal until he was more fully informed as to the details of the case.

Harper for February has for its first article an account of England's standing army by one wholly competent to write it, Gen. Wolsely, who is rapidly becoming a well-known contributor to American periodical literature. This paper touches upon a great variety of topics suggested by the theme, and will be widely read, not only by army men but by readers in general.

When the Boston League Club induced Tucker, the first baseman, to desert the Brooklyn Brotherhood Club Capt. Ward set about to find a man suitable to fill the position. He looked over the field very carefully and finally selected Dave 0rr. The latter is New-York player, but he was engaged by Columbus last season and reserved by that club.

The dispatch published in THE TIMES from Chicago yesterday describing the mismanagement of the agency in that city of the Phenix Fire Insurance Company of Brooklyn by T.R. Burch gave insurance men in this city considerable to talk about. The general opinion, however, was that it would not interfere with the business of the corporation, which is now declared to be in excellent condition.
A cablegram received from London yesterday was taken by a great many shipping men as a pretty sure indication that the National Line steamship Erin had gone down. Said the dispatch:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- To-day was devoted by the House Committee on the Merchant Marine and Fisheries to a public hearing on the question of subsidies to American merchant vessels engaged in the foreign trade. There were present S.W. Carey, Charles Watrous, George E. Weed, William Rowland, W.H.T. Hughes, Aaron Vanderbilt, H.K. Thurber, Capt. Lackland, and Ambrose Snow or New-York: H.T. Gause of Wilmington, Irving M. Scott and C.N. Felton of California.

BOSTON, Jan. 22. -- The tenth annual meeting of the National Divorce Reform League was held here to-day. The Executive Committee, Treasurer, and Corresponding Secretary presented their reports. The Treasurer's report showed receipts of $2,388, expenditures of $2,603, and a debt of $197.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 22. -- Unless the half hundred or more flint glass manufacturers in Pittsburg and what is known as the Western District change their tactics there promises to be a strike of all the bottle blowers employed in their factories. It appears that the blowers have been working on Eastern molds for some time past without knowing that they were doing so.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22. -- The steamship Ohio, Capt. Sargent, of the American Line, arrived here from Liverpool to-day after a voyage lasting nineteen days. Capt. Sargent said it was the most tempestuous voyage across the Atlantic he had ever made, being a continuous struggle against furious gales, which at times blew with the force of a hurricane.
The following business was transacted at the Exchange and Auction Room yesterday, Wednesday, Jan. 22:

ALBANY, Jan. 22. -- The annual election of the New-York State Agricultural Society to-day developed several remarkable features. In the first place Gov. Hill attempted several weeks ago to capture the organization and add it to his growing political machine by securing proxies through James O. Woodward by trick and device. Woodward, whose name is similar to that of the regular Secretary, sent for proxies for Lawrence J. Fitzgerald for President.

The discussion in the New-York Presbytery on the proposed revision of the Westminster Confession of Faith went on at the Scotch Church from 3 o'clock to 5:30 yesterday afternoon. There was a good attendance and all the speeches were attentively listened to. Each speaker occupied the full twenty minutes allowed him, and all spoke with an earnestness of manner that betokened conviction and feeling.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 22. -- News was received this morning from Fishomingo, Chickasaw Nation, of a prospective outbreak between the Byrd and Guy factions, known as the National and Progressive Parties. William Byrd is the present Governor. He ran against William Guy in 1888. A contest followed and was carried to Washington, the Interior Department finally declaring Byrd legally elected.

ON BOARD THE ATLANTA, SQUADRON OF EVOLUTION, TANGIER, Morocco, Jan. 3. -- Getting under way at 3:30 P.M. on the last day of the old year, and parting company off Cape Roca with the Enterprise the squadron of evolution proceeded on its way to the country of the Moors. At dawn of the new year Cape St. Vincent and long coast line, historic in naval annals, were visible.

Kentucky Prince's get are being sought after largely, and Charles Backman of the famous Stony Ford Farm recently paid $1,100 for a yearling filly by him, out of Hattie C., a Messenger Duroe mare, owned by T.L. Millspaugh of Orange County, N.Y.

ALBANY, Jan. 22. -- The State Bar Association closed its meeting to-day. The following officers were elected for the coming year: President -- Matthew Hale of Albany; Vice President First District -- William H. Arnoux; Second District -- William H. Robertson; Third District -- C.P. Collier; Fourth District -- John D. Wardell; Fifth District -- A.H. Sawyer; Sixth District -- S.D. Halliday; Seventh District -- James H. Stearns.

After crying for cold weather for nearly three months New-York had a dose yesterday morning which almost turned its complainings in the other direction. The fall in temperature was accompanied by a rise in the wind, which blew steadily all day and occasionally with such force as to make it extremely disagreeable to pedestrians.

BRUNSWICK, Ga., Jan. 22. -- The flood of last June destroyed the great axe factories of this country, and, as no axes appear to have been imported, it is discovered that there is a shortage in these implements. In the southern part of this State, along Savannah Bay, this fact is causing heavy loss of business and depriving hundreds of employment.

NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 22. -- The concluding important events of promenade week at Yale were the Junior german held this evening at Alumni Hall and the Senior german at Loomis Hall. About sixty couples took part in the Junior german, George S. Brewster leading with Miss Curtiss of New-York. Lander's orchestra of New-York furnished music, and Mazetti of New-York was the caterer.

Commissioner Thomas F. Gilroy was very wroth yesterday over what purported to be an interview with Stevenson Towle, the engineer in charge of paving of the Department of Public Works, that had appeared in the Evening Post of the day before. Mr. Gilroy said that if Mr. Towle had given utterance to any such sentiments as were imputed to him he had spoken foolishly and without warrant.

LONDON, Jan. 22. -- Nothing has been published here in regard to the report that the Bank of England had recently been a heavy purchaser of silver bullion, and was contemplating the issue of pound notes, redeemable in silver, as soon as the necessary authority could be obtained.

Mayor Gleason's efforts to put his elephantine foot on a 150-pound school Principal over in Long Island City are going on right merrily. It is nearly a month since charges were preferred by the burly Hibernian Chief Executive of the town of stenches against A. Hall Burdick, who has been for over two years in charge or the First Ward school.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Jan. 22. -- The publication of the Toronto Empire's expose to-day of the attempt of the Toronto Mail to encourage the annexation movement in Washington, as a result of the recent visit of their special Commissioner to Washington, has caused a great sensation at the Dominion capital.

William Bresford is of patrician parentage, but he is the terror of Eighteenth-street, and the manner in which he uses that more or less important street for his own delectation and amusement is a matter of local indignation. There have been all sorts of attacks upon him, politically and individually, but thus far he has held undisputed sway over the destinies of the children and the nurse girls of the locality.
WINCHESTER, Va., Jan. 22. -- A message from Woodstock this evening says that ex-Senator Riddleberger is no better, but he may linger for several days.

The amateur boxers who have been furnishing amusement for members of athletic clubs in this vicinity of late will give another entertainment on Saturday evening in Parepa Hall, Eighty-sixth-street and Third-avenue. The occasion will be the annual boxing tournament of the Pastime Athletic Club, and the entries in the various classes are numerous.

BRISTOL, R.I., Jan. 22. -- The launch of the new United States torpedo boat Cushing was prevented this morning by the presence of a strong northwest gale of wind. All arrangements had been perfected for getting the boat off the ways by 9:10 A.M., and in anticipation of the event numerous cards of invitation had been sent out by the Herreshoff Manufacturing Company.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 22. -- The State Grocers' Assoaiation met in this city to-day and took steps toward perfecting the laws affecting their interests. The meeting was attended by delegates from over a dozen cities of the State, including Newark, Jersey City, Paterson, New-Brunswick, Passaic, Trenton, Plainfield, Westfield, Atlantic City, Rahway, and Bridgeton.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 22. -- About 2 o'clock this morning a fire broke out in the rear of the oyster stand, 6 Baronne-street, and situated in the three-story brick building 6, 8, and 10 Baronne-street, formerly known as the Pelican, then the Terry House, which rapidly spread, the net work of electric, telephone, and telegraph wires running parallel to the building delaying and obstructing the operations of the Fire Department.

The protest of Mr. GEORGE S. COE at the Commonwealth Club, on Tuesday evening, against Government interference with the finance of private citizens was manly and timely. Mr. COE has been for more than a quarter of a century recognized in New-York as a leader among the small number of able and upright men who have made finance not only their daily occupation, but the subject of patient and intelligent study.
BOSTON, Jan. 22. -- The award of Bowdoin prizes at Harvard for 1889-90 has been made as follows:

That part of the congregation of All Souls' Church composed of the members of the Church of the Holy Spirit, which recently consolidated with if, assembled in force at All Souls' last evening to witness the marriage of their former assistant rector, the Rev. Henry R. Freeman, now of St. Mark's Church at Islip, L.I., to Miss Fannie Ethel Herendeen, daughter of Mrs. James W. Johnston.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 22. -- The iron and steel manufacturers of the Pittsburg district are still enjoying the large business which characterized the close of 1889. The only trouble in the leading iron mills is an insufficient supply of raw material There are nearly a dozen plants where this is the principal reason why one or more trains or rolls have to be indefinitely changed from double to single turn.

The annual meeting of the Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association of this city was held yesterday afternoon, Jan. 30, 1889, at its offices in the Potter Building commencing at 1:30 o'clock, the President of the association, Mr. E.B. Harper, in the chair.

ALBANY, Jail 22. -- The figures in the report of the State Railroad Commission, just finished, permit of interesting study. The gross earnings or the companies operating their lines within this State are thus tabulated:

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 22. -- The Republicans made another ineffectual attempt to break the Democratic lines in the House to-day. After five ballots had been taken for temporary Clerk, with a tie resulting in each case, Mr. Blythe, Republican, arose and stated at length the objections the Republicans had to accepting the Democratic compromise proposition submitted to the House on Monday.

Another revolver-fiourishin idiot put a bullet into an inoffensive companion's brain yesterday, and now lies in the Eldridge-street police station on a charge of homicide. He is John Popoff, a Russian, twenty-four years of age, of 163 Stanton-street, and his victim is Miriam Petrokoffsky, a comely Russian Jewess, nineteen years of age, who lived at 141 East Broadway.

There has very seldom been seen any outbreak of national feeling so violent as that of the Portuguese against England which has not resulted in actual war. Of course, war with England in Africa, or in any distant part of the world, would be perfectly hopeless for Portugal, and would be a matter for very thoughtful consideration on the part of any power whatever.

The opinion of Attorney General MILLER, holding that the decision of the United States Supreme Court in the Watson case cannot be construed as reopening claims for longevity pay which had already been settled without getting the benefit of that decision, has made many army officers indignant.
The New-York Herald has done for Gov. Abbett, who was inaugurated in Trenton to-day, the questionable service of publishing his message in advance of its delivery to the New-Jersey Legislature.

The "prominent Republican" who remarked of Mr. REED yesterday to a correspondent of the Post that "it was a mistake probably to express the party's gratitude to a successful guerrilla chieftain by making him a Judge," was much too severe in his characterization of the Speaker, and was not entirely correct in his statement of the facts. Mr. REED was not chosen Speaker as an expression of party gratitude.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- C.P. Huntington, Vice President of the Central Pacific Railroad, was to-day accorded a hearing by the House Committee on Pacific Railroads, on the indebtedness of the Pacific roads to the Government. He said that the Central Pacific cost about three times as much as railroads usually cost, because the materials for construction had to be carried around Cape Horn.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Jan. 21. -- Salts, the man who was stunned by the electricity at the same time that Thomas Dawson was killed yesterday, is confined to his bed on account of the shock to his nervous system. Dr. Wooley is attending him, and says he does not anticipate serious results.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 23. -- The docket of the United States District Court has for some time been burdened with a number of cases based on naturalization frauds. George D. Reynolds, the recently-appointed District Attorney, has conducted these cases so as to be defeated in every one that has been brought to trial.

CANTON, Ohio, Jan. 23. -- United States Senator Quay, not content with his position as the sole patronage broker in Pennsylvania, has crossed the line into Ohio and is taking a hand in the Canton Postmastership contest. This is the home of Major William McKinley and it had been presumed that the distinguished Republican would be conceded the honor of naming the man.
ALBANY, Jan. 23. -- The annual report of Controller Wemple was transmitted to the Legislature to-day. Following is an abstract of the document:

ALBANY, Jan. 23. -- One of the most interesting and entertaining hearings that has taken place in Albany for several years occurred this afternoon before the Senate Committee on General Laws, on the Saxton Ballet Reform bill. Two advocates of the bill appeared, Senator Charles T. Saxton, its introducer, and Mr. William M. Ivins of New-York.

The wind blew cold and sharp over the Guttenberg track yesterday, but there was a good crowd present in spite of it, and the betting was lively on each race. The favorites were successful in the first three races, but later they were outfooted. The results were as follows:

CHICAGO, Jan. 23. -- Provisions opened stronger to-day and decidedly active, but later eased off under free sales by longs and for speculative short account. These offerings were absorbed at the decline and the market recovered most of the loss, at the same time regaining to a large degree its tone. Still later its values again eased down, and closing quotations were at or near the bottom.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- The discussion in the meeting to-day of the House Special Committee on the World's Fair was interesting in drawing from Mr. Hitt of Illinois the expression that it would be impossible to construct a general bill that would carry out the object for which the committee was formed, until it has been decided where the fair shall be held.

We seem to have reached the point where no one holding a representative position in political or official life any longer openly opposes ballot reform. Opposition takes the form of objections to certain details in the proposed plan of reform. Some of these are worthy of particular consideration. It has been objected to the Saxton bill that it does not provide for a general registration of voters throughout the State.

Lawyer Frank J. Keller, accused by Joseph Weldon, a client, of having taken $125 and then deserting him, attempted vainly to satisfy Justice Kilbreth at the Tombs Court yesterday that he had acted honorably. Weldon was the manager of a store at 18 Tenth-avenue, and was employed by a Mr. Gulke. He appropriated $118 of Gulke's money, and on Dec. 15, when charged with the theft, admitted and promised to make restitution.

The tenth annual meeting of the National Divorce Reform League has just been held in Boston. It must be owned that this body has not very much in the way of practical results to show for its ten years of work. It does report, and doubtless truthfully, a very great increase of public interest in the subject, but of this interest the league itself is much more a consequence than a cause.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 23. -- The Hon. Clinton L. Clark of Ottawa, an ex-member of the Canadian Legislature, while in Pittsburg to-day gave some interesting information about the scheme to ship American cattle to the seaboard over Canadian railroads exclusively. He said the project was one of the biggest known in Canada for years.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Jan. 21. -- The nineteenth annual report of the New-York State Homeopathic Asylum for the Insane, situated in this city, is made public. This institution, of which Mr. Fletcher Harper of Harper Brothers is President and Dr. Selden H. Talcott is Medical Superintendent, is the pioneer hospital in this country for treating insanity in conformity with the principles enunciated by Hahnemann.

The Red Star steamship Rhynland arrived late yesterday from Antwerp, after the stormiest passage which she has yet experienced. None of her officers can remember such severe weather during the last thirty years.

The Hon. Seth Low, the newly-chosen President of Columbia College, was the honored guest at a dinner and reception given to him by his fellow-members of the Hamilton Club in the clubhouse of that organization, corner of Clinton and Remsen streets, Brooklyn, last evening. About 250 gentlemen sat down to a dinner which it took more than three hours to discuss.

ALBANY, Jan. 23. -- The garrulous and extravagant Senate has let loose among the corporations, and at the expense of the taxpayers, the fourth investigating committee. Out of the four it is questionable whether one has been formed purely in the interest of the people, or for the pro-protection of the State.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Jan. 23. -- British Columbians are waging war vigorously against the Chinese. They want the poll tax levied on the Chinamen doubled. Mr. Mara, member of Parliament for Yale, to-day presented a petition on this subject in the House of Commons. The petition is signed by several thousands of the leading business men and employers of labor in the province.

At the session of the Harbor Line Board, of which Gen. Henry L. Abbot is President in the Army Building yesterday, owners of property on the East River from Grand-street to Bushwick Creek and the Gowanus Bay district, extending from Twenty-seventh to Fortieth street, South Brooklyn, were afforded an opportunity to present their views in opposition to the contemplated changes in the harbor line.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 23. -- The Court House here was packed to-day when the prosecutor moved the indictments against Justice of the Peace Joseph Hayter, who is also Coroner and court interpreter, against Thomas Tenneson, the Democratic judge of election, and Matthew Reed, a Republican inspector at the first poll, Sixth Ward.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- The public hearing on the question of the payment of subsidies to American ships engaged in the foreign trade by the United States Government was continued before the House Committee on the Merchant Marine and the Fisheries to-day. Among the gentlemen present in addition to those mentioned yesterday were William P. Clyde of New-York and Mr. Charles H. Cramp of Chester, Penn.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23. -- The publication of the facts in the case of the Phoenix Fire Insurance Company has created a profound impression among insurance men here. It has also resulted in closing the mouths of persons in Chicago who were conversant with much of the internal workings of the office, and who at first were not altogether unwilling to talk about the matter.

Meetings of the stockholders of the Metropolitan and Manhattan Elevated Railway Companies are called for Feb. 26 for the purpose of sanctioning a proposed creation of a blanket mortgage of $40,000,000 on the present system of roads and of $600,000 a mile on double track and $300,000 a mile on single track of extensions of the system hereafter to be made.

There seemed to be a general impression that yesterday's debate at the session of the Presbytery would be livelier than any which had yet taken place. The reports of remarks verging upon personal attacks which had been uttered at Wednesday's session made many people think that there would be still more definite outbreaks in the course of the discussion yesterday.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 23. -- A dead telephone wire fell across the wires of the Pleasant Valley Street Railway Company this morning and treated people to a rare electrical display, for twenty minutes completely blocking traffic on Smithfield-street, the main thoroughfare of the city. A large crowd assembled to witness the antics of the wires. Sparks of fire flew in all directions, melting the snow and burning all the wood with which they came in contact.

The Rev. Albert van Puttkamer, a retired Baptist clergyman who identified his kinsman, Robert von Puttkamer, in Bellevue Hospital, has himself had an interesting and remarkable career as a soldier, clergyman, church organizer, and patriot warrior of his adopted country. He is now living at the Baptist Ministers' Home at West Farms, and it was there that a TIMES reporter called on him yesterday.

The announcement of the approaching sale of the old Revolutionary camping ground at Valley Forge in building lots apparently disposes of the suggestion to set it apart for public uses. Patriotic memories certainly cluster about the spot, and the sufferings of WASHINGTON'S soldiers during the earlier part of its occupation by them have often been depicted.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- Secretary Wisdom has written a letter to the Hon. William F. Frye, Chairman of the Senate Committee on Commerce, in regard to the Alaska seal fisheries, in which he says:

BRISTOL, R.I., Jan. 23. -- At precisely 9:45 o'clock this morning, with a word from Superintendent Nat G. Herreshoff and a stroke or two upon the hydraulic jack, the cradle which bore the handsome hull of the United States torpedo boat No. 1 began to slide down the ways toward the sheet of water that makes into the shore at the Herreshoff Shipbuilding Works.

Early yesterday morning the thermometer had fallen to 15 above zero -- 3 colder than on the preceding day -- and early pedestrians found the wind still strong enough to pick up all particles of dust neglected by the gale of the day before and give them lodgment in the ears, eyes, and nostrils of those who were unlucky enough to be abroad.

BOSTON, Jan. 23. -- The new Graduate Advisory Committees in Harvard football and baseball have been chosen. The Baseball Committee is: Samuel E. Winslow, '85, Chairman; Prof. J.W. White, '77, and William Thayer, '80. The choice of Mr. Winslow as Chairman of this committee is generally regarded with favor among both graduates and undergraduates.
" I arrest you in the name of the State of New-York!" shouted a thick-set little man yesterday morning in front of the Astor House.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- Vice-President and Mrs. Morton gave a dinner party to-night, at which twenty-five guests were entertained. The centre piece on the dinner table was of ferns, with silver stands of hybrid roses at either end. Bouquets of Duchess of Albany roses lay at the place for each lady present. In the large open hearth burned a fire of logs.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23. -- When a prominent citizen dies it is a pretty safe conjecture that he was born in the East, with the chances in favor of New-York State. But there are a good many natives of the Empire State who are still living in Chicago and 200 of them have formed an association under the name of "The Sons of New-York."

Only one regret obtains among the people who attended the annual banquet of the second panel of the Sheriff's jury at Delmonico's last night, and that is that a year must elapse before the second panel can hold another banquet. The dinner was excellent in quality and service, the wines were plentiful even for a banquet of the second panel, and the speeches were as light and sparkling as the champagne.

ALBANY, Jan. 23. -- The World's Fair bill will reach here to-morrow morning. By an arrangement between the leading members of the committee in New-York it was decided that the bill shall be introduced in the House by a Democrat, Mr. Sheehan of Buffalo, and in the Senate by a Republican, perhaps Mr. Stewart of New-York.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the following nominations:

G. De Cordova Co., shipping and commission merchants at 2 and 4 Stone-street, who have been placed in the hands of a receiver, owe about $200,000, with nominal assets about the same. The firm was composed of Gonzalvo De Cordova and Winchester B. Smith as general partners, and Fred Berenbroick as special partner for $10,000 to Dec. 7, 1890.
TRENTON, Jan. 21. -- In his inaugural message to-day Gov. Leon Abbett, the Democratic Governor of New-Jersey, took decided ground on the subject of ballot reform. Following is his language:

It is evident that prompt action upon the World's Fair bill at Albany will greatly facilitate the efforts of the New-York delegation at Washington to secure the international exhibition for this city. These efforts are not really in behalf of any special advantage to New-York, but in behalf of the success of the exhibition, and it is for the same patriotic object that the State Legislature should act.

Park Commissioner J. Hampden Robb's resolution requiring all applicants for places in the Park Department, not covered by the civil service rules, to obtain a certificate of fitness from the Superintendent of Central Park or the Superintendents of the Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Wards before they can be appointed, was lost on a tie vote at the meeting of the Park Board yesterday.
In your issue of the 13th, J.B. McKibbon, President of the Fruit Growers' Union of Florida, in an interview with your representative respecting the control of the orange trade of the State, says:
VIENNA, Jan. 24. -- A terrific storm is raging all over Central Austria. There has been a heavy snowfall in Bohemia.

The Portuguese ought to be told that they are making a very unseemly spectacle of themselves. To plead discoveries of the fifteenth century, not followed by any real occupation of the lands discovered, as a reason why nobody else should now occupy and improve what has remained a wilderness, is a proceeding that finds no warrant in international law or in common sense.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24. -- There were placed in the steel cell in the United States Marshal's office this morning ten sailors who had been taken from the bark Jennie Harkness, which was docked at the foot of Bainbridge-street this morning after an exciting voyage from the Philippine Islands. The names of the ten seamen are: Osher Holston, William Shea, John Skoolgond, William Hale, C. Jansen, Henrique Gonzales, John Hanson, Peter Ingbergsten, I. Carlson, Charles Lax.

Prof. W.H. Farnam of Yale College, the principal owner of the New-Haven Morning News, is the defendant in a suit brought in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, by Mrs. Catherine Goldey of 10 Clymer-street, Brooklyn, to recover $100,000 damages for libel The papers were served on him a few days ago while he was dining at the University Club, in this city.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- Mr. Gardiner G. Hubbard to-day made an argument before the House Committee on the Judiciary in opposition to the International Copyright bill. He appeared in behalf of the public, he said, which was largely interested in the pending bill. The works of American authors were to-day published in England as largely as the works of English authors -- Longfellow had a greater circulation than Tennyson.

The Canal and Harbor Protective Union held a mass meeting last evening at Cooper Institute to protest against the excessive wharfage charges in this city, and the excessive elevator charges here and at Buffalo. Capt. M. Depew declared that the elevator monopolists extorted from the canal men eight times as much as would be a fair charge.

LONDON, Jan. 25. -- The London News says that the Turkish Minister has been instructed to demand of the United States Government that it will suspend the publication of the Sourhantag, an American paper printed in the United States, but circulated in Armenia, and which advocates Armenian independence.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24. -- A letter from ex-President Grover Cleveland was read to-day at the concluding session of the Custom Cutters' National Convention. The full text was as follows: G.H. Huntoon Esq., President:

OTTAWA, Ontario, Jan. 24. -- A deputation waited upon Mr. Dewdney, Minister of the Interior, to-day to advocate the claims for a land grant to a new railroad from Winnipeg to the Pacific slope. The road is promoted by the Northern Pacific and Manitoba, and proposes to reach the coast by the "Mackenzie route," running in a southwest direction through Yellow Head Pass to Port Simpson, close to the Alaska boundary.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Jan. 24. -- Parliament was asked to-day by Mr. Wood, member of Parliament for Westmoreland, N.B., to double the duty on American dressed meats. He represented that Chicago firms have acquired a monopoly of the business in the maritime Provinces by the use of refrigerator cars, thus destroying the home market of the Canadian farmers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- At the hearing before the House Committee on the Merchant Marine and the Fisheries to-day, Capt. J.M. Lachlan of the New-York and Brazilian Steamship Company continued his statements begun yesterday.

Verdi's noble opera "Aida" drew another very large audience at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening in spite of the fact that Frau Lehmann was not in the cast. Her absence enabled Director Stanton to demonstrate that the resources of his house were equal to the demands of so exacting a work without one of his leading sopranos in the cast.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- The Ways and Means Committee heard some interesting statements to-day in regard to reciprocal trading with Canada.

Incoming vessels yesterday reported very heavy gales to be still raging at sea. The ship Samuel Skolfield, which was towed in by the tug C.W. Morse, presented a particularly battered appearance, her upper masts having been cut away. Her trouble had nearly all been met with some time ago. She left New-York Nov. 29, bound for Batavia with a cargo of case oil.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 24. -- The joint convention of miners this morning heard the report of the Committee on Constitution for the new organization and was engaged in the consideration of the same, section by section, till the noon hour. The name of the new organization is to be "United Mine Workers of District Assembly 135, Knights of Labor, and the National Progressive Union." A per capita tax of 5 cents per member was adopted.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 24. -- Articles of incorporation have been filed in the Secretary of State's Office for the North and South Railroad Company of Illinois, with principal office at Springfield and with a capital stock of $2,800,000, to construct and operate a line of road from Eureka, Woodford County, to Alhambra, Madison County.
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 24. -- In the Senate this morning the following committee reports were received:

The American Wool Reporter has made a careful inquiry as to the number of sets of cards represented by the signers of its two notable petitions, which were laid before the Ways and Means Committee -- one asking for free wool and the other for ad valorem duties on wool -- and has found that the entire number is 3,328.

Several journals have recently published extracts from a circular issued by a house in this city that speaks with knowledge and authority concerning the sugar trade, and one of the assertions so brought out is the following:

The New-York Presbytery spent the first quarter of an hour of its session in the Scotch Church yesterday in discussing the time of taking a vote on the proposed amendments to the creed. It was then decided that when all those who desire to speak on the question have spoken, which it was expected would be some time next week, adjournment should be taken until Monday, Feb. 3, at 3 o'clock in the afternoon.

George H. Lounsberry, cashier of the Post Office, put a bullet in his brain at his home in Hackensack, N.J., a few minutes after 7 o'clock last evening, after it had been discovered that he was a defaulter to the extent of about $24,000.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24. -- B.P. Hutchinson, or "Old Hutch," has again been robbed, and one of his settling clerks on the Board of Trade is now in Toronto, across the line, the embezzler of an amount ranging anywhere from $25,000 to $40,000.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Jan. 24. -- Democratic confidence in the outcome of the Gubernatorial contest is at a high tide to-night. Nothing could have increased it more than the utter failure of Gen. Goff to make a case while speaking in his own behalf. Through a long five hours' address he failed completely to show one fact that weighed against the mass of proofs of Republican frauds which the majority report has made public.

There have been larger and more pretentious college dinners this season than that of the Dartmouth Alumni at Delmonico's last night, but there has been none that embodied mere good-fellowship or afforded more real enjoyment. It was the twenty-sixth annual banquet or the association, and there were in attendance about one hundred members, whose class numerals spread over nearly half a century.

Breezy as a small blizzard was the original "Al" Daggett when he turned up yesterday to tell his story in the suit which Tallmadge Martin, printers, are pressing against the Republican League to get about $12,000 due for printing campaign literature in 1888.

The politicians of the time seem to be very suspicious of each other's motives and purposes. Doubtless they have reason to be. They probably understand each other, and have also the common human infirmity of judging others by themselves. Republican politicians suspect Democratic and Tammany jobbery in the Mayor's Rapid-Transit bill, and Tammany politicians are suspicious of the new Commission Rapid-Transit bill merely because Republicans have it in charge.

Instances of intentional and willful disregard and violation of the civil service laws by officials who have been given an opportunity to do so by the Harrison Administration have been by no means rare, but it is doubtful if there has been a more flagrant series of violations than those with which Donald McLean, General Appraiser of the port of New-York, is chargeable.
The Reform Club held a largely-attended meeting last evening to hear Arthur T. Hadley of Yale University on "Pools and Trusts." President Everett P. Wheeler introduced the speaker.

Mrs. Jessie Dean Reynolds, the wife of William R. Reynolds, shot herself through the heart with a 32-calibre revolver a little before 1 A.M. yesterday on the first floor of the flat 948 Ninth-avenue, where the family lived. She was an actress, both before and after marriage, under the name of "Jessie Dean."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- The Meat Products Investigating Committee, of which Senator Vest of Missouri is Chairman, resumed its sessions this morning. The committee has concluded its inquiry into everything except the railroad branch of the investigation, and the meeting this morning was for the purpose of questioning officers of several of the large railroad corporations as to the rates and facilities governing the transportation of cattle and dressed beef.

As a demonstration that Senator INGALLS is "smart," his speech in the Senate on Thursday was superfluous. He can say very biting things about people whom he dislikes, and his power of aversion seems to be of unusual promptitude, range, and versatility. The facility with which he says smart things is a source of pain to his enemies, and must be so occasionally, if not frequently, to himself.

There are fourteen Deputy Collectors of Internal Revenue in the Third Collection District who have very little faith in the present Administration's pledge that "efficiency and not party service" shall constitute a title to retention in office. Every one of them is looking around for a soft place in the sawdust into which his head may drop after the sharpened axe of the new Collector, Ferdinand Eidman. has fallen.

The suit of Mrs. Carlin, dressmaker, of 149 East Eighty-fourth-street, against Terence Leonard, furniture dealer, of 711 Eighth-avenue, for $750 and damages for personal injury, is expected to come to trial in Part II. of the Supreme Court, before Judge Lawrence, this week. J.W. Gedney appears for the plaintiff and James Campbell for the defendant.

CAN WE INCREASE SPEED IN STEAMERS. -- The possibilities of obtaining an increasing speed with steamships seem, at first sight, as limitless as the ocean on which they float; but, like all else, they must end somewhere. At one time it was supposed that there must be a limit in size, beyond which materials did not exist of sufficient strength to enable steamers to be built.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 25. -- The visible business transacted by the Iowa House to-day is briefly told. The session convened at 10:30 A.M. After prayer and reading of the Journal, on motion of Mr. Hamilton an adjournment was taken until 3 P.M. Upon reconvening at that hour a recess was taken until 4 o'clock. Another recess of a half hour followed, and upon reconvening at 4:30 the House adjourned until 10:30 A.M. on Monday.

BRAT. -- If Prof. Max Miller had been in Carlisle Police Court last Friday he would have heard a witness let fall a single small word, which, in its meaning and connection, would have filled him with the pleasure which a naturalist feels on discovering some rare or exceptionally fine specimen. In his new work on "The Science of Language" he has a chapter on the degradation or deterioration of words.

Inspector General Barber has come in of late for a not inconsiderable amount of animadversion on the part of members -- not altogether well-informed, it may be remarked in passing -of the Twenty-third Regiment for his carefulness in taking upon himself the responsibilities of a State Commissioner for the erection of the new armory which "Ours" hopes to occupy in the latter part of 1890 or the early months of 1891.

Some weeks ago we spoke of the tendency of certain high-tariff journals to denounce Trusts in general terms and to say that the duties protecting the products of such combinations should be reduced or removed, while at the same time they carefully refrained from pointing out any of the offending combinations by name and from urging that the suggested action should be taken with respect to any specified duty.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Jan. 25. -- Two of the oldest houses in New-London County are in the town of Ledyard, and both have figured in the history of the Union. One is the Allyn homestead, at Allyn's Point, on the Thames River, and the other the Rodman Niles mansion, which is situated far back from the banks of the river in the heart of the town. Both houses are in a good state of preservation.

A good deal is said in these times about the power of wealth in our politics and the facility with which rich men with no special qualifications for public life take the lead in political management and get into offices of the highest honor and influence. The tendency which it reveals is certainly a dangerous one, and its consequences, if it goes on unchecked, can only be pernicious to the Republic.
Some years ago business took me down to the little town of Temsbury, and as I expected to have to stay some time, my uncle John offered to lend me his house there, as it was standing empty.

The Rev. ASA N. DYER, at present but somewhat precariously the pastor of the Brick Church in North Dighton, Mass., is not the first man, and he is not likely to be the last, to discover that nature is more powerful than grace. There are practices with which a wise minister of religion will temporize, and at which he will even connive after he has become convinced of the futility of trying to extirpate them.

WINDHAM, N.Y., Jan. 25. -- A jury in Justice's Court here has rendered an odd verdict. The parties to the suit were J.T. Travis and L.V. Brisack. It seems that each owned a Jersey heifer. The animals were turned out in the same pasture lot. Later on one died. The action was brought by Travis to decide the ownership of the dead heifer.

The firm of T.J. Keveny Co., on whose importations of linoleum from Scotland an abnormally high appraisement was made, will, in answer to their strong appeals, be allowed a reappraisement. The following letter regarding the matter has been received by Collector Erhardt:

BALTIMORE, Jan. 25. -- The members of the Pan-American Conference to-day paid their respects to Baltimore. They were received, entertained, and feted by the Merchants and Manufacturers' Association, and given an opportunity to see the industrial plant and commercial and transportation facilities of this locality.

There has been a discussion in a French medical society as to whether the recently prevailing, but now happily waning, disorder should be called the grippe or the dengue. But the French word "grippe" and the Italian "influenza" are now too strongly intrenched in the popular favor or disfavor to be in danger from any rival.

The District Attorney's office will not be the Mecca that it is to the political friends of Col. Fellows if a bill introduced Friday into the Assembly by Assemblyman Richard J. Lewis or the Twenty-firs District shall find its way to the statute book. The bill provides that all business pending in the District Attorney's office shall be reported to the Mayor and published in the City Record every three months.

Mayor Gleason of Long Island City was not himself when he appeared Wednesday evening a his stuffy little office to attend the hearing before the Board of Education's committee which is pretending to investigate in a fair spirit certain charges against Principal A. Hull Burdick of the Firs Ward School.

Dispatches tell of the formation in Minnesota of a syndicate with $100,000,000 capital for the purpose of buying and making accessible pine timber lands in the Sierras of California. A Mr. C.M. Loring is said to be in this city already, looking up the project. That this gentleman is in this city is not known, but the formation of such a syndicate is considered very probable by those most familiar with the situation.

Charles Healey, the young man who was beaten by members of the "Growler Gang" in Twenty-eighth-street, near Tenth-avenue, on Sunday night, died yesterday at the Roosevelt Hospital. Healey was twenty years old and had been employed for six years in Gilmore's cracker bakery in Greenwich-street. He lived with his parents in the rear tenement at 528 West Twenty-eighth-street.

The official returns of the number of horses and mules used in the British military service just rendered to the War Office show that there are now actually 24,400 animals at work for riding or draught purposes, exclusive of those belonging to officers, the total being about 1,200 below the number voted in the army estimates.

A remarkable scene was witnessed on the Wear at Sunderland recently. Moored at the manor quay, near Messrs. J.L. Thompson's shipyard, was the steamer Wild Flower of London, which, having been ashore a Southwold, had jus come to the Wear for repairs. She carried oil in bulk, and was being pumped dry preparatory to being docked.

Gladstone at eighty has all the marvelous capacity for work that ever he had. His form is unbent, his physical powers unabated, and his mental faculties show no sign of exhaustion. He has tried more than once to retire from public life, but his exuberant vitality impels him into the political arena again, and never was he more anxious to serve his country than he is to-day.

HOW "CESAR BIROTTEAU" WAS WRITTEN. -- Balzac's method of working was eccentric. When he had well considered the subject upon which he proposed to write he would cover some thirty or forty pages with ideas and phrases. These he would send to the printer, who returned proof sheets pasted upon large sheets of paper. The work was then corrected.

HARTFORD, Jan. 25. -- The rearrangement of the Senatorial districts in this State will depend upon the success of the Democratic Party in the Fall in securing the Legislature. In 1881 the State was "gerrymandered" by the Republicans with the idea of retaining control of the Senate. The effectiveness of the work will appear from the fact that the Senate has not been Democratic since that time.

The most interesting recent literary incident in France is the announcement that the memoirs of TALLEYRAND have finally been turned over to the Duke DE BROGLIE to be prepared for publication. These memoirs were left in the hands of M. PAUL ANDRAL, a distinguished lawyer and member of the Council of State, who has recently died.

BERLIN, Jan. 25. -- Those favored with tickets to the galleries of the Reichstag to-day waited in vain expectation of hearing or seeing Prince Bismarck until the last moment, when Herr von Boetticher, the representative of the Chancellor, in announcing the close of the session summoned the members to hear the imperial message in the White Hall of the Schloss.

Entries for the New-York dog show, which will be held in this city from Feb. 11 to Feb. 14, close to-morrow, and no applications will be received after that date except such as may have been mailed from out of town not later than to-morrow morning. The number of prizes offered by the Westminster Kennel Club for this show is very large, and many special prizes have also been offered.

A KING'S FAVORITE. -- Conspicuous in the vestibule of the Chateau de Luciennes hung the portrait of Mme. du Barri by Drouet. It represents a woman of medium height. The eyes and mouth have that half-sleepy look of which Mme. Lebrun speaks in her memoirs. Her forehead is superb, and her graceful form is dressed in a ringrave, open at the besom, with a waistcoat of white lace.

LONDON, Jan. 25. -- The news of England's contemplated issue of silver notes, which I gave a week ago, is being cabled back here and has stimulated great interest and much inquiry, the result being an absolute failure to learn more one way or the other than appeared in the original announcement. The information

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- Gardiner G. Hubbard continued his argument in opposition to the international copyright law before the House Committee on Judiciary this morning. He said that it was for the good of the people that we should have a domestic copyright law, but its benefits should be confined to American citizens.

It was to be expected that after Thomson had explored the Masai region, told of the magnificent country in and around Mount Kilima-Njaro, and the abundance of game there that hunting Englishmen would pack up their batteries and make for the promised land. Capt. Willoughby of the Royal Horse Guards, with several friends, all good sportsmen, made full preparations for their hunting campaign, and, with Zanzibar for base of operations, took their start from Mombasa.
A subscriber at Bryan, Ohio, sends us the following dialogue that he overheard in the street:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- For over two hours to-day the Senate Committee on Commerce listened in secret to some interesting points in the political and private career of ex-Gov. Henry C. Warmoth, President Harrison's nominee for Collector of Customs at the port of New-Orleans.

WAWONA, Cal., Jan. 18. -- As a preliminary step toward a future provision of water for irrigating the dry lands or the West, many thousand dollars of Government money were expended last Summer in obtaining surveys for reservoir sites in the mountains of California and elsewhere. One of the surveying parties did some work in the region surrounding the Yosemite Valley.

A deeper and over-increasing interest is being manifested in the work of the conference of Educational Workers -- an organization of the men and women of New-York and vicinity who are engaged in teaching. Yesterday's quarterly meeting, which was held, as usual, at the New-York College for the Training of Teacher's, 9 University-place, was crowded to the full capacity of the hall.

" Al" Daggett, who makes postal cards for the Government and is a literary bureau all by himself in campaign times, continued to twirl his eyeglasses and to entertain those interested in the suit of Tallmadge Martin against the Republican League at the hearing in Referee L.C. Raegener's office in the Stewart Building yesterday.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 25. -- Some important testimony was introduced to-day in the election fraud trial pointing to the guilt of at least two of the men accused of robbing the ballot box -- Hayter and Tenneson. These men admit that they were in the room alone during the noon recess, and that the combination of the box had not been used, so that it could be opened with the key only, which Tenneson had.

Considerable comment has been aroused among booksellers in New-York City by the advent of young Mr. Quaritch of London with an assortment of old books from his father's London repository. The two questions most discussed relate to the character and quality of what Quaritch has to sell and to the effect that such sale will have on the book trade.

Senator "Bill" Brown, who has been strutting around in Albany the past week, calling his fellow-members in the Young Men's Democratic Club Pharisees because they stepped on the toes of Gov. Hill in their ballot reform resolution, may have to interrupt his public services and come home to explain why he should charge the city $6,534 for printing the canvass of the last election in his paper, the News.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 25. -- Judge Edwin H. Stowe to-day made a decree legally separating forever Margaret A. Fulton, daughter of Dr. John Douglass, from her husband, Andrew Fulton, ex-Mayor of Pittsburg. The grounds upon which the divorce was asked were excessive use of liquor and neglect. The testimony taken in the case was upon these two points, and the court to-day, by its decree, thinks Mrs. Fulton proved her charges.

OSTRICHES IN AMERICA. -- There are certain old traditions about the ostrich which, I have been told by the owner of the California ranch, are fallacious. He says that the ostrich does not bury his head in the sand and imagine he is unobserved by his enemies. On the contrary, he is a very pugnacious bird and always ready for a fight.

The greatest and most complete reforms have been accomplished affecting modern Italian life. Legislation -- civil, commercial, and penal; legislation that for scientific regulation, opportunity of circumstance, and rigor of method stands alone in the world; legislation solicitous to assure to the masses material welfare by removing causes of wretchedness and misery has been secured to the country.

No tidings were received yesterday from the missing National steamship Erin. Her agents still entertain some hopes that she will yet be heard from. The general impression among shipping men is that the chances of her turning up are slight, although they regard it as quite possible that her crew may have been saved.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- Should the State of New-York now fail to secure from Congress the selection of the city of New-York as the site of the World's Fair of 1892, it is perfectly evident that, so far as Washington will have anything to do with furnishing an explanation of the failure, it will attribute it to the interference and hostility of the Republican Party in the State of New-York.

PARIS, Jan. 25. -- The ex-Emperor of Brazil, having preserved absolute silence on the subject of the revolution since his arrival in Europe, and it having been reported in the public prints that his health of mind and body had broken down since the death of the Empress, a representative of the Press News Association visited him at Cannes.

Among the visitors at the World's Fair headquarters yesterday were Assemblymen Hamilton Fish and William F. Sheehan, the respective leaders of the Republican and Democratic Parties in the State Legislature.

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Jan. 25. -- Dr. J.W. McNamey, a well-known physician of Omaha, came to this city Thursday night. He inquired the time of the first train leaving on the Decorah Division of the Burlington for Decorah, Iowa. The time did not seem to suit him.

The feature of the wills of 1889, according to the Pall Mall Gazette, is "the important place held in the list by landowners, titled or otherwise. The year has been a peculiarly fatal one for peers, but the list of wills includes the names of several peers who died in 1888, and does not include nine of those who died during the last four months:

GARDNER, Mass., Jan. 25. -- The Stevens Block caught fire to-day and was completely destroyed. Aid was summoned from Fitchburg, and Chief Kimball responded with an engine and twenty men, doing excellent service. Heywood Brothers Co.'s wood-chair shop caught fire twice, but their sprinkler arrangement saved it both times. The following occupants of the Stevens Block are sufferers:

Unless all signs fail, "The Prince and the Pauper," now on view at the Broadway Theatre, will be a very profitable stage piece. All mothers like is see pretty children exhibited to good advantage, and all mothers who see such a sweet, attractive child as Elsie Leslie like to imagine that they discover in her traits of their own children.

Nearly fifty years ago the late Commodore Maury in a jesting mood spoke of recording human speech by speaking through a trumpet upon a sheet of paper, and in a general way described the phonograph or graphophone.
In THE TIMES of Sunday, Jan. 19, is a letter from England all about Mr. Stead. Here are some of the things contained in that letter:
DOLGEVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 25. -- The twenty-first annual reunion of the employes of Alfred Dolge, the largest felt shoe manufacturer in the country, was held here to-night.

The Society of Medical Jurisprudence ate dinner last night in the Hotel Marlborough, and it was a very jolly one. It was the seventh annual dinner of the society, and it was perhaps the most successful one it has ever given. More than one hundred gentlemen were present, and the assemblage was made up of prominent members of both of the professions from which the society craws its members.

Things in the amateur athletic world are quiet just now. The recent letter of Capt. Tighe of the Varuna Boat Club of Brooklyn, in which he took back all that he had said concerning the entry of Patrick Cahill in the Varuna Boat Club's boxing tournament, has even stopped the talk about Mr. Cahill, and the dullness of Winter is really at hand.

Modern sociology has witnessed no more remarkable practical development from an almost accidental experiment than that which followed the discussions of an insignificant gathering of railroad mechanics and other workingmen held a little more than twenty-one years ago.

A weight seems to have been lifted off the market. Yesterday's bank statement showed an increase in the surplus reserve of over $7,000,000, which brings that fund up to $15,000,000; with this there was a decrease in the loans of $3,200,000, and the total of loans stands at $400,000,000, while the net deposits are up to $423,000,000.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25. -- The nineteenth regular dinner of the Chicago Commercial Club, held at the Grand Pacific Hotel to-night, was a notable event. It was determined to make it a memorable affair in honor of the memory of the late John Creerar, who left large fortune to public bequest, including the establishment of a public library.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- Congressman Morse of Massachusetts was before the Committee on Ways and Means this morning to speak in behalf of the granite manufacturers and stoneworkers of Quincy. He said he was utterly astonished to learn that there was any member of the Massachusetts delegation who should appear before this committee and recommend a lowering of the duty upon granite.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 25. -- The steamship Caribbean arrived to-day from Liverpool, from West India and South American ports. She arrived at Trinidad on the 9th inst. and found the sugar plantations flooded, the cane under water, and in many places the lower portions of the houses under water and the cattle swimming about. The flood was caused by continues heavy rains.

THE BULL, THE YOUNG LADY, AND THE TRACTS. -- There was once a bull that everybody was afraid of, though he had never hurt anybody, and one day a man came around who was distributing tracts, and he had a young lady with him to help distribute in case they should meet somebody who didn't want tracts, and who was so strong that nobody could distribute them to him without help.

At the first performance this season of Wagner's "Tristan and Isolde," as the curtain was slowly descending before the dead bodies of the Princess, her knightly lover, and the faithful esquire, a young lady, well clad, and bearing evidence in her face of having been reared within the confines of civilization, arose to depart, saying: "Isn't it silly!"

LIMA, Jan. 13. -- Mr. MacNulty and Senor Valdizan, representing the Grace syndicate, have denounced, according to the mining law of the republic, in order to obtain a grant of possession from the Government, forty silver-lead bearing lodes at Cerro de Pomacayan, in the neighborhood of the famous Cerro de Pasco.

BAY CITY, Mich., Jan. 25. -- The bitterest kind of feeling pervades railroad circles in this neighborhood. The new Cincinnati, Saginaw and Mackinaw Road has been making inroads into the freight traffic of the Michigan Central, which has had a tendency to increase the anger of the latter corporation. Yesterday the appearance in this city of a number of mogul engines, owned by the new road, caused consternation among the Central people.

A SWANNERY. -- A very curious sight does the marshy shore at Abbotsbury present in the breeding season. Then the ground is dotted with nests, a pair of swans to each, one covering the eggs, the other sitting or standing, a snow-white sentinel, beside his mate. The swans do not breed until they are three years old; they are strictly monogamous, and the male bird takes his full share in the incubation.

Some time before his much-regretted death the late J. Carson Brevoort gave to the Long Island Historical Society, of which he was one of the founders and the first President, a collection of 127 Washington manuscript. These consisted almost wholly of letters written by Washington to William Pearce, the manager' of his Mount Vernon estates during three years of his absence as President of the United States.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 25. -- After four tedious days of trial, Maurice J. Hart, indicted for the embezzlement of 196 one-thousand-dollar State bonds, was pronounced not guilty this afternoon, the jury not leaving their seats. The trial has occupied a large share of public attention. The best criminal lawyers in the State were arrayed against each other, the Attorney General conducting the prosecution in person.

The Archduke Joseph, Commander of the Hungarian Honved Army, has made the language, traditions, and habits of the gypsies his special study. Extensive as the literature about this strange and interesting people already is, the researches of the Archduke, says a Standard (London) correspondent at Vienna, "have brought several unknown features to light, and he is indefatigable in correcting existing errors and in creating a scientific interest for his friends, the gypsies.
The increase in the use of electric lights and electric motors is shown by the Electrical World to be even greater during the past few years than most people probably imagine.

PARIS, Jan. 4. -- I presume that I shall astonish your readers considerably by my statement that, before last evening, the night of the revival of the "Jeanne d'Arc" of Messrs. Gounod and Barbier, no one knew Sarah Bernhardt. Whatever creation she may make in future, be its lines signed Sardou or Dumas, she may equal her interpretation of the Orleans maid, but she can never surpass it.

The story of "William," the lawyer's clerk, in search of the Richmond County Court House, told in THE SUNDAY TIMES of Jan. 12, (but which an attack of the grip prevented my reading until last evening,) reminded me of my pilgrimage there in September, 1873, and of a pleasing and singular incident connected therewith.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 25. -- At 6:10 this evening flames were seen bursting from the windows of the high building on the southeast corner of Fifth and Sycamore streets. The firs, which started after all the occupants of the building had left it, was caused by an explosion of some sort in the office of Knight Co., printers, occupying the third floor.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25. -- Walt Whitman, the poet, was visited to-day by a TIMES reporter at his little frame cottage, 328 Mickle-street, Camden. Since the banquet tendered him last May he seems to have taken a new lease on life. In talking of himself, Mr. Whitman said: ...

Another landmark of old Paris is threatened, it seems, with demolition, says a writer in the Daily Telegraph of London. "The Palais Royal, with its long and varied train of associations, political and social, monarchical and revolutionary, is about to disappear. It has gone down in another sense, and has been going down for many years past.

ROXBURY, N.Y., Jan. 25. -- Two little boys, sons of James Mead, one night recently set a trap to catch a polecat. Next morning they were surprised to find a large gray eagle fast in the trap, being held by one of its toes. The trap was fastened to a ten-foot pole, but, notwithstanding the heavy weight, when the eagle saw the boys it flew a short distance, taking with it trap and pole.
Capt. Charles W. Read, formerly of the Confederate States Navy, died at Meridian, Miss., at 2 o'clock yesterday morning.

A story was published in one of last evening's newspapers declaring that the Consolidated Telegraph and Electrical Subway Company, which has the monopoly of building conduits for the accommodation of the electric wires, had been purchased by a combination composed of the Westinghouse, the Brush, and the Thompson-Houston Company and that hereafter those companies would control the laying of subways in this city.

" Now all the Athenians and the strangers sojourning there spent their time in nothing else but either to tell or to hear some new thing," but New-Yorkers and the strangers sojourning hero desire first to see some new thing. The ladies find their liveliest gratification of this instinct in the ever-changing panorama of fashion.

Perhaps a leaf from my memory in regard to the statement in last Sunday's TIMES that "one of the popular fads of recent days [phonetic English] was much further developed ferret years ago than it is to-day" will not be amiss. I have not kept tuch with the progress of the phonetic system for some years past, and hence am not prepared to say whether it has made any advance in popular favor.

THE COLORS OF BIRDS NOT "FAST" COLORS. -- At the present moment the menagerie of the Zoological Society, Regent's Park, has an unusually large number of touracos, a species of birds which has not before been exhibited in this country. Touraco is the native name of a beautiful group of birds peculiar to Africa, and sometimes called, from their food, plantain eaters.

The combination of four of the largest six-cord spool cotton concerns in this country for the purpose of crushing a number of smaller competitors has recently met with a check. For the time being the object of this extensive combination has been thwarted, and the consequence is already felt in the market.

The expatriation of the blacks, now seriously proposed by amateur philanthropists in all parts of the country as the only solution of the vexatious race problem, is not a new fad. More than a generation ago there was a colonization society in this country whose object was the colonization of the blacks in Liberia. A copy of its organ, the Liberia Advocate, of September, 1849, was recently shown to a TIMES reporter.

Mr. William Cowper Prime was the first lecturer at the new house of the Grolier Club, Conference, the French word, could better than lecture describe to one who may be reminded of an afternoon with Renan at the College de France these occasional book talks of the Grolier Club; informal, agreeable, not didactic, though the subject be like Euclid.
The tale of wretchedness revealed by the account in this morning's issue of THE TIMES of the suicide of Mrs. Henderson cannot fail to shock the entire community.

The line. There is a word that acts magically upon the memory and imagination of the old veteran -- the line. It recalls the long column, stringing out its weary length as it crawled slowly yet steadily forward; then the quickening roll of the drum, the sharp command, the accelerated movements into position, and the solid, stone-wall battle front presented to the enemy.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Jan. 26. -- There is trouble in the African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church of this city, and to-day the Trustees ordered the doors of the church edifice closed against the pastor, the Rev. J.H. Turner.

There can be no doubt that certain wicked men in this country have conspired to destroy the political reputation of THOMAS C. PLATT. Not long ago these men caused it to be published in all the newspapers that the leading statesmen of Tammany had come into possession of compromising letters said to have been written by Mr. PLATT to Senator FASSETT.

BOSTON, Jan. 26. -- There is unusual agitation among the Republicans of the Bay State just at this time on a number of matters. They think they see a brilliant method of evolving harmony out of discord, and they are working night and day to achieve that result.

Many of the people who went to the Old Guard bali last Thursday night seem to have been most unfortunate in the matter of losing things. THE TIMES has already printed an account of how the outside apparel of the guests got so awfully mixed up, and of how many of the ladies lost their wraps or got others which did not belong to them.

The story of "The Prince and the Pauper" is not fully told on the stage of the Broadway Theatre. Some of the omissions will be supplied to-day in the Court of Common Pleas in arguments for an injunction to restrain the further production of the play until the rights of Edward H. House can be judicially determined.

BOSTON, Jan. 26. -- The Rev. Dr. Rexford preached at the First Church in Roxbury this morning on the subject of missions, and criticised the attitude of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions. Referring to the persecution of the Andover professors, he said it had been hoped that when Dr. Richard S. Storrs had been chosen President of the board its temper would be changed.

The Monmouth Park Racing Association today announces its programme for the coming season at its new race course near Long Branch. The racing will begin on Friday, July 4, and continue on Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays up to and including Thursday, Aug. 28, thus covering the two best racing months in the year, as has been the custom of the association up to last year.

Amateur photographers have had a very busy month of it so far, and lantern-slide exhibitions, meetings of societies, and test nights take up much of their time. Indeed, there is some sort of a photographic meeting almost every night. Interest in the pastime was never greater. Yet with it all there is very little practical photographing done this Winter.

Members of the congregation of St. Timothy's parish, whose church building was recently destroyed by fire, gathered yesterday morning at Mizpah Chapel, at 420 West Fifty-seventh-street, which had been tendered them by the presbyters of the chapel as a place of worship. The chapel was crowded to its utmost, and many were unable to find seats. The Rev. Henry H. Lubeck, the rector of St. Timothy's, conducted the service, assisted by the Rev. C.H.S. Hartman.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- When Secretary Bayard sent to President Cleveland a treaty of extradition with Great Britain, and it was in due course transmitted to the Senate, that body was inspired with an unpatriotic and partisan determination that none of the diplomatic undertakings of the Democratic Administration should be approved.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Civil Service Commissioner Roosevelt has submitted to the full commission a report of his recent investigation into the alleged violations of the civil service law in the New-York Custom House just prior to the last Presidential election. Upon the subject of the collection of political assessments during that campaign, Mr. Roosevelt says:

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Jan. 26. -- Nearly twenty institutions of learning have been represented at the eighth annual New-England Conference of College Young Men's Christian Associations, which closed its sessions in this city to-day. These associations have a total membership of over 2,000. The conferences have been held in the chapel of Wesleyan University. An average of 200 representative members have attended.
RONDOUT, N.Y., Jan. 26. -- The school question in District No. 3, which embraces the Fifth Ward, is once more attracting attention, as a result of a meeting held in the schoolhouse last night.

Policemen arrested Frederick Mayer, manager of Terrace Garden, Fifty-eighth-street, near Third-avenue; Ludwig Croner, manager of Maennerchor Hall, 205 East Fifty-sixth-street, and James Bettis, manager of Fernando's Assembly Rooms, early yesterday morning for allowing dancing and singing in their places after midnight on Saturday night. They gave bail for appearance for examination in the Yorkville Police Court.

The thirty-eighth annual assembly of Grand Lodge, District No. 1, B'nai B'rith, was called to order in Vienna Hall, Lexington-avenue and Fifty-eighth-street, by President Myer Hellman at 10 A.M. yesterday. The First District has 8,900 members in 72 lodges scattered over New-York, the New-England States, and the Dominion of Canada. About 7,200 of its members, however, live in this city, which is really the centre of the order's activity.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26. -- Chairman Walker of the Inter-State Commerce Railway Association to-day decided the appeal of the St. Louis and San Francisco Road for permission to make rates on grain from points in Kansas to St. Louis based on the through rates, to offset the advantage to Kansas City operators gained by the present transit arrangement on grain shipped from Kansas points to Kansas City, and thereafter consigned to St. Louis and Chicago.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Jan. 26. -- Early yesterday morning the average temperature along the Hudson River was 10 above zero. This morning the weather was so mild that a robust child could have played out of doors minus its hat with as little danger of catching cold as though it were in Southern California. This afternoon persons who persisted in wearing overcoats because, according to the almanacs, it was midwinter, perspired freely.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26. -- About 5 o'clock on the afternoon of Dec. 11, 1889, Joseph G. Ditman, one of the best-known men in Philadelphia, President of the Quaker City National Bank, went driving alone, according to his custom, in Fairmount Park. Mr. Ditman drove a spirited but perfectly tractable horse, and a light falling-top buggy.

It is plain that the extradition treaty submitted by the President to the Senate, and of which the full text, with Mr. BLAINE'S explanatory letter, will be found in our Washington dispatches this morning, is very great improvement upon the treaty of 1842, under which we have been for so long trying to get along.

The announcement that Mr. GOSCHEN, the English Finance Minister, will have a surplus to dispose of amounting to $20,000,000 is, according to the London Spectator, exciting "the highest interest in all quarters." The interest, American readers will be amused to know, centres in the question what taxes Mr. GOSCHEN will propose to Parliament to remit.

Mr. D'Oyly Carte, or Herr d'Oyly Carte, as the North German Lloyd passenger list calls him, arrived here yesterday on the steamship Saafe. With him came his wife and Miss Phyllis, a member of the Savoy Theatre Company. Mr. Carte's purpose is to straighten out the affairs of the New-York "Gondoliers" company. At the Victoria Hotel be talked readily and at some length on the subject last evening.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26. -- The congregation of St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church, at St. John and Brown streets, passed through an experience this evening which they will not soon forget. The occasion was the confirmation of eight candidates for membership by Bishop Whitaker.

AMPERSAND, N.Y., Jan. 26. -- For the past week fine clear, cold weather has prevailed, and the air has been of that bracing kind that only those who have been in the Adirondacks in the Winter know of. The last four nights the mercury has been below zero, and the ice on the lakes and ponds is from ten to twelve inches in thickness.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 26. -- The Rev. R.C. Cave, an eloquent and learned minister of the Gospel, is the leader of a new departure that will cause a sensation in religious circles. He was pastor of the Central Christian Church, the wealthiest flock of followers of Alexander Campbell in the city. He preached a sermon denying the inspiration of the Old Testament.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- The friends of the International Copyright bill have not been discouraged by the reappearance of Mr. Gardiner G. Hubbard as an erratic annual opponent of the copyright. The fact is that his argument orstatement before the committee really helped the cause he ventured to oppose.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26. -- Prof. David Swing preached to a large congregation to-day on the theme, "Revision of the Presbyterian Creed." As he was formerly a strong Presbyterian, his discourse attracted much attention. Among other things he said:
Nine European steamships, all of which bore evidences of having had rough usage upon the ocean, arrived at this port yesterday.

The big bark Pythomene, which arrived from Calcutta on Friday and was moored alongside the Pierrepont Stores. Brooklyn, was found to be on fire at 5:30 o'clock yesterday morning, and for two hours the most prodigious labor was necessary to prevent her complete destruction. As a last resort she was scuttled and sent to the bottom of the East River.

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 26. -- It Was learned to-day that late yesterday application was made in the United States Circuit Court by the Thomson-Houston Electric Company of Boston for the appointment of a receiver of the Topeka Rapid Transit Railway, and for the foreclosure of a mortgage on that road.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 27. -- The usual throng of people clamored for admission at the Court House to-night when Coroner Bower polled the jury in the Kniffin murder inquest at 7:30 o'clock. The first witness called was James Murphy, the father of the murdered woman. His testimony corroborated that given by his wife, and he spoke in flattering terms of his son-in-law and Miss Pursel.

NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 27. -- Stoughton Fletcher Ritzinger, a student in the Junior Class at the Sheffield Scientific School, was struck by a train and instantly killed on the Shore Line Railroad at Fairhaven late this afternoon. He was out driving with his college mate, William Ernest Walker, and they were going up Pleasant-street to the Fairhaven Heights when they heard the 5:05 o'clock passenger train from New-London approaching.

VIENNA, Jan. 27. -- The agreement made between the Germans and Czechs at the recent conference has been officially announced. It provides that the Landesschulrath (School Commission) shall be composed of German and Bohemian sections. Questions touching the schools of the minority, especially the founding of new schools, will be reserved for discussion and decision by the full commission.

MONTREAL, Jan. 27. -- Meetings of local bankers are being hold in all the Canadian cities -- Montreal, Toronto, London, Ottawa, and Hamilton -- to arrange a concerted plan of action in connection with the amendments which will be made to the Banking act at the present session of the Dominion Parliament.

For the thirty-seventh time the anniversary of the Young Men's Christian Association came around yesterday and was duly remembered by the young men and their friends at Association Hall, Twenty-third-street and Fourth-avenue, last night. The hall was well filled and the meeting proved interesting and encouraging to those engaged in the work. Mr. Cleveland H. Dodge presided and on the platform with him were:

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Jan. 27. -- Passenger train No. 1 on the Louisville, New-Albany and Chicago Railway, which left Chicago Sunday night at 11:55, was wrecked this morning at 7:50 o'clock one mile above Carmel, a village sixteen miles north of this city.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 27. -- In the House this evening Mr. Mullone of Hudson introduced a resolution calling for the appointment of a joint committee of six Assemblymen and four Senators, to which shall be referred all bills upon ballot reform. Each party is to have equal representation upon the committee, and the committee is to give hearings upon the subject to all persons interested.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Jan. 27. -- The Youngstown and Buffalo Railroad from the mouth of Niagara River to Buffalo has been reorganized. The following officers have been elected: President -- William Wilkeson, Lewiston; Vice President -- A.H. Dutton, Youngstown; Secretary -- J. M. Dipson, Youngstown; Treasurer -- Thomas Brighton, Youngstown.

DOYLESTOWN, Penn., Jan. 27. -- The somewhat famous case of The Commonwealth against A. Nelson Lewis, a member of the Philadelphia Gun Club, who was indicted for cruelty to animals, for participating in a pigeon shooting match on the grounds of the club at Andalusia. Bucks County, on Dec. 14, 1887, was concluded to-day, when Judge Yerkes handed down an opinion, in which he declared the defendant guilty as indicted.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Jan. 27. -- The Summer-like weather of yesterday was followed by a warm rain last night and a dreary drizzle to-day. Would be ice-harvesters are completely disheartened. The ice fields that formed last week up the Hudson have broken up.

EAGLE PASS, Texas, Jan. 27. -- A dispatch has been receives in Piedras Negras stating that the Mexican Government had called upon the Governors of the border States for written opinions as to the advisability of abolishing the zona libra, and recommending that the Piedras Negras Board of Trade appoint a delegate to proceed, in conjunction with other delegates, to the city of Mexico for the defense of the commercial privileges which were given them.

Mayor CHAPIN of Brooklyn finds it about equally difficult to be either a straight forward independent Mayor or a servile tool of the Democratic machine. He has refused to reappoint JAMES D. BELL as Police Commissioner because the bosses demanded Mr. BELL'S official head; but in appointing HENRY I. HAYDEN to the place he has not yielded to the wishes of the bosses, who would have preferred a pliant politician of their own sort.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 25. -- The date for the election of delegates to the Constitutional Convention being fixed, the opponents of the provisional Government have no plausible pretext for continuing their general criticisms. The decrees exiling Silveira Martins and Carles Affonso, brother of Ouro Preto, were doubtless unnecessary as well as unwise, but the moderation displayed by the revolutionists has been remarkable.

The snow blockade on the Central Pacific is having a wonderfully depressing effect on theatrical business in California. Two companies, and possibly a third, are snow-bound on the road between Ogden and San Francisco, unable to proceed or turn bask, and the result of their predicament will be the temporary closing of as many as seven theatres The "Shonandoah" company, consisting of twenty-six people and a horse, is blockaded at Wadsworth, Nevada.
